At 8:16 AM 9/10/96, Leslie Ayres wrote:
>Sorry, have to respond again on this one ....  and I for one apologize to
>MegaBuzz One for taking shit after giving a generous and unsolicited
>donation to two very good causes.  That sucks!!!  I bet next time he'll
>think twice about posting anything to SFRaves.
>
>And all this stuff about "nipping nasty rumors in the bud" ????  Maybe I
>missed something, but I never saw any nasty rumors about this company or
>promoter... all I've seen is criticism AFTER THE FACT when he posted about
>his party.  Perhaps some of the voices on here are confusing this promoter
>with someone else?  Misinformation can be VERY damaging, and it is up to
>each of us to make sure we know what we're talking about when we start
>these threads that feed these rumors.
>
>Where is it written in the official rules and regulations of raving that
>anyone who wants to give a privately funded and organized party has to open
>their personal financial records to anyone who asks?  (Maybe the same place
>it's written that anyone who throws big parties is an evil moneygrubber?)
>
>Now, if someone said ... "this is a benefit for ...." and charged hella
>money or took up a collection and we suspected that the money was going
>elsewhere ... that is different.  And if someone charges hella money and
>doesn't deliver (djs don't show up, party gets busted and no refunds
>forthcoming, etc.), that's different too.
>
>But when a private promoter puts their money on the line and puts on a big
>party, and provides all the stuff he said he'd deliver to the people who
>chose to go, I'm not sure how someone not involved thinks it's their right
>to challenge that promoter to, to quote:
>
>>posting a detailed breakdown of their party's revenues and expenses to the
>>list. Ideally this would include names of individuals, companies, and
>>organizations and how much each received, not simply "Lighting - $200, DJs
>>- $500," etc.  It would also be interesting to know how many people got in
>>free or at reduced cost, and their names and affiliations.  The number of
>>non-paying guests, which can be quite high, certainly factors into the
>>bottom line of a production
>
>Please! that's ridiculous, you're asking someone to give proprietary
>information  to  450 strangers who all have an opinion that's most likely
>based on a total lack of information on costs and logistics, and frankly
>very often is based on a lack of experience with big dollar business at
>all!
>
>And yes, that's *proprietary*... that means private ... I think we are
>confusing the spirit of raving with something else.
>
>Now, about sharing information with other promoters (i.e. cost for police,
>other negotiating points, etc) .. I wouldn't be surprised if that's done
>anyway, depending in the nurturance of those personal relationships,
>because when promoters treat each other with respect, we all win, and they
>know that (at least most of them).
>
>This whole thing makes me sad ... instead of seeing something very positive
>in a situation -- which is that a promoter of a large party is donating
>money from his pocket (yes, that's HIS pocket, not yours, sorry, folks) to
>good causes -- insteadee is being openly roasted and lambasted in a public
>forum.
>
>Promoters aren;t "candidates for office" ... they are people who put the
>work in to put on parties ...
>
>I suggest that every person who belives a promoter should disclose
>everything throw a big and expensive party on their own -- make sure you
>put $$thousands out of your own pocket first -- and then post *every* cost
>detail to the list.  Then you too will  likely be the target of criticism
>that it wasn't enough, you were greedy and underhanded, etc, and if you
>were a REAL raver it wouldn't have cost so much, etc.
>
>We've got to get over this "if it makes a profit, it can't be a rave"
>mentality, because it perpetuates this weird "money bad, poverty good"
>ethic.  Hey, I wish everyone could make a living doing something that
>brings joy to people's lives... and if I can make it happen for me, I will!
>
>Love, Leslie
>
>p.s.  my expenses for popsicles at Sunset was exactly $8.64 this week, and
>$6.98 for the time before that ... didn't accept a cent for them.  Feel
>better?  And the Leeza show isn't paying anything but my expenses (wish
>they would, my car payment is late!)
>
>

>      XXXXXXXXXXXX
>       XXXXXXXXXX
>   XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX

On Tue, 10 Sep 1996, Leslie Ayres wrote:

> Sorry, have to respond again on this one ....  and I for one apologize to
> MegaBuzz One for taking shit after giving a generous and unsolicited
> donation to two very good causes.  That sucks!!!  I bet next time he'll
> think twice about posting anything to SFRaves.
> 
> And all this stuff about "nipping nasty rumors in the bud" ????  Maybe I
> missed something, but I never saw any nasty rumors about this company or
> promoter... all I've seen is criticism AFTER THE FACT when he posted about
> his party.  Perhaps some of the voices on here are confusing this promoter
> with someone else?  Misinformation can be VERY damaging, and it is up to
> each of us to make sure we know what we're talking about when we start
> these threads that feed these rumors.
> 
> Where is it written in the official rules and regulations of raving that
> anyone who wants to give a privately funded and organized party has to open
> their personal financial records to anyone who asks?  (Maybe the same place
> it's written that anyone who throws big parties is an evil moneygrubber?)
> 
> Now, if someone said ... "this is a benefit for ...." and charged hella
> money or took up a collection and we suspected that the money was going
> elsewhere ... that is different.  And if someone charges hella money and
> doesn't deliver (djs don't show up, party gets busted and no refunds
> forthcoming, etc.), that's different too.

Exactly what I was hinting at in my first post...here are quotes from the 
promoter about MegaBuzz One that put my tongue in action (or my hands as 
the case may be)...

(from the original post)

	"Tickets are only $18 in advance.  We did everything humanly 
possible to make them this inexpensive.  This is something we are trying to do to 
show people that large parties do not have to cost a fortune.  This is 
a realy good price, because you are getting more than 3 large parties 
for the price of less than one.   We are also donating a portion of our 
procedes to the Bay Area Homless Alience.  Just think- your partying 
will help the less fortunate this winter.   We encourage everybody to 
buy tickets and please arive early to help set the tone and the mood 
for the evening. "

	"5.  One of thing that we like to do with all our parties is to 
give back to the comunity with each event.  Our event was a partial benefit 
and a portion of the procedes was to be donated to the bay area 
homeless alience.  We were able to raise $1000 for this organization.  
Our intention was to donate the funds and recieve some positive press 
for the rave comunity at the same time.  I know that a thousand dollard 
does not seem like a lot compared to how much money everyone ASUMES we 
made at this party, but trust me, it is quite a bit.  We would have 
been able to donate more, but a lot more people wound up going to BM, 
and leaving town, than we expected, so there realy was not any 
astronomical profit made at the party like people want to think.  
Anyways, as I was saying, the whole idea of giving back to the comunity 
was one of the reasons we wanted to do the party.  
When I heard what happened at BM to a fellow raver, Omar, A member of 
our comunity, we figured that there was no beter, or more deserving 
cause to donate the money to, so instead of giving the $1000 to the 
homeless alience, we gave Omars Mom $500, and to the Homeless Alience 
the other $500.  We wish we only had more to give, but hopefully the 
next party we will be able to generate twice that amount for the 
homless alience.  We send all our love and support to Omar and his 
family during this hard time, and extend any posible help if there is 
to be a benefit party for him."

These posts are supposed make me feel as though this was something great and 
wonderful that $18 was cheap and that we gave so much money to those in 
need?  I'm not in any way condemning the fact that Feel Good gave what 
they did, I think that's great, but I'm questioning the fact that the 
event was advertised as a "partial" benefit and it seems that they really 
did mean 'partial'.  

I was going to make some comparison but it's all apples and oranges 
anyways to most people.  I just get frustrated when I work with people 
throwing a big party with 3 sound systems, and 20 djs and it goes off and 
we can charge *$5* and give a thousand dollars to those in need.  I just 
want to know what are Feel Good doing with all that money?  It's a valid 
question I think?  I'm not asking for a breakdown by item even...but from 
the outside when you add up to $125,000 and you've been told it's a 
partial benefit and you see less than 1% of the gross going to that 
benefit, that doesn't seem right.  I've seen budgets for big parties and 
I know that they aren't the same as small parties, but realistically the 
figures are just way to off here not to say something.

I suppose we should probably end this thread, seeing as it will probably 
only degenerate further.  For me it's an issue of morals, its about what 
is right and wrong, and I won't let those issues die in our rave scene.  

love drenalin

From: "George Feil" <enigma@best.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Tue, 10 Sep 1996 12:55:09 +0000
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT
Subject: so long, and thanks for all the fish!
Priority: normal
X-mailer: Pegasus Mail for Win32 (v2.42a)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I've decided to leave the list for three reasons:

First, things are getting very busy for me. I'm about to start a new
job that will require considerably more time than I have given my
previous one. With my personal projects (including a community web
site) having playing second fiddle to everything else going on, it's
time I focus more energy on creating, and less on media surfing
(which, I have to admit, is a lot of fun, albeit time consuming).

Secondly, the signal / noise ratio of this list has gotten too small
for me. Too much of the massive volume of discussion is on political
and other matters, and not enough is directly related to raves for
it to be informative enough for me. Many times I have had the
temptation to jump in to the political frying pan (and several times
I actually did). However, given the choice of having these
discussions on-line, or having them in person with friends and
acquaintances, I choose the latter.

Finally, I succumb to the negative vibe of the list. I've carried
great intentions of having this list be an overall positive
experience for everybody. I give my highest regards to those who
have shared this intention with me. While I recognize the importance
of having a balance between the darkness and the lightness of life,
I have found things on this list to be a bit too dark lately for my 
taste. In particular, I have been appaled at the seeming lack of 
respect that several participants have had towards their peers.

Thanks to everyone I've had the opportunity to share discussions
with. I invite each of you to e-mail me personally, if you have
something you'd like to discuss, rave-related or not. I plan to
continue to attend raves (and will be subscribed to the calendar),
so I look forward to meeting y'all at parties in the future. I'm not
sure yet, but I may make it out to Harmony for the 3-year blast.

Peace and Love to you all,
George (a/k/a E. Nygma)

Hello dear friends,

Unfortunately, based on the very real agendas of these pulp TV shows, their
producers and hosts, I don't feel that the SF (or any other) rave community
will be served by having Leslie or any other of our friends on TV 'going to
bat' for our community, lifestyle or passions.

They have control of the angle of the show.

They have control of the camera.

They have control of your microphone.

This is not a platform for the guests to advocate their position. You do
not get to speak freely. This is not a pulpit for guests to preach from. It
is the host's pulpit, and they have an agenda. And that agenda is about
building contraversy around a particular subject, positioning guests
against each other, and the audience against the guests. It's a formula, it
works, and that sells ad time. :-)

If this were a panel show, it would be of mutual benefit to all the show's
guests, but remember, this is not a panel and there is no fair moderator.
These type of TV shows are not democracies. They are benevolent
dictatorships... and ultimately all guests will lose.

____________________________________________________________________________
 Wayne D. Correia            +1.415.826.6000            FAX +1.415.826.6100

>Some things i saw downstairs really bugged.  Some people cutting lines by

Saw this, and yeah it bugged me too.  I stood real close to one guy and 
pretended to sneeze.  He glared at me and I just grinned and said, "Just 
kidding!"  and toodled off...

>gangstas standing in the corners.

Forgetting the clothing, I don't recall seeing anyone exuding the "gangsta 
vibe".  I guess I don't make any assumptions about people just by the way 
they're dressed -- or try not to anyway.

Y'know what would be rather amusing?  To have some huge, hairy, burly guys 
show up on Harleys, dressed in full leathers, chompin' on some fat stogies, 
standing around and staring at everyone.  Do you suppose ANYONE would walk 
up and try to give these guys a hug?  Would anyone chat with them?  Would 
anyone sit one of them down and try to give them a backrub?  Would they be 
included at ALL?

Do you *really* believe in raving as an equal opportunity attempt to 
befriend people without any hangups or prejudices?

S

At 1:51 PM -0700 9/10/96, SDream wrote:

>Y'know what would be rather amusing?  To have some huge, hairy, burly guys
>show up on Harleys, dressed in full leathers, chompin' on some fat stogies,
>standing around and staring at everyone.  Do you suppose ANYONE would walk
>up and try to give these guys a hug?  Would anyone chat with them?  Would
>anyone sit one of them down and try to give them a backrub?  Would they be
>included at ALL?

Hmmm...I ride, I have full leather, I love good cigars, and I stand around
and watch people, not ot mention I'm huge, hairy and burly, and I get hugs.
=)

I'd walk up to them and at least say hi.  See, as we like to say, diversity
is our strength.  I've been to huge biker outings, and thus I wouldn't feel
uncomfortable chillin' with a couple brothers; especially if they were
smoking quality leaf.

I'm not dissing your post, but rather saying that because of our diversity,
we could make just about anyone feel welcome.  Hell, what if some lady
walked in with a hat that would make the orginator of Beach Blanket
Babyalon [sp] grimace in his grave?  Why, Leslie could make that person
feel at home, right?  ;^)

Anyway, just because someone's big, burly, wears leather and smokes cigars
it doesn't mean they aren't approachable.

Peace!

Tone

On Sep 10,  2:24pm, Brian Ward wrote:
> Subject: what's it cut with?i
> Actually, E is cut with heroin all the time in San Diego...

Interesting, do you know of any test reports? In the Netherlands the
contents of pills/caps have been tested for years (you can just send them
by mail to a lab or have them tested at raves) and never in 6 years
have I heard anything of heroin being mixed with E. Neither on any of
the dedicated websites. I'd say it's a myth until I see a test report.
Doesn't this discussion return on this list every so many months?

> And by the way...Heroin is NOT that expensive. Considering how little E
> you're getting in your hits, i's say it's quite cost effective for dealers.

Even more cost effective would probably be to add speed or just flower.
Besides I wonder at what doses heroin is _orally_ active, considering
the heroin is probably already cut itself... It seems unlikely that
such a small amount would get you hooked on anything. Most of these stories
come from people who got ill after ingesting some obscure pill/capsule.
Well, there can be many reasons why people puke/flip, even if they took
pure MDMA. Finally, to my knowledge the heroin using/dealing scene has
always been very far removed from the recreational drug using/dealing
scene. Perhaps this is different in the States.

> I don't see why they'd lie.

Many dealers do lie and even more probably don't really know what they are
selling since they don't synthesize/purify their merchandise themselves.
Anyway the last statement confuses me a bit, why would a dealer try to
sell E while claiming there is heroin in it? I can't see many people
being interested in that, unless their looking for "the ultimate kick"
and have shit for brains.

> -alex

The Frying Dutchman

From: rayvonie@ix.netcom.com (Ray Vonie)
Subject: From the promoter of MeggaBuzz
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Precedence: bulk

Dear Friends,

    This has realy gone far enough.  I posted a review of my party on 
the net because I thought that everyone would like to know how thing 
went.  I knew that most people were at BM, so I figured it would be 
nice to tell everyone what went on while they were gone.  Obviously I 
had no idea that there were so many sinical and sceptical people in 
what is suposed to be the "core" of the rave scene.  I does not seam to 
me that my post was treated with a "rave atitude"  Insted it seams like 
people wanted to downplay everything we did, and twist our eforts into 
something negative and unproductive.  
    I certainly know that not everyone out there is like this.  I am 
sure that most of you probably saw it for the way it was ment.  As a 
folowup reviw of the party, Nothing More.
    I forgive all the people for their medeling, and uninformed 
negativity.  It is unfortunate to see such mistrust and decention in a 
comunity that is developed on the basis of understanding and open 
mindedness.  I know that it is real easy to get caught up in a rut and 
become jaded and negative.  And when that point comes I think it is 
time to reavaluate your actions or stop calling yourself a raver, 
Because ravers arn't suposed to be that way.  
    I think that the scene started because people wanted to go 
underground to get away from this type of prejudice and discrimination. 
 But yet here we are, and there are still people talking shit about an 
event that they had no part off, nor were even there.  And the only 
reason that this even started was because their uninformed ignorance 
and negative sceptacism led them to believe that we did not give enough 
money out of our pocket for charity from a party that was not even 
intended to be a benefit.  I have done benefits in the past, and ALL 
the procedes get donated to charity.  This was not a benefit.  Reading 
the flyer or the posts would have told you that.  
    The reason we wanted to give money away to cherity was so we could 
get some good and positve publicity for the rave scene as a comunity 
entity, not a burdon as the media constantly pertrays us to be.  It 
would have been nice to give more, but that was all we could do at this 
time.  In future parties we hope to be able to give more.  Mabee if 
people did a litle more suporting and a lot less talking shit, then we 
might have done better, but thats the irony of the situation, isn't it?
    I was very infuriated by a lot of the posts on the net about our 
party.  I responded to some of you privately, but it wasn't untill I 
read Lesliea's post that I decided to respond.
    Lesliea, I want to thank you so much for your coming to our 
defence.  I almost started to cry when I read what you had writen.  It 
was very suportive and I only wish more people had your atitude.  You 
are example of what I consider somone with a perfect "raver atitude"
    If you or anyone out there has any questions about what it is that 
Feel Good Entertainment is all about, or why we throw parties, please 
do not hesitate to send e-mail and I will respond, or just call me (I'm 
a terible speller) @ 415-593-3664.  I will be more than happy to 
explain any questions you might have.  untill then,

Stay safe, Positive, and Keep The Vibe Alive.
Peace,  Vlad Cood, Feel Good E., 415-593-3664

they're dressed -- or try not to anyway.

show up on Harleys, dressed in full leathers, chompin' on some fat stogies, 
standing around and staring at everyone.  Do you suppose ANYONE would walk 
up and try to give these guys a hug?  Would anyone chat with them?  Would 
anyone sit one of them down and try to give them a backrub?  Would they be 
included at ALL?

befriend people without any hangups or prejudices?

On Tue, 10 Sep 1996, Brian Ward wrote:

> Actually, E is cut with heroin all the time in San Diego...And by the
> way...Heroin is NOT that expensive. Considering how little E you're getting
> in your hits, i's say it's quite cost effective for dealers. I don't see
> why they'd lie.

sigh. as has been written many times by the more pharmacologically savvy
members  of the list, heroin is *not* orally active in the small 
quantities that would fit in a capsule. thus, someone may as well just 
cut it with kool-aid mix since it's much cheaper than heroin and, like 
smack, will have *no effect*.

anyone want to post a weekly faq?

yeah, but remember that people have to meet raving halfway. Don't expect to
get unsolicited hugs if you're a burly biker guy chompin' fat stogies and
glaring at everyone because YOU chose to dress/act that way, and you're
sending a clear message about how you want to be percieved. But if you're
that same burly biker guy with a wide smile on his face, who knows??? I'd
probably say hi or smile back or something...

Give *everyone* a chance but don't let yourself be naive. If someone looks
like an asshole, be cautious, I guess.

smiles,
-m.

hello!

Well, it's nearing 5pm, and many of you are signing off for the day
[not me; I'm trapped here until late :(]. And today's been a noisy
day, complete with mudslinging, accusations of who is(not) a true
raver, bad vibes, etc.

But let's put it all behind us and remember that it's all about the
music, the dancing, and spending special times with some friends,
whether it's 70 or 7000 (what's an order of magnitude or so, anyway?)

And above all, let's all remember to have Leslie in our hearts
tommorrow!!!  She's a really special person, she has her head screwed
on right, and I know that she's going to survive the wolves and the
vultures in talk show land. :)

air kisses,
Steve

Date: Tue, 10 Sep 1996 17:25:33 -0700
In-Reply-To: elizabeth_o'connor@ccmail.rsco.com
        "Re[2]: what's it cut with?i" (Sep 10,  5:02pm)
References: <9608108424.AA842400257@ccmail.rsco.com>
X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.2.0 26oct94 MediaMail)
To: elizabeth_o'connor@ccmail.rsco.com
Subject: Re[2]: what's it cut with?
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

On Sep 10,  5:02pm, elizabeth_o'connor@ccmail.rsco.com wrote:
> Subject: Re[2]: what's it cut with?i
>      Apparently it's pretty big in Dublin to mix an amount of Heroin in
>      with E - you feel even better - get more hooked - buy more. Pretty
>      sick.
>
Hmmm, again, where is the evidence? Most of the E distributed in Europe and
especially Brittain (and I assume Ireland too) is manufactured in the
Netherlands, and that stuff is pretty clean. Unfortunately the web pages
of the Netherlands Institute for Alcohol and Drugs are in Dutch but they
keep a close eye on what is sold and made in the country. The only serious
problems they ever came accross were too high doses of E (ironic, huh?).
Besides, E is a drug that sells itself. Seeing how far its use is spreading
all over the world I would say there is little use for getting people more
hooked. The market is already huge because as someone once put it, not
everybody wants to trip or get high but everybody wants to be happy. Seeing
how the available quantities and quality of the E sold in Holland have
risen over the years (and prises dropping) I'd say dealers have more to
gain by selling good E (which will sell increasingly better by word of mouth)
then by selling bunk of any kind (which essentially works only once).

If there is any mixing done, I'd say people do it themselves. And again,
I have serious doubts about the _oral_ activity of heroin. After so many
years of abuse of that drug I'd say people would have figured out whether
it made sense to eat it, instead of smoking/injecting it like most junkies
do.

And before any similar post follow, let me say this:

- there is no strychnine in acid
- hair doesn't grow on the palms of your hands due to masturbating
- acid/E do not drain your spinal fluid (thanx Andy for reminding me of this
  one!)
- there is no heroin or mashed lightbulbs in E
- etc. etc.

Besides all the horror stories that live in our community, the real dangers
are much more simple. E is a substance of which nobody knows what the long
term effects will be and nobody has a good feel for the purity of what they're
getting. Several of the chemicals involved in the synthesis of MDMA are
at least dubious and I doubt if the people synthesizing it are really
concerned with (or have the equipment to check) the purity of the final
product.

Rave safely,

The Frying Dutchman

--

Given that I've seen a few posts go by with mentions of "E" being cut 
with heroin, I thought I'd mention that there's an article in the current 
issue of High Times that presents test results for several "E" samples 
purchased throught the world. The test was funded partially by Nicholas 
Saunders.

You should recognize the article and it's findings as the same as the 
results that Marc Fathauer (associated with MAPS?) posted to SFRaves back 
in May.

The issue also had some interesting coverage of the recent efforts by 
legislators to change the laws regarding preparations including 
ephedrine, etc.

The current issue of Details also offers some test results for a small 
number of "E" samples purchased around the U.S. They turned up similar 
results.

Wayne said..

>Hello dear friends,
>
>Unfortunately, based on the very real agendas of these pulp TV shows, their
>producers and hosts, I don't feel that the SF (or any other) rave community
>will be served by having Leslie or any other of our friends on TV 'going to
>bat' for our community, lifestyle or passions.

I have a feeling Wayne may have never watched this specific show (today the
guest was Elizabeth Dole and it was a very well-done piece regardless of
our agreement with her and her husband's politics).

I've gotta say (again) that the Leeza show is not "pulp TV" .... it is (as
talk shows go) an intelligent and well-crafted show.  I'm not naive ... but
I have to tell you that the producers went to two parties this weekend in
LA and told me that they were happy to find that many of the things I said
were true ... about great music, happy vibes, drugs not being that
prevalent (they noticed it was the club kids doing the drugs, not the
ravers) ...

And they've invited lots of real ravers to be in the audience as well.  I
like to give people credit until they prove me wrong .. and I hope not to
be proven too wrong on this one...

We cannot have it both ways .. we can't complain about media misinformatin
and then refuse to take a risk to represent the real truth.

So, I am optimistically off to LA in the morning, and ask you all to send
me your energy from about 1:30 til 3:00 or so, when the actual taping will
take place.

Love to all of you amazing people, if they see just 10% of how great our
scene is, we will have accomplished a lot!!

Leslie  (p.s. yes, I have decided to wear a hat ... after all, that is an
integral part of who I am, and the whole point is that we've created an
enviroment where we can be ourselves, and that's all good!)

On Tue, 10 Sep 1996, Ray Vonie wrote:

> Dear Friends,

>     I forgive all the people for their medeling, and uninformed 
> negativity.  It is unfortunate to see such mistrust and decention in a 
> comunity that is developed on the basis of understanding and open 
> mindedness.  I know that it is real easy to get caught up in a rut and 
> become jaded and negative.  And when that point comes I think it is 
> time to reavaluate your actions or stop calling yourself a raver, 
> Because ravers arn't suposed to be that way.  

And just what "way" are they supposed to be? You make derisive remarks
about people's uninformed opinions, yet you refuse to offer any real
information. As far as being a raver, you are in no position to make that
determination.

>     I think that the scene started because people wanted to go 
> underground to get away from this type of prejudice and discrimination. 

What prejudice? What discrimination?


>  But yet here we are, and there are still people talking shit about an 
> event that they had no part off, nor were even there.  And the only 
> reason that this even started was because their uninformed ignorance 
> and negative sceptacism led them to believe that we did not give enough 
> money out of our pocket for charity from a party that was not even 
> intended to be a benefit.  I have done benefits in the past, and ALL 
> the procedes get donated to charity.  This was not a benefit.  Reading 
> the flyer or the posts would have told you that.  

>From the original post:

>for the price of less than one.   We are also donating a portion of our 
>procedes to the Bay Area Homless Alience.  Just think- your partying 
>will help the less fortunate this winter.  

>From your post after the party:

>5.  One of thing that we like to do with all our parties is to give 
> back to the comunity with each event.  Our event was a partial benefit 
> and a portion of the procedes was to be donated to the bay area 
> homeless alience.  We were able to raise $1000 for this organization.  
> Our intention was to donate the funds and recieve some positive press 
> for the rave comunity at the same time.  I know that a thousand dollard 
> does not seem like a lot compared to how much money everyone ASUMES we 
> made at this party, but trust me, it is quite a bit.  We would have 
> been able to donate more, but a lot more people wound up going to BM, 
> and leaving town, than we expected, so there realy was not any 
> astronomical profit made at the party like people want to think.  
> Anyways, as I was saying, the whole idea of giving back to the comunity 
> was one of the reasons we wanted to do the party.  

"Just think, your partying will help the less fortunate this winter."

I repeat this quote because it really stands out. How can you even *BEGIN*
to claim that you did not give the impression that this was at least in
part a benefit, and that something beyond a token amount would be given?

>the other $500.  We wish we only had more to give, but hopefully the 
>next party we will be able to generate twice that amount for the 
>homless alience.  

How many people need to come to do that? 14,000? Would 200,000+ dollars be
necessary to generate $2000 for charity?


>     The reason we wanted to give money away to cherity was so we could 
> get some good and positve publicity for the rave scene as a comunity 
> entity, not a burdon as the media constantly pertrays us to be.  It 
> would have been nice to give more, but that was all we could do at this 
> time.  In future parties we hope to be able to give more.  Mabee if 
> people did a litle more suporting and a lot less talking shit, then we 
> might have done better, but thats the irony of the situation, isn't it?

Not at all, since your budgeting seems so poor that you can only manage
a miniscule portion of your gross. Believe it or not, there are other
groups out there donating to charity, and the percentages are *much*
different than yours.

>     I was very infuriated by a lot of the posts on the net about our 
> party.  I responded to some of you privately, but it wasn't untill I 
> read Lesliea's post that I decided to respond.

You know, I would have absolutely *no* issue with Feel Good Productions if
you hadn't chosen to wave the charity issue around. Charge $100 for your
parties, make 10 million dollars. Good for you. But don't *ever* claim to
be truly charitable, expect people to blindly believe it, and get upset
when a few of the sentient ones question you. 

                                       Black Adder

[ to sfraves list ]

 A DJ Question To You All -

 I've just been bopping around my room, listening to a compilation CD
called "Hard Hop Trypno" on the "moonshine music" label. I like it a lot!
The artists/tunes are:
eboman                donuts with buddha
philadelphia blunts   i like that
uberzone              botz(synthetik)
fatboy slim           everybody loves a 303
keoki                 caterpillar (stepdisk mix)
supersoul             the masterplan
zen cowboys           mad world (the crystal method remix)
more funky shit       listen
the crystal method    blast
mr. funkster          massive

 I guess the style is "trip hop" - it sure sounds good coming out of my
new studio monitor speakers!

 Anyway - which DJs spin this style in the SF Bay area? Are there any
weeklies devoted to this stuff?

 Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Sep 11 01:39:57 1996

Dear Leslie,

	It's okay to use my name here, I'd rather be a person than an
anonymous "voice" or "someone."
	Reading what you've written below, I feel like hostility is being
attributed to me that I never expressed.  While taking issue with my idea
that promoters should go public with their profits and expenses is
certainly legitimate, I don't like the implication that I was giving
MegaBuzz1 shit.  Maybe that particular phrase wasn't meant to apply to me
Leslie, but your post is full of my quotes, so it's not hard to draw that
conclusion...
			(more comments below)

My computer tells me that on Tue, 10 Sep 1996, Leslie Ayres shared:

> Sorry, have to respond again on this one ....  and I for one apologize to
> MegaBuzz One for taking shit after giving a generous and unsolicited
> donation to two very good causes.  That sucks!!!  I bet next time he'll
> think twice about posting anything to SFRaves.
> 
> And all this stuff about "nipping nasty rumors in the bud" ????  Maybe I
> missed something, but I never saw any nasty rumors about this company or
> promoter... all I've seen is criticism AFTER THE FACT when he posted about
> his party.  Perhaps some of the voices on here are confusing this promoter
> with someone else?  Misinformation can be VERY damaging, and it is up to
> each of us to make sure we know what we're talking about when we start
> these threads that feed these rumors.

	What I meant by nasty rumors is the kind of speculation that Feel
Good Entertainment wasn't being that generous, that they really made tons
of money and only gave a token amount to look good to the rave community.
If this is untrue, then I feel as bad as anyone about it that the matter
ever came up.  What I was suggesting is that financial disclosure would
settle such rumors once and for all.  Misinformation can be very damaging,
I agree, and the only way to effectively counter it is with the facts.
Know the truth, and the truth will set you free.
	Now Leslie, maybe you aren't aware that Feel Good is the same
group as Cool World, or maybe you weren't here or don't remember the shit
that Cool World and their parties have taken in the past on this list,
rightly or wrongly (and not from me, I might add).  Like I said, I'm on
the fence, I can see both sides.  My wish for financial disclosure was not
directed at Feel Good, but at all rave promoters; it merely came up in a
thread concerning Feel Good.
	I've met Vlad from Feel Good, and he is a nice guy.  He comped me
and a friend for one of his parties in fact, and I certainly don't have
anything against him.  This doesn't change my opinion that I think it
would be a good move on his part to open the books, and like I said, that
goes for anyone throwing a party, not just him.

> Where is it written in the official rules and regulations of raving that
> anyone who wants to give a privately funded and organized party has to open
> their personal financial records to anyone who asks?  (Maybe the same place
> it's written that anyone who throws big parties is an evil moneygrubber?)

Now this is kind of funny, because I've publicly defended massives on
SFRaves, and I've never belonged to the school of thought that says
smaller is better.

> Now, if someone said ... "this is a benefit for ...." and charged hella
> money or took up a collection and we suspected that the money was going
> elsewhere ... that is different.  And if someone charges hella money and
> doesn't deliver (djs don't show up, party gets busted and no refunds
> forthcoming, etc.), that's different too.

We can definitely all agree on this I think.

> But when a private promoter puts their money on the line and puts on a big
> party, and provides all the stuff he said he'd deliver to the people who
> chose to go, I'm not sure how someone not involved thinks it's their right
> to challenge that promoter to, to quote:
> 
> >posting a detailed breakdown of their party's revenues and expenses to the
> >list. Ideally this would include names of individuals, companies, and
> >organizations and how much each received, not simply "Lighting - $200, DJs
> >- $500," etc.  It would also be interesting to know how many people got in
> >free or at reduced cost, and their names and affiliations.  The number of
> >non-paying guests, which can be quite high, certainly factors into the
> >bottom line of a production
> 
> Please! that's ridiculous, you're asking someone to give proprietary
> information  to  450 strangers who all have an opinion that's most likely
> based on a total lack of information on costs and logistics, and frankly
> very often is based on a lack of experience with big dollar business at
> all!

No, it's when you *don't* give the information that you get 450 opinions
based on "a total lack of information on costs and logistics," and that's
precisely the problem.  
	It doesn't take "experience with big dollar business" to see that
if costs were $10,000, and door receipts totalled $20,000, then $10,000 in
profit was made.  All it takes is basic math.  

> And yes, that's *proprietary*... that means private ... I think we are
> confusing the spirit of raving with something else.
> 
> Now, about sharing information with other promoters (i.e. cost for police,
> other negotiating points, etc) .. I wouldn't be surprised if that's done
> anyway, depending in the nurturance of those personal relationships,
> because when promoters treat each other with respect, we all win, and they
> know that (at least most of them).
> 
> This whole thing makes me sad ... instead of seeing something very positive
> in a situation -- which is that a promoter of a large party is donating
> money from his pocket (yes, that's HIS pocket, not yours, sorry, folks) to
> good causes -- insteadee is being openly roasted and lambasted in a public
> forum.

None of what I've said has been meant to detract from the wonderful thing
that the Feel Good promoters did in donating that money.  They definitely
deserve props for it, because of course it is true that they didn't have
to give anything.  What I fail to understand Leslie is why you
apparantly feel that doing a good thing means that no questions
should be asked from that point forward.

> Promoters aren;t "candidates for office" ... they are people who put the
> work in to put on parties ...
> 
> I suggest that every person who belives a promoter should disclose
> everything throw a big and expensive party on their own -- make sure you
> put $$thousands out of your own pocket first -- and then post *every* cost
> detail to the list.  Then you too will  likely be the target of criticism
> that it wasn't enough, you were greedy and underhanded, etc, and if you
> were a REAL raver it wouldn't have cost so much, etc.

Ah, the old "if you haven't been there/done it yourself, you can't have a
valid opinion."  

> We've got to get over this "if it makes a profit, it can't be a rave"
> mentality, because it perpetuates this weird "money bad, poverty good"
> ethic.  Hey, I wish everyone could make a living doing something that
> brings joy to people's lives... and if I can make it happen for me, I will!

Now this is truly funny, because everyone here who knows my politics knows
that I am a die-hard capitalist.  I would not deny anyone their right to
make a profit, and I am totally against government confiscation of
people's earnings in the name of the community or anything else.  However
as William Safire said...
	I too wish everyone could make a living doing something that
brings joy to people's lives, but isn't it easier to create joy if it's
obvious to everyone that you aren't hiding anything?  I sincerely believe
the rave scene will be better if more people in it do nice things for each
other because they want to and not because there's a profit in it. 
	I'm asking promoters a favor on behalf of our scene, not demanding
money and violating privacy at gunpoint as our government does.

Much love,
				<<< Starchild >>>

P.S. - You can believe me or not as you choose, but if I were throwing a
big party, I would disclose everything, because I would conduct my affairs
in such a way as not to embarrass myself should the information become
public.

> Love, Leslie
> 
> p.s.  my expenses for popsicles at Sunset was exactly $8.64 this week, and
> $6.98 for the time before that ... didn't accept a cent for them.  Feel
> better?  And the Leeza show isn't paying anything but my expenses (wish
> they would, my car payment is late!)

Now let's not trivialize the subject...

Perhaps the MegaBuzz folks are being just charitable enough to make the
IRS happy? Perhaps the $1000.00 makes a good write-off. Or perhaps it
puts them in a completely different tax category so they can pretend to
be a nonprofit organization. Hell, churches do this kind of shit all
the time, and they get away with it, so why shouldn't a rave? Of
course, the government is catching on to these ploys, witness, for
example, the Christian Coalition getting caught pretending to be a
"nonprofit" organization that has done an excellent job of "cooking"
their books while managing to generate huge amounts of bribe money to
pay off the appropriate congresspeople. IMHO, people claiming to be "of
faith" make the best perjurers and swindlers. Whether it be ravers "of
faith" talking crap about how they want to "give back to the community"
or church elders plundering the coffers filled by their increasingly
impoverished parishioners.

Anybody want to Join the Church O' Niels? Please send $100.00 ... You
will do this because you know I'll be giving back to the community
vibe, but first I gotta buy me some slow cars and fast wimmen, and some
houses and boats so I can throw more vibe-laden parties. Peace Love
Unity and Respect, my brothas and sistas!

On Tue, Sep 10, 1996 11:43:00 PM  at Larry Ching wrote: 
 
>[ to sfraves list ] 
> 
> A DJ Question To You All - 
> 
> I've just been bopping around my room, listening to a compilation CD 
>called "Hard Hop Trypno" on the "moonshine music" label. I like it a lot! 
>The artists/tunes are: 
>eboman                donuts with buddha 
>philadelphia blunts   i like that 
>uberzone              botz(synthetik) 
>fatboy slim           everybody loves a 303 
>keoki                 caterpillar (stepdisk mix) 
>supersoul             the masterplan 
>zen cowboys           mad world (the crystal method remix) 
>more funky shit       listen 
>the crystal method    blast 
>mr. funkster          massive 
> 
> I guess the style is "trip hop" - it sure sounds good coming out of my 
>new studio monitor speakers! 
> 
> Anyway - which DJs spin this style in the SF Bay area? Are there any 
>weeklies devoted to this stuff? 
> 
> Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

> 
yours truly baby.........now actually, these tracks are a little fast to be
considered "triphop".....they are more along the lines of "break
beat"...... 
 
many of these tracks are at least 6 months to a year old now.........I play
similar styles and grooves.......... I don't know of any weeklies, (here in
the bay area) but I'll say I played these styles (and actual tracks) in
london, and they loved it......... 
 
I would call it "west coast breakbeat" except that eboman comes from
holland, fatboy slim comes from brighton (in the uk), uberzone is from
germany, and zen cowboys are from the uk as well......... the only track
that doesn't belong, is the kioki track, and if you read my posts, you will
know I can't stand his DJ'ing or his music, or his self proffssed
"superstar status"   Phewtuey spit yuk !!!! 
 
crystal method, massive funkster and more funky shit are all u.s.
artists...... 
 
but for all intents and purposes these are all break beat styles (as
opposed to the old 4/4 style of beat we know as house/techno/ or trance) 
 
I personally like them because they are more funky sounding as well as
possess the acid and club elements........and to me funky will never go out
of style.... 
 
I'm glad to see someone else give some credence to their existence........
I feel justified in my musical choices, even though I find a fraction of
the interest in my spinning than say the avaerage house dj (i won't mention
names)...... moonpup

speed on the quiet, or does it mean I should do all my drugs on the hush,

shouldnt do drugs at all ?????? please clarify your rather open statement  
  moonpup

Subject: Help!  Mixer assistance needed
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

I'm sure that someone out there in rave land has had experience with this
problem:

I recently bought an MTX 1550 DJ Mixer with the highest of hopes -- sounded
solid in the store, sliders knobs and switches seemed solid, and all for
the low low price of $275.  After bringing the box back home and setting it
up, I now see what the difference between a $300 mixer and a $700 one is.

My mixer is really susceptable to radio noise interference.  I talked to
some guys here at work and they told me it was most likely due to a bad
ground somewhere in my house.  One of the outlets I tried the system on was
not producing radio/refrigerator/every other electronic appliance in the
house buzz, but the one room where everything must be set up most
definitely is.

I'm told that poorly constructed and grounded wiring is very common here in
San Francisco, so I figured that people must have figured out ways to
overcome this annoying problem, so I'm asking -- short of having an
electrician come in and overhaul my circuit, what's the next best thing?

Help me!  I spent money I don't even have for the thing, and now it's
coming back to haunt me :-(

Thanks!

Oliver

Subject: Cynicism, memes, reality
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Wed, 11 Sep 96 8:46:53 PDT
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

John Bagby:
>This is a classic argument-- the cynic ... believes no memes can 
>reach escape velocity from within the Spectacle-- that the game is fixed 
>with no chance for a really good hack...

I was talking to a friend at the last Sunset about whether the human
species will destroy itself before any positive (r)evolutionary memes
will have a chance to significanly steer us towards a path more in
harmony with the forces of nature.  There are a lot of assumptions
embedded in this line of questioning, but I think it's obvious that
if you believe that certain ideas or values are worthy of being
spread, then the message needs to come out somehow.  *Perhaps*
even a distorted message is better than none at all, because 
a distortion can carry some truth along as its source.

This is why it was important, and good, IMO that Megabuzz let everyone
know that it gave something (even if only a token) to charity.  Even as
a marketing ploy the theme is a good one.  Same with their their
declarations of PLUR, etc.  Anyone remember that Coke commercial with
the multiracial gathering on a hilltop singing "I'd like to teach the
world to sing in perfect harmony..."?  It may have been a commercialized
perversion of a positive meme, but I can still remember as a kid, not
caring about having a Coke, but seeing a message that championed a
reality much different than the one I knew.  An image to strive towards.

Subliminal messages make a difference.  That's why many of us think that
"Blitzkrieg" is a shitty name for a rave.  (Not that Megabuzz is much
better).  

Cynics like to shout whenever a message doesn't match the reality, and
it is important that we try to be aware of such revelations.  But 
sometimes the message is more important than reality.

Beautiful Dead People:

The BP party apparently stood for something wonderful, and showed
genuine concern for one member of the rave community who was severely
injured due to carelessness at a rave camp.  I found it ironic that
this party was held at such a fire death trap like the ACME warehouse.
But what choice is there?  What the Harmony folks want to say and
achieve may be more important than any high degree of safety for the
people they clearly love.  If and when a bunch of beautiful (or
even ugly) people die there, I can't help but to wonder what the benefit
party will be called.

Lee
_________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com  (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )  lee@hyperreal.com

I haven't been subscribed to the list for a few weeks now due to
proccupations so I'm catching up on the current threads...as far as
people appearing on talk shows to champion the rave scene, I know that
these SF ravers probably have the noblest intentions, but I feel the
media machinery of Hollywood is not the best of vehicles. Leeza as a
standard of journalistic credibility? I think not. The mainstream media
has always tended to sensationalize  everything and there's no way any
talk show can capture the pure essence of hours of music and dancing and
bonding. Why even try? Major media attention also tends to lure hordes
of curious people at once which leads to a major influx of stupidity in
a scene all at once. It's far better to have people turned on in
smaller, steadier numbers. If there are motherfuckers out there who
still are clueless, let them remain so.  Anyway that's just my opinion.

In other matters: my sublet ends in a few weeks and I'm trying to sort
out a new living arrangement. If anyone knows of a room in SF opening up
in October,  I'd be grateful for any leads. You could email or leave a
message on my voxmail: 415.995.4906.
Let's see: I'm an East Coast transplant, BA in English, currently a
software tester at SEGA and working an internship at video prod. company
and I have an undying love for stylin' dance music, be it house or
techno or a lovely mixture of the two! Once again, I'm looking to hook
up with intelligent and fun people who are into the scene, among other
things.
Peace.
--

   O ....digdatbeat!
      Gregor Hoffman

>injured due to carelessness at a rave camp.  I found it ironic that
>this party was held at such a fire death trap like the ACME warehouse.
is it a fire death trap? there are two exits on the first floor, and the
loading door could be opened in the event of a mass evacutation.. the top
floor was not used.. the only problem seems with the basement, but there
were several fire extinguishers downstairs and several more on the main
floor level. if anything caught on fire it would be put out right away; the
only fire problem i could see is if something actually blew up, and if
something did it wouldn't really matter much if you were in the acme or
anywhere else cause you'd still be fucked if you were close to the blast.

>But what choice is there?  What the Harmony folks want to say and
>achieve may be more important than any high degree of safety for the
>people they clearly love.  If and when a bunch of beautiful (or
that's hardly a fair statement. greg didn't have a chance to confirm the
original space planned because he rushed out to reno to be with omar. and
the harmony crew definately had the safety and comfort of everyone at heart.
there were several fans set up (even though more would have been better,
they certainly were nice), there were fire extinguishers in plain view, and
there were specific arrangements made to prevent overcrowding.

if there had been any serious doubts in the harmony crew's minds about the
safety of the acme, it would not have been used.
-brendan-

 I would just like to mention here that I always bring a small, yet fairly 
well stocked 1st Aid box and that I have had CPR and 1st Aid training, 
not to mention experience in medical emergencies (including an emergency 
situation while my mind was expanded and I was required to watch someone 
and keep them from choking on their own blood until an ambulance   
arrived.) Another item is that I use AC boxes with circuit breakers on 
them - this helps to reduce the chances of shorts and electrical fires.
 More good reasons for hiring Dionysus Dreams ;) (BSP)

Yeah!,
I was in seattle & B.C. this weekend and they we're playing plenty up there!
 I can't believe SF doesn't have even one night of funkier beats.
whasupwitdat? I know tons of folks who dig the hell out of this shit, I know
I'm wearing moonpup's tapes down to the reel.  ALSO: what's up with the
"COOL" connection.  There's this video store on haight where this big funky
brother is always playing some really FATFAT beats. He's really nice and all,
but he never really tells me what it is, just says shit like "cool, it's a
way of life man" in this stoney mellow voice. I've heard the term used in AJ,
but his beats are way beyond AJ. (though I like that too)  Sounds like a hell
of an opp. if someone would open a club specializing in a range of laidback
beats.
StEvEo

Hello,

    For everyone who wanted to help with this year's anniversary event, 
there will be a meeting in San Jose tonight @ 7pm, it will go until 10 
or 11. We are meeting @ the City Espresso on Steven's Creek at 
Larwrence Expressway. If you would like to come, it would be greatly 
apprieciated. Please be respectful of the establishment, and clean up 
any mess you make. 

    We will discuss everything that is going to happen on Sat. and our 
goals for the event, as well as how we can all help to achieve those 
goals. Also, we will talk about the future of our brother Omar, and of 
Harmony itself. We could really use a lot of help, so don't be afraid 
to offer it!! Thanks in advance, and we love you!!

Peace,

Greg :)


Ps: this meeting was intended for my house, but too many people want to 
come and we can't fit in my living room, so it will be at City E on 
Stevens Creek and Lawrence Expressway. Coming from San Francisco take 
280 so (or 101so to 85so to 280so) exit Stevens Creek/ Lawrence 
Expressway. Take a left at the light at the bottom of the exit. That 
will put you on Stevens Creek, and you will see it on your left. 
(Across the street from Safeway)

>From east bay take 880 or 680so to 280 no and exit Stevens Creek/ 
Lawrence Expressway. Take a right at the light at the bottom of the 
exit and it will be there on your left. Look for a familiar raver's 
face. C-ya there!!!

>I'm sure that someone out there in rave land has had experience with this
>problem:
>
>I recently bought an MTX 1550 DJ Mixer with the highest of hopes -- sounded
>solid in the store, sliders knobs and switches seemed solid, and all for
>the low low price of $275.  After bringing the box back home and setting it
>up, I now see what the difference between a $300 mixer and a $700 one is.
>
>My mixer is really susceptable to radio noise interference.  I talked to
>some guys here at work and they told me it was most likely due to a bad
>ground somewhere in my house.  One of the outlets I tried the system on was
>not producing radio/refrigerator/every other electronic appliance in the
>house buzz, but the one room where everything must be set up most
>definitely is.
>
>I'm told that poorly constructed and grounded wiring is very common here in
>San Francisco, so I figured that people must have figured out ways to
>overcome this annoying problem, so I'm asking -- short of having an
>electrician come in and overhaul my circuit, what's the next best thing?
>
>Help me!  I spent money I don't even have for the thing, and now it's
>coming back to haunt me :-(
>
>Thanks!
>
>Oliver

Hey Oliver, saw this on SFRaves... I'd guess that the cheapest solution
will probably be getting some heavy duty extension cords to that one outlet
that has no interference. Not pretty, but it will work.

Other than that, the easiest thing to do is lift the ground. It may not
solve the problem, but it's worth a shot. You can do this by getting one of
those 2 prong to 3 prong adapters (ie the one you would use if your house
only had 2 prong outlets, and you had 3 prong plugs). This usually has a
clip attachment for a the screw that mounts the outlet coverplate to the
wall - you would remove that screw, plug the adapter in, and then put the
screw back through the clip. To lift the ground, DON'T do this - the clip
is what makes the ground contact... you'll need to make sure that the metal
clip doesn't touch any metal at all, bend it or break it off. Or you could
just cut the ground plug off of your power strip with a pair of pliers, but
this obviously permanently damages the strip.

I must say, though, that lifting the ground is a last resort option - it's
not very safe. It's a fire hazard, and it's possible to fry your gear if a
major spike comes down with no ground to go to. I've NEVER seen it happen,
I've done it myself a thousand times, but you never know... I'd unplug the
thing when you weren't using it.

Let me know if you find any other solutions that work.

--
Brian

But seeing as as yours was so condescending and patronizing, I actually
believe it now. 

-thanks for the heads up
-alex

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Sep 11 16:52:13 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id QAA19967; Wed, 11 Sep 1996 16:52:13 -0700 (PDT)

From: Ken Lawrence <techno@pacificnet.net>

Hi ho, folks.  Just wanted to let you know about some new mixtapes I got
in...

R.A.W. "Terminate":  This is a double tape of 100% original drum & bass
by R.A.W.!  There's elements of hardstep, intelligent, ragga, and
breakbeat.  These are for sure the most interesting jungle tapes I've
heard in months.

DJ Liquid:  "Listen to Me Roar" and "Trip to Moonville".  LTMR has some
funky progressive trance on the A side, and drum & bass on the B side. 
Trip to Moonville is all funky trance.  Both are 90 minutes.

Snuggles & Slak:  "Silk Cut 3" Dreamy, smooth intelligent drum & bass. 
The only drawback is that it's a 60 minute tape, but it's also only $10.

DJ Trance/Fester:  "Fester Trance 4"  I will probably get this one
tonight.  Trance tells me Fester plays some hard acid on his side, and
Trance plays Acid house, beginning with that "Allright Allright" track.

DJ Dan "Imagine":  This one has been actually out for awhile, but we
finally got more in stock.  It's cool, experimental chillout Trip Hop. 
Kind of nice to hear something a little different from Dan.

Ron D Core & Simply Jeff "Blitzkrieg":  THese are limited.  Simply Jeff
lays down the funky West Coast Breaks & trip hop, and Ron's side is live
gabber.

New stuff on the way--->  Dan Efex "Freakout":  Dan Efex's last hardcore
gabber mixtape!  A tribute to the many faces of Speedfreak.  This one
will knock yer socks off!  Also expect a new trance project to be
released in the coming months. 
Christopher Lawrence:  "Prophecy":  Awesome progressive trance is what's
to be expected here.  It should be available in 3 weeks.

Anyhow folks, those are my newest tapes.  I'll be set up at Magic
Wednesdays tonight and Nocturnal Wonderland on Saturday.
--ken (pure acid mixtapes)
310-793-1021

p.s.:  SF ravers (or anyone else), if you e-mail your paper address I'll
send you a free Pure Acid Mixtapes catalog which I promise is dope. 
Thanks!
--Ken

Y'all techies might get a kick out of this...


>
>True story from a Novell NetWire SysOp:
>
>Caller: "Hello, is this Tech Support?"
>
>Tech Rep: "Yes, it is. How may I help you?"
>
>Caller: "The cup holder on my PC is broken and I am within my warranty
>period. How do I go about getting that fixed?"
>
>Tech Rep: "I'm sorry, but did you say a cup holder?"
>
>Caller: "Yes, it's attached to the front of my computer."
>
>Tech Rep: "Please excuse me if I seem a bit stumped, it's because I
>am. Did you receive this as part of a promotional, at a trade show?
>How did you get this cup holder? Does it have any trademark on it?"
>
>Caller: "It came with my computer, I don't know anything about a
>promotional. It just has '4X' on it."
>
>At this point the Tech Rep had to mute the caller, because he couldn't
>stand it. The caller had been using the load drawer of the CD-ROM
>drive as a cup holder, and snapped it off the drive.

> Or a dyslexic or a foreigner, which has little correlation with intelligence...

Having a learning disorder does not stop you from running a spell 
checker.  I am dyslexic, I have a real spelling problem, but I have a 
dictionary right here on my desk.  See it? ;-)  I need that because I 
sometimes mangle a word so badly that my Pegasus Mail Spell Checker 
can't even recognize it!  Being a foreigner, well that's a little 
different, but a foreigner can still run a spell checker.  I guess 
it's just a problem for me because I over compensate for my own 
spelling problems.  Because I am mostly on the internet for business, 
I have no choice but to look business-like.  And poor spelling is not 
good business! 

It's just my little problem.

Sorry if I scared anyone.

Ross

>I've heard pretty reliable sources state that there has never been H

>for H is actually "Dilaudia" (sp?) in E.  I've also heard "Dilaudia"

>A few months ago I had an E that made me horribly sick for 2.5 days.  I
>couldn't stop barfing, and there was NO identifiable sensasions that
>come along with E.  I felt zapped, basically numbish, and extremely
>nautious.

Sounds like Dilaudid, which is a prescription opiate painkiller. Strong
stuff, and not easily obtained. (This is what the crew in the movie
Drugstore Cowboy were primarily after) I'd be quite surprised if any ever
turned up in e.

 A DJ Question To You All -

 I've just been bopping around my room, listening to a compilation CD
called "Hard Hop Trypno" on the "moonshine music" label. I like it a lot!
The artists/tunes are:
eboman                donuts with buddha
philadelphia blunts   i like that
uberzone              botz(synthetik)
fatboy slim           everybody loves a 303
keoki                 caterpillar (stepdisk mix)
supersoul             the masterplan
zen cowboys           mad world (the crystal method remix)
more funky shit       listen
the crystal method    blast
mr. funkster          massive

 I guess the style is "trip hop" - it sure sounds good coming out of my
new studio monitor speakers!

Hello everybody, 
	I just got home from the taping, and am proud to say that Leslie
did an absolutely wonderful job, even though she was sandwiched
between two ultra-conservative, close-minded mothers, and was up
against a (typically) low level of audience awareness.  She did manage to
convey many good points and she portrayed herself
intelligently and articulately.   There was a large contingent of
colorfully dressed and well spoken So-Cal Ravers.  All in all it was just
what I expected from a talk show; biased, and highly annoying.
Krishna.

Having been to some HUGE events that attracted all kinds of people, I've seen
those people transformed and uplifted by the rave scene that they weren't
necessarily a part of, but had just wandered into by chance. 

If you throw a ball at someone, human reflexes condition them to catch it-

If you were to throw love or peace or compassion, would the same thing
happen?

Let's hope we all have good reflexes...

Precedence: bulk

On Wed, 11 Sep 1996, Randy C Cone wrote:

> 
> 
> Hey folks!
> 
>  Get the fuck off of the backs of your rave promoters!!  NOW!! 

No. 

1) They are not "my" rave promoters.
2) You are in no position to dictate to people to shut up. If you want to
   shut up please do so. However, you telling everyone to shut up is about
   as useful or right as me telling you to shut up. One of the purposes
   of this list is discussion. And that is what is occuring. 

> They (sometimes we) put up with more shit, gamble so much and generally
> put  themselves on the line way more than any of you folks can ever
> imagine unless you have done it yourselves. 

Welcome to life. It is all a gamble. My experiences, or any other persons
on this list are no less valid, despite your obvious opinion to the
contrary,  rather they are a "rave promoter" or "just" a mere mortal.


> While comments and feedback are one thing, the comments and criticism
> (on this thread) are sounding like 
> whiney spoiled brats who can not appreciate the hard work and anguish 
> promoters go through.

And you sound like a pompous ass. Why should anyone shut up, as you have
demanded? Who gives you the authority to limit the discussion, because
you do not like the direction, or the questions being asked?

I have *serious* problems with anyone using the name of charity to peddle
tickets to their events, as Feel Good Productions has. They self-promote,
using in part the guise of largess(I will not bother requoting their posts
to this effect a second time), refuse to offer details, which seems in
direct opposition to their claims of wanting to foster a "community," and
whine about everyone making uninformed opinions when it is they that hold
and refuse to offer the information that would inform us all.
If you are making a living off your "community" then why should it bother
them to tell that "community" where *their*(the party-goers) money is
going?   
 
>  If you you think you can do a better job than PUT UP OR SHUT UP!!!

I am doing my best. Can I have an opinion now?

                                    Black Adder

     It's too late to still be at work...
     
     Whew Leslie!!!  I don't know if I'm feeling into this too much, but 
     for a second, it must have been pretty freaky going up in front of all 
     this negativity and keeping your (beautiful hat adorned) head.  I for 
     one would have started losing it.  It would probably be pretty safe to 
     assume their expert panel of rave skeptics have gone to less raves 
     than most of us... otherwise they would have fallen in LOVE baby.. EL 
     - OH - VE -EE!!!!
     
     I work in a pretty strict corporate environment, and I have to say:
     
     People I meet at work all seem to think:
     
     1. Think raves are all about drugs.
     
     2. Think raves are just a 'front' for gays and lesbians to meet.
     
     3. Are wild sex orgies
     
     4. Are a place were people go to mindlessly go deaf to music
     
     5. Are the last bastion of hardcore EMF fans
     
     6. Are huge events complete with corporate sponsorship
     
     7. Religious abberations were drug crazed freaks worship SUPERSTAR DJ 
     Keoki
     
     8. Where ex hippies go now that the Grateful Dead aren't touring
     
     9. Are the only public performance arenas for people who play Ozzy 
     backwards (that's why they all have those 'old fashioned record 
     players'..)
     
     10.Are the primordial ooze from which the sociological, psychological, 
     artistic, musical, cultural and ethical revolution of the 21st century 
     will evolve from.
     
     11.Where America's teens really go when they say they're going to a 
     friend's house to stay over.
     
     12.The reason JBL is still in business
     
     13.Just a phase to keep us busy until we figure out how to get the 
     Pentagon building for a party/exorcism for new years eve 1999...
     
     I'm so glad it's all true!  I'm so glad it's not all true!  I'm so 
     glad we can embrace diversity and live to tell about it!  I'm so glad 
     it's now!  Here even!  Better than most places!  I'm so glad!!!
     
     Shine you damn raving locos shine!!!!!!!!
     
     Must get more coffee...
     
     Bye for now.  It's going to be an incredible week.  I've seen it.  I 
     have this toilet I go to sometimes, and if there's nothing obscuring 
     the view, I can see the future...
     
     Now to find something to do tonight... somewhere around here there's a 
     place that would benefit from this excess energy.
     
     Peace peace peace
     AndyW

>From today's SF Weekly:

"...Larry Dean Hudson, Jr., driving a borrowed blue 1996 Pontiac Grand Am,
ran through two tents near the rave camp, early Monday morning. Of the
three campers hospitalized, one is in critical condition, another is in
serious condition, and the third has been released. According to [Pershing
County Sherriff Ron] Skinner, Hudson was charged with driving while
intoxicated and causing bodily injury, possession of a controlled substance
and of paraphernalia (a hypodermic needle) and reckless driving. He is
being held in Pershing County without bail."

The article concludes by mentioning that BM organizers are working on a
public transportation system for next year.
