From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Sep 11 22:34:42 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id WAA21482; Wed, 11 Sep 1996 22:34:42 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from dfw-ix7.ix.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with SMTP id WAA21476; Wed, 11 Sep 1996 22:34:38 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from wck-ca7-01.ix.netcom.com (shawna-@wck-ca7-01.ix.netcom.com [204.31.231.33]) by dfw-ix7.ix.netcom.com (8.6.13/8.6.12) with SMTP id WAA19564 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Wed, 11 Sep 1996 22:33:52 -0700
Date: Wed, 11 Sep 1996 22:33:52 -0700
Message-Id: <1.5.4.16.19960910223017.363f91fc@popd.ix.netcom.com>
X-Sender: shawna-@popd.ix.netcom.com
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Light Version 1.5.4 (16)
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: frisco freaks <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
From: The Laffin Happy Trip Farmer <shawna-@ix.netcom.com>
Subject: back from Vacation-Land...  (long!)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Howzit goin for y'alls folks?

I feel like it's been a while since I've posted anything to sfraves, been
running amok for the past 2-3 weeks! :)  Having safely returned from that
Fabled Land of Phat Bong-Hits (Portland, OR), I've finally settled down a
bit & feel like writing once again.  I had my two week vacation from work
with Burning Man weekend smack in the middle of it, and it's been a doozy!
Burning Man was incredible, and I think our camp setups all worked out quite
well in spite of differing opinions on the part of various vw-camp members
as to where to camp.  I liked being in the main camp rather than the rave
camp actually, cuz that was really what I wanted to see/experience, the main
camp itself with all its nifty freaks running around. :)  Rave camp was
cool, altho I did have some difficulty finding stuff in the dark riding
around on my shitty little bike, and I very much enjoyed the CCC music & the
Gateway setup.  Those are the only two camps I checked out, was never into
Wicked and could never find Spaz unfortunately.  And actually, several folk
had smaller soundsystems set up at their camps in the main camp (ie our own
camp, and the Syntonics) which was really groovy, I'd bop on over to the
Syntonics camp & boogie with about 20 other people to one of BioJeff's famed
marathon sets, and it'd be just great!  Familiar smiling faces, great music,
in just a little camp setup 100 yards away from our own camp, and two more
stones's throws away from the hub of activity in the center of main camp.
You all have heard the various descriptions of the Roving Sofa, the Chai
Hut, the House of Doors, the Bubblewrap Camp, etc, all very cool!  I
particularly found the loud rallying politically debating picket-line that
was setup in defense of day-glow colors amusing (especially when I noted the
one sign amongst all the day-glow signs that loudly proclaimed "I like
cheese!" I found this very politically motivating, and not only that, but
I'm eating cheese as we speak!)  I really understand where these guys are
coming from, day-glow is a very misunderstood set of colors, and I for one
am a little tired of the constant abuse & harrassment these colors have to
face every day from callous, uncaring, and bigoted individuals.  It's time
we take a stand folks.

;)

Anyway!  Off my day-glo soapbox!  I know BM is supposed to be entirely
participatory, but I still feel like I was too much of a spectator (I get
the feeling a lot of us first-timers probably felt like that), and
definitely want to do more next time around, assuming they do have another
BM next year.  One thing I thought would be cool to do was to take a setup
like The Ambient Chai Hut and put one out at rave camp.  I thought the one
thing lacking at rave camp was a good chill area where you could hang out
and keep warm ok, cuz I know several people probably danced the whole night
away when they would have liked to sit down for a spell but couldn't cuz it
was too cold on the playa at night.  So I thought it might be cool to build
a structure in the middle of the sound systems with an ambient setup,
smartbar, hot beverages, blankets, pillows, etc for chilling people on the
playa.  Anybody else think this might be a good idea?  The only problem I
see with it is that it would force me to spend a lot more time in the rave
camp alone when I might otherwise be travelling elsewhere. But hey, I'm sure
I could figure something out!   So I'll either do that idea, or I'll set up
a Spaghetti Hut in main camp & feed lots of people spaghetti!  That could be
fun too.  We had a communal spaghetti dinner in our camp the last night
there, and it really was nice having friends & family sitting around all
eating spaghetti together.  Either way, I know I want to figure something
out to do so that I'm not just sitting around going "oh look that's cool."
It was weird realizing that all the stands & setups were not just organized
by the BM crew (like concession stands at a concert or something, where all
the stands are set up & run by "crew members"), they were just by people who
showed up & decided to do something cool!  True freedom of expression
combined with really providing things/services for other people just cuz you
want to.  Perfect! :)  

I ended up deciding that I was glad I didn't do the RV thing like I
originally wanted to, I borrowed this tent from my co-worker which is a
two-room tent, biggest fuckin thing I ever saw!  Yes, it had two rooms, and
I have a blow-up air mattress the size of a double-bed, so we had this huge
"house" with a double-bed in it (comforter, sheets, feather pillows & all!),
coleman stove to cook up fat meals with (wild-mushroom ravioli with tomato
basil sauce! :), lots of community shade to contribute, and even a welcome
mat at the door!  I was pleased to note that our large tent got used by
various crashing individuals, which is why I wanted such a behemoth in the
first place of course!  Tho Sam & I didn't have any big thing to contribute
to Burning Man itself, we still enjoyed being able to wake up in the morning
& make people coffee & cook them up quesadillas with lotsa stuff in 'em,
feed them dinner & share our sleep space with them, our little group of
tents really had a community feel to it and it was our best way of
contributing at the time.  I was pleased with it! :)  And like I said, the
Syntonics camp was right across the way, so it was nice to grab a cold glass
of Odwalla oj (little over $4 at Costco for a whole gallon, folks, bout the
same price you find for a half gallon at a regular store!) & head on over
for some early afternoon music before the dust dervishes got too out of hand
to play records.  The chai hut was great, Steve Simitzis & I would often
head over there & just chill & drink our tea and dance to gruvy jungle
toonz.  I saw the most amazing array of camp set-ups, everything from simply
tying a cloth to the doors of your car to create an overhang, to building
elaborate pc-pipe (that's what that white tubing's called right?) domes
which housed all things imaginable.  RV's abounded of course, and I am
remembering what a classy set-up they had as far as holding tanks were
concerned.  They actually had a roving sewage-type truck that ran around 1)
cleaning all the portapotties on a daily basis, and 2) emptying people's rv
holding tanks for them when they got full mid-burning man.  Very cool!  

Things of course got very dusty, and I have to admit, after hearing
countless times about going to the desert, I was surprised to find what was
actually a dried mud-flat rather than dunes of sand like I'd pictured.  Ya
know how mud dries & crackles, the entire 'desert' was made of this flat
stuff.  And after a while, the dust got so thick that it looked like San
Francisco on a foggy day!  At dusk on Sunday night, before the Burning of
the Man, while watching an incredible desert sunset, I really felt like I
couldn't quite tell which of the two that haze was, fog or dust.  It was so
surreal, with the sky blazing red in the western part of the sky & dust-mist
so thick you couldn't see tents very well that were farther away, people in
our little temporary community throwing frisbees thru the mist, ambient
music playing at somebody's camp somewhere hidden by the mist, really
beautiful actually.  Even tho at that time, Sunday night, I knew that I
would be ready to go home when it was time, standing there watching all this
I began to miss it already.  I get the feeling that for many people I talked
to (& myself), in certain ways it was kind of hard being out there in that
fashion, just being there experiencing it was pretty intense from begin to
end, and relations with those around you and everything in general was
experienced with a heightened sense of intensity, and things would be
intensely negative as well as intensely positive for sustained periods of
time.  But it was really all worth it, and I wouldn't change any of the
negative or positive experiences I had, and I think a lot of people would
agree, it's all part of what makes up the Burning Man Experience as a whole.
And on that Sunday night, I knew that I would miss it! :)  I actually do
miss the group of people I camped with, cuz no matter how I see you all in
the future, no matter where it is, it won't quite be that little, dusty,
tented mini-community out there on the playa!  (and thank you Steve, for
being the most excellent company! :):)

Ok, nuff bout BM, after getting back from BM, I flew up to Portland to visit
our own SFRaver Brenda Brewer!  That was really cool, and it was great of
her to let me stay with her for the time.  I was lucky to be there the time
I was, cuz her collective, the Ahau Collective, threw a nifty daytime
gathering in the strangest place!  Right smack in the middle of downtown
Portland, in this big outdoor square called Pioneer Square!  And get this,
they simply rented it for the afternoon for $50!  I thought it was a
particularly cool location because it was completely accessible by
everybody, so by the end of the evening everybody was dancing, not just the
pierced baggy-pantsed raver crowd, old people, "regular" folk, everybody was
there together in dance, which is a part of the Ahau's deal.  What I like to
see at all raves! :)  

Ok, I'm finally tired of writing!  Time for bed.  'Night y'alls!


Love,
Shawna

            
          Do not go gentle into that good night!
         Rave! Rave into the dawning of the light!

Greetings fellow ravers,

  I want very much to drive up north to attend the Harmony Party.   It will be
PHAT!...    I need licensed drivers to accompany me on this trek up north,
and am looking for anyone who can share the gas and driving.

  It takes about 10 hours for the trek up to San Jose area,  and I have room
for 2 or 3 people in my car.

  For those that went to Burning Man,   one of the Harmony ravers got seriously
injured when he got run over while in his tent.    This party if for his
healing fund,  and I want to show all of you Southlanders what the Bay
Area scene is all about,  so this is your wonderful opportunity to tag along
and party with us.

  I want to leave late friday evening,  around 9 pm or so,  and drive through
the night to arrive in San Jose at around noon (when the party starts).

  The party goes on until Sunday morning,  and after a few hours of rest,
we plan on heading south again.    So please bring whatever donations you
can for Omar,  your love and well wishes...

The Crunchman

Hello,

On Wed, 11 Sep 96 20:30:09 pst, "Andy Wyszkowski"
<awyszkow@smtplink.acer.com> wrote:

>     13.Just a phase to keep us busy until we figure out how to get the 
>     Pentagon building for a party/exorcism for new years eve 1999...

In case anyone cares, the actuall Millenium occurs in less than 3
weeks.

You see, "1996" means 1996 years since the birth of Christ.

HOWEVER, modern historical research is virtually unanimous that Christ
wasn't born on December 25 of 1 B.C.

It seems fairly clear that the calendar got jumbled more than once
over the centuries.

The clearest evidence for dating the birth of Christ is that his
parents had to travel to Bethlehem for the Census.

Using historical Roman records of the censuses (and other minor
details in both the biblical account and other historical accounts),
the most likely date for the birth of Christ is September 29, 4 B.C.

Which makes the Millenium two weeks from Sunday.

At least "they" were considerate enough to make it a Saturday night,
yes?  :-)

PS  Sorry I didn't give you more notice....


Be seeing you,

Ken

kstuart@mail.telis.org

their rave experience more meaningful.  One might want to keep it down a

Wow, what a party! Cool decorations, phat ass laser, lighting was 
excellent! (C'mon, it's a TV studio) Chilll room was decorated nicely.

Leeza grooved as the producer layed out some funky acid-breaks, and 
one of the stagehands busted out an incredible goa trance set. The 
Paramount Pictures lot is such an incredibly gorgeous venue!!!

JUST KIDDING!!!!!

Seriously, I wish I had something good to say.

Way too much focus on raves being just sex ladden all night drug 
fests.

They had a couple mom/daughter duos that they focused on. Two of the 
moms were pro-rave, but the most positive mom was left in the audience 
so she only got about 20 seconds to speak. The other mom looked kinda 
bad to the audience because they couldn't believe she let her 16 year 
old daughter go to these "drugfests".

Plus, they planted this brainless (and ball-less) drug dealer from 
Florida in the audience who rambled on about how raves were about 
selling drugs. ARRRGGHH!!!

They also had a bunch of the most outlandishly dressed clubkidd type 
ravers there to represent us as "ravers". (Love those 3 foot high 
shoes!)

Well, Leslie was definitely a island of relief in that ocean of 
diarrhea. She retorted to comments and questions with nothing but 
exellent examples of the positive aspects of raving. Too bad she 
wasn't given enough time to speak. :(

I was sick to my stomach by the end of the show.

But it was definitely great to see Mhg and liquid there to complete 
the SFRavers row!

My $.02 is that the producers had their agenda way beforehand and 
executed it just as they planned. There was really nothing we could 
do. It would have happened anyway. At least we had Leslie there to 
combat some of the SHIT they were throwing around.

That's Hollywood for ya.

Oh wait...I do have something good to say.....

((((---->>>> SEE YOU AT THE HARMONY 3 YEAR!!!!!  <<<<----))))))

=) =) =) =) =) =) =) =) =) =) =) =) =) =) =) =) =) =) =) =) =) =) 

big mental hugs beamin north,

CT

>If there has ever been any proof that E is cut with H in San Diego or BF
Egypt, I nor anyone I know has ever seen it. Please don't continue with this
nonsense. For H to be orally active it would have to be a monster dose or so
pure that no dealer in his right mind would sell it for that price.
>
>Most commonly found and most likely ingredient to cause "heroin like"
effects is DXM dextromethorphan (decks-tro-meth-OR-fan), the active
ingredient in Robotussin. Often, it is accompanied with other ingredients
also found in cough medicines (pseudoephedrine, phenylpropanolamine,
guaifenesin, acetaminophen and others). It seems that those unscrupulous
producers take multi-symptom cough remedies, extract whatever they can, mix
them with some stimulant (often just cross-tops of ephedrine like you can
get at 7-11)  and pass these off as E.
>
>suggested reading:
>
>DXM faq: http://www.frognet.net/dxm/
>
>Multidisciplinary Association For Psychedelic Studies MAPS
http://www.maps.org/ 
>
>a lot of great info but current issue with North American MDMA sample
testing results is not yet up. Guess what- 0 samples of 22 contained H. At
least 8 had no MDMA but a lot of the above ingredients.

>>in your hits, i's say it's quite cost effective for dealers.

-----------------------
25 Ways to cope with stress

l. Jam miniature marshmallows up your nose and sneeze them out. See how many
you can do at a time.
2. Use your Master card to pay your Visa, and vice-versa.
3. Pop some popcorn without putting the lid on.
4. When someone says "Have a nice day", tell them you have other plans.
5. Make a list of things to do that you have already done.
6. Dance naked in front of your pets.
7. Put your toddler's clothes on backwards and send him to pre-school as if
nothing is wrong.
8. Fill out your tax form using Roman Numerals.
9. Tape pictures of your boss on watermelons and launch them from high
places.
10. Leaf through "National Geographic" and draw underwear on the natives.
11. Tattoo "Out to Lunch" on your forehead.
12. Go shopping. Buy everything. Sweat in it. Return it the next day.
13. Buy a subscription to "Sleazoid Weekly" and send it to your boss's
husband/wife.
14. Pay your electric bill in pennies.
15. Drive to work in reverse.
16. Find out what a frog in a blender really looks like.
17. Tell your boss to "blow it out your mule", and let him figure it out.
18. Sit naked on a shelled hard-boiled egg.
19. Polish your car with earwax.
20. Read the dictionary upside down and look for secret messages.
21. Start a nasty rumor and see if you recognize it when it comes back to
you.
22. Braid the hairs in each nostril.
23. Write a short story using alphabet soup.
24. Stare at people through the tines of a fork and pretend they're in jail.
25. Make a language up and ask people for directions in it.
Bonus: Replace the filling of a Twinkie with ketchup and put it back in the
wrapper.

SuperCenter:  (415) 363-8100
Corporate HQ: (415) 614-7500

Beautiful People,
	As today being my birthday (not bragging......NOT!!), a friend of mine (Arlina) had me 
select from a deck of Indian Medicine Cards. Today I pulled the Beaver and in the explanation
this was said:
		"To accomplish a goal with others involves working with the group mind. 
		Group mind constitutes HARMONY of the highest order, with out individual
		egoes getting in the way.Each partner in the project honors the talents and 
		abilities of the others, and knows how to complete the piece of the puzzle
		that belongs to them. In working well with others, a sense of COMMUNITY
		is achieved and UNITY ensues."
	
	This really made my day and hope it can make everyones life. Hope to see you all
        at Harmony. This will truly be my first rave. I'm 6 foot, Latino and will be 
        wearing a pair of beige, welders over-alls.

							PLUR
							VERTIGO		

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Sep 12 09:37:16 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id JAA14612; Thu, 12 Sep 1996 09:37:16 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from dns1.noc.best.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with SMTP id JAA14604; Thu, 12 Sep 1996 09:37:13 -0700 (PDT)

Received: from [206.86.235.114] (lesliea.vip.best.com [206.86.235.114]) by shellx.best.com (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id JAA24951 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Thu, 12 Sep 1996 09:35:33 -0700
Date: Thu, 12 Sep 1996 09:35:33 -0700
Message-Id: <v01530500ae5cd68cc478@[206.86.235.114]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: lesliea@BEST.COM (Leslie Ayres)
Subject: The Leeza Show is Done!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Wow, what a weird and long day yesterday.  I've been processing all of the
hubbub of what happened to sort out the positive, forward-moving things.

My original goal in going on the show was this:

We as a community cannot complain about media coverage if we are not
willing to put ourselves on the line to defend what we so strongly belive
in.  Yes, you have to put yourselves into the media hype arena ... since we
don't have a public forum on tv ... and you have to play by their rules and
in a way take what you get.  But if you're not willing to do that, you have
NO RIGHT to complain about how you are portrayed.  That's why I did it, and
I knew it wouldn't go as a perfect, flowing, glowing piece.  The people on
this show are not sleazebags, their heart is in the right place, but they
are from conservative america and had a lot of misinformation that they
built on.

First, allow me to say being picked up by a limo driver and having your own
trailer on the set with your name on it is a trip.  Even if I HATED it, I
kept wandering back inside where stuff was happening pre-taping, but they'd
gently guide me back to my trailer -- I think the were worried some mom
would get mad at me and who knows what would happen.  Silly.

Walking into the studio and seeing friendly faces, hearing my name called
out by Krishna, Terry (CT), Madame Mercury (Sherry) and Liquid (Ryan), and
the Crunchman ... that was great ... and there were several SoCal ravers
there I'd met.  The audience was about  70% ravers ... though a visible
contingent of them were really club kids with the makeup, stacked shoes,
gothic-drag appearance .. which I totally love, but isn't really
representative of the whole scene at all.

They reorganized the order of the show mid-stream, so I didn't get the
slice of time expected ... there were three moms there ... one with her 2
daughters, one of whom used to rave and the other does it now with her
mom's ok ... 16 years old, she's from NY and told me backstage that raves
there are about clothes.  Sad and pretty boring really.

The next mom was a fairly cheesy misinformed woman with a shining and
adorable 16-yr-old daughter whose resorted to sneaking out windows to go to
parties, so that mom has actually tried nailing the window shut.  Both she
and her daughter took a lof of shit from the audience (bad disobedient
girl! bad misunderstanding mom! stuff)

The third mom's daughter ran away from home and she blamed it on raving,
found her 10 days later and put her in drug rehab in S. Carolina where they
live.  The girl called on the phone and said when she gets out, she'll rave
again, it's not about drugs.

Bottom line, the topic of the show was restricted to young teenagers going
to raves to get sucked into doing drugs, and the discussion certainly made
people worry about that .. as well they should.

Positive aspects:  I got to tell this story (please tell me if you know who
this is, I'd like to talk to her before the show) ....  When I was at a
party last friday before the party began, a young girl arrived with her
dad.  She showed him the decorations, the sound system, the chill space.
He hugged her goodbye and left, and several kids said "Is that your dad?
That's so rad, I wish my dad would come to a party and see what it's really
about."  I encouraged kids whose parents don't understand raving to take
them to a party and show them first-hand what they're doing.  Kids want
their parents to understand and support them in doing the things that make
them happy.

I said that I don't believe that 14-15-16 year olds have any business
taking drugs, they're not able to handle the experience ... some of the
audience bood me, but they bood and clapped for the oddest stuff ....

I said that kids have drugs available everywhere, not just at raves ...
they take drugs at school ...

I said that raving is about happiness ... it's about music and dancing and
expressing your individuality.

What did other people say?  Its largely a blur ... so we'll have to see how
it edits down.

So much is just a blur to me ... thankfully Terry, Sherry, Ryan, John and I
went to grab some dinner afterwards, so I had a chance to decompress with
friends.  Made my plane by 2 minutes, Terry!

Will this show make any difference in our REAL scene?  Nope, it was about
young kids and drugs really.  I told the producers I was disappointed, that
they should consider doing a show that's actually about the spiritual and
community side of raving ... but hopefully there was some balance added to
this show by my presence that would not have been there at all without me.

Wish I'd have been there the day before ... Whoopi Goldberg was the guest,
would have loved to have met her!

the producers say it will probably air in early October.

Leslie

        . _____. .

At 6:43 AM -0400 9/12/96, Marc Fathauer wrote:
>>Most commonly found and most likely ingredient to cause "heroin like"
>effects is DXM dextromethorphan (decks-tro-meth-OR-fan), the active
>ingredient in Robotussin. Often, it is accompanied with other ingredients
>also found in cough medicines (pseudoephedrine, phenylpropanolamine,
>guaifenesin, acetaminophen and others). It seems that those unscrupulous
>producers take multi-symptom cough remedies, extract whatever they can, mix
>them with some stimulant (often just cross-tops of ephedrine like you can
>get at 7-11)  and pass these off as E.

	Yuk. DXM on it's own (so i hear) can be a pretty amazing
experience, having something like 4-5 different plateaus/stages depending
on dosage. For the amount that would fit into a capsule one probably
wouldn't get *that* messed up but it would depend on body weight, set,
setting, what you have in your stomach, etc.  Another big non-MDMA
ingredient is Ketamine (a cat tranquilizer) which has similar dissociative
properties as DXM does (albeit K requires lower dosages).

	With regard to the person who asked about "synthetic heroin" i
beleive there's a substance called MMTP or MTPT which fits this
description, though i'm not sure on the veracity of any info of it being
passed on as MDMA on a regular basis.

	Word has it that one can tell real MDMA by it's taste which is
'salty' and has a licorice kind of smell and taste to it (caused by the
saffrole which it's made from). So, lick before you buy. (Is that "Lickus
Emptor" instead of "Caveat Emptor" ? ;)

	And, of course, the only 100% safe thing is abstention and relying
on your own endogenous ecstasy which can be produced by the following
process:

	1 part hugs
	1 part techno
	1 part dancing like a maniac
	1 part temporarily turning off all rational thought

	put ingredients into a warehouse with other test subjects, turn up
the heat and swirl with a cosmic swizzle stick. :)

	peace,
		brad

> nonsense. For H to be orally active it would have to be a monster dose or so

   and is available, and no reasonable evidence to the contrary has been
   shown.

2) Herion can be orally active in reasonably low dosages. Morphine, and
   other opiates were routinely mixed to make cough medicines in the 19th
   century. They even have a word for the concoction, but it escapes me 
   at the moment.

         Reply to:   RE>Hello WORLD!

Well, since it doesnt look like we are going to see FGE's books, I decided to do some calculations on my own.

DISCLAIMER!!!!
I am not a promoter, have never thrown a party, have never been involved in throwing a party.  So I'm just doing some very generous estimates at how much it may cost for the following items:


$20,000 Space
$5,000 Security
20 DJ's at $500 each = $10,000
$20,000 Sound
$10,000 lighting
$10,000 crew
$500 water
$  5,000 for rental of Bouncy Castle
$1,000 Charity

For a Grand Total of = $81,500

7,000 people at $18 a pop = $126,000

$126,000 - $81,500 = 

$44,500 left over.

Are there any other unforseen costs that I am missing?  Permit costs?  Insurance?  anybody have an idea on how much that stuff costs?  Didnt Martin post a breakdown of his expenses a while back?  Could we compare FGE with The Gathering (as far as expenses are conserned)?  Anybody want to go back into the archives and repost Martins post.

-M

Starchild, You wrote:

I WOULD LIKE TO SET THE RECORD STRAIT!!

   Feel Good Entertainment, and Cool World are not in any sort of 
similar catagory as you so put it. I am not sure where your 
information, or should I say misinformation comes from, but I do want 
to correct you and tell you and everyone else that this is not true. 
All because you chose to group us this way does not make it everyones 
opinion. 
 Feel Good Entertainment, has in the past been involved in some aspects 
of Cool World parties, and we in no way posible way any regrets for our
participation in those parties, they were all incredibly wonderfull 
events and brought huge amounts of new people into the rave comunity.  
    This however does not change the fact that Feel Good Entertainmnet 
and Cool World Productions are Two compleatly seperate enteties, and 
only work together on project by project basis.  Feel Good 
Entertainmnet has always done its own thing. Our asosciation with 
Cool World, and Cool World association with us has become a lot 
stronger in public perception, then in actuality.  So from now on, 
please do not relate the two organizations in one breath.  
    We have always taken a lot of pride in every project we do, weather
it was a working with Cool World Productions, Or our own party, Or the 
Buzz-Line, or any of the club nights we produce, or any of the other 
promoters we work with.  But that does not change the fact That we are 
are own seperate group of individuals and are not directly asociated 
with any other group or promoter al because we work with them.   


>This doesn't change my opinion that I think it
>would be a good move on his part to open the books, and like I said, 
>that goes for anyone throwing a party, not just him.

    I would not touch this topic for anything.  All I am going to say 
is that you must be frigin nuts if you think anyone is going to 
disclose prices and finances to a forum of people they don't even know,
ON THE INTERNET...of all places.  Anyone not agreeing with your event 
or having a diferent opinion could just forward the post anywhere, 
including many goverment agencies.  You must be some sort of sheltered 
waco to think that there are only ravers on this list and that anything 
is safe here.  Puting any information on here is like giving it to 
everyone in the world.  I don't think that there is anyone out there 
that is clueless enough to put private financial information and 'open 
the books' on this forum, and if there are, well you realy need to get 
your head out of cyberspace, and get a grip on reality. 

If any one else has any questions, plese just call me at @ 415-593-3664
I would rather talk in person, my spelling is, as you can tell, 
absolutely terrible, and I will be glad to answer any aditional 
questions.

PLUR,  Ray Vonie,  F.G.E.

Subject: Media=Limb of Satan? (was LEEza Show Review)

(from Wayne's post)
>   This was not a platform for the guests to advocate their position. They
> did not get to speak freely. This was not a pulpit for guests to preach
> from. It was the host's pulpit, and they had an agenda.... It's a formula,
> it works, and that sells ad time. :-)
> 
[snip]
> 
> 	HOW ABOUT A NEW IDEA RE: THE PRESS. SUMMARILY IGNORE THEM. THEY
> *WILL* GO AWAY, OR AT THE VERY LEAST WE WON'T BECOME UNWILLING ACCOMPLICES
> IN HANGING OURSELVES AT THEIR GALLOWS.

right, so the mass-media are about hype and ratings and are probably
antithetical to and accurate coverage ...

now, i'm not saying there's necessarily any good reason to seek publicity
and popular recognition/understanding -

but, here's an idea - the bay area is full of local cable-casting
companies that by law have to provide free public cable access to
pretty much _anybody_ who asks for it - and so there are a ton of local
news, variety, and just general 'weird and cool stuff' shows being made
and broadcast on local cable.

if some people were genuinely interested in creating some good quality
positive press for the rave community, then i bet there are lots of local
cable shows that would be eager to come to a rave, interview ravers, dj's,
promoters, the whole thing.  probably all it would take is some phone
calls and free passes (like promoters don't paper the house already).

since these shows are semi-amateur and don't rely on advertiser revenue to
stay alive, you can bet there'd get a LOT more creative and editorial
control over the result, especially if help was given during the
editing and so forth.  it wouldn't be slick and polished, and it wouldn't
air on major network prime-time, but it might actually be truthful and
representative ...

just a thought.
matthew.

Subject: A Groovynifty Idea! :)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey guys!

For the past few months a gruvy little idea has been rattling around in my
brain, and I've finally gotten off my ass enough to look in to it and
propose it to you people.

Anybody here familiar with the Tactile Dome at the Exploratorium?  Those who
are have probably already figured out what I'm thinking! ;)

Anyway, for those who aren't familiar with it, the Tactile Dome is this big
ol' dome that is completely dark, no vision whatsoever.  You walk/crawl/etc
thru the passages built into this dome and do it entirely by touch.  The
dome is set up to be an entirely tactile experience, all kinds of cool
textures & things to play with, including small slides that send you into
vats of dry beans, walls with all kinds of weirdo things attached for you to
experience, things like that.  A few years ago I went, and it was fucking
awesome! :)  Now my idea here is to ideally get about 15-20 ravers together
and rent the Dome out!  This is how they work.  You call them ahead of time
to make a reservation, and as a group of at least 15 we'd get it all
entirely to ourselves to play with as a private party!  It's $12 per person,
and this includes admission to the main part of the Exploratorium, so we
could go early & check out the Exploratorium, and then at our scheduled time
go to the Dome for 1 hour & 15 minutes, which is the time they allow you in
there for.  Like I said I'd like to get at least 15 people, cuz if you have
under that, they let other groups in, and I thought it would be fun if we
rented it all to ourselves!  The Dome is closed till September 30 and opens
October 1, but ideally I wanted to do it sometime in October anyway, more
advance notice for you guys.  I would like to get some sort of a head count
as they want the money up front, so confirmations soon would be good.  The
weekend of October 19th is out for me due to other prior obligations, and
Tribal Future is going to be the weekend of October 12th (columbus day
weekend) but let me know what other weekends would be good/not good and we
can work with that.  

Any takers??  Come on, it'll be great fun!  15-20 happy ravers wandering
around a pitchblack dome relying purely on tactile sensation?  :):)  
Oh yeah:  not recommended for claustrophobic people, or people with injuries
of some sort.

I think that's about it, let me know what you all think, and I can get to
making us the reservation asap!


Love,
Shawna

            
          Do not go gentle into that good night!
         Rave! Rave into the dawning of the light!

On Wed, 11 Sep 1996, Tim McKnew wrote:

>         Please understand, this post is not meant with any malicious intent
> (note liberal use of :) 's). I simply wish to convey that I cannot think of
> a single good reason why information such as budgets NEED to remain secret,
> especially since they are budgets built on our $$$$.

	Well, think of smaller production companies who are not obtaining 
permits. If we requested that they open their books, it would put in 
place a document that might allow police to come knocking on your door 
and with all the crap about how it is not emissible in a court of law 
(because unless you get a lawyer who wants some money, you are playing 
Russian roulette with assuming you will get a judge who does not believe 
in cops acting in "good faith") that you threw a party without permits 
and you now have a hefty citation in your face.

	Maybe feel good has bribes on its finical sheet which they can 
not release, maybe they did business with some "legimate businessman" 
groups that will come looking for kneecaps when their payoffs are puton 
the web in the archive for some one investigating the group at the IRS to 
pull off using AltaVista or something... Maybe these things could be made 
into a special category called "Special Expenses" which could hide all 
the expenses that we cannot be informed of their sources, then the books 
could be opened no? Profits could be hidden from us in the "Special 
Expenses" category... But I suppose people will come ask about the 
Special Expenses if they are otrageous...

	Still do not feel like opening the books? Why is iot such a hard 
ship with these measures? Maybe you could come up with additional 
measures to keep things as was agreed upon with the people FGE decided to 
work with... Why is it such a hard ship to open the books? Was loads of 
money spent on decorations and cups and got lost in the process (like 
most parties?). Are there books to open?

dave

On Thu, 12 Sep 1996, Ross Wright wrote:

> 
> On Or About: 12 Sep 96 at 12:07, blkadder@value.net wrote:
> 
> > I haven't heard anyone object to them making a profit. What I, and some
> > others have objected to is the questionable use of the name of charity to
> > encourage people to come to their parties. And yes I will cast stones in
> 
> Questionable use of a charity's name?  Is the charity asking those 

No, questionable use of the *name of charity*, two different things.

> questions?  Or are they happy just to get the money?  Whatever the 
> sum?  If it's O.K. with the charity and if you are not calling it a 
> benefit (where EVERYTHING goes to the charity) I can see no problem 
> here.  

And I have posted two very clear statements from the promoters, one saying  
that this was a "partial benefit," the other saying "just think, your
partying will help the homeless this winter."  

> Even if they give 1 dollar to the charity, if that's cool with 
> the charity, then it should be cool with us.  Or maybe we should 
> question the charity?

Technically, you are correct. They said they were giving some money, they
gave some money. Ethically, however, without any evidence to the
contrary(exept "We won't tell you, but trust us"), I think it is entirely
improper to encourage people to come to your parties in part because
of your donations to charity, and to hype your largess when your largess
ain't so large. 

Ethics is a very complex subject, and open to debate. That is what is
occuring. However, I have heard nothing to change my view on this subject.
I do not accept someone being technically correct as by default also being
ethically correct. You also have to examine the past history of the
involved parties, if you want to come to a reasonably accurate determination 
of their motivation vs. their stated goals. Have fun with that one.....


                                        Black Adder

Dear Ravefriends,

	It occurs to me that all this is an excellent civics lesson:
After all, the government asks us to vote for higher taxes, in the name of
helping the poor, defending the country, maintaining the infrastructure,
etc., and we conveniently overlook the fact that most of the money is
wasted and does not actually go to the stated causes.  Of course the
corporations and other recipients of government welfare are happy to get
their equivalent of $1, so why shouldn't we be happy too?

My computer tells me that on Thu, 12 Sep 1996, Ross Wright shared:

> Questionable use of a charity's name?  Is the charity asking those 
> questions?  Or are they happy just to get the money?  Whatever the 
> sum?  If it's O.K. with the charity and if you are not calling it a 
> benefit (where EVERYTHING goes to the charity) I can see no problem 
> here.  Even if they give 1 dollar to the charity, if that's cool with 
> the charity, then it should be cool with us.  Or maybe we should 
> question the charity?

Subject: Re: LEEza Show Review 
In-reply-to: Your message of "Thu, 12 Sep 96 11:06:30 PDT."
             <v0300781dae5df6505ad7@[157.22.1.251]> 
Date: Thu, 12 Sep 96 14:35:50 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>Well, Leslie was definitely a island of relief in that ocean of
>diarrhea. She retorted to comments and questions with nothing but
>exellent examples of the positive aspects of raving. Too bad she
>wasn't given enough time to speak. :(
> ...
>I was sick to my stomach by the end of the show.

Like Wayne said, like others said, like I said -- told ya so! Y'all
forgot one thing. If you think what happened in the studio was 
sickening, wait till you see what ends up on the cutting room floor,
versus what gets aired. If Leslie did a halfway decent job of
explaining anything in a cogent and reasoned manner, you can be sure
it'll end up cut out. Expect a quick-cut pastiche of the most stupid
and ignorant antics of clowns & doofuses; they'll be sure to cast a bad
light on anybody that doesn't fit their theme ("Look at those crazy
stupid unchristian freaks!") -=- any intelligence and insight will be
chopped up, taken out of context, and generally misrepresented. That's
what TV talk shows are about.

Y'all should learn to be cynical like me. That way, you're often
pleasantly surprised when something turns out well, rather than
constantly disappointed that your unrealistic, idealistic
happy-happy-joy-joy expectations are rarely met. You see, cynicism is a
positive force for dealing with a fucked up world. :-)

PS: Leslie -- I hope you didn't sign any documents saying you wouldn't
sue the show for miquoting you or quoting you out of context. If they
really fuck with your statements (if you're (un)lucky to get any air
time at all), you could potentially sue for public defamation. I hope
you got paid at least.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Sep 12 15:58:51 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id PAA00960; Thu, 12 Sep 1996 15:58:51 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from mom.hooked.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with ESMTP id PAA00949; Thu, 12 Sep 1996 15:58:43 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from also.hooked.net (moonpup@also.hooked.net [206.80.6.45]) by mom.hooked.net (8.7.4/8.7.3) with ESMTP id PAA12330 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Thu, 12 Sep 1996 15:58:50 -0700 (PDT)
From: Milton Cecil <moonpup@hooked.net>
Received: (from moonpup@localhost) by also.hooked.net (8.7.3/8.7.3) id PAA00343; Thu, 12 Sep 1996 15:59:50 -0700 (PDT)
Date: Thu, 12 Sep 1996 15:59:50 -0700 (PDT)
Message-Id: <199609122259.PAA00343@also.hooked.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: random ramblings
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I suppose it has taken me much thought, to decide what to do, and why I
should suddenly decide to pack it all in and return to my place of birth. 
 
I have many reasons, some of which I'll share, some of which I wont share,
and some of which I don't even understand myself............ 
 
I will start by saying that after 20 years in Los Angeles, another 4 plus
in San Francisco, I'm just fed up with California. 
 
I'm fed up with people being so petty and trivial, over issues that don't
mean squat in the bigger picture of things, that it takes up so much space
on my computer.  
 
Now I am not comdeming anyone who is a member of SFRaves, but I can't
believe the back and forth nit picking over subjects that give me a
head-ache......coming from such a small segment of our community. 
 
Topics like..............you should do drugs/should'nt do drugs/ whats a
raver supposed to be or act like/ who makes money/ who can spell/ who
donates in the name of raving/ who doesn't / who is involved with who/ why
my justification is better than yours/ why your opinion is worthless/
etc.... 
 
 literally name calling and bull s**t like this turns my stomach. 
 
now in the uk people are so busy being creative and doing there own thing,
that nobody has the time to point fingers at others, no one has time to
talk shit about what so &so is  or isn't doing, nor do people have the time
to wallow in other peoples misery. 
 
I'm sorry, but watching this so called community go back and forth over
trivial issues and balderdash, has got me thinking......... who the f**k
wants to hang out in a place like that, when the options are open to go to
a place where people treat each other with a little more dignity and
respect. 
 
a place where conversation is more about meaningful dialog, and uplifting
subjects, not rabble about so & so this & so & so that. 
 
this is not to say we don't have meaningful dialog in SF, there is plenty
of happenin and cool vibes goin down, it's just gone underground.......I
thought we were the underground......... when did this shift happen, was it
while I was gone ? 
 
No, it's just that I saw a different perspective, and it opened my eyes as
to how shallow, narrow, and one dimentional we (sf scene/sfrave etc...) 
seem to have become........from time to time.... 
 
I hope to get blasted for saying such controversial subjects, & things so
openly to all of you at the same time, I hope to see 500 posts, replying,
saying I must be wrong, look at the bright side.....and that I'm full of
shit.....by all means prove me wrong. I want so bad to be wrong........ 
 
I really love the drum machine thread, this is the kind of positive vibe
and creativity that S.F. can offer........ well done to all those involved
in trying something new and refreshing......... you lead the way for all of
us...... 
 
I have other reasons that make me homesick for the uk, the festivals, the
historical aspect of the uk, food, the multitude of musical creativity, The
fact that being broke is O.K, because every one else is broke
too............I don't know , I just can't explain it in words, it's a
feeling I have when I'm there.......peaceful, like I belong, like I have
something to discover there........ 
 
So I will be leaving in about 2 months (actually 7 weeks)...... I hope to
party with as many of you as I can before I go....... 
 
please understand, that I am not using SFR as the excuse as to why I'm
going, it is just one small percentage of my reasoning......... I feel like
I landed in the wrong place..... 
 
I'm trying to enjoy the community, and look for the good side of things,
but I am having trouble seeing it......... as usual it probably has as much
to do with me as it does the way I percieve S.F.        but I'll tell you
this, the love and feeling I had 3-4 years ago, seems to have slipped away
with the sands of time.......... London gives me that feeling
now.............thus my desision to continue to follow my heart and
dreams..... 
                                                    
                                                                     
moonpup   415-337-6666

Given his present state of mind and course of action, Moonpup may have 
been too shy or modest to mention this after his recent posts , but 
he's spinning tonight (thursday) at the club funktion. He will be playing 
his stuff in the trip hop room , although I think he will be spinning a
somewhat wider style of music than just stricly trip hop.

 Here's the info on Funktion from the SFRaves calendar -

Funktion - house, dub w/DJs guest DJs weekly. free before 10pm
   9pm-2am, $5. Maritime Hall, 1st & Harrison, SF. 415.273.5308

 I called the number , and the other DJs tonight are ( in the main
room ) Tracy and Buck ( Buck being a DJ from since the early Toon
Town days ) , and Moonpup and Tom in the Dub/Trip Hop Room

 So, if you go tonight, say hello and/or hug Mr. Moonpup while he's
still in tha' States !

 Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com

Hi all,

My name is deeje, and I've been reading this mailing list for about a 
week now.  Yeah, there may be some trivial topics floating around, but I 
am encouraged by the sense of community here in No.Cal.  Way cool!

My brother raves down in SoCal and got me into it just a few weeks ago.  
I've lived in the bay area for about two years, but still haven't found a 
place to hang.  Looks like, with SFRaves, my search might be over.

Anyway, my bro is visiting this weekend, and we're hoping to meet you all 
there at Harmony.  So, if you see two guys just hangin' out at Harmony,

I think people take this list a little bit too seriously.  I'm not pointing out any one person, I'm just using the word 'people' in a general sense.

There's always talk of 'family' on this list.  And although I do feel close to a good number of you, and we are a family in a sense, it will never be the same 'closeness' I feel toward (Blood) family members.  This last weekend, my brother-in-law decided to end his life.  And it has made me really think about families and relationship with other people and communication with family members and being a better family member....it goes alot deeper, but I wont go into that.  

Anyways, my point being, take this list with a grain of salt. IMO,  Its entertainment.  It makes my fairly mundane testing job a little more intertaining.  Everybody on this list has VERY strong opinions.  And they'll fight to the death to make them fact.  its fun to watch.  way better than TV.

.........just MY random ramblings. 

I dont think I'll EVER unsubscribe to this list.  Its just way too much fun! :)

On Wed, 11 Sep 1996, Randy C Cone wrote:

> Hey folks!
> 
>  Get the fuck off of the backs of your rave promoters!!  NOW!! They 
> (sometimes we) put up with more shit, gamble so much and generally put 
> themselves on the line way more than any of you folks can ever imagine 
> unless you have done it yourselves. While comments and feedback are one 
> thing, the comments and criticism (on this thread) are sounding like 
> whiney spoiled brats who can not appreciate the hard work and anguish 
> promoters go through.

	Most of the people involved in this discussion are members of 
collectives that put on low cost raves. Whether this falls into your 
definition of "your rave promoters", I don't know. Many of the people 
involved are trying to break this whole division between promoter 
and party goer because it fosters a consumer feel to parties and that 
adds to a commerical vibe. These happen to be low cost parties, and many 
of them free parties in which we only hope that when something needs to 
be done, we can ask the people there to help. This used to happen a lot 
more - all the full moons with people jumping to help teardown and haul 
speakers up to the truck to head back to Berkeley marina. Granted, people 
are probably going to act a little differently at free parties because 
the exchange of money tends to put people immediately into consumer mode.

This is another reason why some of us examine motives behind throwing 
parties. If we are talking about community, what is that suppose to mean? 
That we are all working toward a common goal, not really. That we all have 
the same set of ethical values. Not the exact same, but hopefully a 
similair set. That we can all live under the same piece of sky? Probably. 
Commerical events that are there first and foremost to make a buck are 
businesses and to a certain extent, opposite of direction that some 
organizers are moving with their parties by keeping that party 
goer/promoter separation. The vibe of a party where you remove the party 
goer/promoter separation is inheriently different. If you look at parties 
as a source of income rather than a gathering of people, this discussion 
is most likely completely foreign to your conception of "raves".
 
So please, instead of driving party-er vs. organizer into everyone's head 
who has not had a chance to help out, let's just get shit done when it 
needs to be done... If you are looking for recongition for what you do 
besides that it helped a party go off, maybe you should look into 
devoting your time somewhere else to something that will bring this 
external recongition to you. If a good job is done, people will know it. 
Assuming otherwise also assumes that no one has the ability to look 
around and make their own decisions.

>  If you you think you can do a better job than PUT UP OR SHUT UP!!!

	I find this to be extremely rude. Some people around here do a
different and sometimes, in my opinion, better job, but that is something I
arrived at through my little tinted perceptions. Each person has a right
to ask questoins. Some questions are based on ignornant assumptions and
hopefully these ignornant assumptions will be exposed and the individual
in question will watch out for the same type of assumptions in the future,
but how else these assumptions going to be exposed if the questions are 
not asked?

Anyway, enough dribble. Hopefully everyone got something out this...

dave

Upon reading Moonpup's post I felt a surge of familiar feeling.  I was
reminded of the day that fell two weeks after I signed on to sfraves back
in Jan.  I had eargerly awaited the two week no-post zone and was anxious
to contribute to the  community that I had finally discovered.  A
community of intelligent, loving, liberal-minded, subversive people that I
thought I could instantly be a part of.  I felt accepted before I had
uttered a single word.  I posted. I believe I was commenting on something
Geoff White had said about the Martin/Gathering stuff.  And to my utter
disbelief, Jon Lee attacked me, all full of indignation and rage, with
his threat to "Put a piece of Lead pipe Up youR ass.".  I guess you could
say I became a bit disallusioned at that point.  I still harbor feelings
of anger towards him right now, and I loath that.  Since than I have
posted very little, and am right now very hesitant to do so.  But,

On Thu, 12 Sep 1996, Milton Cecil wrote:

> Topics like..............you should do drugs/should'nt do drugs/ whats a
> raver supposed to be or act like/ who makes money/ who can spell/ who
> donates in the name of raving/ who doesn't / who is involved with who/ why
> my justification is better than yours/ why your opinion is worthless/
> etc.... 
>  
>  literally name calling and bull s**t like this turns my stomach. 
>  
> I'm trying to enjoy the community, and look for the good side of things,
> but I am having trouble seeing it......... as usual it probably has as much
> to do with me as it does the way I percieve S.F.        but I'll tell you
> this, the love and feeling I had 3-4 years ago, seems to have slipped away
> with the sands of time..........
>                                                     
  This is how I've felt since that day in January.  I hate to see Moonpup
go, he is a positive vibe I can always count on. He offers so much to our
community, and to see him go for these reasons truly fills me with an
overwhelming feeling of despondency.

"I have of late, but wherefore I know not, lost all my mirth, foregone all
custom of exercises, and indeed it goes so heavily with my disposition,
that this goodly scene sfraves, seems to me a sterile promentary, this
most excellent canopy the rave, seems nothing more than a foul and
pestilant congregation of Jon Lee's.

				Krishna.

X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.3 PL11]
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>   I was
> reminded of the day that fell two weeks after I signed on to sfraves back
> in Jan.  I had eargerly awaited the two week no-post zone and was anxious
> to contribute to the  community that I had finally discovered.  A
> community of intelligent, loving, liberal-minded, subversive people that I
> thought I could instantly be a part of.  I felt accepted before I had
> uttered a single word.  I posted.
> [...]  And to my utter
> disbelief, *** attacked me, all full of indignation and rage,[...]
>  I guess you could
> say I became a bit disallusioned at that point.  I still harbor feelings
> of anger towards him right now, and I loath that.  Since than I have
> posted very little, and am right now very hesitant to do so. 

It is always sad when the actions of a few can affect the feelings of
so many.  Well not always.  Not every loud/incessant voice in the 
history of sfraves has been of the "negative" variety.  Unfortunately,
I think this list sometimes falls victim to the American cultural
characteristic of might-makes-right, where the louder, caustic,
persistantly critical voices are usually successful in crowding out
those of a more gentler and forgiving persuasion.  It's interesting to 
see how well folks in the Usenet group (yes Usenet) uk.music.rave get 
along.  They bring up the dreaded PLUR acronym all the time, and oddly,
no one feels the need to fly off the handle over this slogan that so
many here find oppressive.  And they actually seem to be able to go out
and have fun even if the party wasn't put together by their friends. 

But all here is not grim.
Once you've been on sfraves a while, things get quite
predictable and you tend to learn to accept that some of us are always
sharpening our knives, just waiting to make our point with the 2 or
3 issues that we have such selfrighteous bugs up our asses about.
These attempts at waking up the rest of the stupid ravers on the list
rile the few who haven't heard it before while everyone else yawns.

Anyway, it's just words.  Occasionally there's some useful info, but
none in this post, sorry.  So why am I writing this?  Because I have
work to do that I don't want to do and posting to sfraves is much
more entertaining.

ObRave: So what's this about Tribal Future happening on the weekend
of Oct. 12?  More info please!!!

Lee

lxfogel@pacbell.com  (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )  lee@hyperreal.com

Dear Wayne,

I expected "I told you so" from your previous posts, but it really matters
little to me.  Allow me to repeat if you will ... it is my fervent belief
that if you aren't willing to represent your true self and explain and
defend your position, frankly as far as I -- that is me personally, nothing
collective about this -- am concerned, you are patently accepting whatever
anyone says about you.  And you deserve what you get, you have handed your
power to someone you don't even trust.

You want to summarily "ignore" the press?  Sorry, but I disagree 100% ...
if you don't feel confident enough about what you believe and who you are
to explain it IN PUBLIC to people who don't agree with you,then I think
there's something wrong.  It takes courage and conviction, but it has to be
done.

They can say anything they want to about me and the life I choose, but at
least give me a chance to express myself PERSONALLY about what affects me.
That is what happened on this show.  I can't control their venue, I can't
control what other people say, but I CAN control what I say about myself
and what I belive.

Nothing I said reflected negatively on our community, which was important
to me, and I know that, had I not been there, there would have been a large
gap in representing the positive sides of who we are.

And I have very strong feelings about both raving and parenting.

Wanna close your eyes and wish it goes away?  Sorry, don't look for me next
to you. And don't ask me to join you in assuming that all media is the
devil incarnate.  I believe that Leeza and her crew did the best that they
could coming from the perspective where they started.  If we don't show
them the truth, one step at a time, who will?

I've written a letter to the show expressing my concerns about the
potential harm and misinformation they may show -- and possibly it will
have some effect in their editing process.  Again, I can do my best, and
that's all I can do.  But at least I'm willing to stick my neck out and
try.  It's too important to me not to.

Leslie

p.s.  It would have been nice to talk to you personally when I saw you this
weekend about your perspectives rather than getting a copy of your email
the night before I left.  I would have welcomed your personal input.

>  This all kinda sounds like what I was saying earlier in the week, wasn'it
>it?! Well, huh. I was branded a cynic and nearly tarred and feathered and
>sent packing for pointing out these issues. But nooo! "Leeza is different."
>
>  Different my ass. [thanks to Neils for this particular inspiration :-)]
>
>  So now that we've offered up (we, the collective rave community, not
>specifically Leslie) our people, what did we get?
>
>  Screwed.
>

>IN HANGING OURSELVES AT THEIR GALLOWS.

Subject: Re: LEEza Show Review

             <3238b952.72116091@mail.campus.mci.net> 
Date: Thu, 12 Sep 96 19:24:14 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> Are you under some strange impression that TV "talk shows" are in some
> way Christian? :-) :-)
> 
> The fundamentalists have always been in the forefront of those
> attacking the TV talk shows....
> 
> As someone else mentioned, the ideology of TV talk shows is the most
> holy rating point and the sacred advertiser dollar.

Although the fundamentalist "leaders" may publicly attack the shows,
privately, they know they disseminate a lesson that no amount of 
preaching or pulpit-pounding could produce. Meanwhile, back at the
ranch, the flock is sheepishly sitting at home judging the fools that
go on these shows, trying to reconcile the warnings against degeneracy
made by their pastors with the exemplars of degeneracy they are seeing
on their screens. They can then recoil in mock shock, bleating "there
oughtta be a law..."

Since many talk show viewers rarely get out of the house (or rarely go
beyond the confines of the local mini-mall) to experience life first
hand, the shocking revelations cast onto their TV screens constitutes
enough information by which they can come to the conclusions that their
pastors (or the christian coalition, or dole, or clinton) are right.
This happens even if they don't know/experience any "degenerates" like
they've seen on the talk show, even though the percentage of people
acting in this way is a nearly invisible minority. The "manufactured
controversy" inflates the public perception of danger from such
enemies-from-the-inside, and the next thing you know, there are many
uncessesary laws being passed intruding on people's private, moral
choices.

Combined with a prohibition-like conservative moral agenda being set
for this country, the talk-shows are springboards of "manufactured
controversy" used to rally the masses to support a moral agenda that
they would otherwise not care about. That's why I would never do them
the favor of letting them USE me to twist the truth and manufacture a 
political message for the masses.

That's my opinion. You may disagree.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - the Uncle Noah TV Show - the best
       in Techno and House music. 3-5am, KDVS 90.3fm (Davis)
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * Saturday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. and
       Monkeywrench KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

Danger Will robinson Danger!!!!!!!

There's heroin out there!!!

I was just watching one of these old "lost in Space" shows

Anyways-

I read an artical in THE VALLEY TIMES (a paper for the
Pleasanton/Dubin/Livermore area) about Heroin supply in this country.  I
couldn't find the artical at hope but I'm sure I can dig it up some where.

Well it said that the majority of the heroin coming into the US is now
through the columbian drug lords rather than from china.  Because of this
more heroin is coming into the country for cheaper prices and at a higher
purity.  (0% some times as compared to 70% - 80%  (I have to check the
artical to see if these are correct numbers).

Because of this high purity heroin is now being snorted and smoked rather
than injected and is either now or soon to be as great a drug threat as
Coke.  These colubia lords are pushing the H on to their customes and
inturn they are pushing more heroin.  Result: a rise in heroin supply on
the streets that can be taken ORALLY because of the purity.

IF there is more access to H at a cheaper price, with a higher purity it
COULD BE POSSIBLE for H to be in E.  BUT!!!!!!  As Black Adder and others
have stressed before::::  Don't believe the hype until you have SOLID
proof/ tests.


Be care full out there and when I get a hold of the actuall artcal I'll
post it to those who are intereste.

Thanks for the bandwith



    Austin Woffington                    Exodus@earthlink.com

On Thu, 12 Sep 1996, Austin Woffington wrote:

> IF there is more access to H at a cheaper price, with a higher purity it
> COULD BE POSSIBLE for H to be in E.  BUT!!!!!!  As Black Adder and others
> have stressed before::::  Don't believe the hype until you have SOLID
> proof/ tests.

for the love of god, please end this thread now. next thing you know well 
be getting panicked e-mail that someone is lacing the "good times" virus 
with heroin. i'm giving up, since it's clear, facts or no, that some 
people really *want* to believe dealers are spiking e with smack. 

i'll end with one last tidbit though. okay, you're a shyster selling e. you 
want to cut it. you want people to still think it's e (at least enough 
that they won't come after you). you want to do it cheap. you have two 
choices.

choice a is a cheap, easily found amphetamine that, while not providing all 
the "benefits" of e, will keep people guessing for a little while, and 
probably dupe the inexperienced.

choice b is an opiate that bears no similarity to e, and (if it even 
worked) would pretty much negate the tiny amount of e you, oh so 
generously, left in the cap. noone is fooled and certainly noone is 
coming back for anything but an argument.

you do the math...

jmar. adios.

Sorry to make a private response public, but if I'm willing to defend what
I believe on tv against people who I can expect to be skeptical about my
sincerity and credibility explaining something I believe in strongly, then
I damn better be willing to do it in a forum like this ...

I have no regrets about doing the Leeza Show. If it has a positive effect n
just a few people, it's worth it to me.  This will be my last post
"defending" myself on SFRaves, though, I don't see it as appropriate or
productive.  Personal conversations are welcome, though, I'll be at
Harmony, and have lots of interesting stories to tell.


To Niels,

I don't think i've ever met you, have I?  Maybe we should meet some day and
you can judge me on personal experience, and decide for yourself if I meet
your obviously high expectations of a someone who might do "a halfway
decent job of explaining anything in a cogent and reasoned manner"....

Sorry, but I find your cynical attitude sad, and I hope it isn't contagious
... since I haven't managed to catch it from the people I've had to
encounter in my 42 years so far, and I'd hate to see it extend to the other
positive-spirited friends I value so much.

And sorry again, but I think cynicism is more of the cause of what's
"fucked up" in this world, rather than some sort of protection against the
bad people you think are all out to ruin you.  Cynicism is based on a core
belief that the cynic is smarter and more "right" than anyone else, and it
usually incorporates an unhealthy dose of intellectual arrogance.  I find
that viewpoint incompatible with a fundamental respect for other people.
Yep, I'm idealistic, but I'm one of the most realistic people you'll ever
meet.  And I'm also rarely disappointed by expecting the best from people
or situations.

Your post may be further evidence that we see the world as a reflection of
ourselves; if it really represents what you're about, that's too bad.  I
like my mirror better because it has a smile and an open mind reflected in
it.

Leslie

p.s.  I'm not particularly litigious, so I hope you're not disappointed if
I choose not to sue them. Lucky for you, because as far as public
defamation... hmm.  And no, I didn't get paid... not that I couldn't use
the money, but it seems to me that if people get paid to go on talk shows,
it might make someone question their credibility and their motivations,
don't you think?  Then you would have called me not only a "fool" and
possibly a "clown and doofus" (or was that not me you were including in
your sweeping generalizations?) but also an opportunistic sellout.

------- Forwarded Message

Date: Tue, 10 Sep 1996
From: prashkin@wavenet.com (Peter Rashkin)
Subject: My vacation, the Headwaters Redwood Forest, and Neoliberalism

Jerry Brown is talking about the Headwaters Redwood Forest all this week.
Please try to listen: Pacifica Radio. In LA, KPFK, 90.7, 4 pm; in San
Francisco/Oakland, KPFA, 4 pm; in Houston, at 6, I think; in New York at 7.

The Headwaters is a remote redwood forest in Northern California. It is the
largest privately held redwood forest in California (in other words, in the
world...this giant, tallest of all trees, grows only in coastal northern
California and southern Oregon). For a long time it was owned by the
Georgia-Pacific Lumber Co., which trashed its share of the forest but
wasn't in a hurry to harvest every scrap of old growth timber. Plus there is
a strong and old environmental movement in the area. Then it was bought by
speculators; financed by junk bonds, with the intent to turn a quick profit.
I'm not sure, but I'll bet this happened during the "business-friendly"
Reagan administration.

Environmentalists, logging interest, the government...they've been going
back and forth in the courts and the legislature. I can't remember the
details. Now the owner (someone owns this priceless bit of earth spirit)
says that he's going to cut the trees to pay off his junk bonds if the
government doesn't come up with the bucks instead.  Next week, I think.
Jerry says the president can stop it and will if the people put pressure on
him. I hope so.

AS IT HAPPENS, I was just through Northern California last week, and I
stopped and walked a bit in one of the publicly owned redwood groves, so I
have a very fresh memory of the coast redwoods. If you've never been there,
I can't convey the magnificence of this environment. You stand in the middle
of these 300-foot towering wise old trees, some of them more than 2000 years
old. In a way it's like being in a great cathedral, or at Teotihuacan...it's
old, it's sacred, it's grand. But it's also alive, so it's a temple to life.

Not only the redwoods, but old growth forests everywhere are threatened
because they are the most profitable to harvest and now, finally, we have
the technology to really mow them down.

That a forest like this should be chopped up to turn a quick profit is
horrific. It's like Cortes melting down the intricate Aztec jewelry to make
gold bars. It's a crime against humanity. And I'm afraid it is an excellent
example of what is being done the world over under the banner of neoliberalism.

(Not everyone knows the term "neoliberalism." It is quite easy to explain;
it's merely the modern term for colonialism. Besides the term, some of the
methods and institutions and much of the rhetoric have changed, at least
superficially. And the pirates, who rule not only the seas but all the
intervening lands, wear suits and ties instead of bandanas and eye patches.)

(In the US the new generation of pirates is even returning to the old
practice of exploiting people...they've built prison construction and
operation into a fine, profitable growth industry providing good jobs to
thousands of people and stimulating local economies.)

I fear this is what is happening everywhere, all over the world, all at
once...nothing has value if it doesn't generate money. A standing old growth
forest has almost no value...cut down it is worth a fortune. These ancient
communities of living beings have grown here together in a slow, slow dance.
To walk in a forest like this is unforgettable; the experience is
intellectual, scientific, emotional, spiritual, sensual. You can't spend an
hour in the midst of this energy and come out unchanged. "In wildness is the
preservation of the world," Thoreau wrote. How much is preservation valued
on the market?

The old forest is not the only great ancient irreplaceable community that is
endangered because it is not profitable while it lives. The ancient
communities of man no longer have value, in the neoliberal sense of the
word. Ancient tribal and village ways of life are endangered because they
don't produce a sufficient return. Only factory farms and factory people
make any sense at all in the neoliberal value system. Isn't this the story
of Chiapas, where the Maya Indians have been pushed further and further onto
the physical margins, the least favorable lands, as each niche in turn
became exploitable? And now, thanks to the wonders and irrefutable logic of
the market, it is ALL exploitable!

As long as cash flow is the criterion for setting policy, the old growth is
doomed, and maybe the soul of man is, too. That's why the Zapatista call for
an international movement for humanity and against neoliberalism is so
important to us here, everywhere.

IF YOU CAN, try to join Jerry Brown in Oakland Friday afternoon, or over the
weekend in Northern California. Or in Houston, where another protest is
happening. Or do one in your forest or city hall. Or fax Clinton. Or send
him email at <president@whitehouse.gov>, if you think it will do any good
(Jerry seems to).

But if the cutting isn't stopped, please be aware of what we are
losing--perhaps as early as next week--and be sad for our poor planet and
all its poor souls.
========================================================
Peter Rashkin <prashkin@wavenet.com>

SPANISH DAGGER PUBLICATIONS
     PO Box 3008
     Long Beach, CA 90803

Read THE DAGGER on line at
               http://www.wavenet.com/~prashkin/

------- End of Forwarded Message

Leslie says: 
> And sorry again, but I think cynicism is more of the cause of what's
> "fucked up" in this world, rather than some sort of protection against the
> bad people you think are all out to ruin you.  Cynicism is based on a core
> belief that the cynic is smarter and more "right" than anyone else, and it
> usually incorporates an unhealthy dose of intellectual arrogance.

I used to be much more of a cynic than anyone I have ever encountered.
My cynicism new no bounds, and it grew until I became cynical of my
own cynicism.  I think that was around the time I discovering raving.

Most cynics choose their targets carefully so that they have a very
good chance of being "right".  It's just as much a feel-good self-hug
approach to the world as the starry-eyed optimist's.  Too bad it can
be such a downer for everyone else.

Most ravers I know are aware that the world is pretty fucked up.  But 
rather than whine about all the bad, they prefer to focus and support 
what seems to be good.  This seems more constructive to me, and not too 
hard because there really is a lot of "good" out there (including 
"hope").  Each of us is free to choose our illusion.  YMMV

A year ago, I would never have though that I would ever be at a rave
in a Christian church, dancing to DJ Tracy in the early morning next 
to a 70 year old Bishop who was also "getting it".  Cynicism nearly
prevented me from experiencing this.  Lately, I've decided that
there are some things that are more important than being right.

Just another pretentious sermon from 

Lee

lxfogel@pacbell.com  (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )  lee@hyperreal.com

I fully agree with this statement:

| The wonderful thing about the asshole who owns the pertinent portion of
| the Headwaters Forest is that he's "liquidating" the asset to help pay for
| a failed savings and loan he operated in Texas.   
| 
| Now he's holding the forest ransom for more than it's worth commercially.
| 
| This guy is truly a scumbag.  Some people truly deserve to be shot.

There's an article in the SF Chron "Bay Area" section from today on
this scumbag-like action on the part of Charles Hurwitz of Texas. This
suit-wearing-scumbag who is described as a "master negotiator with
nerves of steel" is threatening to start harvesting these 2000 year old
trees unless the government drops the $ 1.6 Billion debt he owes for
the failure of his Texas S&L.

The sad thing is that this kind of morality-free no-holds-barred
deal-making is pervasive in financial/business/banking circles. Once
you enter into this realm, they claim you have to be "cold and steely
and uncaring" in order to "do business." I disagree.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==

Subject: NRR: Headwaters Forest - Buy it or steal it?
In-Reply-To: <199609131457.HAA19275@netcom22.netcom.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.95.960913105835.11658B-100000@pluto>
