Precedence: bulk


Dear Rave Friends,

	The story of the Headwaters Forest is not quite so one-sided as
the below post might lead one to believe.  The company that owns it has
had the legal right to log for some time, in fact the land is zoned by the
government to be used exclusively as timber land (makes you glad for 
wonderful things like zoning laws, eh? <--sarcasm).
	My understanding is that they've deliberately put off logging in
the hopes that a solution can be reached that does not force them to take
a bath on their investment.  They have indicated a willingness and
flexibility to be compensated in the form of other government-owned land
elsewhere in exchange for Headwaters, but officials have resisted this,
perhaps in the hopes that they will be allowed to legally steal Headwaters
from its owners as the environmentalist lobby, Jerry Brown, and Neils are
urging.
	I don't know how much the Headwaters forest is valued at in the
marketplace, but I'd be willing to chip in a few dollars to buy it.  If
everyone so eager to violate the Bill of Rights (which protects us against
government taking our property without just compensation) would just pony
up some cash themselves, I'm sure the lumber interests would sell to us,
since that's what they've been trying to negotiate for years now.
  
My computer tells me that on Fri, 13 Sep 1996, Niels P. Mayer shared:

> 
> ------- Forwarded Message
> 
> Date: Tue, 10 Sep 1996
> From: prashkin@wavenet.com (Peter Rashkin)
> Subject: My vacation, the Headwaters Redwood Forest, and Neoliberalism
> 
> Jerry Brown is talking about the Headwaters Redwood Forest all this week.
> Please try to listen: Pacifica Radio. In LA, KPFK, 90.7, 4 pm; in San
> Francisco/Oakland, KPFA, 4 pm; in Houston, at 6, I think; in New York at 7.
> 
> The Headwaters is a remote redwood forest in Northern California. It is the
> largest privately held redwood forest in California (in other words, in the
> world...this giant, tallest of all trees, grows only in coastal northern
> California and southern Oregon). For a long time it was owned by the
> Georgia-Pacific Lumber Co., which trashed its share of the forest but
> wasn't in a hurry to harvest every scrap of old growth timber. Plus there is
> a strong and old environmental movement in the area. Then it was bought by
> speculators; financed by junk bonds, with the intent to turn a quick profit.
> I'm not sure, but I'll bet this happened during the "business-friendly"
> Reagan administration.
> 
> Environmentalists, logging interest, the government...they've been going
> back and forth in the courts and the legislature. I can't remember the
> details. Now the owner (someone owns this priceless bit of earth spirit)
> says that he's going to cut the trees to pay off his junk bonds if the
> government doesn't come up with the bucks instead.  Next week, I think.
> Jerry says the president can stop it and will if the people put pressure on
> him. I hope so.
> 
> AS IT HAPPENS, I was just through Northern California last week, and I
> stopped and walked a bit in one of the publicly owned redwood groves, so I
> have a very fresh memory of the coast redwoods. If you've never been there,
> I can't convey the magnificence of this environment. You stand in the middle
> of these 300-foot towering wise old trees, some of them more than 2000 years
> old. In a way it's like being in a great cathedral, or at Teotihuacan...it's
> old, it's sacred, it's grand. But it's also alive, so it's a temple to life.
> 
> Not only the redwoods, but old growth forests everywhere are threatened
> because they are the most profitable to harvest and now, finally, we have
> the technology to really mow them down.
> 
> That a forest like this should be chopped up to turn a quick profit is
> horrific. It's like Cortes melting down the intricate Aztec jewelry to make
> gold bars. It's a crime against humanity. And I'm afraid it is an excellent
> example of what is being done the world over under the banner of neoliberalism.
> 
> (Not everyone knows the term "neoliberalism." It is quite easy to explain;
> it's merely the modern term for colonialism. Besides the term, some of the
> methods and institutions and much of the rhetoric have changed, at least
> superficially. And the pirates, who rule not only the seas but all the
> intervening lands, wear suits and ties instead of bandanas and eye patches.)
> 
> (In the US the new generation of pirates is even returning to the old
> practice of exploiting people...they've built prison construction and
> operation into a fine, profitable growth industry providing good jobs to
> thousands of people and stimulating local economies.)
> 
> I fear this is what is happening everywhere, all over the world, all at
> once...nothing has value if it doesn't generate money. A standing old growth
> forest has almost no value...cut down it is worth a fortune. These ancient
> communities of living beings have grown here together in a slow, slow dance.
> To walk in a forest like this is unforgettable; the experience is
> intellectual, scientific, emotional, spiritual, sensual. You can't spend an
> hour in the midst of this energy and come out unchanged. "In wildness is the
> preservation of the world," Thoreau wrote. How much is preservation valued
> on the market?
> 
> The old forest is not the only great ancient irreplaceable community that is
> endangered because it is not profitable while it lives. The ancient
> communities of man no longer have value, in the neoliberal sense of the
> word. Ancient tribal and village ways of life are endangered because they
> don't produce a sufficient return. Only factory farms and factory people
> make any sense at all in the neoliberal value system. Isn't this the story
> of Chiapas, where the Maya Indians have been pushed further and further onto
> the physical margins, the least favorable lands, as each niche in turn
> became exploitable? And now, thanks to the wonders and irrefutable logic of
> the market, it is ALL exploitable!
> 
> As long as cash flow is the criterion for setting policy, the old growth is
> doomed, and maybe the soul of man is, too. That's why the Zapatista call for
> an international movement for humanity and against neoliberalism is so
> important to us here, everywhere.
> 
> IF YOU CAN, try to join Jerry Brown in Oakland Friday afternoon, or over the
> weekend in Northern California. Or in Houston, where another protest is
> happening. Or do one in your forest or city hall. Or fax Clinton. Or send
> him email at <president@whitehouse.gov>, if you think it will do any good
> (Jerry seems to).
> 
> But if the cutting isn't stopped, please be aware of what we are
> losing--perhaps as early as next week--and be sad for our poor planet and
> all its poor souls.
> ========================================================
> Peter Rashkin <prashkin@wavenet.com>
> 
> SPANISH DAGGER PUBLICATIONS
>      PO Box 3008
>      Long Beach, CA 90803
> 
> Read THE DAGGER on line at
>                http://www.wavenet.com/~prashkin/
> 
> ------- End of Forwarded Message
> 
>

On Thu, 12 Sep 1996, The Laffin Happy Trip Farmer wrote:

> Hey guys!
> 
> For the past few months a gruvy little idea has been rattling around in my
> brain, and I've finally gotten off my ass enough to look in to it and
> propose it to you people.
> 
> Anybody here familiar with the Tactile Dome at the Exploratorium?  Those who
> are have probably already figured out what I'm thinking! ;)
> 
> Anyway, for those who aren't familiar with it, the Tactile Dome is this big
> ol' dome that is completely dark, no vision whatsoever.  You walk/crawl/etc
> thru the passages built into this dome and do it entirely by touch.  The
> dome is set up to be an entirely tactile experience, all kinds of cool
> textures & things to play with, including small slides that send you into
> vats of dry beans, walls with all kinds of weirdo things attached for you to
> experience, things like that.  A few years ago I went, and it was fucking
> awesome! :)  Now my idea here is to ideally get about 15-20 ravers together
> and rent the Dome out!  This is how they work.  You call them ahead of time
> to make a reservation, and as a group of at least 15 we'd get it all
> entirely to ourselves to play with as a private party!  It's $12 per person,
> and this includes admission to the main part of the Exploratorium, so we
> could go early & check out the Exploratorium, and then at our scheduled time
> go to the Dome for 1 hour & 15 minutes, which is the time they allow you in
> there for.  Like I said I'd like to get at least 15 people, cuz if you have
> under that, they let other groups in, and I thought it would be fun if we
> rented it all to ourselves!  The Dome is closed till September 30 and opens
> October 1, but ideally I wanted to do it sometime in October anyway, more
> advance notice for you guys.  I would like to get some sort of a head count
> as they want the money up front, so confirmations soon would be good.  The
> weekend of October 19th is out for me due to other prior obligations, and
> Tribal Future is going to be the weekend of October 12th (columbus day
> weekend) but let me know what other weekends would be good/not good and we
> can work with that.  
> 
> Any takers??  Come on, it'll be great fun!  15-20 happy ravers wandering
> around a pitchblack dome relying purely on tactile sensation?  :):)  
> Oh yeah:  not recommended for claustrophobic people, or people with injuries
> of some sort.
> 
> I think that's about it, let me know what you all think, and I can get to
> making us the reservation asap!
> 
> 
> Love,
> Shawna
> 
>

>          Rave! Rave into the dawning of the light!

Starchild -- there are multiple viewpoints on this subject. I am willing
to accept yours as long as you're willing to consider that you may
not have all the information at hand (i'll admit the same).  The issues
here go way beyond your statement here:
| everyone so eager to violate the Bill of Rights (which protects us against
| government taking our property without just compensation) would just pony
| up some cash themselves, I'm sure the lumber interests would sell to us,
| since that's what they've been trying to negotiate for years now.

The government did not take the first step here. Rather, Hurwitz  faced
with paying a 1.5 BILLION DOLLAR (note, that's a lot of money) debt
back to the government for his investment/management fuckups that the
government bailed him out of via FDIC payments to his savings and loan
customers. He then said "hmmm... i think i'll up the ante here and
claim I'll mow down an old growth forest if the government forces me to
repay my debts -- that'll put the government in a compromising position
between "green" voters/constituents and their desire to get
recompensated for my debts." 

The problem is that Hurwitz wants to charge far more than this land is
worth because he is in deep doo doo debt-wise. He's basically saying
the only way he'll sell is if the govt cancels out his debt entirely.
Otherwise he won't sell the land, just mow the trees and sell them,
which is actually more profitable than the value of the land.

This is especially egregious because he CRIMINALLY FUCKED UP by
investing his S&L customer's money in junk bonds and happened to get
this property as part of some other leveraged-with-funny-money biz-deal
swindle. Now, he needs the extra cash to pay back the FDIC and bail
himself out of junk bond debt. Instead of taking responsibility for his
fuckups, he's now sticking it to the government and the people of the
US -- I'm sure he's saying "it's just business" but I think he should
be prosectuted as an extortionist now, and should have been thrown in
jail long ago and had all his property confiscated to repay his debts.
But that kind of treatment is only reserved for drug dealers or
"dead-beat dads" -- if you're a wealthy businessman swindling retirees
out of their life-savings, then you're rewarded w/ a government
bail-out and a pardon by Jeb Bush (George Bush's son).

Please note this message posted to another private list that I received
(and am forwarding w/o attribution). There is a "right to life" issue
going on here that goes way beyond profits.

--------------------

Yeah, I've been following this issue for some years now.  I wrote a letter
to Cal. Dept. of Forestry & US Forest Service in 1990.  My understanding is
as follows (probably missing details) - Hurwitz bought out a fairly
decently-run family business called Pacific Lumber.  Not that they were
disciples of sustainability, but they understood the economically sound
concept of replenishing the resource.  And now he has defaulted on junk
bonds, and also calls the shots for the company.

Now the technology is available to mow like never before.  And this ransom
of priceless wilderness is no less than a mortal crime against humanity and
the earth.  I do not know of a more vile individual living or dead than this
ruthless "businessman."

It was a pleasure to read the description of the old growth forest mystique.
These forests are characterized by a surprisingly open understory - a
magical park with massive diameter trees towering above sparsely-scattered
big-leaved shady plants.  It cannot be replicated without ~1,000 years of
ecological succession.  More precious than gold.  Worth fighting to the
death for.

--------------------

     Neils... I've never met you, but I heard you loud and clear...
     
     Sensational talk shows do suck... they weren't always like that... but 
     then they saw the rating the born and bred in the USA morality 
     hotheads get.  It's what America wants.  Leeza does seem a little 
     mellower than most (don't really know, but I haven't heard about her 
     getting her nose broken lately)... maybe she was a lesser of several 
     evils call.
     
     But could we take a deep breath here?
     
     I'm sick of the 'Cyber paranoid' bulls&#t, and maybe it would be 
     refreshing to see someone who isn't dressed like a speed fed clubber 
     who happens to be a young male 18-24 backing up our scene in front of 
     a lens to a public who couldn't ever really understand.
     
     The typical media presentation of raving might be cruel, puritan, or 
     what have you... the amazing thing about raving is how many faces it's 
     capable of presenting.  The only exposure I think we should be bashing 
     (verbally) are f^@kups like the drug dealer from Miami who stepped 
     forward and said that raves are cool because you can sell mass drugs.  
     That's what will make it worse.  Not much else can by the way...
     
     Historically, there are some personalities that have been able to make 
     a statement that shot right by the editors, and right into the hearts 
     and minds of some people that needed to hear it.  We can hope that 
     Leslie made it past the force fields.
     
     For too long, the geniuses have lurked in the corners prophesizing 
     media fueled doom, while the f^@kups talk right into the camera.  
     Looks like we got somebody who knows what they're talking about for a 
     change acting as a spokesperson (albeit for only a few choice 
     seconds), and you're so ready to bash the f^@k out of her effort to 
     shine some light on something that has brought us ALL this much joy, 
     adventure, and fascination.
     
     Before you rush to the reply feature to bang my skull against a rock 
     until I realize how insightful you are, please find out how good/bad 
     it really is.  I'll wait for the show to air if you will.
     
     Raving is nothing.  It's about as hard to quantify as love or the 
     difference between a polite kiss and a loving kiss.  When laws were 
     passed to limit the playing of repetitive 4/4 music in Britan, artists 
     started coming out with Drum and Bass and use of different breaks, and 
     other modifications that allowed the scene to flourish past that.  
     It's being together.  Sometimes it's a BBQ.  It's not always at night. 
      It's not always in a warehouse.  The people aren't always my cup of 
     tea.  Sometimes it's about driving Crunchman's car through the 
     mountains for 3 hours looking for a party that might not exist.  
     Sometimes the music sucks.  Sometimes it's 20 people and sometimes 
     it's 20,000.  It's about spontaneous community, dancing, loving, 
     sharing and a positive sense that if I smile at you, you will 
     understand.
     
     I respect what Leslie did.  Maybe it will go off and maybe it won't.  
     It's better than not saying anything and letting them determine their 
     own reality.
     
     What would you say if you were in front of the camera Neils and were 
     asked for something positive to say, without censors, to America at 
     large?  To the sleeping, to the blind, to the arrogant, to the cruel, 
     to the greedy...
     
     It might not be that big a deal.  It's nice going to a place were 
     people are a little nicer for a change.  I like to dance, and be 
     freakish.  I'd hate to see it fall apart.
     
     I'm glad we're trying.
     AndyW

Subject: Re: LEEza Show Review 
Author:  "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com> at smtplink-acs
Date:    9/12/96 7:33 PM


> Are you under some strange impression that TV "talk shows" are in some 
> way Christian? :-) :-)
> 
> The fundamentalists have always been in the forefront of those 
> attacking the TV talk shows....
> 
> As someone else mentioned, the ideology of TV talk shows is the most 
> holy rating point and the sacred advertiser dollar.
     
Although the fundamentalist "leaders" may publicly attack the shows, 
privately, they know they disseminate a lesson that no amount of 
preaching or pulpit-pounding could produce. Meanwhile, back at the 
ranch, the flock is sheepishly sitting at home judging the fools that 
go on these shows, trying to reconcile the warnings against degeneracy 
made by their pastors with the exemplars of degeneracy they are seeing 
on their screens. They can then recoil in mock shock, bleating "there 
oughtta be a law..."
     
Since many talk show viewers rarely get out of the house (or rarely go 
beyond the confines of the local mini-mall) to experience life first 
hand, the shocking revelations cast onto their TV screens constitutes 
enough information by which they can come to the conclusions that their 
pastors (or the christian coalition, or dole, or clinton) are right. 
This happens even if they don't know/experience any "degenerates" like 
they've seen on the talk show, even though the percentage of people 
acting in this way is a nearly invisible minority. The "manufactured 
controversy" inflates the public perception of danger from such 
enemies-from-the-inside, and the next thing you know, there are many 
uncessesary laws being passed intruding on people's private, moral 
choices.
     
Combined with a prohibition-like conservative moral agenda being set 
for this country, the talk-shows are springboards of "manufactured 
controversy" used to rally the masses to support a moral agenda that 
they would otherwise not care about. That's why I would never do them 
the favor of letting them USE me to twist the truth and manufacture a 
political message for the masses.
     
That's my opinion. You may disagree.

Precedence: bulk

Dear. Mr. Pup,

Interesting dillema here.  I've been thinking a lot about the identities we
carry online, and it seems like for a lot of this, the anonyninymoty (!) of
being hidden behind a keyboard brings some interesting things out of our
psyches.   The ideal behind electronic communication is that it helps us
break down our prejudices.  I.E., we are experiencing a person for their
thoughts, without regard to skin color, sex, sexuality, attractiveness, or
whether or not we wear baggy jeans.
I think this aspect of it still works magnificiently, but along with it,
something a bit uglier has  risen.  Being a voice to 450 pairs of ears
isn't necessarily a humbling experience, if you're the sort of person who
likes to fly off the handle.  But then again, if you're the type who likes
to spread good vibes, then this is the perfect breeding ground.

I'm curious: was your experience with the British ravers online or at
parties?  I have a suspicion that for many of us, a louder, darker, side
comes out when we log-on...something that we don't normally express,
because we've been trained over the years about proper etiquette in public.
For example, I honestly can't remember the last time some told be to
bugger off! or shut the frick up! to my face...but I see it everyday
online.  Meet those same people at a party, start the same conversation,
and it will probably go a lot smoother.(I guess because it's harder to get
your fanny kicked through a computer if you say the wrong thing.)

Also, people with computers have the chance to go back and revise...seems
like this could lead to a manic passion to be as witty and sharp as
possible, leading to more arguments. And I think that we have a tendency to
take the written word more seriously than the spoken.  For example,
sometimes say to my buddies, "ah, fuck off!" and don't really mean it.  The
written word just sort of sits there on your screen and drills a hole in
your head, making it seem as if it's much more ominous than it really is.


What I think it boils down to, is that we're all savages inside (What I
mean is, we're wild, impulsive, instinctual, defensive, and on the prowl
for a fight.) Most of us have spent our lives learning to act civilized.
Now that we're online, we've sort of been set free from the laws of
etiquette, and it will probably take us some time to learn how to be
civilized again.  (I don't think this applies to *everyone*...some of us
are just cute and snuggly by nature, some of us are not.)

But we all have one thing in common...

Boom Boom Boom Boom     Boom Boom Boom Boom    Boom Boom Boom Boom

If we stick together we'll work it out.


Catch me next time,

b))merang fidget

p.s.  I remember dropping into a club on Oxford street in London in 1990,
seeing a bunch of crazy kids in striped shirts and glow sticks, thinking
"what the *hell* is going on here with these loopy kids?"  I only stayed
about 10 minutes...Two years later I went to my first party in the US, and
said to myself,   "Nowww I get it!"


Peter Sandifer
Customer Service

Date: Fri, 13 Sep 1996 13:41:47 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: leftjab@well.com (leftjab)
Subject: (NRR) Headwaters Forest
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

        Some alleged answers to Starchild's questions are on a front page
Chronicle article today.  But his characterizations are inaccurate as well,
not that I know the full picture either.

        The logging rights -- for salvage timber, which is supposed to mean
in this case only trees that have already fallen, not standing trees --
only kick in next Monday.  The company hasn't yet had the right to log it,
but people knew for a while when the deadline was and that the company
would probably not be denied this "right" by last minute judicial appeals.
The government is offering something like $200 million for the land, and
the owner wants $500 million and is enjoying the increased leverage
afforded by the imminent deadline.  He also was involved in an S&L scandal
which cost over $1 billion and has been interested in a new form of "debt
for nature" swap, or a swap of other federal land.  The federal government
has been avidly negotiating with these people, offering serious money.
There is no evidence they want to "steal" Headwaters away. The political
pressure from the environmentalists is counterbalanced by the conservative
forces in-state, who, after all, are in charge of the Governorship &
Assembly. To its partial credit, the Wilson administration is not siding
with the owners, and wants a deal in principle to be reached that will
prevent logging next week, and commit the parties to some form of
arbitration to determine the "value" of the land.  This "value" would be
derived from some approximation of the worth of the trees as forest
products.

        As old-growth areas dwindle, the value of the land increases
dramatically, due to the low supply of forest land for either logging or
beauty.  If the owners could get as much by not logging as logging, of
course they should not log.  This problem will only get worse.

        I'd love to debate how environmental laws hardly violate the Bill
of Rights, or how there should be plenty of legal ways to control logging
due to its external effects on the larger environment (stream pollution,
flooding run-off, etc. -- ask the people in Oregon about this years killer
floods in early February in clearcut areas).  But let's keep that off that
list.  However, it is true that the owner has the right not to have his
land taken by the government without compensation.

Starchild wrote:

>        The story of the Headwaters Forest is not quite so one-sided as
>the below post might lead one to believe.  The company that owns it has
>had the legal right to log for some time, in fact the land is zoned by the
>government to be used exclusively as timber land (makes you glad for
>wonderful things like zoning laws, eh? <--sarcasm).
>        My understanding is that they've deliberately put off logging in
>the hopes that a solution can be reached that does not force them to take
>a bath on their investment.  They have indicated a willingness and
>flexibility to be compensated in the form of other government-owned land
>elsewhere in exchange for Headwaters, but officials have resisted this,
>perhaps in the hopes that they will be allowed to legally steal Headwaters
>from its owners as the environmentalist lobby, Jerry Brown, and Neils are
>urging.
>        I don't know how much the Headwaters forest is valued at in the
>marketplace, but I'd be willing to chip in a few dollars to buy it.  If
>everyone so eager to violate the Bill of Rights (which protects us against
>government taking our property without just compensation) would just pony
>up some cash themselves, I'm sure the lumber interests would sell to us,
>since that's what they've been trying to negotiate for years now.
>

leftjab

At 11:08 AM -0400 9/13/96, Lee Fogel wrote:
>Leslie says:
>> And sorry again, but I think cynicism is more of the cause of what's
>> "fucked up" in this world, rather than some sort of protection against the
>> bad people you think are all out to ruin you.  Cynicism is based on a core
>> belief that the cynic is smarter and more "right" than anyone else, and it
>> usually incorporates an unhealthy dose of intellectual arrogance.
>
>I used to be much more of a cynic than anyone I have ever encountered.
>My cynicism new no bounds, and it grew until I became cynical of my
>own cynicism.  I think that was around the time I discovering raving.

	Word that could have come right out of my own mouth! :) I look back
at the "pre-rave" me now and i wonder where the connection is (there are
some, like i now listen to gabber instead of industrialdeathmetal but i'm
smiling as i bang my head ;).
	But doesn't this, what you've said (and what we've experienced)
point to something?  If there are now two people in the world that have
gone from cynicism to a "new" life then that means that there are two less
cynical people in the world.  Because of raving maybe, maybe because of a
little chemical help, & for me definitely from an admission that i was
"wrong" about things.
	I *wasn't* a realist, i was a pessimist.
	But these concepts, being relative like everything else, had to
have some "higher" or more "positive" mindset to bounce off of one's
regular mindset.  There's a saying (which i'm going to horribly paraphrase)
that says "in order for peace and joy to be realized, one must first know
that they exist."  If you're a cynic, a pessimist, you'd say that
light-grey is white and dark-grey is black, because you have a limited
scope of what's "real" because of the limiting conceptual boxes you put
onto experiences.  A "realist" can see a larger scope of the spectrum,
admitting the world is made up of opposites and doing a little
psychospiritual alchemy to transform the - into the + .
	I have much hope for the world in general, simply because i know
that i've turned out alright going from being perpetually negative to
someone who tries to aknowledge both ends of the spectrum, but only reflect
the most positive aspects into my words and behaviours and even thoughts.
And from my own experiences, i can extrapolate and wonder "how many other
people out there have had their lives and mindsets changed around because
of raving?" Evidently there's at least one other person out there! :)

>Most cynics choose their targets carefully so that they have a very
>good chance of being "right".  It's just as much a feel-good self-hug
>approach to the world as the starry-eyed optimist's.  Too bad it can
>be such a downer for everyone else.
	Most cynics are really insecure, i should know; i'm not only
president of Ex-Cynics Anonymous, i'm also a client ;)  Once you have a
grip on a sense of your REAL self, you don't find the need to tear other
people down.  Similarly, if you have a handle on the fact that "being
right" or getting pats on the back for your observations are ego-based and
arise out of these insecurities, then you don't feel bad about being
"wrong" because that's how you learn new things and stay dynamic (just like
the universe itself) :) And if anyone has a problem with what i just said
well...*sniff* *whine*...go take a flying leap at a rolling doughnut! ;)
	And yeah, i'd rather be around a "starry eyed e-head raver spouting
good intentions and platitudes" than someone constantly telling me "don't
bother, it ain't worth it, you'll fail, we're fucked, etc".  Evidently
other people feel similarly, explaining why i used to have so few friends!

>Most ravers I know are aware that the world is pretty fucked up.  But
>rather than whine about all the bad, they prefer to focus and support
>what seems to be good.  This seems more constructive to me, and not too
>hard because there really is a lot of "good" out there (including
>"hope").  Each of us is free to choose our illusion.  YMMV

	I agree, a glass of water is both half-full and half-empty
*simultaneously* so why not look at it as being half-full?
	I don't think it's a matter of denying anything, just a recognition
that there are always different and equally "true" perspectives to anything
and so why would you not choose to take on perspectives that are positive?
Even if it means that you're "wrong" or seem like a silly e-head
raver/hippy/whatnot, if it makes you feel good thinking good, why not?
Anything on the other end of the spectrum, imho, verges on masochism and i
don't know about y'all but i'm definitely closer to being a hedonist than a
masochist.

	Hmmm...then again, for some masochism is pleasurable. Oy! See,
multiplicity of perspectives in action! ;)

	The base of many of my attitudes is found in the idea of
"Morphogenetic Resonance" which is a theoretical approach to how species
communicate with each other with specific reference to how species evolve
new traits.  Theoretically, all members of a species communicate through a
gridwork of energy (which some may call the "collective
(un)consciousness"), if a critical mass of individuals in the species start
behaving in one way, that energy is put into the collective pool, and is
"downloaded" by the rest, affecting their behaviour.  So, theoretically, if
you have a large amount of positive-thinking people focussing on hope,
peace and joy, that will trickle down to the rest of the members of the
species.  Similarly, if you have a critical mass of people living a life of
pessimism and giving off "bad vibes" that will affect the way the rest of
the species in the system evolve.  Which one would you choose?  Would you
rather swim in the warm and fuzzy meme-pool or the one that looks like the
Exxon Valdez hit it?
	This is not only something that gives me "hope" for the future, but
also a sense of self-empowerment because if this theory is true, my own
thoughts have an impact on the rest of the collective and so there *is*
something that one person can do to change the world. :)

	peace
		brad


ps-->ulp! holy bandwidth. Maybe i should stick to just thinking about stuff
and save some electrons ;) Sorry! :)

On Fri, Sep 13, 1996 12:09:51 PM  at Customer Service wrote: 
 
 
Very well said, I have to agree totally.......moonpup 
 
 
>Dear. Mr. Pup, 
> 
>Interesting dillema here.  I've been thinking a lot about the identities
we 
>carry online, and it seems like for a lot of this, the anonyninymoty (!)
of 
>being hidden behind a keyboard brings some interesting things out of our 
>psyches.   The ideal behind electronic communication is that it helps us 
>break down our prejudices.  I.E., we are experiencing a person for their 
>thoughts, without regard to skin color, sex, sexuality, attractiveness, or

>whether or not we wear baggy jeans. 
>I think this aspect of it still works magnificiently, but along with it, 
>something a bit uglier has  risen.  Being a voice to 450 pairs of ears 
>isn't necessarily a humbling experience, if you're the sort of person who 
>likes to fly off the handle.  But then again, if you're the type who likes

>to spread good vibes, then this is the perfect breeding ground. 
> 
>I'm curious: was your experience with the British ravers online or at 
>parties?  I have a suspicion that for many of us, a louder, darker, side 
>comes out when we log-on...something that we don't normally express, 
>because we've been trained over the years about proper etiquette in
public. 
>For example, I honestly can't remember the last time some told be to 
>bugger off! or shut the frick up! to my face...but I see it everyday 
>online.  Meet those same people at a party, start the same conversation, 
>and it will probably go a lot smoother.(I guess because it's harder to get

>your fanny kicked through a computer if you say the wrong thing.) 
> 
>Also, people with computers have the chance to go back and revise...seems 
>like this could lead to a manic passion to be as witty and sharp as 
>possible, leading to more arguments. And I think that we have a tendency
to 
>take the written word more seriously than the spoken.  For example, 
>sometimes say to my buddies, "ah, fuck off!" and don't really mean it. 
The 
>written word just sort of sits there on your screen and drills a hole in 
>your head, making it seem as if it's much more ominous than it really is. 
> 
> 
>What I think it boils down to, is that we're all savages inside (What I 
>mean is, we're wild, impulsive, instinctual, defensive, and on the prowl 
>for a fight.) Most of us have spent our lives learning to act civilized. 
>Now that we're online, we've sort of been set free from the laws of 
>etiquette, and it will probably take us some time to learn how to be 
>civilized again.  (I don't think this applies to *everyone*...some of us 
>are just cute and snuggly by nature, some of us are not.) 
> 
>But we all have one thing in common... 
> 
>Boom Boom Boom Boom     Boom Boom Boom Boom    Boom Boom Boom Boom 
> 
>If we stick together we'll work it out. 
> 
> 
>Catch me next time, 
> 
>b))merang fidget 
> 
>p.s.  I remember dropping into a club on Oxford street in London in 1990, 
>seeing a bunch of crazy kids in striped shirts and glow sticks, thinking 
>"what the *hell* is going on here with these loopy kids?"  I only stayed 
>about 10 minutes...Two years later I went to my first party in the US, and

>said to myself,   "Nowww I get it!" 
> 
> 
>Peter Sandifer

>Most ravers I know are aware that the world is pretty fucked up.  But 
>rather than whine about all the bad, they prefer to focus and support 
>what seems to be good.

the extent that the world is fucked up, it is only because of
negativity (aka fear).

Thus, the only real long-term solution for our problems is being
positive.

Which, oddly enough, doesn't mean being idealistic.   There is nothing
contradictory between being positive and being realistic....

>[...]   There is nothing
> contradictory between being positive and being realistic....

There may even be a fundamental truth to this.

A metaphysical argument can be made that Existence itself is a positive
thing because afterall, the sum total of all existence is more than
nothing.   Time moves forward.  Reality (even illusion) is an assertion.

I exist therefore I am.
I exist therefore I am positive.
I am positive that I exist.

Even if "I" am not sure what it is, "something" is sure that there
*is* some kind of existance.  So it seems that positivity resides
at the basis of conceptualization.

Perhaps that is why the experience of harmony with the world, or
getting in touch with our true essence, (or whatever terminology for
divine realization suits you) tends to feel good.

Lee

lxfogel@pacbell.com  (    (   (  ( ((0)) )  )   )    )  lee@hyperreal.com

From: Wayne Correia <wayne@club.net>

Precedence: bulk

Leslie,

I am sorry you feel personally attacked. That is and was not my intent. My
intent that I attempted to convey was that it did not matter who or how
many went, our story would not be communicated through their editorial
grinder to the world. It saddens me to see you protecting them from this
criticism that they deserve. If they did a great job then why do even you
feel the need to write them a letter telling them that you weren't as happy
as you had hoped on the way things turned out? Again, I am not chiding you
for making a valiant effort in communicating our story. I myself try to
communicate to people outside our community how great we are on a daily
basis. But sometimes it doesn't work. And, after going to a *beautiful*
rave in the desert called Dune in So Cal (that HARD COPY did a totally
constructed and anti-rave baised story on) earlier this year, I have
learned to distrust mainstream media -- especially shows that have
sensationalization as their charter. That's why  I instinctively felt like
this may be one of those times.

We don't need traditional and in this case, pulp, media to convey our
story. They prove on a daily basis they are only there to use us. And 'us'
is not limited to the rave world. It's teenage unwed mothers, it's
transsexual hookers, it's feuding spouses and families, it's the problemed
of humanity. It's, unfortunately, basically any identifiable group that
appears on their shows.

So I have decided for my personal efforts, at least, that instead of
attempting to convert traditional media to viewing our world the way we do,
we should be spending all our energy of what we do best: Make music, spread
a positive vibe, throw parties, and be beautiful people wherever we go. If
that positive influence is always exhuded, people will follow, one at a
time.

And we already have partners for our movement in the media: They are the
countless underground record labels, they are mixtapes made by our friends.
They are URB, XLR8R, FIX, and others (in print) and great shows like FLUX
and now AMP on TV to move our message forward. They are Hyperreal and other
sites online decidated to a pure, honest communication. And best of all,
they are already on our side and free of anti-rave bias. Because of these
resources on our side, I find it very easy to summarily ignore the
mainstream media.

Sincerely,

wayne the happy raver

____________________________________________________________________________
 Wayne D. Correia            +1.415.826.6000            FAX +1.415.826.6100

>A public service announcement.....

> ---------- Forwarded message ----------
>Date: Thu, 12 Sep 1996 07:05:41 +0000
>From: Varna Ramaswamy <vramaswa@nature.snr.uvm.edu>
>To: SNR_GRADS <SNR_GRADS@trillium.uvm.edu>

>This was a message sent to me by my uncle that deals with your
>private information being easily accessible to the public.

>Varna
>
>FYI (sent to me by one of our attorneys):
>
>
>Your name, social security number, current address, previous
>addresses, mother's maiden name, birth date and other personal
>information are now available to anyone with a credit card through a
>new Lexis database called P-Trax.  As I am sure you are aware, this
>information could be used to commit credit card fraud or otherwise allow
>someone else to use your identity.
>
>You can have your name and information removed from this list by
>making a telephone request.  Call (800)543-6862, select option 4 and
>then option 3 ("all other questions") and tell the representative answering
>that you wish to remove your name from the P-trax database.  You may
>also send a fax to (513) 865-7360, or physical mail to LEXIS-NEXIS / P.O.
>Box 933 / Dayton, Ohio 45401-0933.  Sending physical mail to confirm
>your name has been removed is always a good idea.
>
>As word of the existence of this database has spread on the net,
>Lexis-Nexis has been inundated with calls, and has set up a special set
>of operators to handle the volume.  In addition, Andrew Bleh (rhymes
>with "Play") is a manager responsible for this product, and is the person
>to whom complaints about the service could be directed.  He can be
>reached at the above 800 number.  Ask for extension 3385.  According
>to Lexis, the manager responsible is Bill Fister at extension 1364.
>
>I called this morning and had my name removed.  The representative will
>need your name and social security number to remove you from the list.  I
>suggest that we inundate these people with requests to remove our info
>from the list and forward this e-mail to everyone we know.
>
>

it's seems for real - nexis has a special voice-mail selection set up to
tell you that they aren't accepting requests to be removed by phone any
longer - you have to fax or snail-mail.  in my view, that is complete
bullshit, and i plan to call back and give somebody an ear-full of my
opinion on this sort of big-brother crap as soon as i have some time to
kill listening to hold music.

sometimes (like right now) i wonder whether computers are a blessing or
some sort of uber-conspiracy ...
matthew.

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Fri, 13 Sep 1996 18:06:06 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: leftjab@well.com (leftjab)
Subject: The Media and Raving
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

first off, there are so many complex, intermingled concepts involved with
this subject that we should all admit there are no "right" answers.  Let me
say, though, that I'm glad Wayne clarified himself, because I didn't think
he was personally attacking Leslie, but it wasn't as clear as it could've
been that he wasn't chiding Leslie for being "an accomplice" to the
"hanging" of the rave scene, as he put it.

I believe sfraves members take a more critical and measured view towards
the media than most americans.  We seem more inclined to question the true
motives behind the media (money, advocacy rather than neutrality).  Perhaps
we knew this before we raved, but the media's treatment of raving has
certainly revealed this to us.  At the same time, the media hasn't really
dealt with raving that much yet, but it seems to be doing so more in recent
months.

I also believe that many of us have a spiritual view of raving, and despair
that too many people don't "get" it.  We want people to know that ravers
aren't sex-crazy, druggy teenagers -- we are everywhere, we are members of
your family, friends, co-workers, neighbors, etc.  But the media isn't
telling people this.

What to do?

I myself have sympathies with both sides of the "say something/avoid it
entirely" debate, and the third option of "do it yourself."

I unfortunately admit that because of worries about workplace response I
find it convenient to avoid it entirely (well, other than here, as this
list can be considered as do-it-yourself "media" of a sort, but I'm fairly
certain that no one with whom I work is on sfraves, just those crazy Xinet
folks down the hall ;) ).  This may, frankly, be an overcautious worry
because I was an "out" Deadhead, and the worries they might have over that
status are similar to those about raving.

Ultimately, it really doesn't matter what we do.  None of us can predict
how the authorities will treat raving in the future, and I'm not convinced
that increased media coverage will doom us.  I do worry that media coverage
will usually be very negative, and that the authorities could use that as
an excuse to crack down harder.  Maybe I'm selfishly focusing on us, but I
am confident that most of the possible futures over the next few years in
the sf area will include phat raves, as the authorities here aren't so
crazed as to make going after us a big priority (despite a few reminders of
their power).  The same can't be said of the rest of the nation.

Do we avoid the media, because they will never treat us fairly?  Do we do
it ourselves?  Do we accept the inevitability of the media, and do our best
to have them report the positivity raves have on our lives?

I have no problem with people with people who love raving saying so in the
media, and I hope when they do so they do it well.   And given the
realities of the talk show scene -- which Wayne predicted fairly well --
and the fact that there was probably going to be this shitty show given the
show's premise and realities, I hope that Leslie provided any contrary
view, not that a balanced result occurred.  I know her motives were good,
and I hope she convinced at least one parent not to freak about their
child's raving.

Yet, I agree that no news is good news.  I had rarely heard of raves in the
media before I started raving last December, and I am a print media junkie
(a little less so now that I'm on-line).  I want people who love raving to
continue to be able to do so.  I want new people to come to the scene
without many preconceptions from the media, accurate or inaccurate, and
those who love it to feel encouraged to become part of the scene and
contribute their energy.  some new people will be attracted by the negative
sex and drugs coverage, and by any positive spirituality coverage too.
There is a danger from any media coverage of the scene of increasing the
size artificially; we all know there must always be part of the scene that
is underground and fairly small, alongside massives.  I don't think the
underground is exclusive, but by remaining underground it makes it
difficult for authorities who might oppose raving to get a handle on it.
This is true to a certain extent even where we control the coverage.

Too much media coverage of any sort could hurt the rave scene.  But
Leslie's appearance didn't increase the amount of coverage -- the show
would have gone on without her.  [But will there be the follow-up interview
in one of the free weeklies, Leslie  ;) ]

You know raving when you feel it, and no media coverage will ever make
someone "get it."  Just being ourselves is the best response.

leftjab

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: leftjab@well.com (leftjab)
Subject: COOOOOOKIE!!!!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Tomorrow, the final Harmony, will also mark the final appearance of one of
my favorite t-shirts.

Once upon a time all these Deadheads used to crash in my living room for
local shows, and inevitably stuff would get left with me (and stuff would
disappear).  It seems now that the stuff that was left there was meant for
me to not be interested in until I started raving.

My friend Brett's ex-girlfriend Jody left this white t-shirt with the Dead
skull on the front (the "Steal Your Face"), with a big, blue, happy Cookie
Monster in the skull.  On the back, it says "Steal Your Cookies."  When I
found it a couple weeks after everyone was gone (Leslie can attest to my
Cancerian mess of an apartment), I told Brett (who had by then broken up
with Jody) and he said I should just keep it.  But soon after Jerry died,
and the shirt wasn't my style at the time (why, I don't know).

Cut to a few months later, after I had started raving, and seeing and
enjoying so much Sesame Street imagery, and feeling more connected to my
childhood.   When I saw Cookie on Nancy's backpack at some rave, I
remembered the shirt, dug it out of the depths of my closet, and debuted it
at the Beautiful People with the stuffed baby Muppets on the flyer . . .
it's had a gleam in its eye since.

Of course, Brett now wants the shirt back, despite my reminders that he
already said I could have it and that it wasn't his in the first place (he
now says he gave Jody the shirt).  When he was back here visiting in June I
had to make a deal with him -- he got the shirt for a month, and then I got
the shirt back until the final Harmony (which by then was announced).  He
did live up to his end of the deal, and said he understood why I loved the
shirt so much, so I feel like I should give it to him (sigh).

But until then I plan on wearing the hell out of the shirt this weekend!

leftjab, extremely psyched for tomorrow!

p.s. random thoughts on the same page of the chronicle today -- if we get a
few more this year in the atlantic, there will be a Hurricane Omar . . .
and Sesame Street just announced that it will soon be on Russian TV.

p.p.s.  if you bring any cookies to Harmony, be careful ;)

I have seen people get busted for playing on a not-that-loud
soundsystem at Marx Meadows in GG park.  If I remember right there's a
picture of that on the Headtravel CD.  On the other hand you could get
a permit to play music at Dolores park.  I was at a concert a while
back there and it went OK.  It's sunny and there's lots of open space.
Not sure about the specific legalities, though.

David

concert in the RE:search Zines book!

At 09:13 PM 9/13/96 GMT, Ken Stuart wrote:
>to the extent that the world is fucked up, it is only because of
>negativity (aka fear).

The ones responsible for most of the fucking-up rule by fear.
Dispell fear, and you take away their power.

Music and dance are excellent tools for dispelling fear,
and have been used for this since the dawn of time.
While we dance,  fear tends to fade away,
and we radiate the very antithesis of fear.

I have found color (as in lots of color) to be useful as well.
Trying to process more than six distinct bright colors at a time
often causes an overflow and shuts down the fear center
(or something like that).

I try to project a zone of anti-fear around myself all the time.

The Tie-Dyed Side of the Force

Hello everyone!!!

    This will be the last post from me about the three year 
anniversary, for I am going off into a distant land. (a land called 
stress!!!) Anyways, I just wanted to clear a few things up before the 
event...

    First, this event has taken almost a complete year to bring to 
life!! We started working on this project last year, right after the 2 
year ann. So there is nothing, absolutly nothing that would stop us 
from going through with it!! There have been a ton of recent problems 
thrown at the Harmony family, but we are not going to let them get in 
the way!! Most importantly, Omar. But on a lighter note there has been 
some specualtion that we were going to cancel the event because of rain 
this weekend... Well we don't care!! This event is going to happen rain 
or shine!!!! It doesn't matter if it snows!!! That's just one more 
attraction!!! Both of the rooms are indoors, with a outdoor field in 
between them. Plus, it doesn't look like it's going to rain anyways!! 

    The first bus will leave at around 1 or 2pm (depending on when it 
fills up). After the first bus takes off they will run continuously 
throughout the night. You can leave at anytime, but if you leave you 
can't get back on the bus to come back. The last bus will come back to 
the parking lot at noon on Sunday.

    We are so looking forward to this one!!! It's gonna be insane!!! 
Remember, feel free to bring your tents, toys, glow sticks, invisible 
friends (they get in for free), and any other crazy things. Please, if 
you plan on bringing water, it MUST be sealed!!!!! This is very 
important!!! If we find a bottle or container that is not sealed, it 
will not be permitted into the event. We will have plenty of water for 
sale at the event. (cheap too!) Also, please be extra, extra 
responcible for yourselves and your friends. Be aware of your 
surroundings, and always be safe!!! We want things to run as smooth as 
possible, but most of that is all up to you!!! We all love you, and 
can't wait til tomorrow!!! (408) 486-9591  (408) 450-3044

Peace,

Harmony

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

hello all-

for work related reasons (i have to sing on early sunday morning)  i will
not be able to physically join you all at harmony.  but, with a little
help, i can be there in spirit:

i need for someone to take my place in the chill room, wandering around
aimlessly with a water bottle, giving water to people who look like they
need it.  i've fallen into that function at raves for about the last year,
and i would love it if someone was able to do that for me.

i'm not worried about my hugging capacity being replaced, for there are
others who givve hugs like i do.

so, i hope ya'll have a great time, and send me some of your positive
vibes.  i'll be sending positive vibes from up here as i sit and practice
my music for sunday.


love to you all-

matt

From: Karen Hardie <pounce@vcn.bc.ca>
Subject: Raving and the media again :)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9609141058.A15268-0100000@opus.vcn.bc.ca>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I didn't catch the Leeza show sady, but from the posts i've read, it 
seems obvious that the media has their own views about how they are going 
to "promote" the rave scene to their viewing public.  Telling the masses 
that all this is nothing to worry about is just not good television, and 
so they make sure to skew their reports/interviews to suit the view they 
want to project.  I'm sure Leslie did an admirable job of speaking up for 
the "responsible" rave scene, but the viewers will remember the evil 
drugs and wild sex, because that's nicely sensationaist.

We have had our own share of difficulties here with raves in the news etc.
especially after Summer Love.  The Province newspaper made us all out to
be a bunch of subversive types who want to undermine "normal" society with
our drugs and sneaky way of life.  Although the "slang term dictionary" 
they provided was amusing (did you know that ambient is any soothing
electronic music regrdless of bpm?) i was offended by the rest of the
articles.  They haven't seen fit to print any of my replies, however ... 

Reasonable representation is gonna be an uphill battle whether we like it 
or not, IMHO.

pounce
----------------------------
You know, there are many people in the country today who, through no
fault of their own, are sane.  Some of them were born sane.  Some of
them became sane later in their lives.  It is up to people like you
and me who are out of our tiny little minds to try and help these
people overcome their sanity.
                                           -- Monty Python

hello all-

i'm posting this for a friend, annon (that's dannon, like the yogurt,
without the d!).  she has an extra ticket to sell to some worthy soul, so
give her a call.

415-759-9649

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Sep 14 23:43:39 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id XAA12013; Sat, 14 Sep 1996 23:43:39 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from Zool.AirTouch.COM by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with SMTP id XAA12007; Sat, 14 Sep 1996 23:43:33 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from nit.AirTouch.COM by Zool.AirTouch.COM (SMI-8.6/SMI-SVR4)
	id XAA12732; Sat, 14 Sep 1996 23:43:28 -0700

	id AA25818; Sat, 14 Sep 96 23:43:26 PDT
From: eric@nit.AirTouch.COM (Eric Pederson)
Message-Id: <9609150643.AA25818@nit.AirTouch.COM>
Subject: nyc trip report
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (SF Ravers List)
Date: Sat, 14 Sep 1996 23:43:25 -0700 (PDT)
Cc: pauld@nit.AirTouch.COM (Paul Duey), neil@nit.AirTouch.COM (Neil Palmer),
        timb@nit.AirTouch.COM (Tim Beauchamp),

Precedence: bulk

dear sfravers:

i recently got back from vacation in NYC.  i promised a few people a trip
report when i got back so here it is...

i flew into JFK from washington national.  i had planned to rent a car for
the first week so that i could make it to some outside-of-nyc places
(new jersey and the hamptons) and to help out my friend jacob who
i was staying with in brooklyn.  the last time i saw my friend he had just
moved to nyc after going to school in SF for a year for photography.
now he is doing freelance photog in nyc and has turned into quite
the club kid.  in fact he had us on the guest list for the tunnel
that weekend.  the tunnel is this massive club in chelsea that
features junior vasquez as a resident doing these amazing 8 hour hard house
sets.  anyway, when we got to the tunnel, it had been shut down
by the city for 'creating a nuisance'.  the cops had bought drugs
there a number of times and they implicated the owner of the club in
the sales.  both the tunnel and the limelight are now shut down
indefinitely.  it sucked cause i had always wanted to check out
the limelight.  never fear in nyc though, something is happening.  it
just so happened that sasha and john digweed were playing at a club around
the corner called twilo.  what the heck.  we went to twilo and had a
swell time.  twilo is in the same location as the old sound factory NYC
and it has a main floor about as big as the one at 1015.  the music was
excellente and we ended up staying till 8 the next morning.  i went
to twilo a couple more times while i was in nyc, and i'd generally
rate it 'thumbs up'.  big sound, plenty of fresh air (needed in
muggy sweaty nyc), and people in the mood to get off their ass & jam.
it is mostly straight on friday and mostly gay on saturday.

during the week we went bar-hopping to some of the zillions of bars
they have there.  nyc is lounge city.  most of the nightlife is
dedicated to providing places for people to kick back, drink and
chat, preferrably in a super-tony atmosphere.  even the dance clubs have
lots and lots of chill type space.  another difference is that most dance clubs
are 18 and over, so the crowd and the vibe is different.  club kids are
everywhere, and ravers are few and far between.  the drugs of choice are
different from SF too.  in NYC the favorites are pizza (j/k), cocaine,
e and ketamine.  other things (eg. green bud) are very hard to come by,
even via club kids :).  prices at clubs were always inflated, with $5 for a
water and $7 for a drink pretty standard.  admission was usually $20/$25 for
dance clubs.  ins-and-outs were non-existent, though you could usually get a
good laugh out of the door staff by asking about it.

we did make it to new jersey, but not to the hamptons (or coney island).
in NJ obed fernandez (from the bpm list) has a web site called
internet dance radio where you can listen to dj sets.  i went with 
a friend who is a dj in nyc to record a set at obed's studio/web site.
while i was there i got to play with the new pioneer dj cd players and the
new pioneer mixer.  both the cd players and the mixer are the shit!
big improvement over the denon-style cd players.  i am saving to get one in 97.

the next weekend i went to robots, formerly home of save the robots,
in the east village.  when i first got there around 4am, there was a big
crowd trying to get in.  it was one of those roped-off-door, no real 'line',
kissy-kissy, beautiful people thing to get in so i went to twilo instead.
i did end up going back to robots at around 8am and there was no crowd outside.
it has a loungy upstairs part and a tiny, dark, loud basement
and they were playing hard house (what else).  by then the crowd
was small (though fierce) downstairs but eventually it petered out around 10am.
i would like to go to robots again when it is packed.  it shows promise.

the next day i returned my car and got a hotel room/shoebox in tribeca.
(btw - driving/parking in NYC is not as bad as people make it out
to be.  mainly because not very many people have cars.  SF is way
worse for parking and boston still takes the crown for chaos).
during the next week i did some sightseeing and the usual barhopping thing.
i got a chance to meet eve from vrave and we went to the metropolitan museum.
if you only visit one museum in nyc, visit this one.  be prepared to
spend a whole day.  other museums that i recommend are Musem of Modern
Art and the International Center for Photography.

if you are visiting NYC be sure to check out the invaluable weekly
magazine "Time Out" for things to do.  it covers everything from
art to clubs to theatre to films.  it's mindblowing how much
stuff is going on in the city every day.  be prepared to be bummed that there
is just not enough time in the day/week to do everything you want to.

my friends neil & jenny flew out from SF to join us for the weekend and we
went to the palladium which was hosting a wigstock benefit party.  wigstock
96 had been planned for that weekend but fell through due to typical
city hall bullshit.  the palladium is another huge club, this time in
the village.  it was converted out of an old theater.  there is
a main dance floor and one small one upstairs.  there's lots of bleacher
type seating in between for the lounging contingent.  going in they made us
empty our pockets before giving us a thorough pat-down.  pretty intense.
it turns out the palladium is owned by the same guy who owns the tunnel and
the limelight and they are now 'getting tough' on drugs coming into
the club.  another time we went they were actually making people
take off their shoes and feeling their socks.  whoa!  i didn't 
experience that kind of shit at any other clubs while i was there.
the others were no search, no carding, no nothing, just give us your $20.
anyway, the music and the energy level on the wigstock night was
incredible.  at 8am the dance floor was still packed.  it was wierd
because there was no sunlight coming into the club at all.  it was
that way at all the after hours places i went to.  really makes it
easy to just lose track of time. 

the next week i explored tribeca, soho and the village(s).  nyc is by far the
most fashion conscious place i've ever been.  everyone is dressed to
impress, even if they are just slacking.  brian d. would love it! :)
one day we went used clothes shopping (at domsey in brooklyn.
recommended).  i bought a couple outfits so i could do a reasonable nyc club
kid impersonation.  nothing better than funky polyester prints and gold pants!!
in soho there are tons of art galleries, boutiques, clothing stores
and models.  soho also has the cybercafe which is an internet-cafe
type place, probably the best one that i found in manhattan.  the
stations are $5/hour at most places and they have web, telnet, etc.
cybercafe had the fastest connection (T1) and the best setup by far.
i also went record shopping.  there are too too many dj stores
in NYC.  two that i would recommend are satellite in soho (nice staff, ravey
selection of music) and vinyl mania in the village.  you could spend
a week just record shopping in manhattan but i limited myself to 10 12"s
(including, ironically, the garth 12"). i didn't find any places
like amoeba where the prices are reasonable for used records.
at one point i stopped in liquid sky in soho, a 'rave culture' type store
(like ameba/housewares).  they have a small selection of 12"s.
the east village is the most like san francisco.  fairly laid back
and fairly young.. the scene kindof reminds me of the mission.
the west village is more sohoish, but a little bit more gay and a lot
more touristy.

the CMJ (a college radio conference) was in town that week
and there were lots of bands playing.  on one night there was an
orbital/goldie/+ show at the roxy and the cardigans (swedish fluffy pop band)
at the roseland.  my friend just happened to be a big cardigans
fan so we went there (free tickets helped convince me).  of course
now i have major regrets. :)

the last weekend we had our hopes up that the tunnel would reopen
but it didn't.  we also heard a rumor that all the names on the tunnel's
guest list are now in FBI files!!  damn!  my friend paul flew out from SF in
route to boston.  we hooked up with some club kids (free e's for everyone!)
and went to the roxy, a fairly large club in chelsea.  big hair was everywhere,
beefy boys cruising like flies and cheese pop house (complete with
live wailing diva) on the sound system.  we left to witness shoe removal
at the palladium ,'sorry, you're not on the list' at robots and finally 
vinyl, a cool club in tribeca where our club kids were on the guest list.
vinyl had one medium sized main dance floor and a muddy sound system, 
but it also had a very cool, urban mix of people boogieing away.
the music was house and it was funky and hard.
we wanted to stick around for the next morning's 'body and soul'
with francios k but we were too tired and had to drive to boston that
day so we left around 8am.

in summary i can't wait for next summer and another trip to nyc.  i feel
like i just scratched the surface.  i also gained a new appreciation for
san francisco.  SF is just so 'nice'.  NYC is really in your face.
on one hand it's an artist's paradise.  so much is centered on art
and it really effects the culture.  on the other hand there is
no equivalent to the endup! :) you know how the cliche goes:
it's a nice place to visit but i wouldn't want to live there - unless i
had a trust fund!!

-e

On Sat, 14 Sep 1996, Kristofer Ananda Carrison wrote:

> Jeeeezuss.  I can't believe haw much cynicism and negativity Leslie has
> had to deal with as a result of the Leeza show.  
> 
> What Leslie went through up on that stage, in the name of all that's good
> and meaningful about raving, was extreemly difficult, both brave and
> noble, and she did a fabulous job.  I was very proud of her, and I think
> all of you cynics out there should be too.

I think that if you go back and re-read the messages, you will find that
most of the people are not criticizing Leslie personally. I am happy to
see that she is doing what she thinks is right. I do not however feel that
most mainstream media, and especially pulp media(Hard Copy, the 10
million+ sensationalistic daytime talk shows, et al.) are going give
anywhere neat a balanced or accurate representation of what "raving" is
all about. And given responses of people that attended, it would seem that
the "SLeeza"(thanks Wayne) show is no different than the rest. And
unfortunately, this was to be expected. To say that it wasn't flys in the
face of what the genre of daytime talk shows produce. 

How many people do you think have gone on those shows, thinking that they
were going to get a chance to share their views on a subject, only to be
used as a good, ol' fashion Roman spectacle?

                                           Black Adder
                                   
P.S. The above is not a critisim of Leslie. ;-)
