---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Sun, 15 Sep 1996 08:57:57 -0700
From: "Gregory T. Samson" <gts@oz.net>
To: nw-raves@hyperreal.com
Subject: NRR: a little story about Love

hope you like this as much as i did...

--
Blueberries and Chocolate (my love anecdote)

You know, Love came up to me one fine day and Love said, "Don't be afraid,
I'm only going to hurt you."  I giggled when Love said that to me because
it reminded me of a _Dragnet_ TV show when the pervert tried to lure a
little child into his car.  But after I giggled, Love got mad and yelled "I
mean it!  Come on over here so I can hurt you good and plenty!"  After
that, I didn't giggle anymore.  I wondered why on earth Love would go
around saying things like that.  I thought, "What a terrible way to attract
clients."  Why would anyone ever go an' say hello to Love if it was going
to say things like that?

So I hemmed and I hawwed and I steered right clear away from Love.

That was fine, for a time, until this morning.

There was a knock on my door and it woke me up.  I went to the door and who
should I find there but good ol' Love.  And Love looked so damn lonely when
it came up close like that.  I felt sorry for Love, and invited it in for
coffee with Blueberries and Chocolate, which I happen to know is one of
Love's very favorite breakfasts.  We sat and chatted cordially for a while.
Really, it was quite pleasant.  After a lull in the conversation, Love
said, "Please dearest, can I hurt you now?"  I had to laugh.  It somehow
seemed so sweet.  I said, "Yeah Love, you can hurt me now."

So Love hurt me and Love hurt me good and plenty.  And when Love was all
done hurting me, Love said, "See?  I told you not to be afraid."  Then Love
laughed, jumped up into the Blueberry dish and turned itself into a
Blueberry.

Ate all them blueberries, an' one of 'em was Love.

-by Inga Muscio; taken from the Valentine's Day 1994 _Stranger_

--
Gregory T. Samson, MD - Dr. Evil Microwizard
"this isn't music.  this is just noise!"





From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Sep 15 18:54:29 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id SAA11793; Sun, 15 Sep 1996 18:54:29 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from umr.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with ESMTP id SAA11785; Sun, 15 Sep 1996 18:54:25 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from ee.umr.edu (ee.umr.edu [131.151.100.20]) via SMTP by hermes.cc.umr.edu (8.7.5/R.4.17) id UAA05262; Sun, 15 Sep 1996 20:53:49 -0500 (CDT)
Received: by ee.umr.edu (SMI-8.6/SMI-SVR4-kaw-30-jun-94)
	id UAA06529; Sun, 15 Sep 1996 20:53:47 -0500
From: rkumar@ee.umr.edu (Roger Kumar)
Message-Id: <199609160153.UAA06529@ee.umr.edu>
Subject: Re: nyc trip report (cmj)
To: eric@nit.AirTouch.COM (Eric Pederson)
Date: Sun, 15 Sep 1996 20:53:41 -0500 (CDT)
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <9609150643.AA25818@nit.AirTouch.COM> from "Eric Pederson" at Sep 14, 96 11:43:25 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL25]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

i'm still recovering from my trip to nyc, so i thought i'd post my report as 
well. We arrived at Lagardia on Wednesday, Sept 4 with my radio station picking
up the cost for airline tickets. being rather silly people, we took a but, not
the subway, to our hotel, the Radisson Empire, at lincoln center (also paid for
by the radio station). We dropped off our stuff and headed over to register
to the CMJ Music Marathon confrence (confrence fees also picked up by the 
radio station). The College Music Journal Music Marathon, for those who don't
know, is an annual confrence in NYC, all about "college music". In reality, 
this turns out to mostly a bunch of people from record labels schmoozing with
radio station music directors to try to get them to play their stuff. But its
a whole lot more than that...its also about 1000 bands and 3000 radio/college
kids converging in manhatten for a week-long megaBuzzparty.

After checking out a chineeze restaruant and some record labels, i called up
john speakman, a nyc-raver. he invited my over to his place for a party that
his housemate, Mattie White (mattie of vrave) from novamute records was 
throwing along with Want Ads. One of the girls from Nerdy Girl came and played
accoustic guitar. Plenty of vegan burgers, tofu dogs, beer, and soda and a 
stearo were all set up on mattie's and john's apartment's roof, with a great
view of the manhatten skyline and stuff. A bunch of cmj people were there, and
i met some jungle dj's and Tye Comer, the rpm guy of cmj. Also met Alice 
Chang of KALX. Anyway, most everyone left, and mattie, john, tye, some jungle
dj's and a few more people hung out at the apartment, and about midnight we
treked down to a party thrown by Astelwerks, React Records, and Deconstruction
at a place called the Den of Thevies. There was an open bar and everyone was
ordering fancy drinks, courtesy of the record labels. Ardo Bender and some
Astelwerks dj's were there, and since i was with tye, we schmoozed with some
label people. The bar sucked, but they had some nice projection panels. But
even that got old and we headed a couple blocks down to a party thrown by
Jungle Sky records and Koncrete Jungle called I love NY Jungle. DAMN, this
party was the BOMB! DJ Soul Slinger, MC TC Islam, and a bunch of great jungle
dj's ripped it up until about 4:30. There was a cool back room with live 
ambience and some chill dj's as well. Two floors, free water on both floors,
and no club/bar type people that were at the Astelwerks/React/Deconstruction 
party. Quite a few cmj people were there too. hollie from WMWM was there,
plus Kurt and Kiren, who I met at mattie's party (from KSCY maybe?), + Dara
(azzreal(sp?) of vrave). For being in a club, this was a sweet party, with
enough drum and bass to make anyone a convert. Even though i'm not much
of a jungle person, i couldn't help thinking i love ny jungle, i love ny 
jungle, I LOVE NEW YORK JUNGLE when it was over. Dara and I shared a cab 
back to the hotel. (oh yeah, i ment astrelwerks, not astelwerks up there,
and dara is from ohio. i have no backspace)

Thursday morning i headed back to lincoln center, and sat in on some panel
that sucked. hooked up with mike, one of the guys i came with, and lisa of
vision threat records and went off to buy records and eat. We went down to
the village and hit Subterranean records first, but i didn't buy anything.
Next stop was VinylMania, and i bought a rad acid jazz record. This place
had more house records than i ever ever wanted to see, so we headed to
Sonic Groove, and I went insane. Bought lots of detroit stuff and a little
trance. Frankie Bones was working behing the counter and checked me out.
We went to bleaker bob's and some other places, all of which i forget the
names of. we grabbed some food and headed back to lincoln center, where
I hooked up with mattie and kurt and we rounded up a lot of people
(Hollie, Melanie, Jeff, Kiren) and went to Kurt's room at the Paramount
for a little fun. The Paramount was totally totally rad, with wierd mirrors
and lighting everywhere. Mattie put dinner on his expence account, and then
we headed down to the Roxy for the most incredible show...:

We got to the roxy and got in free (everything was free for cmj people).
Alothough this was a club, it was HUGE and had cool intelligent lighting
and free water. Dj Shadow was on for a while, and then Money Mark came on
for a live performance. OHMYGOD!! he started out his first song by holding
a little amp to a microphone and moving it around to cause funky feedback.
Then he had a second mike in his hand and was moving it around to trigger
a moog MG-1!!!! it was pretty strange :). He started playing another song
by holding a little casio keyboard to the mike, but it didn't work out so 
he trashed the keyboard rocknroll-style. Next, he played "Insects are
all around us" (my favorite money mark song) and i melted. After Money Mark,
Goldie came on, and dropped some nice drum and bass. this was more jungle 
than i'd taken in a while. Someone told me that Bjork was there (because
she's maried to Goldie?!?) and that tricky was there but tricky and goldie
got in a fight and tricky left. Anyway, a little bit later Rabbit in the 
Moon came on and did some live stuff that wasn't too impressive, butthen 
again, i had my heart set on...ORBITAL!!! Orbital's set was a little 
similar to the show at the Filmore, and they stopped between songs. There
were a ton of clueless people and orbital did a bunch of remixes of club
songs and rave anthems that drove em all wild. and they did an encore
and the played the satan remix. and the kicked ass again. couldn't believe
this was all free.

After orbital, another jungle dj came on and dara and i went to the empire
diner for some food (free by scam). Friday, i went to some panels with hollie.
First was the jazz panel. and it sucked, a bunch of commerical jazz people.
we went to an "artists and their addictions" panel and it sucked hard core.
Gave up and went to another panel, which quickley ended an DJ Spooky came on!
Spooky did a 30 min set, cuttin and scratchin like only spooky can :) after
his set, was the artists panel with DJ Spooky, Money Mark, Goldie, Mike Watt
and some others. it rocked. Money Mark is cool. :) 
After that we went to the RPM panel, which also sucked. but paul? of orbital
and goldie were there. goldie's cool too :)

After spooky's set, we had talked to him, and he had invited us to a 
small party that night. we (dara and i) went, but it was packed with record
label schmuks so we left and went record shopping. We hit Sattelite, 
Eight Ball records, and Strange?.. then went to a party thrown by Quango
and Axiom. Being cmj goons, we were let in free again, and the party was RAD!
Rob swift of xmen and DXT were there, battling each other and stuff. Then
Razell, The Grandmaster of Noize, of the roots, battled rob swift, except
Razell DIDN'T USE TURNTABLES!! it was incredible, he was doin all these
hiphop tricks and stuff by just his voice!! after beatboxin' a while, they
turned some wack jungle dj loose, who soon got relieved. dara and i left
when the house dj's came on. it was strange to see drunk club people trying
to dance to jungle. actually they were just bouncing around. there was some
guy speakerboxing as well. 

saturday, dara and i saw the new quinten tarrintino film called curdled. it
sucked. i went to buy ore records, and this time went to liquid sky/temple
and got annoyed (but they had lots of drum & bass). I went to the DMC store
but it was closed.I went back to sonic groove and got a rad record bag and
stuff. got a falefel and went back. Later, Dara and I went to a silly party
at wetlands, with call of da' wild and chino xl. wetlands was cool, but the
dj's were crappy. but it was free :) We went to a party that DJ Spooky
invited us to at the NY Film Academy. but unlike everything else, it wasn't
a free cmj event, we had to pay ten bucks. for some reason, we were both
a little tired after too many shows and too many record stores and too many
parties and too many panels and didn't want to pay ten buxks, so we found a
rad diner and had breakfast went went back to the hotels

i left dara at times square and hung out with the guys i came down with for a 
while, then it was time to go home. The coolness didn't stop there, though.
At the airport, they served Peets Coffee!!!!!!!! It had been almost a month
since i left berkeley and hadn't had Peets in a while.. Peets in NY was great!

Anyway, i met lots of cool people (dara, hollie, jeff, john, kiren, kurt, 
tye..). Thanks for hanging out with me guys :) also thanks to my radio station,
kmnr, for sending me. between the station and the records labels, almost all
my expenses were covered and i only had to spend 23 bucks! 

i'm leaving out a lot, but oh well, this is long enough and i have a test
tomorrow and if you've made it this far, you can tell i don't feel like 
writing today.. but

	i miss berkeley
	i miss bay area
	i miss sf raves
	I LOVE NEW YORK JUNGLE

but i don't think i'll be going back to ny for a while.. the west coast
is a little more my speed. but it was fun. thanks to all the ny ravers i met
thanks to cmj for the parties. thanks to the record labels. if you ever want
to hear jungle for a week solid, you know where to go. kids in nyc play
breakbeat in their cars. you meet people wearing jungle sky tshirts on the
subway. oh yeah, the subway is only $1.50 anywhere. its hot, its skanky, but
its cheap and i can actually afford it. wish bart was $1.50 and ran all night.

anyway, missouri is hot if anyone wonders. it rained today. i'll see you
all soon...-raj

Subject: forced into veganism!
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

hello all-

i've been, against my will, forced into veganism.  it that sound's odd,
here's how:

last week, i went vegetarian, for health reasons.  i was really getting
into that, and was enjoying getting to know more vegetables and stuff.

this morning, i found out (under suspician from my doctor) that i have a
dairy alergy, so if i eat any dairy products, my thouat will get
continually get more and more fucked up (which is bad for a singer).

so, at that point, i could eat vegetables, fruits, grains, and eggs, and i
said, i'm so close, i might as well do it, so i'm now a vegan!

so, wish me luck on my new culinary quest!

love to you all-

matt

In fact I DID!!!  What a blast!  My bro and I met up with some great 
people in tent city, then spent much of the night in the ambient room 
(which boomed quite nicely at one point), and left around 7am.

Like I said, we met lots of cool people, but I am terrible with names, 
and in my "trance-like" state, I probably won't remember too many faces 
either.  I hope I can meet up with more SFRaves list members at my next 
rave.  Does anyone have personal websites I can visit?  Anyone interested 
in visiting my fledgling digital gallery?

Also, I found a beautiful glass "object" in my backpack at nights-end.  
If anyone lost a beautiful glass "object", describe it and it's yours! :-)

>NWRaves has their laminate design downloadable on hyperreal, a great idea I

So,  whats the URL....    By the way,  if you ever want to give directions
to some place,  but don't want to deal with the geography of the situation,
check out:  http://www.mapblast.com/mapblast/locator.html
or also:  http://www.proximus.com/yahoo/

These sites take an address,  and draws a map,  with an X marking the
address.    GREAT for passing out rave directions info,   or telling
someone where their place is located.    I'm finding it invaluable
to me,  because I know little about the geography around the San Diego
area.   You just type in the address,  and it displays a map.   Then, you
can copy the URL and paste it into the web browser.   For instance,
my location is:

http://www.proximus.com/cgi-bin/webmap?Template=yahoo&File=world&Style=Plain
&Alias=1&Height=250&Width=400&Icon=Smallcross%2C%2C0%2C0&Context=%2d117%2e15
8133%2c32%2e715614%2c20000%2c0%2c0&UA=624%20Broadway%20%2f%20San%20Diego%2c%
20CA%2092101

Just copy and paste it into your web browser and it draws a map and CX marks
the spot....    An excellent topol for those geographic brain dead folks
who are lousy with directions.

Crunchman

I've been told that all forms of dance music are considered forms of techno, 
e.g. that techno came first and house, acid, etc all evolved from techno and
fall under that classification.  What I'd like to see is a sort of family 
tree of all these forms of music.

any help most appreciated,

here is my stab at it...just for fun...

                house ~~~~~~~ techno
                 /  \            |       \
                /    \          acid    breakbeat
       kmelHouse   deep house      \           \
                       \          trance        jungle
                       hard house    \ goaTrance    |reggaeJungle,popJungle
                           hardcore-hardtrance-GOjungle
then of course you got acid-jungle and trancy-breakbeat...ambient fits in
prettymuch anywhere...:) :) :)

UC Berkeley CS
http://www.ocf.berkeley.edu/~trose

rkumar@ee.umr.edu (Roger Kumar) wrote:
>Then Razell, The Grandmaster of Noize, of the roots, battled rob swift,

>these hiphop tricks and stuff by just his voice!!

Anyone who hasn't seen The Roots live should go, at least once, just for
the experience of hearing Razell.  I don't really thrill to their
performances, but the Grandmaster is just that.  Awesome.

>We went to a party that DJ Spooky invited us to at the NY Film Academy.
>but unlike everything else, it wasn't a free cmj event, we had to pay
>ten bucks.

Tragedy.

anarch@scruznet.com

[ to sfraves list ]

An End To Burning Man ( at least at Black Rock )

 There is a story on page D1 of today's San Francisco Chronicle 
( Sep. 16th ), titled "Desert May Not Host 'Burning Man' Party".

 Some selected quotes from the article:
 --------------------------------------------------------------

 Citing financial concerns and incompatible values, Pershing County
commissioners have voted to seek an end to the annual Burning Man
celebration in Nevada's Black Rock Desert.

 At the urging of Sheriff Ron Skinner, commissioners agreed to write 
a letter to the Bureau of Land Management asking it not to reissue a
permit to event organizers next year. The event is sponsered by a San 
Francisco-based group.

...

 This year there where at least five arrests ... the most serious involved 
a man who was booked for felony drunken driving after slamming into 
occupied tents on the desert. Another man was killed when his motorcycle 
ran head-on into a van.

 Event organizers could not be reached for comment. A recorded message 
at their San Francosco headquarters said, "The Burning Man Project is 
shut down for cleanup and reprogramming."

 ---------------------------------------------------------------

what an incredible location. the tents gave me a pleasant reminder of 
burningman, teh surrounding redwood trees and green vegetation brought a 
peaceful aura and the two rooms were decorated with care and warmth. this 
was more than a typical good party. a lot of drums and the various people 
contributed to a tribal energy outside and in the 'chill' room while the 
main room pounded with the energy of a full on rave, where mike clay 
provided some mind melting visuals. 
i got there around six, with a small soundsystem outside and tim's BBQ 
going it felt like BBQ and beats all over again:). as teh busses brought 
more people in, the place filled up nicely, and was so spacious there that 
it never got overcrowded. this was very well organized so props to greg 
and harmony crew and most people that went that made it so. 
the live act, stella lunar, was great - pounding acoustic rhythm and some 
acoustic and electronic overlays the finished product came out very groovy 
and psychedelic.

little tidbits:

wayne and marcy it was great to hang out with you two. 

claire and rob's little puppy was just too adorable:) 

the pancakes provided by jason out of teh back of tim's truck made the 
morning complete.

we were just missing amy and melanie, i got used to running into those 
two at these great events...


    happy monday everyone:)
	*ahau*

______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: forced into veganism!
Author:  "matthew d. p. k. lanier" <mdpkl@best.com> at ccsmtp
Date:    9/15/96 8:33 PM


hello all-
     
i've been, against my will, forced into veganism.  it that sound's odd, 
here's how:
     
last week, i went vegetarian, for health reasons.  i was really getting 
into that, and was enjoying getting to know more vegetables and stuff.
     
this morning, i found out (under suspician from my doctor) that i have a 
dairy alergy, so if i eat any dairy products, my thouat will get 
continually get more and more fucked up (which is bad for a singer).
     
so, at that point, i could eat vegetables, fruits, grains, and eggs, and i 
said, i'm so close, i might as well do it, so i'm now a vegan!
     
so, wish me luck on my new culinary quest!
     
love to you all-
     
matt

> >>>  Magical Grapefruit of Love is a way to say "Hey, you're really damn cool,

> >>>  is no actual citrus fruit contained in this letter.  Unfortunately, at

Subject: Harmony 3 year love-fest!
Message-ID: <Pine.SGI.3.93.960916091930.5606B-100000@shellx.best.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----

Wow.

To start off, I have to say that this was THE BEST rave/party/whatever you
call it that I have ever attended (narrowly defeating the Beautiful People
on Mission, a couple of months back).  I have to say this now, because I'm
actually going to try to describe the experience, and I know that I can't
come close, at least in language, to describing it adequately.

For me, the party started at about 7:30pm on Friday, when Steve Simitzis,
Blossom and I drove down to the site (we had mistakenly thought that
people were staying on-site overnight to help set up :)  In the end, it
became a lovely, laid back evening of little sleep and much cuddling &
small talk with some of the most amazingly wonderful people around,
while helping to make laminates & number tickets, etc.  I was bouncy from
the instant Steve put on a tape in the car (yay for Steve's jungle tape!
wooooo!), and for me, that was the beginning of the experience.

While I'm at this stage: thanks very much for the ride to & from, Steve!
You're the best!

I had gotten my money's worth out of the experience before we even went
out to the site Saturday morning, just from being near all the wonderful
people who were helping out.  Everything that happened after noon was a
bonus :)... the site was gorgeous - clearly the perfect location for this
event.  I spent the first few hours helping out as much as I could,
primarily in the main room, and greeting people with big hugs, eating
veggie dogs, and being excessively bouncy.  I even made a half-hearted
attempt at taking a nap around 3:30, but it failed; I was just too
excited!  At around 5, Tom started spinning on the little outdoor sound
system, and I finally unleashed a bit of my bounciness.  Woo!

For fear of burning myself out before the real sound systems even turned
on, I went up to the main room & helped a bit more, and then just sat on
one of the picnic tables outside that room, watching the beautiful people
stream into the site (hugging as necessary :)  From time to time, I would
lose my self-control and bounce down to dance for a few minutes, but
mostly I was able to restrain myself & save up some energy for the main
event.

Which leads me into saying: WOW, what a setup.  The harmony decorations
are so wonderfully warm, and happy... even though I've seen them at 4
different events now, they always manage to be fresh and incredible and
unique.  The lighting in the main room was spectacular - just the right
mix of glow-stuff and flashing-stuff for my tastes.  I have no idea what
DJs were spinning when, but it matters very little, because *all* the
music was simply extraordinary.  Woooooo!  I actually totally burned out
for a few minutes right after the sound came on, and went up and listened
to the first half of Stella Luna's (amazingly wonderful) set - definitely
one of the highlights of the night.  And even though by this point I was
totally burned out (give me a break, I barely slept the night before :) I
didn't get any sleep - just laid back on the floor and felt the music and
the people around me... wonderful.  I was energized enough at that point
to head back down to the main space for quite some time & dance some more!

At some point, I wound up totally spaced out and ready for sleep, sitting
on a couch in the ambient room, listening to some really really beautiful
breakbeat/trip-hop and about to sleep.  This was when a very beautiful
experience ocurred - one which can't really be described but which
energized me for the rest of the night.

The rest of the night passed in somewhat of a blur of happiness, dancing
my ass off, lying on the side of the path staring at the stars, hugging
people, hearing incredible music, and just generally being exceedingly
happy.  There were highlights of this blurry time though - someone,
noticing that my DISCO sticker (thanks Brendan (sp?)!) had been sweated
off, and took theirs off and gave it to me; Karen infusing me with energy
via a hug and a wave of her hand; the girl who asked if she could e-hug me
- - i had no idea what that meant, so to be safe I said no, but here's a
regular hug... and 5 minutes later, after the hug was over, she said
"that wasn't a regular hug!" (but it WAS, it's just that Mattloaf taught
me how to hug :); meeting incredible people & smiling & hugging with
them... whoa.  The list goes on.

Speaking of meeting people, I don't remember very many names.  But I added
about 25 people to my hug-on-sight list, so watch out :)

There were a couple of seriously lacking people for me - Matt Lanier and
Shamini Jain.  Matt, I saw your post when I got back, I'm *so* bummed you
weren't there!  I was looking forward to mega-hugs and some kick-back
time.  Next time, eh?  And Shamini... where were you?  I looked and
looked.  I hope you were able to make it out, and that I just missed you.
But if you didn't make it, we're even for me missing Burning Man :)

I have to send out super-special thanks and love to the Harmony crew and
to everyone who was there for the set-up and tear-down.  It was a lot of
fun, and seeing the site beforehand, and seeing the finished product and
how happy it made people, and knowing that I was a small part of that, was
an indescribably good feeling and added another level of pleasure to this
already perfect weekend.

I also have to say how amazingly grateful I am to those of you who
explicitly thanked me for the little gifts I've been bringing to the last
few events and for being so energetic.  I couldn't be energetic without
you!  I don't think anyone has that much energy within themselves - the
energy comes from that indescribably thing we all talk about and love
desperately, the VIBE.  And as we all know, Harmony are the masters of
vibe :)

I love you all so much!  Thanks everyone for making my weekend perfect.
I'll be sore until the next millenium, I'm sure, but it was *so* worth it!
See you at the next one... and gobs of hugs and love 'till then!

: : J. David Lowe :: dlowe@best.com :: http://www.best.com/~dlowe/ : :
:  "I believe that imagination is stronger than knowledge - That     :
:   myth is more potent than history.  I believe that dreams are     :
:   more powerful than facts - That hope always triumphs over        :
:   experience - That laughter is the only cure for grief.  And I    :
:   believe that love is stronger than death."                       :
::                                          - Robert Fulghum        ::

still in a daze after that wonderful event - about all i can muster is a
few random comments - luckily i remembered a few names this time!
p.s. my face still aches from smiling so much.

hello's, hugs, and thank-you's to:

the harmony crew and the people who own/run that retreat - you saw the
possible and made it actual and our mouths are still agape

ran and stella luna - yow!  tugged me loose from reality in the most
pleasant-est way.

leslie - the first <brilliant!> smile i received that night - thank you!

the BEAUTIFUL PEOPLE  who were breaking down the the main floor with me
around 1am - i know you felt that vibe too, it was REAL.

especially matthew with your super-textured bald head and jess (tear it
DOWN!)

moonpup - pleasantly twisted with a trippy aftertaste!  and a good arm for
the thing that goes WHEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEE-EEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEEE!

lorin and jason, you fed us uncut NRG right off the drum head - 
GOOD GOD how can you NOT dance to that?

adam <r.lunatic> - a glowing moment of perfect frenzy as the fog rolls in

mattloaf of the inexhausible hugz - now THAT is an addictive substance!

john k., who received the most passionate description EVER on the
subjective WUMPH that starts a choice acid lick.  hey john, the nut was
freely given ...

steve - we passed mostly like two ships in the night - boo.  i missed you.

eric, ben, and all the troubled boys of the frequent frier's club - they
held the sky up when gravity started looking iffy that morning.  1st
person perspective IS a lot harder than 3rd person, ya know

quote of the morning:
  - HOW can it get any better than this?
  - just wait, man, it WILL!

see you all soon ...
matthew.

BUT WAIT:

last but definitely not least:

david and blossom - david, who found his keys and never lost his smile!
and blossom, who might have been spotted whirling to funky breaks in the
chill room but was never seen again =(

brian and jon (BK) and john and two more wonderful smiling people (dammit
i lost your names but not your faces) - my first hand orgy.  aaaaah ...

I will keep this as short as I know how..... 
 
I don't know about the rest of you, but I have a lot of trouble reading a
post that is very long and is written in ONE paragragh........ 
 
I find that when there is a break every 10 or so lines, it is easier on the
eyes and brain. 
 
Now I don't claim to be an English expert (as seen from many of my own
posts), so I'm not sure of the exact time to end one, and begin another
paragraph, but I think it has to do with subject matter per
paragraph........... I think sort of maybe kinda 
 
Anyway, a lot of times I will just delete a post if it is long and one
paragraph, as I don't like hurting my brain.........well at least not
unless I mean to !!!! 
 
this was just another friendly ramble from ............... dot man 
 
                                                        moonpup

At 01:11 AM 9/16/96 -0700, you wrote:
>hi,
>I've been told that all forms of dance music are considered forms of techno, 
>e.g. that techno came first and house, acid, etc all evolved from techno and
>fall under that classification.  What I'd like to see is a sort of family 
>tree of all these forms of music.
>
>any help most appreciated,
>Bruce
>
Hey: 

The following paragraphs are excerpts taken from my memory, from various
conversations I havve had with other musicians and DJ's:

Nobody really knows what genre of electronic dance music came 1st.
Basically, the areas that people tend to narrow it down to is Chicago and
Detroit.  Detroit "invented" techno, but in Chicago, disco never died, and
became house. You can still hear elements of disco in a lot of music that
comes out of Chicago ("garage house" is a form of music that was basically
disco but was written by people with small electronic setups at home back in
the late 70's/early 80's and couldn't afford the big-budget disco
productions of the time).  However, in Detroit the nu-beat sound (dance
music that spawned from industrial) was rapidly evelving, and at some
threshold became techno.  Therefore it's hard to tell where it originated.
Germany and Belgium played a huge part in it's development as well, with
record labels such as Tekno Drome International and ZYX, as well as
Kraftwerk and Front 242. 
Now, basically, I hate classifications.  Its nearly impossible to really
know who invented what, and what evolved where, unless you had a collection
of about 10,000 records that you could sort by date. For example, take Acid
house, or house in general.  As a musician myself, most of my best sounds
are caused by mistake.  I might have the wrong sequence playing the wrong
synthesizer and it sounds awesome. 
         Then, take into effect the musicians who could only afford "cheap"
equipment.  When hip-hop originated, it was created by musicians of the
street, who couldn't afford ultra- expensive fairlight samplers and
synthesizers that at the time averaged about $5,000 each or more.  So they
had to deal with what was affordable: piece-of-shit TR-808's and Technics
1200 turntables.  Later, the big hot-shot producers ended up eating their
fairlights and $5000 synths when the street musicians were making millions
with their "shitty" TR 808 
        Same goes for house. At one point, a broke musician could only
afford the plethora of TR909 drum machines and TB303 synthesizers, which,
ended up making some smokin acid house. And thus, a new movement was born.

But to me, what it boils down to is what you love, and it doesn't really
matter what came 1st, for it gets really confusing :)

>thought.  Is ours?

I've got several designs on my page, contributed by various members of our clan:

        www.tgrigsby.com/sfraves

Anyone wanting to put their design, ANY design, on that page, forward it to 
me attached to an email.

S


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Sep 16 11:46:07 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id LAA28602; Mon, 16 Sep 1996 11:46:07 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from uclink4.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with ESMTP id LAA28590; Mon, 16 Sep 1996 11:46:04 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from [128.32.91.96] (mmf26.Berkeley.EDU [128.32.91.96]) by uclink4.berkeley.edu (8.7.5/8.6.12) with SMTP id LAA09413 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Mon, 16 Sep 1996 11:45:55 -0700 (PDT)
X-Sender: lachim@uclink4.berkeley.edu (Unverified)
Message-Id: <v02130507ae6358f581ec@[128.32.91.96]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Mon, 16 Sep 1996 11:43:32 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: lachim@uclink4.berkeley.edu (michal migurski)
Subject: Re: H3
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> hey -
>
>I'd have to say that Harmony last night was one of the coolest parties I've
>ever been to.  Everything was done so wonderfully there.  I wish Harmony was
>going to do some more parties.

They (we? =) are!!! That was just the last "harmony," but the crew isn't
going to drop outta the party bi'ness or anything... a good thing too
because

HARMONY THREE FUCKING TORE MY HEAD OFF!!!!

this was the most unbelievably beautiful party I've ever experienced!!!

It felt so good to be part of the crew and know that I'm playing a small
part in bringing this event to life. I loved putting all that work into
helping out with setup, cleanup and karma patrol. I put so much energy into
this party that I think I need to take a (short =) break from raving just
to RECOVER. =)

anyway, a quickie review:

space: YOWZA! Chill room was the chillinest chill room I've ever seen.
lighting and setup was beautiful. Nice touch putting the DJ/musician right
in the middle, and that stage that opened up when live bands played was so
nicely decorated. The shrine to Omar was really special, and even though I
didn't know him personally, I really felt a connection just because so many
people were there thinking about him. The main room was the bomb too (it's
dusty up there in those rafters... I pity the kid who had to drag down all
the extension cords I put up there =). There were so many blacklights that
perfectly accompanied the day-glo disco and happy-face-speaker stickers
that brendan and I were tossing around. Oh yeah.. the campground. A nice
place to hang out where you could talk to people and occasionally SCREAM
LIKE A MANIAC with hundreds of others joining you...  fun!

music: didn't even keep track of the DJs but I gotta say that SOMEONE blew
me away with a MONSTER buildup at about 4 or 5am... never screamed so loud
in my life! =) The chill room music was very... chill! =) Allegra's (sp?)
voice is so beautiful (the girl who sang moonshadow at about 430am) we're
all going to miss her!

cool moments:

meeting so many smiling people while running around the main room. Made so
many new friends!!! hi kc, david, and all the other sfravers whose names
have completely slipped my mind right now (D'OH!! i'll remember you guys as
soon as I see you next! =)

checking out that little redwood grove with the christmas lights.

the smiles on the faces of my SJ friends who've never been to a rave before
(starting off on the right foot? =)

every time the bus arrived the passengers would scream and the camp would
scream back! well, pretty much every time the camp screamed in general;
there's something beautiful about a huge clan of happy people raising
they're voices like that in unison.

brendan, I finally figured out how to spin those glo-sticks on strings
without hitting myself (too much). thanks!

wierd moment: while on karma patrol, we ran into a couple that wasn't doing
too good. The guy was freaking out a little, but he *seemed* happy. The
girl was miserable though, mainly because she was worried abouther friend
"making a scene." I don't want to go into too much detail, but taking care
of these two (with caryn --thanks) really disturbed me. I really got the
feeling that they were two incredibly depressed, emotionally unstable kids
who SHOULD NOT have taken the substances they did, at least not as much as
they did. I think e (or any other mind-altering chemical) isn't a "cure-all
hapy disco biscuit" and that if you take it you should either a) have your
shit together or b) be with someone who knows what they're doing and can
help you take advantage of the e to improve your self-esteem. These two
were NOT helping each other, and I felt so helpless because I'm not at all
experienced with dealing with these kinds of situations. =(

well, that bummed me out for awhile, but I soon I was back on my super
happy trip (I was sober too! =) trying to make everyone's party experience
just a little bit nicer.

morning came, the music was turned off and people started packing up,
hugging good-bye and leaving. Cleanup, though tiring, was fun and we were
outta there by early afternoon.

in short, this was one of the best fuckin' parties I've ever attended.
THANKS FOR EVERYTHING GREG AND HARMONY!!!

smiles,
-m.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Sep 16 12:34:49 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id MAA03164; Mon, 16 Sep 1996 12:34:49 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from netcom17.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with SMTP id MAA03158; Mon, 16 Sep 1996 12:34:46 -0700 (PDT)
Received: (from simitzis@localhost) by netcom17.netcom.com (8.6.13/Netcom)
	id MAA06914; Mon, 16 Sep 1996 12:34:44 -0700
Date: Mon, 16 Sep 1996 12:34:44 -0700
From: simitzis@netcom.com (Steve Simitzis)
Message-Id: <199609161934.MAA06914@netcom17.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Harmony :)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Thought I'd take a minute and share my Harmony experience with y'all
[would you expect anything else from me? :)]... The music was
terrific, of course, although I didn't spend much time in the ambient
room. Sadly, I heard not a trace of jungle all night, but oh well :(

Harmony 3 was a bit like "Burning Man Lite"; there was a campground,
some rave stuff, some people cooking food, a fun vibe, porto-johns,
drum circles, techno-hippies, computer geeks, and so on.

The main area was incredible; the sound system and lighting(?) were
from Gateway and provided a nice sensory overload. I don't think I've
tranced out that deeply in years; the lighting at times was simply so
blinding, that there was nothing else that one could be aware of other
than the rapid change of colors, strobing, and smoke. At times, vision
of objects would be impossible. One could only see in terms of colors
and rough shapes.

Between the visuals and the powerful sounds coming out of the sound
system, I was transported to another plane. While I was dancing, I was
unaware of myself or of the world around me. Sound became
movements. Closing my eyes only left me with a slightly darker version
of what I saw with my eyes open. Quickly, everything disappeared, even
myself. It was no longer was important to connect with people around
me, because they were no longer there as people. Everything to me felt
as a continuous stream of light, sound, and energy. Nothing physical
was left. incredible :)

At some point, my physical body starting knocking at the door; my
trance had been interrupted by my physical needs. But just as well; so
I sat down with some friends, had some water, and enjoyed watching
everyone else have the time of their lives. :) And I was able take
some some time to mentally record my experience on the dance
floor. I'm a non-drug person, and I wondered if what had happened to
my state of mind was in any way similar to other people's drug
experiences...

I spent much of my time connecting with people that I don't normally
see in non-rave social settings, which was nice. I was also feeling a
bit anti-social, which is rather unusual for me. A lot of it had to do
with the fact that I was really tired due to setting up and staying
awake all weekend; maybe I was just feeling moody. Nonetheless, I
missed spending time with many of my friends that were there.

I really have to hand to the Harmony people; that was my first time
contributing to a party, and it's really hard work. There is so much
sweat and stress that goes into throwing events like that, and this
past weekend made me appreciate it.

David and I went together, so much of my experience overlapped with
his. Though, I'd like to add a footnote to his post: Friday night, we
stayed at Greg's house and watched Dead Alive. This was the scariest,
goriest, most vile movie that I've ever seen. I was so disturbed after
seeing this! Fortunately, Ren & Stimpy made it into the VCR to clear
my head of all of the gore. But I surprised; the last thing you'd
expect to see in the Harmony house would be a horror movie :)

cool stuff from this weekend:

being saved by technology and Brendan at Camp Swig on friday
the scary road
Mike going off with the laminator
"I kick ass for the *Lord*!"
selling water to thirsty ravers
sleep deprivation
DJ Tom's set
wrestling with the sketchy ladder
glowsticks from Shawna
meeting new SFRavers
phat hugz from Mattloaf
Chai tea from City-E

Anyway, I've said all I can about this, and it was definitely a
weekend to remember. But I'm not worn out yet! mad's tonight, and I
will be there :) [that is, after I get some packing done].

Steve

From: Randy C Cone <randream@cats.ucsc.edu>
Subject: H3 (long review)
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9609161125.A18021-0100000@si.UCSC.EDU>

Precedence: bulk


Hi all!

 Wow!!! What a party!  =) I've never had so much fun being stressed out! ;)
I visited the site on Wed. and Fri. with Greg and crew and immediately 
became way more eXcitEd than I already was. The ambient room was SOOOO 
nice and perfect for the live acts. Some folks mentioned that they felt 
the main room and the ambient room should have been switched, but for the 
live acts the temple room was perfect.

 Got to the site at 1:30 (only an hour and a half late :) and started to 
unload. Once again big thanks to the ever wonderful Jess for helping me 
get there and tolerating my storage locker ;).

 At one point Greg says to me "You're in charge of the ambient room." 
YIKES!! I should have expected that, but didn't (although that has been a 
dream of mine for five years now) and the onslaught of questions from 
eager, smiling ravers on what goes where, do you think that looks good, 
etc., was somewhat overwhelming. Now I have a taste of what Greg goes 
through on a regular basis ;).

 At this point I would like to apoligise to everyone who had to deal with me 
those two days; I was very sick and losing my voice and my shoulder still 
hurts every day, so I was a little cranky =(. And then when JK Sound set 
me back two hours in set up time by; 1) bringing the wrong mixer and 2) 
having that mixer die, that really put me in a foul mood as I couldn't 
sound check the two live acts (Stella Luna and 23 Degrees).

 Big thanks to the Harmony crew who kept coming by and asking if I needed 
help!!!!! I did but none of you folks are licensed. ;) Also big thanks to 
everyone who worked in the chill room with decorations and such!! And the 
biggest thanks to those who stayed and helped to clean and pack at the 
end (hi John!!). It is people like you folks that make this world worth 
living in!!!!!!!! Dagny, you are the sweetest!

 Other folks that helped me; Martin and Jennifer, thanks!

 And oh my God the rib that I recieved from Tim (with his award winning 
sauce) saved my ass! It was SOOOO good!!! Thanks Tim!!!!! =)

 Well, despite the problems that I had from the power genny and JK (I had 
to repatch my audio hookup, lucky I brought both of my sub-mixers) we 
started on time. Big thanks again to Stella Luna and 23 Degrees for their 
patience and understanding. :) Also big thanks to Madeline for her slide 
show. Very beautiful!

 Stella Luna was over the top!! they were SOOOOO good it hurt! ;) What an 
ensemble of of complete lunatics! Their performance was a mixture of 
music, performance art/parade and pure  celebration of life! I loved them 
and highly recommend them! 23 Degrees had a very solid set with very 
beautiful sounding vocalists and incredible percussion.

 My highlight was having Allegra sing. She sang two songs acalpella (sp?) 
the first being Cat Steven's "Moon Shadow" and the second being a song 
whose title I don't remember. Her voice was very soothing and beautiful. 
Also my hugs from Greg were very soothing (as well as his coment; "I just 
loved watching you stress so beautifully. ;) And looking back and seeing 
Moonpup (whom I haven't yet met formally) sitting on my couch and nodding 
with a smile as I played an ol' gospel church tune.

 Because of my exhaution, sickness, etc. I felt that my set really 
suffered and as such I would like to apoligise to all those who wanted 
to hear me really go off.

 Big thanks to Andrew K. for letting me crash and recuperate at his 
flat!!! =)

 A huge hug to all those who came! You folks are why we do what we do!!!  =)


Peace all,


Ran


                                   -=*=-
                                     ~

PS Hi to all those whom I talked to and didn't mention in this post!!!!

> hi,
> I've been told that all forms of dance music are considered forms of techno,
> e.g. that techno came first and house, acid, etc all evolved from techno and
> fall under that classification.  What I'd like to see is a sort of family
> tree of all these forms of music.

as i understand it, the history of modern music shows,
that house was before techno, and so all techno
could be called house-offsprings - but techno became
a way of making music in generel - the method is 
the techno-algorithm!

and that means, even jungle is techno - 
and breakbeat is there it all comes together again -
the house, the techno, the jungle and the acidsounds
(acid actually is not techno, but can be!)

cu, frieder

ps: and still no word about TRANCE! 

## CrossPoint v3.02 ##

Hi!

I just had a couple corrections to Steve's Harmony post...

At 12:34 PM -0700 9/16/96, Steve Simitzis wrote:
>Thought I'd take a minute and share my Harmony experience with y'all
>[would you expect anything else from me? :)]... The music was
>terrific, of course, although I didn't spend much time in the ambient
>room. Sadly, I heard not a trace of jungle all night, but oh well :(

Rob spun some ambient drum&bass in his first of two sets, say around 1am.
It was funny too, becuase he wasn't quite sure what to drop and it turned
out to be perfect...

>Harmony 3 was a bit like "Burning Man Lite"; there was a campground,

Hmmm...that's a far, far stretch...Burning Man is more about survival and
building a virtual community, Harmony was at a camp ground with a convient
store no more than ten minutes away.  I understand your point, though.  I'd
say it was more like "Light Lite", that is, a more convenient, and shorter
version of Gateway's Light campout over July 4th weekend.

>
>The main area was incredible; the sound system and lighting(?) were
>from Gateway and provided a nice sensory overload. I don't think I've

They were from JK, not Gateway.  Definitely intense and interesting.  Truth
be told, I had a problem with the Golden Scans being on the floor like they
were.  We kept getting blinded by these high-powered lights.  No so bad
when you get hit straight on, but when it hit your peripheral, damn!  Ouch!

It was a rockin' night!  =)

Tone

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Sep 16 13:36:31 1996

Date: Mon, 16 Sep 1996 13:36:33 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: andy@pythagoras.org (Andrew Nourse)
Subject: Harmony 3 - - Extreme Wonderfulness!!
Message-ID: <19960916203618.AAA20968@[205.158.215.178]>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I live in the Santa Cruz Mountains, and have long thought they would be a
wonderful
backdrop for a rave.   Harmony made that dream come true.  "Rave summer camp"
on the last full weekend of summer.   Dancing outside in the afternoon.   I
gotta track
down some Platipus.  This is the second party I've heard a really tasty
track by them.
More wonderful music, not much dancing, most saving their energy and digesting
the food from the barbecue  [Thanks Tim!].  Then the outside system shut
down, and
I saw a moon and a star parading through the campground.  Someone [thanks,
whoever you are] clued me in that that meant that Stella Luna were about to
perform.
Stella Luna was a real treat!  I had never even heard of them before, let
alone heard them.
Lots of really spacey space between the Stella and the Luna!

Mucho trance in the main room.  Is it my imagination or have I been hearing
a lot more
trance lately?  I love to dance to this stuff, but I need to develop a
little more stamina to
dance to it all night.  Until then, I'll have to rest a bit from time to
time.  Which is where
the really excellent chill room came in.

This was a really really wonderful party.  Thanks to everyone who helped to
put it on.

I don't think I've ever done so much hugging in one day.
The Tie-Dyed Side of the Force

My computer tells me that on Fri, 13 Sep 1996, leftjab shared (in part):

> I also believe that many of us have a spiritual view of raving, and despair
> that too many people don't "get" it.  We want people to know that ravers
> aren't sex-crazy, druggy teenagers -- 

	You left out the people who are sex-crazy, druggy, *and*
spiritual!  Come on leftjab, think Dionysus, Greek god of wine, dancing,
orgies, and good times!
	Getting in touch with God needn't be an experience of sitting
Buddha-style in silence or kneeling in front of an altar while listening
to organ music.
	It can be getting in touch *physically* with that irresistable
someone, or letting the beats do scandalous things with your body on a a
crowded sweaty dancefloor as your mind flies around the room!

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Sep 16 13:43:14 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id NAA09939; Mon, 16 Sep 1996 13:43:14 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from acergw3.acer.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with ESMTP id NAA09931; Mon, 16 Sep 1996 13:43:10 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from smtplink.acer.com ([204.160.139.137]) by acergw3.acer.com (8.7.3/8.7.3) with SMTP id NAA19386 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Mon, 16 Sep 1996 13:39:42 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from ccMail by smtplink.acer.com (SMTPLINK V2.11.01)
	id AA842906847; Mon, 16 Sep 96 13:35:55 pst
Date: Mon, 16 Sep 96 13:35:55 pst
From: "Andy Wyszkowski" <awyszkow@smtplink.acer.com>
Message-Id: <9608168429.AA842906847@smtplink.acer.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Long, Drawn out review... Harmony
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     
     SHORT VERSION+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
     
     Harmony was cool.
     
     EXTENDED VERSION++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
     
     Stayed at band rehearsal until 11:00am Sat morn after 3 
     hours of sleep, and packed up to pick up the ride I 
     promised.
     
     Moonpup is a fucking trip... You will be most missed!  
     Badass set as well (scores most unique of the whole event I 
     think).  Very dopey trip hop, and a great way to get me 
     going (I didn't really ever give that stuff a chance 
     before... fuckin groovin!).  Mark and Milton spin some 
     killer yarns too... fuckin brilliant stories!~  Must visit 
     Europe soon!
     
     As for the party... very clean.  Only let down was the 
     absence of any hiking when I got there, but I'm glad I 
     didn't find anything (would have worn me out).  The place 
     was killer though, I guess it was a camp for a Hebrew school 
     or something like that.  Had a serene vibe that sometimes 
     seemed at odds with the big sound techno of the main room, 
     but went killer with drumming and dancing and sharing 
     outside.  There was lots of stuff to just check out (the 
     chill room was gorgeous... loved that tweaked looking pointy 
     thing with the designs projected on it).  Stella Luna 
     started setting off my evening with a dense mix of synth / 
     looping and groovin on various sonic toys, with a real 
     primal energy about it.  Much favored the second set to the 
     first.  It was nice to see the band set up forward of the 
     stage, playing drums, singing and Omming their way into a 
     tighter vibe with the chill people.
     
     As for dancing, I took off for the main room about 12:30 and 
     never went back.  Only time I left was when I had to get 
     more water or visit the Tidy Bowl man (who was suffering 
     from rising seas by morning if you catch my drift)... some 
     of the DJ's weren't that impressive, and Daniel seemed tired 
     (I think he played two other parties earlier the same day), 
     but the vibe really got going around 2-5.  Honestly it's all 
     a blur of gratuitous hugging, smiles, dancing, buildups, 
     lags, and breaks.  Couple of eyes rolled back in head what 
     the hell just transpired/when did the DJ's switch / what 
     happened to the last half hour type trances.  That's when I 
     love you all the best, coming back from one of those.  
     SMILE.  Mmmm... I corked out for a little while (in the main 
     room no less), then woke up to enjoy the sunrise... which 
     was fuckin awesome yet totally non-climatic.  I never 
     actually saw the sun, but the colors of the clouds were 
     changing the tweakiest shades of orange and pink and peach.  
     and the trees, and the sound of tired people from a long 
     great evening packing up.  Gorgeous.  Bonus Terry Mullin... 
     almost forgot to mention that.
     
     I did end up having to talk a couple people down over the 
     course of the evening, and that part kinda sucked.  Glad I 
     could fish a couple people out of a bummer though.  
     Chemicals are potentially dangerous, stay informed, stay 
     positive and be careful.  As for myself, I still have to 
     wait for my jaw to ease up, I tried eating fries this 
     morning and it HURT... clench clench clench.
     
     The Bummer:    It was kinda weird that so many people there 
     seemed like they all knew each other from high school or 
     something (lotta young Saratoga locals).  That's probably 
     the worst thing I could say about the party... it had some 
     clique factor going.  I'd like to meet more people there who 
     don't hang with a particular group.  More social that way.  
     I'd do it again a hundred times though!
     
     X-tra bonus kickback the head on the PeZ Dispenser of 
     Respect lovin to:
     Marisa, Robert, Moonpup, Mark, Dawn, Knucklehead (loved the 
     Garden Burgers.. mmmm), Leslie, Michal, Jay, John K, the 
     drum circles, the groovy womun with blue sweatshirt and 
     cropped hair from the next door tent that listened to my 
     extended morning stone ramblings, the Harmony crew for 
     making this so damn easy to enjoy, the guy from the guitar 
     store (bizarre!), the laid back afternoon picnic vibe, 
     MadameMerc and the usual crew and the so many other fucking 
     cool people I met who deserve way better than to have me 
     forget their names (argh!)... if I meet you somewhere and I 
     just smile at you like a moron, don't panic.  I probably 
     remember you, and I'm hopefully scanning the abyss in my 
     head for your name.
     
     Peace peace peace!
     AndyW

[snip]

> > Rob spun some ambient drum&bass in his first of two sets, say around 1am.
> > It was funny too, becuase he wasn't quite sure what to drop and it turned
> > out to be perfect...

Rob was great, especially his second set (IMHO).

> Yes, I missed Rob unfortunately. I had wanted to hear him, esp after
> Chrysalis, but it was difficult to find out what was happening at what
> times. I've always longed for a schedule at parties (helps when there
> are more multiple rooms, and when you're not sure when you should
> arrive or leave).

Actually, all anyone had to do was ask me (for the ambient lineup 
anyway) as I knew the lineup times for the ambient room. We did change 
things a bit as Terry Mullin was late (?) and Greg wanted Liquid (who 
was spinning in the ambient room) to cover. So Rob generously covered 
for Liquid as Liquid was covering for Terry.

[snip]

> They were from JK, not Gateway.  Definitely intense and interesting.  Truth
> > be told, I had a problem with the Golden Scans being on the floor like they
> > were.  We kept getting blinded by these high-powered lights.  No so bad
> >when you get hit straight on, but when it hit your peripheral, damn!  Ouch!


The Golden Scans were supplied by Mark Mehlman at Pacific Coast Stage 
Lighting. They were on the floor as there was not any really good spots 
to hang them from; too many support beams and rafters that would have 
interfered if they were hung high and not enough throw distance for the 
light beams if hung below the rafters. I personally thought the main 
dance floor looked sweet! The two video screens with the very robotic 
looking Golden Scans were very nice!


Peace,


Ran

Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

(FYI: I was actually e-mailing this to myself at my other computer but I
figured I might as well spread this recipie around cause I love it so much)





BLACK BEAN CHILI
Serves 6

1.5 cups Textured Vegetable Protein (TVP)
1.5 cups boiling water
Seasoning or 'broth' flavoring (optional)
2 tsp. olive oil
2 onions, chopped
4 cloves garlic, chopped
2 roasted red bell peppers (optional)
Jalapeno peppers to taste (2 - 4 for this recipie)
4 cups cooked black beans, rinsed & drained (2 - 15 oz. cans)
16 oz. can tomato sauce
2 Tbs. chili powder
1 tsp. ground cumin
1 tsp. salt
________________________________________________________________________

        * In a medium bowl, cover TVP with boiling water, add seasoning if
desired.  Set aside until liquid is absorbed (15 minutes).
        * Heat oil in large skillet, add onions & garlic, cooking slowly
over medium heat about 5 minutes.
        * Add peppers, saut=E9 1 minute.
        * Add TVP, beans, tomato sauce, chili powder, cumin, & salt.
        * Bring to a boil, reduce heat and cover. Simmer until thick, about
15 minutes.

        * (Save 4 cups for Tamale Pie)

Serve with: Polenta, Tortilla Chips, Cold Beer,

////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
////////
MAKE A DOUBLE BATCH AND USE LEFTOVERS FOR:

TAMALE PIE
Serves 6

4 Cups Black Bean Chili
8 oz can tomato sauce
8 oz can tomatoes, coarsely chopped, with juice
12 oz can whole kernel corn, drained
4 or 8 oz can whole olives, drained
1 Tbs. sugar
Hot pepper sauce to taste
1/2 tsp. black pepper
1 tsp. cayenne pepper
6 or 8 oz soy cheddar cheese, grated (optional)

1.5 cups yellow cornmeal
1/2 tsp. salt
4 cups cold water
2 Tbs. margarine (or olive oil)

----------------------------------------------------------------------------
----------------------

        *In a large pan, combine chili, tomato sauce, tomatoes & juice (use
less juice if mixture seems watery), corn, olives, sugar, pepper sauce, &
pepper.
        * Bring to a simmer, stirring. If it needs thickening, cover and
cook slowly about 15 minutes.
        * Preheat oven to 375=B0.  Add soy cheese to chili mixture(optional)=
,
stir well.
        * Pour into oiled 9 x 13 baking dish, smooth top with spatula, set
aside.

        * In a medium pan, stir cornmeal and salt into cold water until
smooth. Bring to a boil over medium-high heat, then reduce heat to medium.
        * Cook, stirring constantly, until thick, about 10 minutes.
        * Add margarine, mix well, and spread over chili mixture.
        * Bake until top is golden brown, about 40 minutes.
        * Let cool sufficiently before serving.

Serve with: Spanish Rice, Chips & Salsa,

Courtney Nielsen

Electronic Artists Collective
408 275 9972
cnielsen@earthlink.net

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey everyone,

Last Friday, some of the folks who perform at Burning Man had a little
party at the Coconut Grove on Van Ness St here in SF.

The party was labeled as "Formal Attire or Dream Costume". Well, since I
have no dream costume, I decided to get fancy and rented a tux.

Good thing I did, because the place was pretty posh, with a capital "P"!

The first thing I noticed were lots of wonderfully vibby people
eminating incredible energy. Nice!

The reggae band kicked in and every started gyrating. Well, almost
everyone. There were a few people who seemed to be regulars at the
Coconut Grove who were a bit miffed at everyone having so much fun. Oh
well, their loss.

So gyrate I did. I suddenly realized that most of these people were
sober. Where did they get their energy?

After speaking with a few of the gyraters, I realized that this was
their normal state. Energy Junkies! These people were/are permanently
"keyed in". Right on!

I then remembered the thread on sober raving a while ago. And just
seeing all these wonderful people and dancing with them gave me the
encouragement to shine on.

The party was over at 2am with everyone still in high spirits. 

I then remembered something a freind mentioned to me a while ago.

"It's all about energy, man."

Yup.

See y'all at MAD!

;)

Jonas

Date: Thu, 12 Sep 1996 14:13:14 -0700
From: Tom Welsh <tom@newalbion.com>

Subject: (amb) P.Oliveros/Deep Listening Band info

Sorry I didn't post this the first time (didn't have it), but here's the
complete detail for this Monday's Deep Listening Band concert.


MILLS COLLEGE CELEBRATES 30 YEARS OF CONTEMPORARY MUSIC:
PAULINE OLIVEROS HEADS ALL-STAR CAST OF CCM CELEBRITIES


NON STOP FLIGHT:  30 YEARS OF CCM
WITH PAULINE OLIVEROS
Pauline Oliveros and the Deep Listening Band
Stuart Dempster, David Gamper
The Hub
Abel-Steinberg-Winant Trio

Monday, September 16
PLEASE NOTE NEW START TIME:
a marathon, beginning at 7:00 p.m. and ending at 11:33 p.m.
Admission: $10/$5

Mills College Concert Hall
5000 MacArthur Blvd., Oakland
Information: (510) 430-2296

        OAKLAND, Calif. -- Mills College presents a concert to celebrate thirty
years of innovation and experimental music at the Center for Contemporary
Music.
The concert features Non Stop Flight by famed composer Pauline Oliveros.
Currently composer-in-residence at Mills, Pauline Oliveros was the first
director
of the Mills Tape Center (which later became the Center for Contemporary Music).
  In this special event, Oliveros will perform with the faculty of CCM as well
as the Deep Listening Band, the Hub, and the Abel-Steinberg-Winant Trio.

        Non Stop Flight uses a new version of the expanded instrument system,
a performer-controlled electronic processing environment.  The piece is
structured
so that all performers are playing continuously, with highlighted solos and
small
ensembles emerging at various times.  The music is improvisational and
meditative.
According to Oliveros, "This is not a set of pieces.  It's a non-stop
flight.  Included
is a memorial to David Tudor."  Tudor, who died recently at the age of 70, was
known as an avant-garde performer and composer.  He taught at Mills and was
a close associate of John Cage.

        The concert begins at 7 p.m. and will continue as a marathon
for several hours.  Audience members are invited to come and go as they
 please throughout the event.  General admission is $10, with a $5 admission
price for students, senior citizens, and disabled.  The concert is in the
Concert Hall, which is partially wheelchair accessible.  For further
information,
call (510) 430-2296.  Beautiful, historic Mills College is located at 5000
MacArthur Blvd. in Oakland, at the junction of Highway 580 and the Warren
(13) Freeway.  Visitor parking on campus is free.


Tom

New Albion Records
584 Castro #525
San Francisco, CA 94114 USA
t: 415.621.5757
f: 415.621.4711
e: tom@newalbion.com
http://newalbion.com

REGARDING THE WARNING SENT OUT BELOW:
Upon calling Lexus database @ 800-543-6862 [opt.3,opt.4}, the machine nicely
informs you that you must submit your request for removal in writing.  It
then politely calms your fears by assuring you that P-Trax only gives your
personal information to trustworthy folks, like lawyers, the government, and
law enforcement agencies.  This is sick, and I don;t understand how it's
legal, I'm going to try and find time to call the consumer affairs office
tommorow, I beg you to do the same. I've also faxed the 513 865 1930 # to get
my name removed.
BTW: it states that no credit information is included, and it never says
"your mothers" maiden name.
Suffocating in convenience,
-StEvEo
(Please don't start some rhetorical flame about how this information is
everywhere and it's hopeless to fight it)

>>Your name, social security number, current address, previous addresses,
mother's maiden name, birth date and other personal information are now
available to anyone with a credit card through a new Lexis database called
P-Trax... ...You can have your name and information removed from this list by
making a telephone request.  Call (800)543-6862, select option 4 and then
option 3 ("all other questions") and tell the representative answering that
you wish to remove your name from the P-trax database.

I think that the appeal of the techno that we're hearing now is that it
borrows from EVERYTHING that came before it. I hear the influences of soul,
funk, r&b, rock, reggae, world music, disco, and jazz every time that I go to
a party. This could also explain why you can hear some really good dubbing
going on- it's just taking the raw elements and re-integrating them.

I think a family tree would have to really explore the parentage of the
elements that are being combined to create techno as it is today. Good
suggestion! I look forward to hearing from all those who can keep all of the
names of techno straight! I know that I'm having troubles.

[ to sfraves ]
Sabot-aged By Sore Foot at Harmony

 Well, I got to Harmony both "late" and "early". I had bought a ticket,
but was also going to help around . I got there around 12:45 , a bit late
to help Tim Knucklehead with setting up the BBQ, so I made myself useful
here and there. I also brought the bananas and the garlic bread, and would 
appreciate any useful feedback re: the garlic bread. ( Leslie - great 
potato salad! Also, mucho thanks to Tim , who fronted much $$ to buy food
for everybody! ) 

 It was so nice to see the Harmony crew make the event a reality! So much
energy - I was pooping out by late afternoon. Got to do some little 
boogy to Moonpup's tasty tunes. 

 By early evening, I was getting twinges in my left foot - I have some 
sort of ache in it that's been around for a few weeks now . My wife thinks 
it might be due to a lack of heel padding in one of my shoes . My latest shoe 
purchase was some steel toed Red Wing outdoor shoes with a steel shank
in the sole - and I didn't have this particular ache until these new pair
of shoes.

 Anyway, it only took a few minutes in the main room to make the pain/pleasure
ratio too high to ignore. I tried resting some, and taking some analgesics,
but then I just decided that resting my foot would be the best course
of action. So, I left at about 1AM! Bah!

 Sounds like everyone had a good time ! I'm glad to have helped in some
way to make this last Harmony a reality!


 Larry Ching/larryc@netcom.com

        bradburlingham@disney.com
Subject: A review from the new guy (H3)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well, I must definitely say that my roommate and I picked the right event to
start our raving life in NorthernCal! We were very pleased with what we found
at Harmony. Some things that we took note of:

-No speaker kids (these are highly decorated, usually younger ravers who
climb up    
  on the speaker towers and cheer everyone on.)
-A HUGE cross section of people! Way to bring it together, guys!
-A lot of first timers. More power to them!
-We brought pixie stix, ring pops, and starbursts to pass out and we got two 
  reactions;
                  1-they thought I was trying to give them drugs in the form
of candy
                  2-they were SO gracious (its a given that we bring candy
for                                                        
                      everyone-do you all not do that here?)
-there were some really BAKED individuals. And I mean BAKED. They musta
started 
  at noon and kept on goin'!
-that music was THE SHIT! We dug everything our ears could ingest. The
ambient 
  room was like nothing I've ever experienced-nice touch!

Overall, we had a great time. Everyone was so friendly. (Not that we were
surprised from watching the list.) I'll even say that I liked the event more
than most I've been to out of L.A. (Sorry guys back at home) I only wish that
I knew more people. I guess time will take care of that!

Happy to be in Monterey-
-hugh

I had too much fun this weekend.  I know I had more than my allotted 
amount of fun, because now my body is getting back at me by being sick.  
Does anyone have any secrets for raving and staying healthy???

Too Much Fun, the annotated version:

Thursday Night -- drunken hot tub debauchery, with *17* butt-naked people 
piled into a hottub (including another SFRaver, who shall remain 
nameless!).  Definitely rivals e-piles for sheer physical fun with people 
in altered states!  Have to go to work way too early in the morning.

Friday Night -- drunken boisterous slamming around the edges of a mosh 
pit to grooving ska band.  Little sleep.

Saturday Night -- the MOST fun!!  Harmony was BEAUTIFUL!  I danced ALL 
night, to the most awesome trance, aided by the most awesome vibe and 
energy in the room - and a too-fun chemical cocktail.  No sleep.   

Monday comes, and brings with it sobriety and ill-health.  Sigh, too much 
fun has its price.  But can one party and still be a healthy person, or 
is a drawn-out recovery impossible to avoid??  I'm drinking orange juice 
and taking vitamins, but wish there was a way to painlessly binge...  
Health secrets, anyone?

P.S.	THANK YOU HARMONY for an AMAZING party!  I won't review, because 
"it's been done" :).  But this was one to remember! 

N

From: simitzis@netcom.com (Steve Simitzis)

To: nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU
CC: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-reply-to: <Pine.3.89.9609161734.A10955-0100000@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU> (message from Nancy Shaw on Mon, 16 Sep 1996 18:05:32 -0700 (PDT))
Subject: Re: Too Much Fun
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


> Date: Mon, 16 Sep 1996 18:05:32 -0700 (PDT)
> From: Nancy Shaw <nancys@ucdata.Berkeley.EDU>
> Subject: Too Much Fun
> To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
>
> Monday comes, and brings with it sobriety and ill-health.  Sigh, too much 
> fun has its price.  But can one party and still be a healthy person, or 
> is a drawn-out recovery impossible to avoid??  I'm drinking orange juice 
> and taking vitamins, but wish there was a way to painlessly binge...  
> Health secrets, anyone?

Yes! Vitamins and orange juice the day after torturing yourself is not
going to work (it's like changing your oil after blowing your engine).

Things you should definitely do (or definitely consider):

1) Change your diet. Try to eat only pure, healthy foods on a regular
basis. You don't have to become a vegan, but it helps ;) Fruits and
vegetables contain so much good life energy and nutrition. You'll feel
bouncier after a few weeks of eating like this.

2) Don't use drugs. Drugs leave behind sludge that you don't need in
your brain. Learn to feel happy and fun without chemical
enhancement. Extra bonus: There's no "coming down" from a natural
high.

3) Spend your week (in the "real" world) being as positive and happy
as much as possible. Look at the bright side of things; nothing is all
bad.

4) Chai tea and fruit smoothies. I would not be the same without them!

The goal is to rid your body of toxins, whether they are physical or
spritual. Once you do that, you will always be energized at parties
(or anywhere else) and always refreshed the next day at work.

If you're looking for a quick fix, then I don't know of one. My
suggestions take a long time to set in. If you already do this
stuff, then drink lots of coffee, and hope for the best :)

Glad to have met you @H3!, btw.

Steve the healthy raver

well I'd like to thank & congratulate the H3 promoters for producing a
lovely party. 
 
my highlites were...... 
 
the location / tent village...... 
 
hanging out in the small forest between the main room / tent city..........

 
the bubble boys in the morning......and the incredible bubbles they
produced 
 
throwing around the nerf bomb laughing, saying don't worry you can hear it
coming.........and having it hit some poor girl square on the head, and it
didn't even hurt her ......phew.........and having kenneth paul to throw it
back to me 
 
the chill space.......beautiful set-up and staging...... 
 
walking to the holocaust memorial building in the morning 
 
finding the groceries I dropped, thanks to some good folks....... 
 
dancing like a maniac to Major Major, for about 15 minutes....... 
 
room to dance 
 
hanging out with Tim 
 
hanging out with Wayne 
 
meeting Shawna 
 
meeting SFRavers and putting  faces to the names  
 
the happy tent (painted with glo paint) 
 
finding a group of english friends who are my age (well almost) so I felt I
had a clique of contemporaries to hang out with too !!! 
 
playing music outside during the late afternoon, and especially Jay Baum's
song "The Underground" (a rap track) and having people kind of get it. 
 
peeing in the forest (sorry greg :) 
 
drum circle 
 
people screaming in unison through-out the nite 
 
watching some real cool crazy wacky characture wearing a purple tam, having
the time of his life 
 
 
lowlites: 
 
forgetting the names of 3/4 of the people I met 
 
crappy gear 
 
missing mid-range on the main system 
 
missing the moonshadow song 
 
having my santa cruz conection pull a no show  
 
not having more of my friends there (FnF, BM, etc....) 
 
not hanging out with leslie 
 
security guards dressed in black miltant riot gear, with police batons
etc.... 
 
west coast break beat in the chill room 
 
I can't remember any more hi/lo-lites.....it mostly all highlites and good
times !!!! 
 
I think It will be a party that goes into my top list of 50 all time
parties......I am glad I went, and I got some great pictures .......... It
is a party that was attended by 2 other friends that were at a festival
called "Out There" in France, the Burning Man in Nevada, and a complete
social victory for the banished art of dancing in the streets, called
"Reclaim the Streets" in London,. Unfortunately for me, I have yet to go to
Goa, however  they were already both attending some of the same parties
there earlier this year........                                  
                                                                moonpup

On Mon, 16 Sep 1996, Steve Simitzis wrote:

> Things you should definitely do (or definitely consider):
> 
> 1) Change your diet. Try to eat only pure, healthy foods on a regular
> basis. You don't have to become a vegan, but it helps ;) Fruits and
> vegetables contain so much good life energy and nutrition. You'll feel
> bouncier after a few weeks of eating like this.
> 
> 2) Don't use drugs. Drugs leave behind sludge that you don't need in
> your brain. Learn to feel happy and fun without chemical
> enhancement. Extra bonus: There's no "coming down" from a natural
> high.

[snip]
> If you're looking for a quick fix, then I don't know of one. My
> suggestions take a long time to set in. If you already do this
> stuff, then drink lots of coffee, and hope for the best :)

	If one is going to give up/not eat or use the things mentioned 
above, then coffee is probably one of the least appriopate things to be 
adding to your body. This nice legal drug is as destructive on your 
digestive system and CNS as most any of what many people take in any 
scene, as well as being a diurectic which will add to ones dehydration 
quickly (although you will piss clear, after you're done, your body has 
purged itself of most of its water reserves, so if you go back to dance 
without taking a few big swigs, you're going to get dehydrated and 
dehydration weakens your body's ability to sense when things are 
invading)...

dave

>heres an attempt at a sort of music tree
>
>
>
>
>                                             sticks and rocks & other
>various bobbles
>                                                 /
>     |
>                      Europian -- folk --early              drums
>                     china etc....
>                  /                         /        gothic
>|                                         /
>                 |       john denver                             tribal
>                      eastern -- australia etc...
>                 |
> /            \                      /
>                 |                                                rhythm--

Er uh, this is some list....

I am not going to get into  who started what when.  Since man developed
grew and moved OUT of Africa some long time ago, I would think we could
easily assess that European musical form came sometime later...FAR AFTER
the aforementioned international styles....

Eurocentrism....puhleeze.

First came man, of course, from Africa.  Then came the beat. The rest is
history.

As far as American music goes, there are only two that were created on
these shores, Native American, and African (blues, jazz, call & signify).

(Jazz has been called the only true american art form...I agree.  Of course
there was blues and call & signify which are/is directly AFRICAN!).

The rest is certainly history.

I hate an  incomplete historical perspective.

Out,
John
