Harmony was truly something special!!

I thought I knew what to expect, but what happened that beautiful 
saturday night surpassed my wildest dreams. =)

A few highlights:

- Tim, your BBQ was perfect! Thank for providing all that food and 
slaving over the heat.

- Setting up with Mike, Adam, and Chin. Seeing the place tranform into
  a rave wonderland was incredible!

- Watching all the happy ravers arrive on the Harmony school buses,
  screaming and cheering =)

- Not being able to take three steps without encountering a smile!

- Finally getting to really chat with some of you SFRavers! (you know 
who you are)

- Hearing the main room go "Wuuump, Whuuump, Whummmp, Whummp, Boom, 
Boom, Boom" from the outside.

- Allegra piercing my soul with her voice.

- Catching Greg actually smiling a couple times =)
 
- Seeing all of YOU again!

Harmony's three year was amazing! New ravers were born, friendships 
were made, and together we were able to produce enough postive energy 
to fill a small country. I was glad to be a part of it, and may be 
suffering from afterglow for the rest of my life.

I love you all!!!

CT

Starchild posted early today:

>My computer tells me that on Fri, 13 Sep 1996, leftjab shared (in part):
>
>> I also believe that many of us have a spiritual view of raving, and despair
>> that too many people don't "get" it.  We want people to know that ravers
>> aren't sex-crazy, druggy teenagers --
>
>        You left out the people who are sex-crazy, druggy, *and*
>spiritual!  Come on leftjab, think Dionysus, Greek god of wine, dancing,
>orgies, and good times!
>        Getting in touch with God needn't be an experience of sitting
>Buddha-style in silence or kneeling in front of an altar while listening
>to organ music.
>        It can be getting in touch *physically* with that irresistable
>someone, or letting the beats do scandalous things with your body on a a
>crowded sweaty dancefloor as your mind flies around the room!
>
>Spiritually yours,
>                                <<< Starchild >>>

        Starchild's absolutely right . . . there's nothing wrong with being
sex-crazy, druggy, & spiritual (or a teenager, duh) . . . and I might've
exhibited all of these behaviors recently on my own spiritual quests :).

        Perhaps I should've said "just sex-crazy, druggy . . ." because
that description doesn't nearly cover the entirety of the scene.   It is
the prevalent media description, though, and from the reports of people who
attended the screening the focus of the Leeza show.  The media coverage of
the sensual and drug aspects of the scene should emphasize the spiritual
aspirations of many ravers, both those who partake and those who don't.


peace,

leftjab

I know I've already gone way over my bandwidth limit for the day... but
more memories are demanding to be shared... mostly triggered by Steve's
post (dammit, Steve - I read "I kick ass for the LORD" and laughed
uncontrollably at work for about 5 minutes - I think I drooled on my
XTerminal :)

... at the Harmony home, finding a frog which I had given to some
wonderful person at the Beautiful People on Mission, and being amazed at
the small world we live in ... being awakened after an hour of sleep by
fluorescent orange hair, and finding myself still bouncy and excited ... 
breakfast with Mattloaf and Blossom ... playing with a parrot & even
giving the parrot a mint ... getting peoples' names wrong ... petting a
beautiful person's hair backwards twice before getting it right ... having
to pee, then just dancing 'till it went away ... seeing freqout and
aleph1, familiar people in an unfamiliar setting ... crushing hugs upon
meeting Mattloaf's significant other ... Eric P's yummy peach & bread ...
a really really good smart drink ... the collective screaming ... hanging
out briefly in the little niche in the trees ... hugging random strangers
...  smiling up at people while lying on the side of the path staring at
the stars ... getting stickers stuck to me ... entrance duty, watching the
sun come up alone ... pancake in the morning ... being tickled by a
feather on a stick ... chai tea for the first time ... drinking a double
iced espresso and then falling asleep 2 minutes later ... realizing just
after hitting the send button that I spelled Caryn wrong in my last post
:) ... 

  I'm going to take a nap and head off to Mad, where I intend to collect
the missing hug from Matt Lanier!

Is there sound in space, a beat...I dunno....anyway I was talking about MAN
(Humankind) use of beats, not the universe.

Man is out of Africa.  Thus the development of the beat.

Of course you have to buy into certain rules of evolution, migration, etc.
But we know where we as humans came from, and it certainly didn't start in
Europe (although some good things come from there as well as everywhere
else).

Moon's chart was screwed anyway, not his intention.  So who knows what he
was really trying to say in just 72 columns! :)

cooler: yellow paper with thick black marker (I can still smell
it)

Definitely catch this one (not a BSP):

'Realize a World without Violence'
A Benefit

Help us continue our mission to server
free food on this city's streets

For our community
@ El Rio's 9/26 (Thursday)
9pm, Sliding scale admission

in solidarity with Food Not Bombs
415-985-7087

DRC
Mars
Mystr-E
DJ Tom (is that you Tom???)

I was seriously impressed by the simple, handmade flyer. It reminded
me of my hardcore/punk days when flyers like this would float around
all the time.

This is just a quick hello to introduce myself!  My name is Ariel and I
although I have met several sfravers (hi Adam, Steve, Todd, etc...), I am
new to the list as well as to this fair city!  Yes, I am a recent immigrant
from up north...I just moved down from Seattle where I was active in
what we *like* to call the party scene up there (although, Seattle only
WISHES it could compare to the community down here) as well as
NW-Raves, the regional list in for the Pacific NW.

Before I moved down a few weeks ago, I  was lucky enough to catch a
few choice parties on visits...I made it to MADNESS in May (that was fun
defined) and to a Beautiful People in August.  Since moving down to San
Fran (well, ahem, Hayward, to be exact) I've been lapping up the last of
the Harmony parties before they slip away (yes last weekend WAS tha
bomb).

So, there's my brief introduction.  Now I'll try to be quiet and just listen for
a while (quite difficult for me) till I get the hang of things here on the
list...although if anyone has any desire to discuss all things Seattle, let
me know!  I look forward to talking to everyone!

PLUR,
Ariel

At 11:43 PM -0700 9/14/96, Eric Pederson wrote:
>dear sfravers:
>
>i recently got back from vacation in NYC.  i promised a few people a trip
>report when i got back so here it is...
...
>in fact he had us on the guest list for the tunnel
>that weekend.  the tunnel is this massive club in chelsea that
>features junior vasquez as a resident doing these amazing 8 hour hard house
>sets.  anyway, when we got to the tunnel, it had been shut down
>by the city for 'creating a nuisance'.  the cops had bought drugs
>there a number of times and they implicated the owner of the club in
>the sales.  both the tunnel and the limelight are now shut down
>indefinitely.  it sucked cause i had always wanted to check out
>the limelight.
...
>the last weekend we had our hopes up that the tunnel would reopen
>but it didn't.  we also heard a rumor that all the names on the tunnel's
>guest list are now in FBI files!!  damn!

The Limelight should be closed. Their management and staff's ego alone
would justify the city/DEA/FBI closing the doors.

Marcy and I were in NYC around the end of June and I have never seen so
much attitude from club staff -- ever.

When you are on the "guest list" that means that you "only" pay $10 instead
of $15. No cameras are allowed, either. So I was forced to check my camera
in coat check. While we were down there the coat check person offered to
sell us some "X" but I refused. I already knew that the owner and staff of
the Limelight were dirty when I read that the DEA had busted them with 6000
hits of e just a few weeks earlier. This confirmed my suspicions that this
place sucked.

Anyway, we did the camera in the coat check routine and went back upstairs
to go through the metal detector gauntlet and found that we were going to
pay $10 each for the honor of being guest listed and said hell no.

We went immediately back downstairs and found that the ass behind the coat
check had taken out my camera's batteries and they were nowhere to be found
(2 AA's). So in the end, we got the "Limelight Experience" without even
actually having to go into such a poser venue.  It only cost us 5 minutes
and two batteries. It was a deal.

Other than this little blip on our NYC radar, we had a *great* time in NYC.
Lots of bar/lounge hopping, lots of record stores, lots of culture.

____________________________________________________________________________
 Wayne D. Correia            +1.415.826.6000            FAX +1.415.826.6100

Hey Everyone,

	Even though this has been my 1st real rave summer, I have become so
facinated with every aspect of the scene that I've been looking into
voluntering my time with the promoting and throwing of parties. But my
delema is who should I start working for? I only made this decision
early last week so right now part of my plan is to take a sort of
critical look at the parties that I go to in the next couple of weeks.
Who's throwing it? Whats the general feeling? Does this seem like the
kind of group I would want to work with?

My motives for becomming involved are very well intended. I feel that
being at a party that _you_ helped put together, standing back to see
and feel the vibe that you helped make possible would be a TOTALY
satisfying rush. :)

Does anyone have any advice? Anyone I should avoid? Do YOU need an extra
hard working person for your next party? I'm all ears....

Peace,

-=Pengo=-
Blake "Pengo" Merriam

Wayne, you write:
> The Limelight should be closed. Their management and staff's ego alone
> would justify the city/DEA/FBI closing the doors.
> 
> Marcy and I were in NYC around the end of June and I have never seen so
> much attitude from club staff -- ever.

<story of Slimelight snipped>

>  So in the end, we got the "Limelight Experience" without even
> actually having to go into such a poser venue.  It only cost us 5 minutes
> and two batteries. It was a deal.
> 
> Other than this little blip on our NYC radar, we had a *great* time in NYC

One of the funniest moments I had was when I was living in New York was
when I went to talk to -I have totally forgotten his name now- 
this supposed Slimelight bigwig because he needed promoters.  
I figured what the hell, I'd try to help him out...maybe at least 
I could get some friends in for free one night.   So we were all
put on the "guest list"...meaning as you said, $10 instead of $15.
What-EVER!  I'm promoting for them, and I'm supposed to PAY $10 to go?
We split right away of course.  But the funniest thing was talking to
him about it later...we started talking about being nice in general, and
he started giving me this lecture about "business, and being nice 
doesn't pay" and that someday I would "grow up and realize that 
that (being kind) just isn't the real world," and I would
have to become part of HIS world if I wanted to "get anywhere".  At that
point, I realized more than ever  
			1.  that I should get out of NYC ASAP
			(sorry, but this attitude was just so rampant there)
			2.  the HUGE differences between raves and
			clubs, and how I had no desire to ever "go
			clubbing" ever again...

    PrAiSe Be To RaVinG!!! ;o)

shamini

> my time with the promoting and throwing of parties.

What are you, some kind of nutcase?

>But my
>delema is who should I start working for?

That's not your only dilemma.  Grab the yellow pages, turn to S for Shrink,
and have your head checked!    Drop the idea before it gets too big,
otherwise, intensive therapy might be your only hope.  Let someone else
throw the parties and pay the lousy $20 to get in, at least you'll have a
good time.   Otherwise you'll be dealing with debts, cops, paperwork, dirty
warehouses and entire weekends without sleep.

Run while you still can, kid.




OK, you're going to work for anyone, I recommend the BeautPeop/Harmony
folks.  I've heard rumors that they're very solid, decent caring folks.
And they throw a heck of a party, if you haven't yet been.









Peter Sandifer

Precedence: bulk

At 11:45 AM -0700 9/17/96, Pengo wrote:

>Does anyone have any advice? Anyone I should avoid? Do YOU need an extra
>hard working person for your next party? I'm all ears....


I think the single most effective way of showing your sincere committment
to helping a group, short of offering a sound system for free =), is to
stay and help clean up a party.  I can't express in words how difficult it
is sometimes to clean a party, especially big ones like this past weekend's
Harmony, after working for 24 hours straight.  (Imagine picking up the
thousands of cig. butts that were scattered all over creation on that
field.)

It's relatively ungratifying, for their isn't that pre-party rush once the
party is over, but it has to be done.  When people stay and help it truly
is like having a little elf come and sweep a floor or do something else
that in the back of a groups collective mind is one more thing that needs
to be done.

It takes time to establish trust, and so investing your time and energy is
what you must do.  It is, as you say, a rush to know that some of you is in
the party.

That's why I do it.  In fact "I just did it, and I'm gonna do it again!"  =)

TONE

Just thought I'd add that helping out at a party is a *lot* of grunt
work. At H3, I was exhausted before the party had even started. If
you're going to do it, be prepared to get dirty, sweaty, and tired. And
also be prepared to be sweeping rave-spooge at 8 in the morning.

[snip]
> 
> > OK, you're going to work for anyone, I recommend the BeautPeop/Harmony folks.  I've heard rumors that they're very solid, decent caring folks.
> > And they throw a heck of a party, if you haven't yet been.
> 
> Yea I was at Harmony3. What can you say? It was killer!
> 

The Harmony people are very cool, and very receptive to having people help
out with their parties.

Also, if you're ever interested in throwing your own event someday,
helping out even with grunt work is a good way to see what goes on
behind the scenes before actually leaping into it.

Steve

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Sep 17 13:09:57 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id NAA12789; Tue, 17 Sep 1996 13:09:57 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from acergw3.acer.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with ESMTP id NAA12782; Tue, 17 Sep 1996 13:09:53 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from smtplink.acer.com ([204.160.139.137]) by acergw3.acer.com (8.7.3/8.7.3) with SMTP id NAA26672 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Tue, 17 Sep 1996 13:06:22 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from ccMail by smtplink.acer.com (SMTPLINK V2.11.01)
	id AA842991242; Tue, 17 Sep 96 13:02:06 pst
Date: Tue, 17 Sep 96 13:02:06 pst
From: "Andy Wyszkowski" <awyszkow@smtplink.acer.com>
Message-Id: <9608178429.AA842991242@smtplink.acer.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Dear Abby style emotional haul... 
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     
     I was asking about this a couple weeks ago amongst some old friends, 
     with mixed responses.
     
     Does anybody here get some heavy mood swings (dancing alone in my room 
     totally groovin to the new Hardfloor to sitting reading depressing 
     history books by myself until 4am on weeknights.. while remembering I 
     really should call my folks more often but it's too late and I'm just 
     plain a little lame) after raving or raveing?
     
     Raving:
     If it hit one sober, I usually notice I just feel kinda afterglow the 
     next day, and get a little uppity that next evening, or kinda bummed 
     if I don't find something to do.  As a general rule I have to stay 
     pretty busy.  My house usually gets pretty clean the first couple days 
     of the week after a good one.  I wouldn't say it's downright 
     depressing, but I do tend to get bored easier, as well as have some 
     trouble sleeping, even though I might be tired.
     
     RavEing:
     My oh my.  Mood swings bigger, more intense, but easier to deal with 
     in a way because they're easier to justify (its the chemicals man..).  
     They also fade in slower.  Seems like 2-4 days after the event 
     (usually I'm still wicked grinning the day after).  Feel like spending 
     mucho time with other people, solitude is somewhat depressing.  Work 
     is a pain in the ass, but do-able.  Coffee is great at the onset, but 
     coming down or jonesing for coffee seems to turn me into a evil 
     bastard.  Same with hunger.  Driving in traffic after working all day 
     becomes very difficult (I've still got that LA wild hair) without 
     reaching for the glovebox (just kidding).  I get major munchie attacks 
     (my pantry got cleaned out just last night actually).  In general, I 
     have to struggle to fight off the very tendencies I'm so I feel so far 
     away from when on E.  I tend to snap, judge, and decide too quickly.  
     It DOES teach me restraint that serves me for a much longer time (i.e. 
     full blown positive personality modifications have been noticed since 
     I started raving), but it kinda freaks me out.
     
     Has anybody noticed a cycle like this?  The tendency exists for me 
     whether or not chems are involved, but it's much more profound in the 
     post chem state.  It's just that there's so many facets to raving, 
     with the sleep deprivation, the sense of community, the marathon 
     dancing, the socializing, the relaxed society, hugging and I almost 
     always go all night.
     
     Is it that after having so good a time everything else seems mundane?  
     Is it that I need to find the elements in raving I find the most joy 
     in and bring them into my day to day life (good morning boss!  skip 
     skip skip ... hug.  Here's the schedule for the next two quarters... 
     want a sticker?).  Is it that I really am stuck in a pretty 
     suppressing environment (San Jose, PC Manufacturing Company, ties, 
     reports, no veggie stuff in cafeteria, ewww) and need out (this theory 
     does hold major water for me right now).
     
     Sorry for being bum, I just know some of you have gone through this 
     crud before.
     
     Love,
     AndyW
     
     Mindlessly spewing emotion at the multiverse... until my old best 
     friends get here to help me celebrate my 25th B-day this weekend (that 
     could be it too...).  You all have to meet them as they are fucking 
     BYOOTEEEFULLL!!!  Any recommendations for vibeiest event for this 
     weekend?  I have only Friday and Saturday night to show them the 
     splendor of SF.

From: FringeWare News Network <email@Fringeware.COM>

Subject: ADMIN - FringeWare returns

Sent from: FringeWare News Network <info@fringeware.com>

Dear Friends,

If you've wondered why you haven't heard much out of
FringeWare over the past few months, here's our story:

The Earth is a harsh mistress, and consequently we have
lost everything, even the backups. Four years worth of
everything -- but we've come back, perhaps even stronger
than before.

End of story. Or, rather, a nuther beginning...

Now we'd like to make contact with all the kind beings
who've participated in this Internet discourse over the 
past few years. All that we have to start from is a very 
old version of our email list and press release list.

You may receive a couple copies of this message, depending
on whether we've known you by different email addresses in
the past.

Please disregard this message if you don't wish to hear 
>from us further.


If you do wish to hear from us further, then take a 
peek at:

	http://www.fringeware.com/msg/

or send the message SUBSCRIBE to our infobot at:

	info@fringeware.com


Quite obviously we're going to miss contact with many
assorted sentients who might care to be included -- so 
please tell your friends and help spread the news.

We apologise for the inconvenience, and welcome your
resumed participation in the fray.

Thanx -

pxn
FringeWare Inc.
http://www.fringeware.com

Date: Tue, 17 Sep 1996 13:35:25 -0700
Message-Id: <199609172035.NAA02489@dfw-ix10.ix.netcom.com>
From: ascend@ix.netcom.com (Gregory Sandler )
Subject: Harmony's responce and thank you!!! (H3)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hello sfraves!,

    Well, well, well... I have finally gotten the brainpower to do 
this!! So, here it goes!!!

    A big, giant, f**king galactic size thank you to everyone who 
helped out with that party!!! It took close to 150 people to set that 
up, work and tear down!!! That is completly insane!!! (usually it's 10 
- 50 people) I thank every single one of you for your devotion to 
making the 3 year happen. Even though I missed the meeting on Wed., 
even though I might have been a little stressed (and hard to deal 
with), you guys pulled it off!!! I love all of you!!! It is a really 
good sign to know that the community can come together and help Harmony 
become the reality it is!!! Thank you!!!

    Now a super-sized, ultra loud shout of thank you to everyone who 
came and supported the 3 year, and our goals. We wanted to achieve 
complete "Harmony" between the performers, the promoters, the djs, the 
crowd, the surrounding nature, and everything else that was a part of 
the event. We achieved our goal! The sounds of everyone screaming in 
unison, the positive vibe that you could not get away from, and energy 
that was surrounding the camp was incredible!!! We are proud to say, 
that in a unanimous vote, you guys made the 3 year anniversary of 
Harmony, the best party we have ever thrown!!! We are very thankful to 
all of you, and the rest of the Harmony family!!! We love you!!!

    This party was in the works for almost a year, it was such a rush 
to see our dreams unfolding before our eyes. Being responcible for that 
event, was the greatest feeling that I (and the rest of the crew) have 
ever felt. We didn't make any money, (I am pretty sure we didn't lose 
any money) but that is definately not our concern. The 3 year was our 
last big Harmony (or at least for a long, long time). We weren't 
concerned about the $, in fact we were planning on losing $, but by 
some stroke of luck we didn't!! Anyways, what I am trying to say is 
that being the promoter of that party was simply incredible!!! (and I 
speak for the entire Harmony crew when I say that!) 

    The total budget for those of you who care was about $21,000 (give 
or take $500 or so). The total revenues of the event just barely 
covered that price. (this includes the water money) So, this was the 
highest budget party that Harmony has ever put together, and it paid 
off!!! Thanks to everyone!!!

    As for the future of Harmony itself, that's a tough one to talk 
about. Seeing what occured last Sat. really left a tremendous impact on 
the crew. Harmony Productions will still be throwing parties, (we can't 
stop, and will keep going until the last raver on Earth says, "I had 
enough!"). Look for all the "Beautiful People" parties, as well as 
"Hunny", "Tigger" (which is Omar's benefit), and more to be announced!! 
So stay tooned in to what we are doing, cause we aren't done yet!! As 
far as the actual party called "Harmony", I believe that was the last 
one, but only time will tell...

    Well, we all had a really great time on Saturday and hope that you 
did as well! It was a blast!!!

Peace and positivity!!!

Greg :)

Ps: if you lost anything from the party please let us know we have a 
lot of stuff, including a car stereo, so call us!!! (408)486-9591

To: "Andy Wyszkowski" <awyszkow@smtplink.acer.com>

Subject: Re: Dear Abby style emotional haul...
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

Andy,
Wow.  This is way cosmic.   I was thinking about sending out a similar
message  just *an hour ago*, asking if anyone felt mood swings in the way
I've noticed them.   But the I thought, nah, who'd care?   In the last
couple of years, I've noticed a cyclical mood pattern, on a monthly basis,
something akin to a woman's cycle.  'Ceptin', of course that I ain't a
lady.

My body follows the moon cycles, I'm sure of it.  I know when a full moon
is coming without looking at the calendar.  About a week before the full
moon I go through a phase of giddiness, then a few days of clarity and
focus right around the full moon, and then, sadly enough, I spend about 2
weeks or so in a sort of unfocused, mixed up state of mind.

I guess my only reassurance is that I feel GREAT right around the full mon,
and that I know the feeling will be back in another month.  Of course the
coffee/chemi/crack/Coors and crank throw another wrench into the
mechanism...something to be careful of if our bodies have peculiar
reactions to outside pollutants.

But, something to think about...our bodies are, what? 95% water?  If the
moon is strong enough to control the tides, surely it must have some sort
of affect on our wee bodies.

It was pretty damn weird to see your post right after thinking about
sending out one of the same theme.  Ever read "The Celestine Prophecies"?
Hmmm....Our psychic energies are starting to link up.

As a test, try to keep clean for a month, and follow the moon cycles on
your calendar.

Evolve.

b))merang

oh, yes...

i've been noticing a hard comedown after raving, too.

absolutely it has everything to do with raves being a lot of fun and
work/day-to-day shit not being very fun at all.

and i also begin to realize how alone i feel when i'm not with good
friends. this is, i think, a combination of, on the one hand, a real
loneliness which i was comfortable ignoring until i found a group of loving
people via raving, and, on the other hand, a very real side effect/flip
side of E (for me, at least.)

but i've always felt bummed a few days after a really fun event... i used
to go to jazz festivals to perform with my high school band, and a couple
days after a good one, i would just feel way down.

maybe we should form an after-party support group. :)
(wait a minute, that might actually be a good idea... any takers?)

love,

brian

At 3:48 PM -0700 9/17/96, Brian Denny wrote:

>but i've always felt bummed a few days after a really fun event... i used
>to go to jazz festivals to perform with my high school band, and a couple
>days after a good one, i would just feel way down.


We in the medical community call this:  PHD -- Post Hedonism Depression.
It's a very real disorder and one that can only be cured by more hedonism!!
=)

I too suffer from this dastardly syndrome, but it's much easier to conquer
with a warm bath and a lover by your side.

Seriously though, drugs fuck with the naturally occuring drugs in your
body.  You're altering the balance of your own egosystem.  As has been
mentioned before, there are about as many recipes for post-raving cures as
for hangovers, howevere unlike my cure for a hangover (drink more beer =),
I find Tyrosine to work well in helping to resort my emotional balance
after raving.

Peace and pissing!

Tone

	id AA843002999; Tue, 17 Sep 96 16:18:27 pst
Date: Tue, 17 Sep 96 16:18:27 pst
From: "Andy Wyszkowski" <awyszkow@smtplink.acer.com>
Message-Id: <9608178430.AA843002999@smtplink.acer.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re[2]: Laminates on hyperreal site?
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     
     Okay...
     
     You can buy the ones Adam has (beautiful SFRAVES with kind of an 
     intelligent green lights blasting out from behind the black 
     background, but I'm always afraid to come near him... I've seen how 
     nuts he is with those glow sticks).
     
     Laminate making for the DYI SF-Raver....
     
     You'll need 
     *   One PC/Mac/Workstation
     *   One groovin graphics program (some shareware ones are pretty damn 
     clean)
     *   A diskette
     *   A local kinko's
     *   An idea of what you want to do.  Ideas are all over, think of fave 
     personalities, images, hallucinations, or designs.  Keep the SFRAVES 
     part of it central so you don't lose the benefit of having a laminate.
     
     Make a design.  Rather than actually create art, I take other people's 
     stuff and tweak it till it's better (visual sampling?).  I try to work 
     everything out so I'm looking at a 2" x 3" thing.  I mess with it for 
     hours.  I make sure it says SFRAVES in big letters somewhere on it, 
     and look fuckin weird from far away so people have to see what it is.  
     I finally feel satisfied.  I save the file to the diskette of love.
     
     I carry the diskette of love to Kinko's, where I start up their 
     beautiful PC complete with outdated versions of many popular programs 
     (including Corel 4.0, my programs of choice as Kinko's goes).  Within 
     5 minutes, you can log in, log out, and print.  (The timer on the 
     computer is how long you use it, not how long it takes the printer.)
     
     Now stand indignantly by the printer and wait anxiously for your 
     handiwork to come screaming out (use the best/most expensive printer 
     they have).  I recommend having your design print both sides of your 
     laminate to one peice of paper (time, ink and paper saving!).
     
     Now it's arts and crafts time.  Go to the table with the scissors... 
     you know the one.  Cut out the front side of your beautiful design.  
     Use that as a template for cutting out the other side so they match 
     perfectly.  Now paste them together.  Okay, it's not paste... use the 
     gluestick.  Not too much...
     
     Walk to the counter, and ask to have them laminated.  Punch a hole in 
     it.  You are now badass.  Pick your favorite string, or chain and 
     sling that puppy up.  Wear it everywhere.  Scare your coworkers and 
     classmates.  Tell the world you made it, because you did.
     
     The whole thing should cost you about $3.42 or so.  The expensive part 
     is misprints or time spent on the PC... so keep these to a minimum 
     (plus smile in knowing you saved a branch or two!).  Do as much of the 
     work as you can at home.
     
     If you want to do more than one, you save a lot of money.  Also 
     remember to never try to print within half an inch of the paper's 
     borders (more on some printers).
     
     I think the coolest part of this is you can do it at 4:00am, as 
     certain Kinkos have 24 hour desktop publishing.  Perfect for an 
     inspired moment.
     
     AndyW
     
     P.S.       I hadn't seen Michal's SF Raves T Shirt till this 
     weekend... MUCHO BADASS!!!!

On Tue, 17 Sep 1996, Brian Denny wrote:

> absolutely it has everything to do with raves being a lot of fun and
> work/day-to-day shit not being very fun at all.

  For me, this required an outlook change about a year ago.  I had been
experiencing something similar to this - where I would go through an
intense, wonderful experience and then be down for awhile.  About a year
ago, I started to realize that intense, beautiful experiences were
anywhere and everywhere I looked for them.  I no longer need a thousand
beautiful people and 50,000 watts of sound system as an excuse to smile
(though they are a fantastic reason to do so!)  There is beauty everywhere
(to me), and all I had to do was open my eyes a bit - take the time to
enjoy *everything*.

  By sheer coincidence, my signature file is currently displaying a brief
summary of this philosophy.  Cool!

** please note that i'm not trying to preach in any way - just relating my
   own experience!

  I hope everyone is having a great day so far, by the way!  *hugs* to
you all!

: : J. David Lowe :: dlowe@best.com :: http://www.best.com/~dlowe/ : :

::               experience wonder at the mundane....               ::

On Tue, 17 Sep 1996, Brian Denny wrote:

> oh, yes...
>

> work/day-to-day shit not being very fun at all.

	i have the same thing happen. i used to go on vacations to far-off
places and coming home inspired the same feeling of loss, depression, and
a small sort of emptiness. but it always seemed very natural and i always
accepted it. what do the high's mean without the low's? you have a great
time and when it's over, you miss it. it doesn't mean i can't enjoy my
life in general, just that, when i have a great time and it's over, i tend


> maybe we should form an after-party support group. :)
> (wait a minute, that might actually be a good idea... any takers?)
	
	that sounds like a wonderful idea. perhaps a post-rave gathering
at someone's house. a place to talk, relax, nap, eat, and just be after a
rave with some friends sounds like a nice way to end a rave weekend. you
hang out as long as you feel like or is convenient for the host. then when
you're really ready to go home, you do. and if not, maybe you can convince
the host to adopt you. ;)



-stan

Well, I know as soon as I move there, I will definately be up for 
something like that.  At least I have people to hang out with and let Mel 
and me crash at their place (namely Jon Logan and Wayne Correia).  Often 
there'd be at least 5 other people konked out as well.  I used to have to 
drive all the way back to Sacramento right after a rave and go to bed all 
by myself as I listen to the rest of my family clanging around doing 
their Sunday things.  I yearned for comedown company!

((xlr8r & The Gathering)) * Hall of Flowers at 9th & Lincon in Golden Gate

Gathering in front of city hall ((as part of the canabis expo fair)) rates
as one of my better moments from 1995. This time around I don't even mind
shelling out $8 for 3 hours of music because I believe in supporting this
particalar cause.

>From smith@newton.gis.saic.com Tue Sep 17 17:49 EDT 1996

>

 A boy was crossing a road one day when a frog called out to him
 and said, "If you kiss me, I'll turn into a beautiful princess".  He
 bent over, picked up the frog and put it in his pocket.

 The frog spoke up again and said, "If you kiss me and turn me back into
 a beautiful princess, I will stay with you for one week."  The boy took
 the frog out of his pocket, smiled at it and returned it to the pocket.

 The frog then cried out, "If you kiss me and turn me back into a
 princess, I'll stay with you and do ANYTHING you want." Again the
 boy took the frog out, smiled at it and put it back into his pocket.

 Finally, the frog asked, "What is the matter? I've told you I'm a
 beautiful princess, that I'll stay with you for a week and do
 anything you want. Why won't you kiss me?"

 The boy said, "Look I'm an engineer.  I don't have time for a
 girlfriend, but a talking frog is cool."



------- End of Forwarded Message

>> maybe we should form an after-party support group. :)
>> (wait a minute, that might actually be a good idea... any takers?)
>
>        that sounds like a wonderful idea. perhaps a post-rave gathering
>at someone's house. a place to talk, relax, nap, eat, and just be

hey, let's not forget _hug_!

yeah, the couple of times that i've gone to hang out with people after
raving have been really nice.

i don't know about anyone else, but i'm never ready to be alone after a
rave... having 1 or 2 or 5 people to revel in ravE afterglow with is really
nice, and i think the lack of that experience is one of the things that
made the comedowns so difficult for me after the last couple of parties i
attended.

so anyway, i don't know when the next rave i'm going to be attending is,
but we should definitely try to put something together, perhaps
ahead-of-time.

love and HUGS,

brian

   _Groove_ - techno w/DJs Dreamer, Carlos, special guests. 10pm-?, $5.
   415.437.6905
   
   _Step Off_ - acid jazz, trip hop w/DJs Mark Farina, Miquel, Julius
   Papp. begins September 18th
   21+. the EndUp, 6th & Harrison, SF.

Info Lines

     * Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087. Usually has 5-10 listings, updated
       daily.
     * the Buzz-line, a global party network - 415.568.1338
     * Clubline - 415.979.8686
     * Fatline - 415.207.3668
     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * The Groove Line - (415) 331.1500 ext.4788
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - the Uncle Noah TV Show - the best
       in Techno and House music. 3-5am, KDVS 90.3fm (Davis)
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * Saturday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. and
       Monkeywrench KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

On Thursday, September 26, there will be a techno/trance benefit for SF Food
Not Bombs and the Prisioners' Literature Project.

DJs include D.R.C., Mars, Mystr-e, and DJ Tom.

Cost will be 3-$5, sliding scale.  No one turned away for lack of funds.
There will lots of vegitarian food.

I have been on this list for about two weeks, and really like the vibe.  I
hope to meet some of you there.  Much to my dismay, I had to miss harmony.  :>(

If you have any questions, feel free to email me (or reply to the list).

Hi Everybody,

Time to introduce myself. My name is Rudi and I just moved to the
Bay Area a few months ago. Ive been reading this mailing list for
around a week now. I moved to Santa Clara from Rochester, New York. I
moved to Rochester from the island of Mauritius (look it up on a map)
and finally I moved to Mauritius from Sheffield, UK.

I wasnt at harmony and I probably wont make it to a rave in the next few
months :( but watch out for me in December :->

Im into all forms of dance music and I love to dance. I am drug free,
nicotine free and recently stopped drinking alcohol. Ive never been to a
rave so I look forward to joining all of you wonderful folks from
SF-Raves in a few months.

I figured this little piece of humor was a good excuse for me to join
the fun. Anyways I take offense to that joke ... Im an engineer and I
have plenty of time for a girlfriend (oh wow !!) :)

>  anything you want. Why won't you kiss me?"

From: The Laffin Happy Trip Farmer <shawna-@ix.netcom.com>
Subject: Re: Dear Abby style emotional haul...
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>i've been noticing a hard comedown after raving, too.
>
>absolutely it has everything to do with raves being a lot of fun and
>work/day-to-day shit not being very fun at all.
>
>and i also begin to realize how alone i feel when i'm not with good
>friends. this is, i think, a combination of, on the one hand, a real
>loneliness which i was comfortable ignoring until i found a group of loving
>people via raving, and, on the other hand, a very real side effect/flip
>side of E (for me, at least.)



It's funny, but I rarely ever get depressed after a party, drugs or no
drugs, I think it's only happened a couple times, and that was a result of
actual personal problems that had occurred at the time.  I do love, however,
getting a group of my favorite people and hanging out at a friend's house
(yay BK! :), but I still find that upon occasion I just want to be alone
after a party.  Sometimes there is so much external stimulation and so much
happening constantly at a party, that afterwards I often want to be alone to
be allowed to "digest" everything I've experienced, to just mull it over,
especially when I have to go to work on Monday, which is usually the case.
Gotta get in that digestion & relaxation by myself before having to go in on
Monday & deal with the real world!  I do occasionally have trouble dealing
with the real world if I'm really tired at work, which is often the case
after a party (altho I am almost alarmed to admit that I was less tired at
work this Monday after Harmony and ingesting more types of partee favors in
larger quantity, than I usually am after a more normal party on a Monday. :/
So who knows, guess it differs from person to person.  Of course, this is
only when it's my choice to be alone.  It kinda sucks when I want to hang
out with people after a party and I hafta go home alone! :P
Anybody else here like to hang out a bit alone upon occasion after a party
to digest the events of the weekend? Or am I a Freak of Nature for feeling
this way? (no snotty comments, stan! ;)  


Love,
Shawna

            
          Do not go gentle into that good night!
         Rave! Rave into the dawning of the light!

> 25 Ways to cope with stress
> 
> l. Jam miniature marshmallows up your nose and sneeze them out. See how many
> you can do at a time.
> 2. Use your Master card to pay your Visa, and vice-versa.
> 3. Pop some popcorn without putting the lid on.
> 4. When someone says "Have a nice day", tell them you have other plans.

> 6. Dance naked in front of your pets.
> 7. Put your toddler's clothes on backwards and send him to pre-school as if
> nothing is wrong.
> 8. Fill out your tax form using Roman Numerals.
> 9. Tape pictures of your boss on watermelons and launch them from high
> places.
> 10. Leaf through "National Geographic" and draw underwear on the natives.
> 11. Tattoo "Out to Lunch" on your forehead.

> 13. Buy a subscription to "Sleazoid Weekly" and send it to your boss's
> husband/wife.
> 14. Pay your electric bill in pennies.
> 15. Drive to work in reverse.
> 16. Find out what a frog in a blender really looks like.
> 17. Tell your boss to "blow it out your mule", and let him figure it out.
> 18. Sit naked on a shelled hard-boiled egg.
> 19. Polish your car with earwax.
> 20. Read the dictionary upside down and look for secret messages.
> 21. Start a nasty rumor and see if you recognize it when it comes back to
> you.
> 22. Braid the hairs in each nostril.
> 23. Write a short story using alphabet soup.
> 24. Stare at people through the tines of a fork and pretend they're in jail.
> 25. Make a language up and ask people for directions in it.
> Bonus: Replace the filling of a Twinkie with ketchup and put it back in the
> wrapper.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Sep 18 09:27:04 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id JAA28253; Wed, 18 Sep 1996 09:27:04 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from xanadu.cyborganic.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with ESMTP id JAA28245; Wed, 18 Sep 1996 09:27:01 -0700 (PDT)
Received: (from tsheets@localhost) by xanadu.cyborganic.net (8.7.5/8.7.1) id JAA16450; Wed, 18 Sep 1996 09:26:59 -0700 (PDT)
From: Troy Sheets <tsheets@xanadu.cyborganic.net>
Message-Id: <199609181626.JAA16450@xanadu.cyborganic.net>
Subject: the rave "Spin"
To: socal-raves@ucsd.edu
Date: Wed, 18 Sep 1996 09:26:59 -0700 (PDT)
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL25]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I am always curious to see how our underground scene sometimes bubbles up
into the mainstream...

Has anyone checked out the latest issue of Spin, with the big story
on electronic music?

Haha, they are trying really hard to make underground electronic music
commercially viable.  I think most people know that to make big money,
the music industry needs a few bands that they can mass-market.  That
way they can make millions of CDs and ship them out over their finely-tuned
distrobution networks to Towers, Blockbusters, Sam Goodies, and Best Buys
around the world.

So, the article opens up with (what else) the Organic concert that was in
Big Bear... you know, the one with all the big "rave" bands.  They talked
about how a kroq dj was introducing the bands (but the selectively failed
to mention how most people booed him and kroq).

The go on in a pretty boring article talking about those bands that are really
big now, but who most ravers are pretty sick of... chemical bros, Goldie,
loop guru, Underworld.  All with big, colorful pictures of the bands 
(Ohhhh, ahhh!)

I once read in a article about a cynical Punk fan that the bands that
become really big out of a subculture are those which are universally 
recognized in the subculture to suck.

Now, sure, Orbital is pretty cool.  But In Sides and Snivilizaiton are pretty
weak compared to Orbital 1 and 2... and don't even get me started about
the Orb...  

Now, I didn't read the whole article, but I didn't see anything about DJ
culture... or mixtape culture.  That is what our scene is all about, yet
they completely gloss over it.  You just can't mass-market dj culture.
You need big names.  big stars.  big egos...

The only place i have seen mention of DJs and mixtapes in a mainstream
publication was on the MTV web site... a story done by socal's own
Tamara P.

Also, I saw no mention of recreational drugs...  Yes, they are trying
to create the clean-cut, mass-marketable, "sanitized" culture that the
rave scene isn't.  Personally, and remember, this is just IMHO, the
rave scene is a vehical for spreading the mind-expanding qualities of
certian recreational drugs.  No mainstream media would talk about the
positive effects lsd or mdma has on our culture.  So they filter all out.

The result?  BOOOORRRRIIINNGGGG!!!!  Everytime rave culture surfaces in
the mainstream, it sucks.  Who would be into this kind of sanitized
electronic music culture?  I mean, who is really into Chemical Brothers
CDs?  Yeah, I bought one... like 9 months ago!  The sound is pretty darn
stale now... yet it is the next cool thing according to Spin... yeah right.

I think we are pretty safe in the underground... safe from exploitation
by the mainstream.

Thanks for the rant time,

-troy

hello cosmic family,

like it says up there, i will be in SF Oct 4-6.  i'm not sure what's going
on for parties and stuff, i'm just going with the flow on that but i would
really love to get together and talk about
Conscious Manifestation with anyone who may be interested.  Conscious
Manifestation is a process of self-discovery and learning how to use the
combined powers of mind-emotion/spirit/physicality in balance with each
other to  create magic.  i am a student and nothing turns me on more
(except for enjoying the results of my process) than sharing what i've
learned and watching other people get turned on by it, ask shawna :)  let
me know what you think...i can't wait to see you :)

lots of love,

brenda

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Sep 18 10:46:30 1996

X-Mailer: Novell GroupWise 4.1
Date: Wed, 18 Sep 1996 10:46:22 -0700
From: Ariel Stallings <ASTALLINGS@gcwf.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject:  Re: after-party support group -Reply
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

One of my first introductions to the SF scene was hanging out with a
group of kids at Beautiful People, and as the night wound its way
into morning, one of them approached me and said "You will, of
course, be cracking out with us today, right?"

Me, being unused to the lingo was like, "Uh, crack out?" thinking
"EW!! Oh god!  They all do e at night and then the sun comes up and
they start smoking CRACK!  Oh shit!"  Thankfully, it was explained
that what they meant was just be spun and unwind together...go back
to someone's apt. or house and fit as many people on beds/couches/
floors as possible and just RELAX, REFLEX and SNOOZE.  (well, and
maybe a bowl or two for good measure).  I had never experienced such
a thing (how many times have I left a party and showered and gone to
WORK?  Ug!  Talk about MOOD SWING) and found that "cracking out" with
my friends was almost as enjoyable as the rave itself!

Now the idea of going home and being ALONE after a party seems
unthinkable!

Ariel

> stale now... yet it is the next cool thing according to Spin... yeah right.
> 

Live 105 is doing the same thing.  They play Chem. Bros. and I've heard
the Prodigy, too.  I don't know who they are exactly marketing too, but
obviously there is some kind of developing market.  I think it is just
going toget worse,too, because there *is* a burgeoning market.  I mean, look at
the clubs.  Most people aren't "ravers", but they sure are familiar with
all the big names and the music.  And the youth, that is where the big
money comes from.  So, although you see this sound as stale, there appears
to be a market in existence that is moving forward with great force.

-kc

On Wed, 18 Sep 1996, KaySEE wrote:

> > The result?  BOOOORRRRIIINNGGGG!!!!  Everytime rave culture surfaces in
> > the mainstream, it sucks.  Who would be into this kind of sanitized
> > electronic music culture?  I mean, who is really into Chemical Brothers
> > CDs?  Yeah, I bought one... like 9 months ago!  The sound is pretty darn
> > stale now... yet it is the next cool thing according to Spin... yeah right.
> > 
> 
> Live 105 is doing the same thing.  They play Chem. Bros. and I've heard
> the Prodigy, too.  I don't know who they are exactly marketing too, but
> obviously there is some kind of developing market.  I think it is just
> going toget worse,too, because there *is* a burgeoning market. 

I guess I bought the Chemical Brothers several months ago too, but they
still don't cease to move me. So I guess I'm still into it. I guess I
still like the Prodigy too. Does this mean I like what is yesterday's
news? "Oh nooooooo!!!" 
If - those mainstream people- start liking it, there's probably a reason 
why, more power to them, 'cause unless you're the superhero of cool you 
maybe were once one too. I mean, everyone starts somewhere. I sure had 
a lame-o beginning that is taboo in the "Land of the Truly Hip".
Sure you can bemoan the loss of underground culture, because somehow 
those in our modern society like to think of ourselves as individualists, 
when really what is true is quite the opposite.
"Are we relegated to the likes of grunge!?? Green Day?!?!! Oh god..."
Music can be a true communicator.
If our scene truly upholds particular ideals, then should we be 
separatist? If we yearn to be inclusive, if we yearn to love. Is that 
what we're about? 
So live by example and show what's up.

By the way. Do you really read Spin and listen to Live 105?


rebecca.

     Well DeepFog, my fave dance step:
     
     How often do I find myself in 'the trance'... which is that part where 
     I almost fall over because so much epic shit just blew through my 
     head.  This is usually after one of those soul cleansing builds that 
     just blows up and leaves you with almost nothing beatwise, except for 
     a real epic buzz, and the sense of opening your eyes to all you fellow 
     travelers (LOVE YOU).. Of course I immediately resume with the ass 
     shaking, arm swinging, leg twitching spasms some bravely call dancing 
     as soon as all centers report full functionality again.
     
     I would recommend telling those concerned parties:  I dance, and it 
     feels good.
     
     Oh... and scary would be:
     "Keoki-mania is sweeping the nation... 13 year old girls are fainting 
     at his very presence.  The new hot gift this Christmas is the 
     Kara-Keoki, a play along portable CD player that allows the user to 
     push one of four buttons (Wailing Diva, Doubled Up Kick, Billion Note 
     per second drum roll, and 303 Riff) along with specially made Keoki & 
     Friends CD's (sold separately).  It also comes with a custom paint 
     job, featuring pictures of the superstar DJ, and one in five come with 
     a rare collector's edition action figure, complete with fury scratchin 
     grip and a ozite carpeted lunch box that looks like a DJ coffin."
     
     Where do I get one?

On Wed, Sep 18, 1996 9:26:59 AM  at Troy Sheets wrote:

>CDs?  Yeah, I bought one... like 9 months ago!  The sound is pretty darn 
>stale now... yet it is the next cool thing according to Spin... yeah

Troy, I havn't seen the article, and I'm sure I would agree on all aspects,
but I will point out that yes while the Chemical Bros, is a worn out cd
now, they have helped create a lot of new london/uk  break beat dj's and
artists...... I was in london this summer and the new sound is not only goa
trance, drum & bass, and jungle (also old hat by now......) chemical
brothers are at the forefront of a new sound called london breakbeat......
it's related to the west coast breakbeat sound but has less 303 action and
more variety in the acid sound efx. 
 
                            just my 2c worth    moonpup

>>> Rebecca Klassen <rdk4@axe.humboldt.edu> 09/18/96 12:09pm >>>
If our scene truly upholds particular ideals, then should we be 
separatist? If we yearn to be inclusive, if we yearn to love. Is that  what
we're about?  So live by example and show what's up.

rebecca.
>>>

This is SO exactly it!  Every time I catch myself at a >>club<< thinking
"Ew, check out THEM...they like to THINK they can dance, but they don't
know the TRUE JOYS OF THE UNDERGROUND." I have to stop myself
and say "Ariel, these are people who are *enjoying dancing*.  To criticize
them in their enjoyment is to be hypocritical and just plain mean.  They
may not enjoy dancing the same way you do, or for the same reasons,
but at least they're dancing!"

Raving IS about the love of the music and the love of dance.  The
concern shouldn't be how >many< people are raving (the more the
merrier!) but that the ideals are kept pure.  PEACE LOVE RESPECT AND
UNITY.  Instead of condemning those who are more mainstream, how
about giving 'em a hug and showing them what it's all about?  Spread
love, don't be selfish with it! :) 

Just my .02...
Ariel

Unfortunately i see the same thing happening, and it sort of saddens me.
While i am completely FOR spreading the "rave" culture and house music, i am
totally against commercialism.  Commercialism takes away from the GOAL and
brings people that may not be as enthused about expanding themselves and
creating a really positive vibe.

It also makes it too "profitable" and producers, promoters and musicians
will begin to do it for reasons that may not be to the benefit of the scene.

These r just my personal feelings, do as u will with them. PLUR!!
-Dan
>
>

The after-party idea is really cool. 

Another cool idea which works well with Ausravers is a pre-rave
restaurant munch. Publicise it at least a few days before to get some
idea of numbers, book a restaurant, arrive, talk, eat.

This works well even if people are scattering to different parties
afterwards.

The restaurant needs to be cheap, able to handle large groups (the
Ausrave record is about 25), and have both veggie and non-veggie food.

Jeremy

version to the 2-CD version.]

ground breaking as the earlier ones.

Precedence: bulk

At 10:48 AM -0700 9/18/96, KaySEE wrote:
>> The result?  BOOOORRRRIIINNGGGG!!!!  Everytime rave culture surfaces in
>> the mainstream, it sucks.  Who would be into this kind of sanitized
>> electronic music culture?  I mean, who is really into Chemical Brothers
>> CDs?  Yeah, I bought one... like 9 months ago!  The sound is pretty darn
>> stale now... yet it is the next cool thing according to Spin... yeah right.
>>
>
>Live 105 is doing the same thing.  They play Chem. Bros. and I've heard
>the Prodigy, too.  I don't know who they are exactly marketing too, but
>obviously there is some kind of developing market.  I think it is just
>going toget worse,too, because there *is* a burgeoning market.  I mean,
>look at
>the clubs.  Most people aren't "ravers", but they sure are familiar with
>all the big names and the music.

How can you tell someone who is "down with the underground" from those who
aren't "ravers?" Is it someone who doesn't wear the "right" clothing? They
wear a laminate or some other badge? I have to say that if you saw me at a
club, you'd probably call me an outsider, a tourist, whatever - I don't
dress all ravey... but I've been going to underground stuff for ages, since
the days of toontown and before (back in my day, we had to walk through 75
feet of snow, just to stand in line for a rave :) ). One of the things I
always liked about the 'rave' scene is that it drew a lot of different
kinds of people, and there was room for them all. I hated to see when it
got all commercial, when every flyer was huge with a zillion colors, and
cost more than the event itself. This big comercial wave died down, but
there's still lots of 'mainstream' interest... And there is still a
constant influx of new people into the scene. Is that getting "worse?" I
think the culture can only benefit from new people and ideas.

It's up to you to show the newcomers what the scene should be like. If
hardcore ravers treat newcomers with attitude because they're "just not
down with the scene," what kind of impression do you think those newcomers
will leave with?

-Brian

proverb:
In this country, where it is slack and spare,
we have everything we need.
Except what we don't have.

Hello,

On Wed, 18 Sep 1996 13:15:44 -0700, Dan Capriles
<dcapril@gebcoeng.com> wrote:

>At 10:48 AM 9/18/96 -0700, you wrote:
>>> The result?  BOOOORRRRIIINNGGGG!!!!  Everytime rave culture surfaces in
>>> the mainstream, it sucks.  Who would be into this kind of sanitized
>>> electronic music culture?  I mean, who is really into Chemical Brothers
>>> CDs?  Yeah, I bought one... like 9 months ago!  The sound is pretty darn
>>> stale now... yet it is the next cool thing according to Spin... yeah right.
>>> 
>>
>>Live 105 is doing the same thing.  They play Chem. Bros. and I've heard
>>the Prodigy, too.  I don't know who they are exactly marketing too, but
>>obviously there is some kind of developing market.  I think it is just
>>going toget worse,too, because there *is* a burgeoning market.  I mean, look at
>>the clubs.  Most people aren't "ravers", but they sure are familiar with
>>all the big names and the music.  And the youth, that is where the big
>>money comes from.  So, although you see this sound as stale, there appears
>>to be a market in existence that is moving forward with great force.
>>
>>-kc
>>
>
>Unfortunately i see the same thing happening, and it sort of saddens me.
>While i am completely FOR spreading the "rave" culture and house music, i am
>totally against commercialism.  Commercialism takes away from the GOAL and
>brings people that may not be as enthused about expanding themselves and
>creating a really positive vibe.

You should look into details of what happened in the original "Summer
of Love" in the Haight in 1967.

Essentially what happened is that the more people who became involved,
the less it was about PLUR and raising consciousness, and the more it
was about mindless intoxication.   This is why the original community
broke up.

The state of mankind, for the forseeable future, is that only a
certain number of people are going to be able to understand OR are
going to WANT to understand, higher consciousness and PLUR.  The
conditioning just runs too deep, and many many people just don't have
the requisite reference points, and don't have the time and space in
their lives to acquire them, and don't see why they should want to.

So, it is best to expand it on a person by person basis, rather than
in any mass way.


Cheers,

Ken                         <*>
kstuart@mail.telis.org

" Turn the earth to sand and still commit no crime
  How one thought will live provide the others die
  For I have riches more than these " - John Lodge

Subject: (BSP) Monday night dinner

Hey SFRavers! If you're itching for some pre-rave and post-rave
activities, why not get them both in one night? Every Monday night
before Mad, join Dianna Greer's wacky pre-Mad, post-weekend dinner.
Whether you go to fuel up before partying at Mad, or if you go to just
wind down after an intense party weekend, there's always fun
conversation and good food.

Dinner starts at 8:30, at varying locations (last Monday was Tai food,
yummy yummy). After dinner, we head to Mad (@ the Bahia Cabana on
Franklin and Market). Many of us are in the veggie/vegan end of the
eating spectrum, so all diets are considered.

See you then!

Steve

underground music.  I didn't see any PLUR in the Spin article.  Only

Jessica Robin Berkson wote:

>> Ps: if you lost anything from the party please let us know we have a
>> lot of stuff,  so call us!!! (408)486-9591

I was so depressed about this and so certain that it was permanently gone 
that I didn't bother to write about H3, but here goes....

PLEASE READ:  I left a camera, a small, black, automatic Ricoh camera, in 
the chill space when they kicked everyone out.  If ANYONE found it, please 
let me know!  

LAST SEEN:  From what I gather, it was picked up in the chill space by a 
young man wearing long purple shorts and carrying a blue backpack.  He was 
hanging out with another guy that was wearing a Kelly green tank top.  The 
guy that picked it up showed to a young lady that was looking for her 
camera.  When security saw this, they suggested that he leave it with them 
so the owner could find it, but the guy didn't want to and put it back in 
his backpack.  Which suggests to me that he intended to keep it.

You don't want to hear my opinion of a person that does that sort of thing, 
especially at an event like H3.  I came to conclusion a while back that 
there are  ravers and there are partiers.  One has respect for others and 
for the venu, and the other doesn't.  Respectively.

S

Hi All,

Before anybody flames me for posting Non-rave-related stuff, let me state
right here that I ASKED if anybody was interested first, and I have received
(in 30 minutes) 10 requests for the update.

This update comes from MW-RAVES, and it originated at Ford Motor Company,
and it actually sounds like Lexus/Nexus is working hard to set things
straight...

pauly

To: mw-raves@hyperreal.com
Subject: FYI - PTrak Database
Sender: mw-raves-owner@hyperreal.com

*** Resending note of 09/18/96 09:32                                            

Hi virtua-crew!  Here is an update on that PTrak database scare for ya          
compliments of FORD:                                                            

Recently, a chain letter has been flying about OV regarding the Lexis/          
Nexis "P-Trak" database.  The note warns that this publically accessible        
database contains sensitive info, and the reader is urged to contact            
Lexis/Nexis to remove themselves from the database.  THIS WARNING IS            
NO LONGER VALID.  PLEASE DO NOT FORWARD ANY MAIL ON THIS SUBJECT.               

In early June, 1996, Lexis/Nexis began marketing their P-Trak database.         
P-Trak is marketed to Attorneys, Law Enforcement and Police, and is a           
business-to-business service.  AT THAT TIME, the database did contain           
such items as an individual's social security number, and mother's              
maiden name.  Within weeks, due to public reaction, and concerns over           
potential for misuse, the sensitive information was removed from the            
database distributed via the P-Trak service.                                    

Calls to Lexis-Nexis (9/13/96, recorded information) reveal,                    
the info that "MAY" now be contained in the database includes:                  
The individual's name                                                           
The INDIVIDUAL'S MAIDEN NAME (not the mother's)                                 
Assumed names (aliases)                                                         
Month and year of birth                                                         
Current and two previous addresses                                              
Current phone number                                                            

Specifically mentioned as NOT included:                                         
Credit History or other financial data                                          

Not mentioned (and I assume not included)                                       
Social security number                                                          

There is apparently little cause for concern, since most of this                
information is obtainable through legitimate venues.  This information          
is of little use for fraudulent purposes.                                       

If you are still concerned, you can have yourself removed from P-Trax           
by putting your request in writing.  Lexis/Nexis has been swamped with          
calls due to the warning being rampantly widespread via the Internet            
and e-mail.                                                                     

The toll-free voice number for Lexis/Nexis for inquiries about the              
P-Trak service is (800)543-6862.  You may call and follow the                   
instructions there, but you will not get to talk to a person.                   

=======================================================================         

Interestingly enough, most of the warnings can be traced back to                
Paul Hart of CNET - the CNET service applauds itself for breaking this          
"story" to the net community, yet the now incorrect warning which               
spams the country came from them.  Mr. Hart claims he sent a follow-            
up note just minutes after this one, but apparently it didn't catch             
up.                                                                             


__________________________________________ x-radio ____
____ http://www.x-radio.com/x-radio/ __________________

On Wed, 18 Sep 1996, Rebecca Klassen wrote:

> 
> 
> On Wed, 18 Sep 1996, KaySEE wrote:
> 
> > > The result?  BOOOORRRRIIINNGGGG!!!!  Everytime rave culture surfaces in
> > > the mainstream, it sucks.  Who would be into this kind of sanitized
> > > electronic music culture?  I mean, who is really into Chemical Brothers
> > > CDs?  Yeah, I bought one... like 9 months ago!  The sound is pretty darn
> > > stale now... yet it is the next cool thing according to Spin... yeah right.
> > > 
> > 
> > Live 105 is doing the same thing.  They play Chem. Bros. and I've heard
> > the Prodigy, too.  I don't know who they are exactly marketing too, but
> > obviously there is some kind of developing market.  I think it is just
> > going toget worse,too, because there *is* a burgeoning market. 

Rebecca,
I wrote the little blurb about Live 105 above.  I just wanted to thank you
for your commentary.  It was right on!!  I love the Prodigy, too, and the
Chemical Brothers, and, especially, Underworld.  I'd like to add a few more 
thoughts that have been running in my mind in relation to this topic.  
One special thing about raving that I love is the emphasis on the individual.
Everyone feels a part of a rave, like they are contributing by just being
part of the vibe.  The rock and roll world of superstars caters to the
few, the rich, the hip.  Superstardom is about the desire to be something
you're not, about worshiping an idol.  To me that is the contrary of
raving, where I feel just by being open and warm, I am a contributer.
Where no one is such a star that you can't talk to them.  Where the power
is in the hands of the many rather than the few.  Where you cast aside
everyday assumptions about yourself and others, and allow real room for
self-expression rather than conformity.  If raving were to lose that, I
for one would be sad.  

Oh yeah, and I do listen to Live 105 on occasion, and I'm pissed that they
tend to make one hit wonders out of respectable bands in search of
their "I'm so fucking alternative" attitude.  And they tend to co-opt
Indy bands (like Sebadoh) as being the "new" alternative.  Duh,
Sebadoh was the antithesis of that attitude for years.  But it's all about
money, so who knows what's gonna happen.

-KaySEE


> 
> I guess I bought the Chemical Brothers several months ago too, but they
> still don't cease to move me. So I guess I'm still into it. I guess I
> still like the Prodigy too. Does this mean I like what is yesterday's
> news? "Oh nooooooo!!!" 
> If - those mainstream people- start liking it, there's probably a reason 
> why, more power to them, 'cause unless you're the superhero of cool you 
> maybe were once one too. I mean, everyone starts somewhere. I sure had 
> a lame-o beginning that is taboo in the "Land of the Truly Hip".
> Sure you can bemoan the loss of underground culture, because somehow 
> those in our modern society like to think of ourselves as individualists, 
> when really what is true is quite the opposite.
> "Are we relegated to the likes of grunge!?? Green Day?!?!! Oh god..."
> Music can be a true communicator.
> If our scene truly upholds particular ideals, then should we be 
> separatist? If we yearn to be inclusive, if we yearn to love. Is that 
> what we're about? 
> So live by example and show what's up.
> 
> By the way. Do you really read Spin and listen to Live 105?
> 
> 
> rebecca.
> 
> 
> 


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Sep 18 16:05:12 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id QAA16075; Wed, 18 Sep 1996 16:05:12 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from slip-3.slip.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with SMTP id QAA16066; Wed, 18 Sep 1996 16:05:07 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from patrick.littler.com [205.178.66.66] 
	by slip-3.slip.net with smtp (Exim 0.55 #2)
	id E0v3Vfy-0006PN-00; Wed, 18 Sep 1996 16:05:02 -0700
Message-ID: <32408031.3D23@slip.net>
Date: Wed, 18 Sep 1996 16:05:27 -0700
From: "Patrick R.Hancox" <patrickh@slip.net>
Reply-To: patrickh@slip.net
Organization: The Loft communications
X-Mailer: Mozilla 3.0 (Win95; I)
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
CC: "Diana D. Greer" <inanna@ccnet.com>
Subject: An open letter to the SFRaves community, the Burning Man VW camp, and Diana D. Greer
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

The great majority of you will have no idea what I am talking about,
please bear with me. 

I owe the community as a whole an apology, and Diana Greer one most of
all.  From my arrival on Friday morning at the Burning Man VW Camp,
until the moment I got out of Moonpups van Monday night in the City, I
demonstrated a wide variety of appalling behaviors.  I started out just
irritable and arrogant and finished the festival as a paranoid recluse,
talking trash about a good person.

Some people just wrote my behavior off as a bad tweaker trip.  I wish
that was true, then I could shrug my shoulders and say it wasnt really
my fault.  In good conscious, I neither can, nor will offer, an excuse
for my behavior.  That was a very ugly side of me you all saw.

Diana, I once again want to thank you for the many times in the past you
had shown faith in me. You were willing to work on our former
relationship through long periods of  abuse and neglect that no one
should have suffered.  Your love was real and I want you to know that I
understand and believe that.  I stupidly drove you away.  I hope that
one day you can forgive me for the mess I made of your life.

I said many outright lies and exaggerations about Diana to many people
that last night of Burning Man.  I harassed and frightened her, Jonathan
Logan, and some of you, too.   Im not even sure exactly who I talked to
in some cases.  It doesnt matter any more beyond this;  Diana D. Greer
is one hell of a good person and possessing of a very genuine nature. 
By initially welcoming me into VW Camp, she had once again shown faith
in me.  I repaid her faith by showing ever-increasing jealousy and
controlling behavior.  When she finally placed some distance between us,
I freaked out and wandered the camp bemoaning my self-inflicted wound. 
I spread lies and bullshit to any who would listen.

One of the most insidious things that I did to Diana while we a couple
was I cut her off from her own world.  You cant control a person who
has an independent life, and an isolated person is far less likely to
leave you, even if you are an asshole.  Since we split up,  Diana has
discovered the SFRaves community,  and has eagerly joined in as a
member of the extended family of ravers.  This family and new sense of
community is very precious to Diana. I know that my horrible
behavior at Burning Man has shamed her deeply, and made her reticent
around you, her friends.  Whatever else happens, please support your
friend Diana on this issue.  I will not make the same mistake again.  My
actions and words were inexcusable.  Diana was blameless and undeserving
of the embarrassment I caused her.  My apologies to all.

Patrick Raymond Hancox
Recovering Batterer

>I propose that someone (could be me?) start putting together a mailing list

>their house with other people who want to get together after parties.  This

I think that's way too much organizing ... I mean, what if don't want
everyone to know if I'm inviting some people over?  Or someone wants to
keep their chill session more discrete?  Or someone changes their mind and
decides it's not the right day to have people in their house?

verbally to people at a party, and leave it more freeform .... that's
worked when I've chilled at people's houses in the past...

     +++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
     
     There was a man with only one real fault: he used extremely foul 
     language all the time. His friends tried to get him to stop, but he 
     wouldn't. So they cloned him, thinking maybe a clone would use better 
     language. But the clone was just as bad, so his friends put him up on 
     a high bridge and pushed him off. They were arrested for making an 
     obscene clone fall.

Harmony: 

You like Stella Luna?  I certainly do, they're what got me
to go to Harmony (I don't do many raves these days).  I was
listening to the most recent Mandible Chatter CD, "Grace"
and it occurred to me that they were really going in the
direction that Stella Luna is going in now.  One of the two
main people in Mandible Chatter is also in Stella Luna.
Anyway, Mandible Chatter is on the Manifold label, if you
care:

   http://www.vdospk.com/manifold/

And come to think of it, one of the other guys I know in
Stella Luna did some drumming on the "Indestructible Beat of
Palo Alto" CD, though I still haven't heard that one yet. 

I have to say that overall I was a little disappointed with
Harmony, outside of Stella Luna... I mean we go check out
the main dance area, and it's nothing but this soulless hard
core that I would rant about a lot except that there's not a
lot of point in arguing about musical taste.  We head back
to the chill space, and the dance music there is a bit
better... except that there's no place to chill really, it's
a second dance area (yeah, I know, we should've brought a
tent).  So we split fairly early (like 1 AM).  

These days I guess I'm more interested in improvised music,
(though it is a shame that no one ever gets up and dances at
events like that... except when the Arkestra is in town, of
course). 

Anyway, let me know if Weird Blinking Lights are playing
somewhere.  

   -- JB

>I think that's way too much organizing ... I mean, what if don't want
>everyone to know if I'm inviting some people over?  Or someone wants to
>keep their chill session more discrete?  Or someone changes their mind and
>decides it's not the right day to have people in their house?
>
>I think it might be easier if the specific "host" just put the word out
>verbally to people at a party, and leave it more freeform .... that's
>worked when I've chilled at people's houses in the past...


I think I'd hafta agree with Leslie on this one.  One thing I've learned
from raving (and a lot of other people seem to be this way) is to just go
with the flow on almost everything involving raving, which of course
involves where I end up.  I've never really planned ahead of time to be
somewhere after a rave, but I almost always end up there anyway!  Very nice
to just flow right along with the evening, into the morning, and into
somebody's cool house to hang. :)  Unless I specifically don't want to go
somewhere after, I almost always do end up somewhere, usually at BK Jon's or
Wayne & Marcy's.


Love,
Shawna

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Sep 18 19:22:00 1996
