Date: Wed, 18 Sep 1996 19:21:18 -0700 (PDT)
From: Karen Hardie <pounce@vcn.bc.ca>
Subject: re: this chill house thing
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9609181913.A28439-0100000@opus.vcn.bc.ca>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

When i lived in a concrete building, my roommate and i used to round up
people we liked after raves and take them home to chill while he (my
roomie) spun for us.  It got to be such a bad she-told-two-friends-and-
they-told-two-friends situation that one morning we ended up with SIXTY
people in a small two-bedroom apt, all smoking speed and various other
stuff.  My roommate had a guy passed out on his bed for hours barely
breathing while his pals hotboxed the room.  There were maybe ten people
there that we actually KNEW we invited. 

So instead of not having the sessions, cos we LOVED them, we printed 
tickets!  One ticket meant one person, and that was IT.  if you didn't 
have one, too bad.  The tix were of course free, and we just gave em to 
folks throughout the night, so the people were almost never the same 
twice.  It was fun.

my point is ... it's HARD to have just a house or whatever somewhere that 
is the "accepted" chill house, unless the people who are running it don't 
actually LIVE in it.  Do you want people you don't know well just knowing 
where you live?  Even if you try to keep it to JUST sfravers, word does 
get out ... and also, sometimes, after a particularly Exciting gathering, 
i know i'd rather have the house to GO to rather than be the person in 
charge of it ... maybe rotating houses?  :)

just some thoughts
pounce
----------------------------
You know, there are many people in the country today who, through no
fault of their own, are sane.  Some of them were born sane.  Some of
them became sane later in their lives.  It is up to people like you
and me who are out of our tiny little minds to try and help these
people overcome their sanity.
                                           -- Monty Python

Precedence: bulk

        I'm sick of our mail server.  Every two days or so it will stop
receiving mail correctly.  Consequently, I have nothing to read at the
moment.  So instead, I thought I'd just send out something, especially since
I haven't been posting very frequently in the last few months.  Most of that
has been due to the fact that I was far away in the Evil Southland, the rest
just due to a not-so-rare disease I have called Slack.

<paragraph for Mr. Moonpup>
        First of all, can someone reply to me if this message shows up on
the list?  I haven't seen my messages showing up recently, and I was
wondering if they're actually getting there.

<'nuther paragraph for Moonpup>
        So what have I been up to, some of you may be wondering?  Well, in
LA I was sort of destressing myself, and, more than anything, proving to
myself that I shouldn't be a slave to my job.  I kind of felt like I had to
be here over the summer for no real reason, and needed to show myself that
if I wasn't going to be happy then it wasn't worth it.  So.  I did a lot of
temp work, which I wasn't real fond of, but it paid the bills.  And I played
a lot of frisbee golf.  And I hung out with some of my bestest friends.  In
short, I relaxed hard core (if such a thing is possible).

<you get the idea>
        Then I came back.  I started work, started class, started flamenco
dance (yes, really), etc.  Then, after the first two days of class and labor
day weekend, I decided I needed a break.  Hey, what can I say, I'm a senior.
It's my right.  Actually, I just wandered around California for a week to
see my favorite band on the planet, His Name Is Alive, play about five or
six shows.  I had to give up BM to do it, but it was worth it.  A lot of
experiences strike you as something you had a good time doing, but a very
few experiences strike you as something that, in addition, you _needed_ to
do.  Well, this was one of them.  It clarified a lot for me.  And I got to
hear a hell of a lot of good music in the process.

        As usual, I seem to have gone off on long tangents.  But I'm good at
it.  One last thing, though.  I'm considering trying to requisition funds
from the city of SF to build a frisbee golf course in GG park.  However,
after speaking to my father (who's a city planner), he said the way to have
the best chance at getting the money is to supply the labor yourself.  So I
was wondering, just tentatively, if anyone would be interested in getting
together some weekend and helping me set it up.  Please let me know if you
would, because that would greatly increase the chances of this becoming a
reality.

That's all.

Jake

...there's a distinct lack of people for me to run up and hug on the USF
campus :\

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Sep 18 20:54:01 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id UAA11758; Wed, 18 Sep 1996 20:54:01 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from emout18.mail.aol.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with SMTP id UAA11742; Wed, 18 Sep 1996 20:53:58 -0700 (PDT)
From: Hughdhyana@aol.com
Received: by emout18.mail.aol.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) id XAA28857 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Wed, 18 Sep 1996 23:53:25 -0400
Date: Wed, 18 Sep 1996 23:53:25 -0400
Message-ID: <960918235325_481609673@emout18.mail.aol.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Better worship through chemistry
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I have very decisive views about the use of chemicals to expand spiritual
awareness. So,I have waited until I had quality time to put into this
response, and, hopefully, there are individuals who can benefit from my
views. I welcome response to this, as I am not closed of to other points of
view.

_I DO believe that drugs can open you physical body to the awareness of the
greater universe.

_I also believe that you do NOT walk away with the benefits of that awareness
after you have finished your trip.

I explained my feelings to a friend by the use of this analogy; It's as if
you had an ailment (longing for spiritual growth) and you went to the
drugstore (the universe) for a remedy (energy as information). The use of
drugs opens you up to more than just the remedy that will help your ailment,
you're also going to get the remedy for ailments you don't have. It's like
taking every remedy a drug store has to offer when all you have is
indigestion. This influx of information in your conscious awareness can cause
serious confusion and jack with your personal energy field (aura, if you
will). It takes a soul who's worked VERY HARD in their past lives to handle
such a wide frequency of energies. I wouldn't suggest that anyone who isn't
absoultely sure about their place in the universe try to expand themselves
chemically.

Don't get me wrong, drugs are great. They've opened up my level of compassion
greatly by helping me to connect more deeply on this physical plane. I've
used them in the past, and i will probably use them again. But, as far as
spiritual growth is concerned, I'll take good old fashioned meditation any
time!

Anyone wishing to expand on these issues is welcome to e-mail me directly. I
look forward to hearing what everyone thinks!
Remember, it isn't where you are on the path to awareness that counts- It's
the fact that you're there in the first place.

love for everybeing
-hugh

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Wed Sep 18 23:31:57 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id XAA23129; Wed, 18 Sep 1996 23:31:57 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from acergw3.acer.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with ESMTP id XAA23123; Wed, 18 Sep 1996 23:31:54 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from smtplink.acer.com ([204.160.139.137]) by acergw3.acer.com (8.7.3/8.7.3) with SMTP id XAA05972 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Wed, 18 Sep 1996 23:28:18 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from ccMail by smtplink.acer.com (SMTPLINK V2.11.01)
	id AA843114992; Wed, 18 Sep 96 23:23:16 pst
Date: Wed, 18 Sep 96 23:23:16 pst
From: "Andy Wyszkowski" <awyszkow@smtplink.acer.com>
Message-Id: <9608188431.AA843114992@smtplink.acer.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Believe it if you need it, or need it if you dare
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     
     To the only people who might understand...
     ______________________________________________________________________
     
     I used to live in a bizarrely laid out portion of Irvine California 
     called Turtle Rock.  Turtle Rock is fairly unimpressive, except for 
     the fact that it was designed in a manner that very few houses would 
     experience through traffic.  This was done mostly through master 
     planning the zoning, road layout etc.
     
     I went to school at the bottom of the hill, and I lived at the top.  
     The main road (Turtle Rock drive), arced, so it was very inefficient 
     to follow that road up the hill.  But it was the only sure way.
     
     Sometimes, when I got out of a class early, I would choose a different 
     path.  Sometimes I found a another street that I could cut through.  
     Sometimes I found a dead end.  Sometimes I found a weird house, or a 
     fence with some strange feature on it, or a greenbelt that shot 
     between houses.  I met this with the fascination and wonder, and the 
     drudgery of having finished another day of school.  But it was better 
     than taking that same lame road home.
     
     Sometimes, I'd get a little lost, and worry my mom (you haven't been 
     yelled at till an Argentine woman with a thyroid condition after 
     working a double shift yells at you).  Sometimes I'd remember a 
     shortcut, get screwed by my awful memory, and have to resort to the 
     main drag again.  But eventually, I found a better way home.
     
     I think my point is, there are a lot of wrong turns, but if I didn't 
     take them, I would have taken the only road I knew again (the road 
     everybody else took, the road my parents used, the road that the plan 
     called for).  This road I knew was somehow wrong, or at least for me.  
     In life, I think we should all take the time to find some of those 
     wrong turns.  There are many crappy decisions you can make, I've been 
     making a lot lately.  I've had trouble spending real time with the 
     only woman I care for right now (intimately that is).  I've moved in 
     with some pretty crude jerks... 
     
     Raving is beautiful because it doesn't ask us to forego the road we 
     know is our life.  It doesn't ask us to burn baby burn, or Turn on 
     tune in and drop anything.  It's a different way, and you can visit or 
     leave anytime.  Drugs are a different way.  Investigating spirituality 
     is a different way.  If we take care, we can go down those paths.  
     Some of them are dead ends.  If you see the end coming up, don't freak 
     out... just remember how you got there.
     
     To those of you that I've met, and those I haven't...
     
     Remember where the main drag is.  Sometimes it's a good way to go for 
     a while.
     
     Walk slowly and look about.  There is so much there.
     
     Don't risk getting lost if you don't have the time.  Make the time 
     when you can.
     
     Life is really amazing, and there's so many things you can do with it.
     
     SomEthing this weekend opened a door I couldn't imagine opening any 
     other way.  I found out that love can stop and start people.  I looked 
     at people and they stopped, and turned and smiled.  I said I know you, 
     and she said she knew me too.  I will probably never see her again, 
     but for a second I felt so amazed and so in awe...  I hugged him and I 
     knew how he felt, and that was everything.  You smiled at me.  I 
     forgot to dance, and the room stopped.  In the calm, we were together. 
      And together we met the next wave.
     
     .  .  .  .  o  o  o  o  O  O  O  O 
     
     We were so close to being in love with each other.
     ______________________________________________________________________
     
     I had to work so hard last night just to remember how I felt at that 
     moment last weekend.
     
     I want to try again.
     
     See you this weekend.
     
     Love,
     AndyW
     
     
     
     
     
     * Frank Baum was a genius *

So many people have emailed me asking what FringeWare is all about, I 
thought I'd respond list-wide.  Bottom line:  FringeWare ROCKS.

My opinion is that FringeWare is the watershed where intelligent fringe 
culture accumulates for cross-pollination and mass distribution.  It is 
the group of people that took over where Mondo 2000 and bOING bOING left 
off, in terms of wicked clever thought and culture, memes and gadgets.  

They describe themselves as follows:

"FringeWare Inc., is a Texas corporation operating in the city of Austin 
(Dun & Bradstreet #87-622-8982), as a guerrilla media collective. Founded 
in 1992, our activities comprise several lines of business, including: 

       a retail store and mail order catalog 
       a printed magazine, Fringe Ware Review 
       an email list 
       design and engineering consulting services 
       helping to sponsor fringe events 
       a staff of trained professionals"

Let's just say that FringeWare is home to syncronistic convergences of 
chaotic attractors.  It was the original home of the Schwa meme as well.

For further info, try the following URL:
http://www.fringeware.com/what.html

happy mutating!
-john

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: Dan Capriles <dcapril@gebcoeng.com>
Subject: Update on "chilling out"
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

There has been a mostly positive response to the idea of having chill out
sessions after parties.  There, however, were a couple of postings that had
some concerns with it being too organized or what not.....i have no
solutions for these...sorry  :(

There has, however, been a quite a few people (so far) who are interested in
attending and/or hosting on of these gatherings.  That's all i think i would
like out of this, for it to be a gathering, not an event, and not someplace
where a 100 random people come over abuse various drugs and also abuse the
space/privacy of the host.  I want this be all inclusive, but not get out of
hand, after all we MUST respect the space and lives of those who have
offered to host.  There shouldn't be "one" chillout house, but rather have
it be a rotating thing...it doesn't even have to be every weekend..if
someone feels like hosting and there are people interested in going, then it
will happen.

Part of the reson i think this will be a good idea is that it will allow us
(sfravers&friends) to get together and know each other, even if we didn't
all go to the same party.  I'm sure there have been several mornings when
all of us have not been ready to go home yet and be alone, or have to drive
1-1.5 hours home (like i often have to) or even those that are with 1-2
other people, but still have no place to go hang out, relax and revitalize
themselves.  I think it would be a beneficial and nice communal thing to do. :)

Finally, there is that problem of too many people inviting other
people...etc. etc.  Like i said i don't want to this to be a "clique" thing
and not introduce new people into it, but i also don't want this to get out
of hand (who knows if it actually would, but better safe than sorry). So, i
think maybe the ideas of tickets, with a 1-2 extra ones given out to each
group of people, or maybe some sort of RSVP thing would be good.  That way
the host knows if they can handle the 10-15 or 30-40 that are interested.

Sorry this got so verbose.  Please give me yout feedback.  For all those of
u that wrote in saying u were interested, i have written down your addresses
and hopefully we can get something togethter.

:P
Dan

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


A few ideas on this...

The morning after a rave is a great time, but usually people are all
in various states of "awakeness"... ie, some people will be up for
much of the morning, and some people will be ready to completley crash.
When I had people over at my place for post-party chills, sometimes I felt
wierd if I needed to crash, and everyone else was still up at my place.

One idea is to have a sunday-afternoon get together.  That was everyone
can get a few hours of sleep and catch a shower.  Personally, when
I get back from a party I want to take a short break from partying,
and maybe just chill by myself (or with my very close friends).  But
come Sunday afternoon is when I start feeling like I would like to be
partying with my friends again.  Getting together for the Simpsons or
a video is great post-party fun.

This may be especially relevent now that summer is drawing to a close
and Sunsets will be fewer and farther between.

Personally, I really like pre-party get-togethers, becuase everyone is
all excited and bright and pumped up to go party.

just some thoughts to throw into the mix...

-troy

	how about this: shawna and leslie had good ideas. go with the
flow. but the fact that there's a predetermined chill-house doesn't negate
the possibility of spontaneity. remember, this isn't mandatory. if some
people want to organize this and plan to meet at someone's place,
wonderful. if others just want to hang out with a small, specific group of
friends, wonderful. i'm sure we can all handle our own plans. just this
way, we have more alternatives.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Sep 19 11:57:41 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id LAA06070; Thu, 19 Sep 1996 11:57:41 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from dns1.noc.best.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with SMTP id LAA06065; Thu, 19 Sep 1996 11:57:37 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from 206.86.220.227 (bwret.vip.best.com [206.86.220.227]) by dns1.noc.best.net (8.6.12/8.6.5) with SMTP id LAA12453 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Thu, 19 Sep 1996 11:57:26 -0700
Message-ID: <324198D0.6AB0@best.com>
Date: Thu, 19 Sep 1996 12:02:40 -0700
From: Alex <bwret@best.com>
X-Mailer: Mozilla 2.02 (Macintosh; I; 68K)
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Record Bag- jungle(long)
Content-Type: multipart/mixed; boundary="------------59E32DEA6B19"
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

This is a multi-part message in MIME format.

--------------59E32DEA6B19
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

hi- September has been both a good and bad month. good because the
jungle market has stepped up quality wise within the past couple weeks.
Bad because we still have to pay $10 bucks for each record. Hope this is
useful:)

Fugees or NOT- Promo

Remix of 'Ready or Not' by the blockbuster rap trio. Starts off mellow
with that "hunt for red october' type submarine keyboard which instantly
makes me want to run away and sulk in a corner or something. Solid
vocals samples. One cheesy part in the middle where there's a cuss word
and they bleep it out...weird...

Origin Unkown- Valley of the Shadows- RAM

Remix of a classic. Original mix is sped up to fit todays jungle tempos.
'96 mix is nice and sparse. Good to see they didn't try to do too much.
If it ain't broke...Anyways, this is a beautiful song built on the
contrast between this nice bell progression and the dark bass lines.
Really moody.

Paradox- Renegade Hardware Promo

Excellent trancy lucid drum'n bass with strange wha-wha'd echoing vocal
samples. Busy drums never get too overwhelming and the breaks are really
pretty.

Barcode- New Dance/Soundz Of- Formation Records

A-side is a pretty jump-up track. Starts off with a classical intro
(some well known 18th century piece) with bomb blasts and beats. Pretty
funky.After a Prince sample the meat of the song kicks in and let me
tell ya...it's amazing. Almost tech-steppy but will really get the crowd 
jumping. b-side is another solid steppy track.

Penny Black#6- promo

yeah..I've got no info in this track. PB has been on eof those labels to 
watch out for as of late, and they really come through this week. Two 
sides of nice melodic thick jungle which will have the crowd dancing 
through the pristine breaks to the wicked drums. hype!

P.F.M.- For all of us/ The Mystics- Good Looking Records

Though both these tracks have been out for ages on dubplate, we finally 
get a chance to hear what all the fuss was about. Pretty standard PFM 
format...moody strings in the beginning followed by energetic drums and a 
breakdown which reminds me of the summer of '92. Flip side is a bit more 
sophisticated and just as atmospheric. nice one.

Flynn and Flora- Bass Speaker/ Revolution- Independent Dealers

2 solid but different trax. Bass Speaker gets a remix by Krust who goes a 
bit overboard. I'm not so used to him doing agro hardstep, but it works. 
Revolution is a really solid track with some cool samples about the 
construction of a revolt. Melodic and uplifting, but never cheesy, it 
would work well at the beginning of a set.

Aphrodite- Recuts II- Aprhodite

3 tracker. One sample-heavy stepper. One weird light roller with weird 
metal sounds in it. One ambient 'deep forest' type mix. Good stuff. but 
nothing new.

Adam F- Metropolis- Metalheadz

This has got to be one of the most hyped tracks in recent weeks. It 
delivers. Eerie strings and swooshing noises fill up half of the track 
until the breakdown is built and then demolished by massive cutting bass 
hits. Not for the weak of heart.

DJ Die- Reincarnations/Stoned Groove- Full Cylcle

Sure, his name sort of threw me off at first, but after purchasing a few 
choons of his, he's one of my favorites. Sparse minimal DEEP grooves 
perfect for the armchair or the dancefloor. Sountrack music for life.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------

if anyone wants to hear some jungle, there's going to be an entire room 
of it at Buggin Out featuring Josh Swissman (from back east) and tons of 
local talent. 

-peace-
alex

--------------59E32DEA6B19

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Disposition: inline

At 1:20 PM +0000 9/19/96, Mark D. Camp wrote:
>>I was wondering if anyone had anything to say about moderately priced DJ
>>headphones?
>
>I really like the Sony MDR-V600 head phones.  They're very comfy, sound
>great, plenty of bass response, and they're Light.
>
>I got em for about $100 and Circuit City.
>
>-M

I have MDR V-600's... I got them at Audio Images for around $85 (on Oak
Grove, near 6th and Bryant)... the generation of DJ's before us used
MDR-V6's, which were a little more minimal than V600's... both are good...

If you want to spend more, try the Sony 7506's... they are the "pro"
version of V600s.

Also, Sennheiser make good headphones but I don't think they are very
suitable for "rave" environments... may be too fragile.

Cut the wax, baby!

-w

From: sho@goonsquad.spies.com (Sho Kuwamoto)
Subject: Re: <NRR>  DJ Headphone Question
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (sfraves)
Date: Thu, 19 Sep 1996 14:36:16 -0700 (PDT)
Content-Type: text
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Wayne Correia writes:
> I have MDR V-600's... I got them at Audio Images for around $85 (on Oak
> Grove, near 6th and Bryant)... the generation of DJ's before us used
> MDR-V6's, which were a little more minimal than V600's... both are good...
> 
> If you want to spend more, try the Sony 7506's... they are the "pro"
> version of V600s.

As far as I can tell, the 7506 is exactly the same as the
older V6, except that
	(a) the stripe is blue instead of red
	(b) the connector has a goldish color instead of
		being a silverish color
	(c) they cost about $40 more
	(d) you can still get them

I prefer the 7506 (and the V6, if you can still find it)
over the V600, but they do tend to fall apart. I find I need
to replace mine every year or so, with admittedly heavy
use. After this time, the pads fall apart (but can be
replaced), and the drivers start to go. 

Their main advantage is that you can hear them in even the
worst monitoring environments. They have good sound
isolation, bright highs, and are incredibly loud, which is
important when you find yourself faced with a mixer with an
inadequate headphone amp. I also find their shape to be 
comfortable in almost any position, unlike some other
headphones, which can be too bulky or too rigid.

-Sho

I'll 2nd that - I've used V6's and 7506's for a few years, and swear by
them, but they do fail fairly frequently. I just bought my third pair after
one channel failed on both the 1st and 2nd pairs, which I then cannibalized
to make a whole pair, which then blew out. Other than reliability they're
great. They were something like $109 at Leo's. The V600's have larger
earcups and are bit bit bulkier.

Joe

One thing you should check out w/ the sony's: 

The models that say "studio monitor" reproduce the frequencies exactly as
they are given.

The models that dont ususally have a higher bass response. 

It is all a matter of opinion as far as which you prefer.

At 10:23 AM -0700 9/12/96, Mark Camp* wrote:
>         Reply to:   RE>Hello WORLD!
>
>Well, since it doesnt look like we are going to see FGE's books, I decided
>to do some calculations on my own.
>
>DISCLAIMER!!!!
>I am not a promoter, have never thrown a party, have never been involved
>in throwing a party.  So I'm just doing some very generous estimates at
>how much it may cost for the following items:
>
>
>$20,000 Space
>$5,000 Security
>20 DJ's at $500 each = $10,000
>$20,000 Sound
>$10,000 lighting
>$10,000 crew
>$500 water
>$  5,000 for rental of Bouncy Castle
>$1,000 Charity
>
>For a Grand Total of = $81,500
>
>7,000 people at $18 a pop = $126,000
>
>$126,000 - $81,500 =
>
>$44,500 left over.
>
>Are there any other unforseen costs that I am missing?  Permit costs?
>Insurance?  anybody have an idea on how much that stuff costs?  Didnt
>Martin post a breakdown of his expenses a while back?  Could we compare
>FGE with The Gathering (as far as expenses are conserned)?  Anybody want
>to go back into the archives and repost Martins post.
>
>-M

The Home Base warehouse costs $10,000 + 3-5% of gross ticket sales to rent.
Security is another ~$7500 (Oakland PD offduty officers)

Sound would cost NO MORE than $5000.

Lighting would cost NO MORE than $5000.

They probably got a bunch of kids to "crew" for free.

FEEL GOOD ENTERTAINMENT is probably named that becuase that's how they feel
when they're counting all their $20's.

But then, what exactly would you expect from the people that bring you COOL
WORLD?

FWIW here's an article about Lexis-Nexis from Money Daily

------- Forwarded Message

Thursday, September 19, 1996

Privacy storm shows the best and worst of the 'Net

The flap over a new service from Lexis-Nexis is probably 
misguided, but raises interesting questions about privacy and 
the power of online communication

by Michael Brush

An online brouhaha that broke out this week over alleged 
privacy breaches caused by a new Lexis-Nexis product has put 
both the best and worst of the 'Net community in high 
profile.

The Dayton, Ohio-based online database company has been 
swamped with phone calls and faxes this week because of a 
flurry of e-mails and news-group postings warning readers of 
the allegedly dire consequences of its new product called P-
TRAK. Many of the warnings falsely claim that P-TRAK provides 
a wide range of potentially sensitive personal information 
ranging from social security numbers to medical and credit 
histories.

On the bright side, the controversy shows the huge power of 
the 'Net when used by public-spirited advocates to mobilize a 
response to a perceived danger -- in this case, a threat to 
privacy. On the dark side, the fact that many of the 
allegations in the electronic correspondence are plain wrong 
shows how easy it is to spread misinformation and, 
potentially, raise what could amount to an online lynch mob.

At issue is a product launched last June which provides 
Nexis-Lexis clients with basic public information about 
anyone in a 300 million-name database. The information 
available is culled from credit bureau records. It is limited 
to your name, your maiden name or alias (if any), your 
current and two most recent past addresses, the month and 
year of your birth, and your phone number -- though not all 
of that information is available on every person.

For nine days after the product was released last June 2, P-
TRAK also included your social security number. But the SSNs 
were pulled on June 11 because of complaints, says Lexis-
Nexis spokesman Steve Edwards. If you already <em>know</em> 
someone's social security number, though, you can search for 
him or her using that number.

P-TRAK is meant to help attorneys track down witnesses, heirs 
or parents who have stopped paying child support, says 
Edwards.

While the scope of P-TRAK is relatively limited compared to, 
say, credit reports, which carry news of your payment 
history, bankruptcies and other such sensitive material, it 
nonetheless sparked the ire of many 'Net users.

For example, one posting that was later widely circulated 
this week claimed that your social security number, "mother's 
maiden name, birth date and other personal information are 
now available to anyone with a credit card." It postulated 
that the information could allow someone to commit credit 
card fraud or use your identity.

The truth is somewhat tamer. The SSN and mother's maiden name 
are not included, for example, and  the database is available 
only to clients like law firms and news organizations that 
can afford Lexis-Nexis's relatively hefty fees.

Furthermore, Money Daily's spot check shows that the 
information available is spotty at best. A search of P-TRAK 
run on our behalf by the Time Inc. Research Center turned up 
the right addresses but no phone or birth date for this 
author. It got the addresses and birth year correct for Money 
Daily editor Kevin McKean, but had an obsolete phone number. 
And when confronted with relatively more common names of two 
other Money Online staffers -- tech director Wilson Smith and 
reporter Joseph "Tripp" Reynolds -- turned up dozens of 
people, none of whom proved to be the correct ones.

Those limitations notwithstanding, the roar on the 'Net was 
heard at Lexis-Nexis headquarters. "We have been deluged with 
people calling, writing and faxing," says Edwards. "People 
are asking us: 'Why are you putting my medical records, my 
mother's maiden name, and my credit card history out there?' 
This has been testing the limits of our customer service."

In response, Lexis-Nexis posted a statement on its home 
page</a> to correct false information about the product and 
also a form you can use to remove your name from the list, 
something the company says people could have done all along 
by calling. By next Monday, Edwards says the firm will also 
have an 800 number that callers can use. People who phone the 
company's current 800 number are told to fax name-removal 
requests to 513-865-1930.

The company has stopped short of posting responses in news 
groups or bulletin boards, though. "There are different 
schools of thought on that," says Edwards. "One says that you 
should never respond to news groups from a company standpoint 
because that increases the amount of flaming. But at this 
point, I don't know how much worse it could get."

In the company's place, other news group participants have 
stepped in to set the record straight. "I think you owe a 
post to correct this error," one such correspondent scolded 
in a reply that pointed out several errors in the message 
quoted above.

Ironically, the information available in P-TRAK is mild 
compared to what is available elsewhere in the vast Lexis-
Nexis database.

A related product, called P-FIND, for example, offers 
additional household information like the appraised value of 
a home in many states and the number of dependents (both of 
which are public information). The main Nexis database digs 
up information from news stories -- often from local papers 
- -- published around the world and in several different 
languages. Many of those stories, of course, contain 
information of arrests and charges that may later prove 
groundless, as well as a volume of personal information about 
the people cited in the articles. And the legal Lexis service 
contains not only details from civil and criminal court cases 
around the nation, but also other potentially sensitive 
information, such as tax liens and judgments against 
individuals.

Before you get your hackles up over invasion of privacy, 
though, consider that all of the above is public information 
- -- and, of course, much of it is potentially more sensitive 
than your previous address.



For more Web-formation, visit:

http://www.lexis-nexis.com
Lexis-Nexis

http://www.lexis-nexis.com/lncc/p-trak/index.html
Lexis-Nexis statement

http://www.lexis-nexis.com/lncc/about/ptrak.html
Form to remove your name from the Lexis-Nexus database

I've seen the MDR-V6's for as low as $60.00 (that's how much i've paid
for mine). A good place to shop for cheap gear is J&R Music World in
NYC. They got a 1-800 number, call 1-800-555-1212 (1-800's free 411) to
get their actual number. Good thing about shopping there is you don't
have to pay the 8.25% state sales tax (actually, you're supposed to,
but nobody does). Incidentally, they have very good prices on the
Pioneer CDJ-500mkII and M-500 mixer; I got mine there and it's awesome!

One question regarding playing in loud environments. I find that it's a
lot harder to pick out sounds on the headphones than it is on a
loudspeaker, esp. for beatmatching. Beatmatching really sparse tracks
is really easy, but beatmatching more complicated music (e.g. Banco de
Gaia into Loop Guru) can sound ok on the 'phones, but ends up sounding
like a mild trainwreck on the speakers. I've found I can actually do a
better job beatmatching more complex material if i use a small set of
monitor speakers running out of the headphone monitor instead of using
headphones. But I know that's cheating and doesn't do the trick...

How do you solve the problem? For example, you can "simplify" an overly
complex track by cutting down the bass on the headphone monitor
(monitor eq) so you can just beatmatch the hi-hats, but a lot of times,
you gotta get the bass in synch too, and that's where headphones fail.

I'm bored mixing simple sparse stuff into simple sparse stuff (e.g.
house music or really simple and repetitive acid squonqs). I hear good
DJ's mixing more complicated stuff successfully. How do they do that?
On headphones at least, I find it a lot harder to pick apart the music
than on speakers. Why is that, and how do i solve that?

PS: i use MDR-V6's. are my ears shot? Am I using the wrong headphones?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

through chemical means. i truly wish that this could be everyones experience.

>   From the people who brought you Beltane and Summer Solstice we bring you

	That's funny, I didn't know any people could bring you Beltane or
the Summer Solstice. Granted we people put some silly name on a few days
of the year and have since chosen to use those to recongize that these
years pass around us and we gather for whatever reasons each of us has,
(and each of us has our own reasons, some are the same as others, but each
of us has our own reason for driving some awful long distance into the
middle of no where, some of us hauling gear, some of us hauling food, some
of us only hauling themselves and their energy) to gather and spend time
in a place where there is no one to take care of us except ourselves...

	Anyway, I don't think any of the people hauling gear out to the
site really agree with such termology even if sounds odd or funny just
because it is against the values that we came together to gather around
when it first started. It is not one group of people's party, and it is
not "put on by a group of people", simply because the people who started
the party are long dead and we are just people who have chosen to come
together on those same dates. Why do people come out to full moon parties
(or why did they use to before they were the shit and everyone and their
mother came out leaving beaches trashed and energy faltering)? Everyone 
has their own reasons. Enough rambling now... Just for everyone that 
comes, I do hope that each of you will help me carry a speaker up the 
hill if I need help doing it, because in one sense, that is what these 
parties are about...

dave

this one's for plex

from extensive research and reading that i've done on my own, it seems that
integration of the mind, body, and higher-self planes within your being is
the key to attaining TRUE higher awareness. i feel that drugs may be able to
bring two of these planes together,creating an opening of awareness that you
would be able to walk away with and can be very good for a soul.(it seems
that mind/higher-self seems to be the one with most impact on one's psyche)
 but, i also believe that there is a "spiritual agenda". that there is an
order to the universe that should be followed. by opening to lessons that you
may not be ready for, i feel that could affect one's karma in a distorting
way. putting the horse before the cart, in a way. 

the bottom line is- we'll get there, let's not be in a hurry and enjoy the
journey. if you think drugs can truly help you to get more out of your
experience here on earth, do them. but, also, be responsible with your soul.

seeking compassion
-hugh-

At 8:17 PM 9/19/96, Hughdhyana@aol.com wrote:
>that my first trip in "e" felt like coming home,
>rather than running away from home. now, i feel that i have a reference point
>that allows me to define the experiences i have when i alter my conciousness
>through chemical means. i truly wish that this could be everyones experience.

although i never achieved such states through meditation or other means,
experiences with certain drugs still felt like a homecoming to me. the
first time i experienced a psychedelic trip, i felt, quite intensely, like
"i've been waiting all my life for this drug!"... it put me in touch with
many feelings, philosophies, and memories which were definitely already
inside of me but which i hadn't been in contact with recently if ever.

and as far as E... the first (and especially 2nd) time i ravEd, i really
felt like i had come home, found a long-lost family, etc. the E itself was
not the home i found, but rather the rave scene itself... but the E
certainly helped make very emotionally clear what i'd been missing.

i really believe that drugs like this can help you get in better touch with
yourself, and that (even if you never take the drugs again) you _can_ take
something of what you learn with you into the rest of your life... but only
if you try to.

love,

brian

Hey SFRavers! If you're looking for something cool to do on Sunday,
then head down to San Jose for a free afternoon party. It starts
around 11am or noon in downtown San Jose.

Directions from SF: take 280 south to the Guadelupe pkwy (same as hwy
87) and exit south. Take the San Carlos exit off of 87. From there,
look for a big purple building; this will be the Children's Discovery
Museum, and the party is in the park right in front of it.

What could be more perfect than raving in front of a children's
museum? :) Also going on right nearby on the same day is the SoFa
street fair (I believe it's $3).

The party will be free, but they are gladly accepting donations, as
this is benefit party to help raise funds to throw Charity! Charity
will be on October 4th, and the proceeds from *that* party will be
divided among a couple of really worthwhile causes (to be announced
next time!!!).

So come down and enjoy a sunny San Jose afternoon this Sunday! And
don't forget to support the Charity crew!!! These guys have been
working really hard to put together a killer party next month, and do
some good for the community.

cu then! :)

Steve

Subject: Re(3): Better worship through chemistry

Precedence: bulk

>but, also, be responsible with your soul.

i like to make a simple and effective analogy about LSD (i know, not thE
drug of usual discussion here... actually to some extent it applies to any
drug, but it just seems so right for acid...) by comparing it to fire.

fire is powerful stuff. it changed human civilization. it can be very
illuminating. it can be a source of power. it can be the most useful thing
in the world.

if you disrespect it, it will burn you. let it get out of hand, and it can
destroy a city.

'nuff said.

love,

brian

Another vote for MDRV600s.

Just try not to pay more than $85 bucks for them. They are fairly 
profitable and I'm sure most Good Guys wouldn't mind beating a mail 
order price.

Actually, I like the Sennheisers more. That's what I have. But at 
$150, the Sonys are clearly a better value.

-CT

SF welcomes lots of guests at Out-A-Sight, Auto and the Space Children
parties, including lots of Detroit techno...   Sunset and Mission Rock
should be a good way to finish up the weekend too.  See you out there!

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - the Uncle Noah TV Show - the best
       in Techno and House music. 3-5am, KDVS 90.3fm (Davis)
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * Saturday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. and
       Monkeywrench KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
       
   
     _________________________________________________________________
   
   For a _search_ interface to the calendar, see the Late Train club
   section (http://www.latetrain.com/clubs/).
     _________________________________________________________________
   
Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

	(Smail-3.2 1996-Jul-4 #1 built 1996-Aug-2)
Message-Id: <m0v3ujG-001UuRC@goonsquad.spies.com>
From: sho@goonsquad.spies.com (Sho Kuwamoto)
Subject: Re: <NRR> DJ Headphone Question
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (sfraves)
Date: Thu, 19 Sep 1996 18:50:06 -0700 (PDT)
Content-Type: text
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Niels P. Mayer <mayer@netcom.com> writes:
> One question regarding playing in loud environments. I find that it's a
> lot harder to pick out sounds on the headphones than it is on a
> loudspeaker, esp. for beatmatching. Beatmatching really sparse tracks
> is really easy, but beatmatching more complicated music (e.g. Banco de
> Gaia into Loop Guru) can sound ok on the 'phones, but ends up sounding
> like a mild trainwreck on the speakers. [...]
>
> How do you solve the problem? 

You're absolutely right. It's easy for your ears to play
tricks on you, and it's worthwhile to spend some time
figuring out how to get around this. Here are some things
that I do.

1) Almost all mixers allow you to mix the main output of the
   mixer back into the headphones, along with the thing you
   are cueing. Take advantage of this! I find that mixing in
   a small amount of the main output into the headphones
   alleviates the perceptual delay between the monitor and
   the cue.

2) For particularly difficult mixes, or for those which you
   absolutely have to nail tightly, you should audition them
   in the headphones without the use of the monitor (i.e.,
   try not to pay attention to the monitor, or put both
   headphones on). Use the knob described above to sweep the
   mix back and forth a couple times and make sure that it
   sounds tight. This might seem like a pain, but it only
   takes a couple seconds.

3) After introducing your new track, you may have to make
   minor adjustments before fully entering your mix. Listen
   to the monitors to see if things seem lined up before
   committing to a mix. 

4) Riding a thick mix has more to do with setting your
   levels right than with having microscopic precision in
   your beatmatching. There's often a sweet spot between
   two records where the mix sounds the best, and it's
   usually not right in the middle. Of course, the problem
   is that you can't really tell ahead of time what the
   levels should be, so you have to get used to finding the 
   right balance on the fly.

5) When you *do* hear a mix going out of whack, don't
   panic. Having a song cut out in the middle of a mix, or
   hearing a song being sped up when it was supposed to be
   slowed down is a real drag. Learn to adjust things while
   they're playing, and to recover from errors as gracefully
   as possible. 

Just some thoughts.

-Sho

moved to Humboldt a month ago for skool from San Diego, and prior to that
I lived in Monterey (and before that in the MW, but there's a whole tale
before that). A year ago I went to some Cloud Factory parties, and lots of
parties in SF, and I also went to an SFR party in Sept(?) in a cove in
Santa Cruz (I believe it was the clothing optional one with the leather 
skinned old men). But I had lots of fun and I met this guy and he asked 
if I was on the list and I said nooo... 
And then I moved down south 
And then in April I went to a party in the Presidio (Generations of Love) 
and I saw -the same guy- (plus some other people I hadn't seen in a super 
duper long time) and I think he asked me -the same question- and I said 
noooo... 
So now I'm back up in No. Cal and yeahhh I'm on the list now.  
The tale of an often displaced raver. So now I'm in Humboldt with an e-mail 
account that comes with registration fees and by gosh darn it, I'm gonna 
utilize this sucker.

went wrong, right down to the malevolent, conspiratorial third party stuff 
that everyone will always say when its a party gone bad...

know) was evil too and left way before the appointed meeting time.

there except for 5 people all because of the air-headed girl leading the 
cars. But anyway, they are very very apologetic.**

X-Sender: tgrigsby@best.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: SDream@tgrigsby.com (SDream)
Subject: Review: Harmony 3, by T. Hamsta (long)
X-Mailer: <PC Eudora Version 1.4>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hi!  This is Thomas.  I'm one of SDream's hamstas.  Since SDream is still 
really upset about his camera being stolen, he doesn't want to write a 
review of Harmony's 3 year anniversary.  Me and the other hamstas had such a 
great time, and we feel so bad for him, we decided to write a review ourselves.

We caught a ride in SDream's backpack (as usual).  At one point we knew we 
weren't in the car anymore but we were in some kind of vehicle.   We sent 
Spaz topside to figure out what was going on.  He said we were on a school 
bus!  There was a cool couple in front of us talking to SDream and Marty.  
Marty is the cool girl that lives in Fresno.  She comes up and parties with 
SDream now and then.  She's really cool, with long curly red hair.  She 
brings us peanuts and sneaks them to us when SDream isn't looking.   Anyway, 
there was also this cool dog on the bus named Amber.   She was the coolest 
rave dog we've ever seen, with sparkles in her fur.

After a while we came to a stop, so we sent Spaz up to look around again.  
He came back down, his eyes huge!  "Dood!", he says, "It's SO COOL!"  We all 
looked at each other and then scrambled to see what was up!  We were all 
hanging out every available opening in SDream's backpack as he walked 
around.  The main room was classic Harmony, with fantastic artwork and the 
best music you've ever heard!  Spaz couldn't wait -- he jumped down, 
scrambled up one of the speakers, and started bopping like crazy!  I think 
he stayed there the whole night, bumming water off other ravers and 
worshipping the best visuals in the rave scene!

Then we headed out to where the tent city was.  Wow!  Life size hamsta 
nests!  People would wiggle in through the holes, nibble on some goodies, 
hang out, curl up, sleep for a while, then wiggle back out to dance some 
more!  Tim K. was there, and Tony R.  We were waving at all the little rave 
kiddies, but we didn't want to venture out just yet.

SDream walked over and checked out the chill space.  It was the best chill 
space we've seen!  SDream found Eric P. there -- Eric is so cool!  Brownie 
and Grumpy jumped ship at that point and spent the better part of the 
evening doing a slow groove to funky slow beats.  I guess they caught the 
live performances.  We wanted to see them but we didn't get back in time.  
At one point this girl's necklace broke, and Brownie and a bunch of other 
ravers helped pick up the pieces.  Isn't it cool how everyone helps each 
other out?  Then they spent part of the evening sneaking up on people that 
were almost dozing off and jumping up and down and squeezing their 
shoulders.  Of course, to a people raver, this feels like a backrub.  Then 
the person would turn around to see who it was and Brownie and Grumpy would 
jump down and run off before they were seen.

At this point the rest of us jumped down and started doing our own 
explorations. 

We found the "Fairy Ring", a tight ring of huge redwoods with chairs and 
Christmas lights in the middle.  Tiny crawled up and turned on the Christmas 
carol boxes, but after a while the people ravers turned them back off (thank 
goodness).  It was beautiful, a truly incredible touch.

We danced with Rikki in the main room, raced around Kirsten's silver tennies 
(very quickly -- she really goes crazy, jumping around and stuff), and we 
hitched a ride in Marcy's Dr. Seuss hat (it looked a lot like SDream's if 
you ask me).  Several of us came to the conclusion that Kirsten was in fact 
the embodiment of the Rave Goddess!  At one point I looked up and saw Spaz 
circle dancing on top of Wayne's head.  Twinkletoes and Starchild were 
discussing libertarian issues and sharing a doobie in the corner.  

CTD and Rlunatic were looking around for their glo-sticks, which Cutey and 
Slim and made off with and using to play swordfight across the stacks of 
records behind the DJ.   Slim got to be Darth Vader since he's taller, and 
Cutey was OB1 Kenobe.  Cutey forced Slim back until he fell into a huge cup 
of water.  He was spluttering and spitting, with the glo-stick floating on 
the surface.  Pretty funny stuff.

While SDream was hanging out with Rikki, I met Ariel.   <whistle through 
teeth> What a babe!  We've seen her at a couple of Bps, and she's such the 
PLUR kiddy!

Speaking of kitties, about that time we saw DJ Log Cat spinning!  Well of 
course all the little hamstas ran up to the speakers and started squeaking 
at the top of their lungs.  We danced and bopped our stumpy little tails 
off!  After his set, he and Moonpup were talking music, and we dragged them 
off for an adventure.  We decided to sneak off into the woods and have a 
little mini-rave among the trees.  Unfortunately one of the security guards 
saw Moonpup and made him come back.  Which was too bad cause DJ Log Cat laid 
down a set among the trees that was Da Bomb!  We were dancing among the tall 
grass and bushes...

Finally everyone was winding down, so we went back to the chill space.  
Brownie was hanging out with Leslie, giving her a scalp massage.  This means 
running through her hair and jumping up and down on her head.  If anyone saw 
Leslie's hat doing strange things, that's what that was about.

Grumpy got caught in one of those lotion-hand-orgy things where everyone is 
rubbing all their hands together.  He was greasy from one end to the other, 
but I've never seen him so happy...

We found SDream there sitting next to Amber and curled up under his shirt to 
doze for a while.  It's nice and warm in there.  Then, suddenly, SDream was 
moving.  Security was kicking us all out.  I guess none of us saw SDream 
leave his camera in the chill space.  We heard later that someone did find 
it, but in spite of security asking him to drop off the camera at lost and 
found, he kept it.  What a jerk!  The guy had purple shorts and a blue 
backpack, and his friend was wearing a Kelly green tank top.  If you know 
this guy please oh please drop Sdream a line, ok?  He's left voice messages 
for the Harmony crew but hasn't gotten a message back yet one way or the other.

Well, it was about time to bug out, but there was this huge crowd waiting 
for a bus.  At first we hung with SDream and Marty, munching on sunflower 
seeds and watching this cool whistling football fly through the air while 
listening to the drummers do their thing.  

But after a while we got  bored so we called a cab -- not easy, it took Slim 
and Cutey both to hold the receiver while Spaz jumped on the numbers to dial 
the phone.  And then of course we have to shout in the phone to be heard.  
Geez.  They've got a button on the phone for mutes, you'd think they'd have 
one on there small rodents or something...

So if you saw a cab drive up with some guys in it and then leave empty, 
well, it wasn't empty.  If you'd looked close enough, you'd have seen tiny 
little faces at the window and little paws waving goodbye...

Slim stuck around and helped clean up, but all he could pick up were the 
cigarette butts, and there were a BUNCH!

Thanks go out to the Harmony crew for creating such an incredible event!

<paw print>  

Thomas Covenant Hamsta, esq.


From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Thu Sep 19 22:02:58 1996

             HARVEST MOON


A free event on Friday September 27th - the night of the Full Moon

>From a tribal drum circle at sunset to breakfast at sunrise

All DJs are planning to REALLY mix it up from tekno to trance, gabber to
ambient, Old School to Celestial with lots of strange detours along the way.

Please come with an open heart, a big smile, sensible shoes (for walking
up the cliff) and a flashlight (so you don't walk off of the cliff)

>>>1.  Their #1 product would be Microsoft "Winders '95"
>>

>>

bag.
>>

>>

>>
>>>6.  The "Recycle Bin" in Winders '95 would be an outhouse.
>>
>>>7.  Whenever you pulled up the Sound Player you'd hear a digitized drunk
yelling "Free Bird!"
>>

"Achy-Breaky Heart."
>>

>>

>>

>>

	.heatsync "jupiter" ep
	.release date
	.october 7 1996

on monday october 7 1996, orbitrecords will release heatsync's
first recorded work, the jupiter ep.  this 12" release features
four tracks of progressive dance music.

heatsync's sound is unique -- a blend of hard percussive beats and
sweeping analog synthesizer tones that pushes the boundaries of
musical genre.

audio samples of selected tracks from "jupiter" are available at the
orbitrecords web site in varying degrees of file size and resolution.

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Mon, 9 Sep 1996 13:58:10 -0500
From: FringeWare News Network <email@Fringeware.COM>
Cc: Keith Sullivan <KSullivan@worldnet.att.net>
Subject: UFO - Alien Impregnation Insurance

Sent from: Keith Sullivan <KSullivan@worldnet.att.net>

SPACE-ALIEN IMPREGNATION:  ARE YOU INSURED?

REUTERS

LONDON -- Worried about sex with space aliens, maybe after a trip to
"Independence Day?"

A British broker claimed yesterday to be the first insurer in the world to
offer a policy against impregnation by beings from another planet.

Specialist broker Goodfellow Rebecca Ingrams Pearson (GRIP) said for $155 a
year, adults living in Britain could insure against two sorts of
extraterrestrial interference.

Abduction by aliens would net the victim about $160,000.  Impregnation -- a
risk against which both men and women can insure -- would double that sum.

"I personally would not buy a policy of this nature because I don't think
the risk is commensurate with the premium," said Simon Burgess, GRIP
managing director.  "But if there is the fear of these things out there, we
are justified in offering to cover people against them."

Some U.S. insurers, cashing in on the box-office movie phenomenon
"Independence Day" and on recent evidence that life may have existed on
Mars, have offered policies covering abduction by aliens.

But until now, Burgess said, it has been impossible to insure against being
impregnated by a being from another planet.

I agree!! The Charity crew could use a lot of support!!! This party 
will be coming on Oct. 4th. It will be in the city (sf) and should be 
tons of fun!! The promoter's purpose of this party was and is to bring 
several different sound systems together to form one party, on one 
night. Together, raising some $ for Omar and a local S.F. homeless 
organization (I think). This party is going to have a tremendous impact 
on our scene, which can hopefully lead to a tremendous impact on our 
local world!!! The is much more to talk about regarding this party, so 
keep your eyes and ears open!!! Try to make it on Sunday to find out 
what these guys are all about!!!

> i really believe that drugs like this can help you get in better touch with yourself, and that (even if you never take the drugs again) you _can_ take something of what you learn with you into the rest of your life... but only if you try to.

I have heard a lot of people talk about bringing their ravEing
experiences to the their everyday life (such as Brians example above).
However I haven't heard much in the way as to _how_ a person brings
their experiences with them. 

The way I do this is by sucsessfully *associating* the state I was in at
a rave with something that I can do at any time. Small example: I have
only taken LSD twice in my lifetime, but during both times I was able to
*link* the expierence by running my right thumb across the back of my
left hand twice. So during my trip whenever I felt  a peak I would do
the guesture I gave above. Now my eyes don't exactly dialate into
pankaces when I do this, but I do get a very strong feeling of joy and
satisfaction when I do. And I can do this ANYTIME I WANT! So anytime I
feel frustrated or depressed =( I can instantly put myself back into
that state of pure joy. =)

-=Pengo=-
Blake "Pengo" Merriam

Subject: Re: Technics & accomadation
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Precedence: bulk

>     Or can anyone recommend a good, but less expensive, direct drive
>     turntable that is a good starter ?

I'm not a zen master of equipment, but I wouldn't recommend anything below
Technics 1200's.  I onced goofed around on a friends "DJ" turntables which
looked very nice on the outside...they were Pioneers or something, but
there were slight, easy to miss details that made them harder to use if you
know what 1200's are like  (in this case, these "DJ" tables had a harsh
metal rim around the edges of the platter, which grabbed a sucka hold on
the slipmats, and made cueing, scratching, etc *very* difficult.

I'm sure there were other details that I would have noticed if I'd spent
more time on them (or if I knew half of what some other people know about
equipment)

There's a reason why 1200's are considered the standard...don't sell
yourself short.   You might regret it.


-Peter

     Idea!
     
     Next rave, everybody rub Pengo's left hand with their right thumbs at 
     once... I wanna see what happens.
     
     8P   
     
     I know what you mean though.. If I'm in a good mental/physical state, 
     I can get body rushes just by willing them.  A lot of people who have 
     done acid, shrooms or E claim they feel a similar sensation with the 
     isometric tension used when practicing katas, or through other 
     stretching or disciplined motion exercises.
     
     And then there's dancing.  Did anybody else check out Robbie Hardkiss 
     last night in San Jose...? pretty damn good vibe for a club if you ask 
     me (I was the guy in the brown shirt going off under the air 
     conditioner that kept dripping water right in front of the TT's).  
     
     He skipped the needle about three times, but the tasty selections and 
     smooth ass fades more than compensated.  Really really tasty all 
     around.  And you can tell he likes to see people have a good time... I 
     guess I like DJs that scan the crowd before picking out the next 
     track, and seem to really get into it.  Too bad I didn't start really 
     going off until the last half hour or so... he saved some yummy 
     uptempo acid tracks for last.  Makes you appreciate it more if you 
     haven't heard it all night.  .. and then they closed ... DOH!  If it 
     ain't the carding and the money and the security and the people who 
     get evil on booze (I strive to be a happy drunk) and the bullshit then 
     its that 2:00am thing.  Yuk! phooey!  Clubs... eeewwwww... this one 
     was much better than most though.
     
     Aieee my head...
     AndyW

     And now for the scoop...
     
     I was reading an old copy of High Times (too much time on me hands) 
     that had an article concerning that very shoe.
     
     I'm paraphrasing here, so all quotes are top o de head...
     
     +++++++++++++++++++++
     
     They were originally named the Chronic because some researchers 
     determined it was a cool slang for "the Best", and that would help it 
     sell to the groovy younger crowd.
     
     Some marketing agent decided they had to pull the name the Chronic 
     after some higher ups heard that it's a slang for a strain of strong 
     marijuana (*you're shittin me*).  The name was changed, but at time of 
     printing, they were still serious about getting them to market (I 
     recall the issue was about a year and a half old).
     
     +++++++++++++++++++++
     
     Boy they sure seem to be acting naive... I wonder what their marketing 
     staff would do if we told them how great their three stripe track 
     suits look under a black light when they leave knappy trails that just 
     surpass any other non-baterry powered garment known to humans.
     
     Work, I only do it for the money.
     AndyW

The hemp Adidas ARE available, although I didn't know they were 
called the Chronic (hee hee hee).  I've seen them both in "Soccer 
Madness" (a soccer clothes/supplies mail order catalog) and at a 
store in Seattle called "The American Hemp Merchantile."  (uh, I wish 
I had the number, but I don't...you can always do 206.555.1212 and 
ask the nice information folks...)  They are pretty dang phat, I 
would have to say.

     Hi all :
     
     I started to send a mail with a couple of questions and ended up with 
     the following list. It is a San Francisco Bay area "Best of.." from 
     the unique viewpoint of those of us on the scene.
     
     1.Anyone bought any good cd compilations lately (all genres)? 
     
     2.What's on your playlists ?
     
     3.Any good RR books/literature that you feel is too good to keep to 
     yourself ? Inquiring minds (i.e. me) want to know.
     
     4.Best free dance magazine ?
     
     5.Best commercial dance magazine (domestic) ?
     
     6.Best commercial dance magazine (imported) ?
     
     7.What are your favorite clothes stores ?
     
     8.What are your fav music stores ?
     
     9.Best place for a beer (and dance music) ?
     
     10.Best place to go after the party's ended ? who said "home" ?

     12.Best radio station for house/techno/dub/trance ?
     
     13.Best natural high ?
     
     14.Best place to hear newest records ?  
     
     15.Best place to buy used dj equipment ?
     
     16.Best place to buy used stereo equipment?
     
     17.Best place to bring a rave newbie ?
     
     18.Best illegal high (duh !) ?
     
     19.Best place to have a spiritual raving experience ?
     
     20.Best Sunday party ?
     
     21.Best Dj - Garage house/progressive house ?
     
     22.Beat Dj - Goa Trance
     
     23.Beat Dj - Jungle
     
     24.Best Dj - Techno
     
     25.Best Dj - Trip hop/downbeat
     
     26.Best Dj hip/hop
     
     27.Best Dj (Eclectic)
     
     28.Best Dj (all categories)
     
     29.Best one-off this year (so far)
     
     30.Best regular event (indoors)
     
     31.Best regular event(outdoors).
     
     32.Best kept secret (club)
     
     33.Best record label ?
     
     34.Best clothes label ?
     
     35.Best outdoor party for those not driving ?   
     
     36.Best mixer ?
     
     37.Best collective ?
     
     38.Best company to rent a sound system from ?
     
     39. Best visual/lighting company fort your party ?
     
     40.Best place to pick up rave flyers ?
     
     41.Best company for printing flyers ?
     
     42.Best weekly :
        
        Monday,Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, Saturday, Sunday
     
     PLease send your replies along with any other category suggestions to 
     me and I will post the results next week.

I spent part of this afternoon and evening collecting some statistics
on sfraves that I think may stimulate some discussion. I was surprised by
some of the things I found, and profoundly unsurprised by others. I hope
that this message causes all of you to think about what this list was
designed for and how we're all using it.

If you don't want to look at all of these boring statistics, at least
skip to the end and read my conclusions. I think you all might find them
thought-provoking, if not completely flameworthy.


STATISTICS
==========

Number of subscribers to sfraves: 429

Number of distinct hosts in subscriber list [1]: 234

Number of top-level domains in subscriber list: 195

January    1899549 (~1.8 Mb)
February   2008795 (~1.9 Mb)
March      2821839 (~2.8 Mb)

June       2375955 (~2.3 Mb)
July       4168784 (~4.1 Mb)
August     4092664 (~4.0 Mb)
September  2152850 (~2.1 Mb) [2]

Total size of 1996 archives: 26,959,736 bytes (~26 Mb)

Total network bandwidth [3]: 6,308,578,224 bytes (~6Gb)

January     972

March      1506

Posts with NRR (Non-Rave-Related) in the subject [4]: 801

NOTES
=====

[1] The number of distinct hosts is the number of machines in the
    subscriber list, not the number of domains

[2] September archive statistics only include the month to date.

[3] Network bandwidth is computed by multiplying the number of distinct
    hosts by the total size of the archive files, because it is only
    necessary to initiate one SMTP connection per host, regardless of the
    number of sfraves subscribers at that host.

[4] The NRR subject tag is not used rigorously and was only adopted
    halfway through this year.

[5] BSP also is not used rigorously.

[6] This was a first-level approximation: I don't include the messages
    that initiate a thread, and I don't even attempt to track threads
    whose names change. This may lead to skewed results, but hey, I'm not
    being paid to do this, so deal.

[7] Many of the most frequent posters have changed email addresses at
    least once. If I was able to figure out their previous email
    addresses, I incorporated them into the figure for their most recent
    address. I may have missed a few, though.

[8] This does not include foreign subscribers who have email addresses
    through US domains (.com, .edu, etc.)


CONCLUSIONS
===========

I have been an sfraves subscriber since September of 1993, when I was a
student at the University of Montana. Over the course of the last three
years, both the list and my relationship to it have changed profoundly.
In those three years, sfraves has gone through many sets of active
participants, and the list has spawned many beautiful and unique
organizations (Friends and Family being perhaps the most prominent). I,
too, have changed, first becoming a DJ, and then a community-oriented
rave promoter (in Montana) myself.

SFRaves has never been the most focused or terse of mailing lists. Part
of its charm is that it is the voice of a community, and not just a place
for people to announce (or plan) parties. People in the community care
about each other, and one of the things that makes the Bay Area's rave
scene one of the world's most vibrant is its commitment to fostering a
caring, vibe-heavy community spirit. I admired this spirit enough to make
it one of the primary things that drew me to San Francisco.

However, it is my considered opinion that SFRaves used to be a much more
useful and easy-to-deal-with resource than it is now. Over the last year,
I've watched the amount of traffic on the list skyrocket while the amount
of actual information has remained pretty much constant. I find myself
deleting messages unread far more frequently than I used to, and I often
find myself purging whole threads.

Often these threads have nothing at all to do with raving. I know that
this has been discussed often on the list over the years, and I'm not
going to be a dick about this, but I will say that the number of threads
that have left me rolling my eyes in frustration has increased sharply
over the last year. 

It is a mistake to assume that we all share the same ideology. It's
probably a mistake to assume that we share anything at all, beyond a love
for raving and a fondness for dance music (in its most general sense -- I
love hard techno, dark jungle, and extremely minimal, quirky hard house,
can deal with trip hop, breakbeat house and old-school trance, and
absolutely cannot stand Goa trance, garage, and disco. Are any of your
tastes exactly the same as mine? I don't _think_ so).

I'll very quickly point out that I don't think that any problems with the
list are any individual's fault -- it's just the way that the atmosphere
has changed on the list over time, and that I personally liked the list
better back in the old days. I've talked to many other "old-school"
subscribers about this recently (many of them people who've been on the
list since it was hosted on techno.stanford.edu) and they've voiced a
similar sense of discontenment.

I'm not trying to start a flamewar here, only making a heartfelt plea. I
think there are a lot of wonderful, interesting people on this list, but
could we talk about raves a little more and the random other stuff a
little less? I personally would like sfraves a _lot_ more if we
collectively tried a little bit harder to keep our messages focused on
raves and raving. Barring that, could everybody try a little harder to
post fewer, more informative messages? Eric (Peterson), I don't mean to
single you out, but if you look at my statistics, you've posted almost
two messages for _every_ _day_ in 1996. Doesn't that seem just a tiny bit
excessive?

Something to remember is that each and every message you post consumes a
healthy amount of bandwidth. As I point out in the statistics I've
compiled, each message posted to sfraves initiates 234 network
connections so that the mail can be distributed. That's a good chunk of
network bandwidth. Hyperreal has an _extremely_ heavy mail load. While
the whole reason that Hyperreal exists is for all of us to have a
resource, I think it would be nice to remember that we all have to share
the machine and that network bandwidth, like other resources, benefits
from conservation and prudent usage.

Anyway, I've ranted enough for one night, so I'll step down off the soap
box and fade back into the shadows. I've been very frustrated with the
list recently and have been strongly considering unsubscribing, but I
figured I'd give the list one more chance. You are all beautiful people
(albeit often in fashions that are completely foreign to me), but I can
only take so much noise in my inbox, you know?

ozymandias

PS -- If people find these statistics useful, I may consider posting them
semi-regularly. I may even figure out more statistically valid things to
monitor. If you have ideas about these sorts of things, please get in
touch with me.

       . . . the self-reflecting image of a narcotized mind . . .
