From: knucklehead@club.net (Knucklehead)
Subject: It was fun, time to go home
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

First off let me tell you it has been the best 1 1/2 years here in the SF
rave scene and I'm sad to say I have to return home. I'm not from this time
period. That's right you heard me correct. I'm from the year 2095, 100
years from now.

I was sent back in time to hopefully make a change in the rave scene. You
see, in the year 2090 all rave music was band. Any type that you would hear
at a rave or similar party was band for reason unknown, or at least it is
keeped secret. If you are caught with and type of that music, you were sent
to a holding cell for 5 years and a 10,000 credit fine, Oh, credits there
are like dollars here,  If you were caught with any type of flyer the was 3
years and 7,500 credit fine. We threw underground parties once a month or
every other month and when I say underground, it was just that. Some of us
dug underground tunnels about 100 feet below the surface and used cement
and made little homes there and places to have parties. However it was
getting so bad that we had to do something. With technology so advance from
my time period, we have determined the time period the rave scene was
influenced and when it started to effect my time period in a negative way.

I was sent here to bring a positive vibe to this scene and to hopefully
influence some people about how great this scene is.  I had to reach 6
individuals that in some way effected our scene in 2095. Touch them in
anyway I could that was positive. My supervisor would contact me when there
was progress. Well that time has come.Two weeks ago I was told that our
monthly party ended up getting busted, but no one was fined or sent to the
holding cell. This has never happened since 2089. Usually the promoters was
sent to the holding cell for life, equipment taken and smashed into nothing
and records melted. Whoever they caught was sent to the holding cell for
the normal 5 years and 10,000 credit fine. Anyway, no one was busted. So
something was changed in 1996 that effected that. My supervisor didn't want
to take a chance and told me to stay until the end of the month. The
security droids that busted the party might have been tampered with or it
is a plan to draw us out more so they can bust more people.

Last night I was contacted again and was told they had 3 other parties 1
underground and 2 in the deserted area in Old San Francisco's warehouse
sector. This was the first ground level parties since 2089. The security
droids came, looked around and said have a good time and keep it under
control. My supervisor has told me my mission was succesful and to come
home, they have looked over all the data from the computers and the time
line has been changed.

So, with everything going good there I must return. To all the people I've
met, I wish you the best. It has been alot of fun. I can't wait to go back
home to tell some of your grandchildren that there grandparent were some of
the greatest people I've known and show them pictures that I've collected.
In 2095, I party with alot of your grandchildren and you will love what
they have done for our scene in 2095, you'd be proud. Maybe I'll get lucky
and visit again in 15 years. That's when I'll be able to time warp again.

Until then, keep the scene alive

Tim (knucklehead)

Message-Id: <s247a239.050@gcwf.com>
X-Mailer: Novell GroupWise 4.1
Date: Tue, 24 Sep 1996 08:56:47 -0700
From: Ariel Stallings <ASTALLINGS@gcwf.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com, mswietzke@ucdavis.edu
Subject:  Circle dancing -Reply
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

The main thing I have against circle dancing is that it is an ego-based
dancing style. I mean yes, it's fun to have people watch you when you're
dancing, and it's fun to trade energy back and forth, but cirlces always
seem to become "HEY CHECK THIS SHIT OUT."  And then, after some
breaks, "HA!  CAN >>YOU<< TOP THAT?!"  Then the next person steps
out and does their funky shit and the ego-masterbation continues.

Funny story:  At a Frankie Bones party in Seattle a few months ago, a
circle got formed and all of a sudden the record SCREACHES to a halt
and Frankie starts screaming "YO SEATTLE!  This ain't muthafuckin' 1983!
 It's 1996, muthafuckers, so FUCK THE BREAKDANCING SHIT."  I have
never laughed so hard as when I watched the geared-out breakpimps
slink their way off the floor with their tails between their legs.

I would agree that they are fun to watch though at times, although the
people in circles always seem to take their shit very serious.  There's
very little fun in circle dancing, most of the time...

just my.02
Ariel

David Lowe asked about a Thursday night eclipse/full moon/harvest moon party.

I haven't heard about this either, unless he is thinking of the Benifit for
SF Food Not Bombs with DRC, Mars, Mystr-e, and Tomcat. 

In any case, this party is at El Rio, 3158 Mission near Ceasar Chavez.  It
starts at nine, ends at two.  There will be free vegitarian food included
with door price ($5, sliding scale; no one turned away for lack of funds).
Should be tremendous.  What better way to celebrate the harvest than to
dance for food!

Peace,
Kerry

A free event on Friday September 27th - the night of the Full Moon

>From a tribal drum circle at sunset to breakfast at sunrise

With Bonnie (New Moon) Dave Bayer (FnF) Ronan (River, St John's)
     Jerry Bonham (yes!) and Jim Cyr (F8, River)

All DJs are planning to REALLY mix it up from tekno to trance, gabber to
ambient, Old School to Celestial with lots of strange detours along the way.

Please come with an open heart, a big smile, sensible shoes (for walking
up the cliff) and a flashlight (so you don't walk off of the cliff)

FIRE DANGER IS EXTREMELY HIGH - NO SMOKING EXCEPT ON THE BEACH

All volunteer help lugging equipment greatly appreciated !!!!

Directions will be posted at noon on the 27th at (415) 437-2378.

Subject: Re: Circle dancing -Reply

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey,

I occasionally appreciate circle dancing, especially among a group of
dancers that have been dancing next to each other all night.  I like the
mutual encouragement that happens between the circle and the person in
the middle.  When I dance sober I draw a lot of energy and inspiration
from the dancers around me.  (I don't feel really confident about my
dancing. I don't have any 'moves'.  If you ever see me on the floor, you
know I am there because my urge to move is greater than my shyness.)  I
am mostly trying to find a way for my body to express what I am feeling
about the music.  While I am out there I notice others going through
similar forms of thought, and it is really great when a fellow dancer
starts really "figurin' it out" on the floor.  (You know, the point that
your body and mind are working together in a way that makes you
personally pleased with yourself.)  Dancing makes you feel good about
yourself, might as well show it.  I never read anything negative into
the cocky arrogance displayed by the person in the middle.   The
competitiveness that I have seen always seems to be in the spirit of
fun.  Circle dancing is pretty neat-o by me.

Dance on,
D.

> Date: Mon, 23 Sep 1996 19:02:24 -0700 (PDT)
> From: "Matt Wietzke\DJ Xpress" <mswietzke@ucdavis.edu>
> 
> I know this has probably come up mucho times, but why do most people dislike
> circle dancing?

Circle dancing reminds me of where am I and what I'm doing. It causes
me to stop and watch some else dance because my attention has been
distracted. Dancing can be a meditative state, and watching someone
else showing their stuff can make me become self-aware of what I'm
doing. Although sometimes I'm thankful because it reminds me to rest
and get water.

Also, it means less roomon the dance floor for everyone else.

Steve

Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

My S.O thinks circle dancing is pretentious so I always feel a little 
guilted but sometimes I like to dance in circles as of late. It really 
depends on the particular circle though, whether or not I want to join 
it. Some circles are very supportive and enthusiastic, and are a way for 
you to absolutely break loose that dancing alone may not always inspire; 
others are carriers of dread territorialism tripped out immaturity. Big 
circles I agree do Suck! 
I think some people take it way seriously because it can be such an 
intense, concentrated form of communication.If you notice gestures, the 
most minute movement can convey so much. Dancing -with- other people is 
interesting, -showing- people your story through dance is powerful indeed.

PLEASE LOUISE PRODUCTIONS
=46OR IMMEDIATE RELEASE 	 CONTACT: Jeffrey Winter, (415) 864-5453


ANNOUNCING A UNIQUE ART EXPOSITION DEDICATED
TO THE LIMITLESS POSSIBILITIES OF THE PROJECTED IMAGE...

PROJEXPO '96
VIDEO =83 FILM =83 SLIDES =83 SOUNDS =83 ENVIRONZ

=46RIDAY, SEPTEMBER 27, 8:30 PM - ?,
at THE JEWELRY STORE, 2519 MISSION ST. IN S.F.

Nineteen Bay Area artists present an eclectic range of video, film,
slides, sculptures, installations, and performances as part of PROJEXPO
'96, Friday, September 27, 8:30 p.m., at The Jewelry Store, 2519
Mission Street in San Francisco. Part media technology exposition, part
experimental laboratory, and in all ways a multimedia "happening,"
PROJEXPO is dedicated to decidedly non-conventional approaches to the
presentation and context of the projected image in contemporary art and
entertainment. Produced by San Francisco's queer media arts group
Please Louise Productions, PROJEXPO will transform the studios,
performance stages, and lounges of The Jewelry Store into a sprawling
high-stim audio/visual landscape, created out of the visions of
accomplished media artists and professionals who are seeking to expand
their craft beyond the confines of traditional two-dimensional
presentation into a more fully immersive experience. Representative
works include filmmaker Jon Bush's Multiple Projector Montage using
custom screens, four Super-8 film projectors, and mirrors;
multidisciplinary artist Michael Dates' sculptural installation Milk
Porn, composed of a distressed pornographic film imulsion loop
projected on a vibrating pool of milk; an installation/performance by
Mark Ewert and Daniel Hinojo-Baca incorporating live video feeds
entitled Two Mimes in a Live Painting;  a multiple-monitor installation
featuring the signature queer-pop video collages of Museo Contempo; and
a two-hour program of independent film and video works curated by
Jeffrey Winter and Sharon Donahue. At Midnight, PROJEXPO '96 attendees
will be treated to a special  90-minute screening of the finest in
trash, glam, and cult films, hosted by Fred Adler of The Jewelry Store.

PROJEXPO '96 occurs for one special night only, Friday, September 27,
8:30 p.m. (sharp!), at The Jewelry Store, 2519 Mission St., in S.F. A
$5 donation is requested at the door. For more info., please call
Please Louise Productions at (415) 864-5453.
pg. 1 of 2

pg. 2 of 2
PROJEXPO '96:
PARTIAL LIST OF WORKS TO BE EXHIBITED

Pee-Cam
Concept/Installation by Bert Green.  Hidden surveillance camera records
private moments within public lavatory space.

Hypo-Kino
Queer-pop video collages by Museo Contempo displayed on hidden video
monitors are reflected by spatial composition of mirrors.

Milk Porn
Installation by Michael Dates with distressed film imulsion loop
projected on a vibrating pool of milk.

Transparency on Water Projection
Installation by Heather Haynes will spotlight focused on color
transparency floating in bowl of water.

Textures Descending Stairs
Video monitor installation by Museo Contempo using text based visuals.

2 Mimes in a Live Painting
Concept/Performance incorporating live video feeds by Mark Ewert and
Daniel Hinojo-Baca

Lunatic Vidi-Fest [Program]
Two-hour independent film and video works curated by Jeffrey Winter and
Sharon Donahue.  At the discretion of hosts, the stage will be open to
spontaneous Dada-inspired performance action.

Psychic Surgery
Multimedia performance/hosted strangeness by Fred Adler

Psycho-Sex-Ax
Concept/Performance featuring projected settings by Museo Contempo with
=46elicity Perez as Marion Crane.  [Performances at 9:45, 10:45 & 11:45]

Dress Slide Show
Slide projection environments by Lissa Ivy with suspended
"figure-screens".

Underwater Fantasy
Sculptural screens and sound compositions by Pam Kibbee and Tom
Williams using video projection on layers of netting stretched on
lightweight metal frames.

Multiple Projector Montage
=46ilm projection installation by Jon Bush using custom screens, multiple
projectors and mirrors.

Reel-to-Reel Tent
Installation by Charles-Hermann Wurmfeld using enclosed tent/screen
structure for continuous loop projection using 2 devices and magnifying
glass.

Movie Madness (12 midnight)
=46ilm shorts and cult/trash/glam feature with popcorn for audience.
Hosted by "Hitch" [Fred Adler].

TV Guide
Concept/Design by Jackrabbit.  Walking wearable audio/video sculpture
that confronts audience personally and directly with it's technology
and presence.

______________________________ Reply Separator _________________________________
Subject: Re: Circle dancing
Author:  Rebecca Klassen <rdk4@axe.humboldt.edu> at ccsmtp
Date:    9/24/96 3:15 PM


My S.O thinks circle dancing is pretentious so I always feel a little 
guilted but sometimes I like to dance in circles as of late. It really 
depends on the particular circle though, whether or not I want to join 
it. Some circles are very supportive and enthusiastic, and are a way for 
you to absolutely break loose that dancing alone may not always inspire; 
others are carriers of dread territorialism tripped out immaturity. Big 
circles I agree do Suck! 
I think some people take it way seriously because it can be such an 
intense, concentrated form of communication.If you notice gestures, the 
most minute movement can convey so much. Dancing -with- other people is 
interesting, -showing- people your story through dance is powerful indeed.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Tue Sep 24 15:55:59 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id PAA17858; Tue, 24 Sep 1996 15:55:59 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from emout11.mail.aol.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with SMTP id PAA17813; Tue, 24 Sep 1996 15:55:49 -0700 (PDT)
From: Hughdhyana@aol.com
Received: by emout11.mail.aol.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) id SAA07442 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Tue, 24 Sep 1996 18:55:17 -0400
Date: Tue, 24 Sep 1996 18:55:17 -0400
Message-ID: <960924185517_528903169@emout11.mail.aol.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: a review about an attempt-(I just can't call it a rave)
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well, I went to this thing on Saturday night in Monterey. It was at the CBS
affiliate news station by the fairgrounds... our hopes were high, and our
minds were open but,

we left early-which is really hard to get me to do.

I'm not sure who the promoters were, although they stopped us on the way out
of the door, (more on that later) but, they were really concerned with
getting something solid established down here, which I respect.

Anyway, the first Dj (He was the main promoter, didn't get a name) spun some
OK stuff, but it just seemed like he was spinning all of his favorites
together. He didn't stick to a format. We heard hardcore, next to house, next
to the trainspotting soundtrack, next to tracks we knew from the Dj Dan CD,
next to house, next to house, next to house, next to house. A real
hodgepodge. Not really the way to create a solid vibe, or a solid
underground. As a result, there were always a number of individuals who were
standing on the perimeter. I tried to trance out and get lost in the music,
which is usually easy for me, but never got there. 

Then they faded out to dead air instead of blending the next Dj in- ACK!
Then, when the next guy started, it was weak and he proceeded to play nothing
but house, which didn't seem to have the masses enthralled. (nor I- what do I
have to do to hear some trance, tribal, breakbeat, trip-hop, even acid jazz
in  the Monterey area?)

xthat was when we left.

On our way out, a co-promoter of the event stopped us, surprised that we
would leave. We had to explain that we weren't used to so much house music
and that we just weren't into it. The guy really made us feel kinda guilty
that we had the nerve to leave, and then asked,"If you heard that this were
going to happen next month, would you come?"   -I didn;t want to say "no" so,
I told him I'd think about it. ;]

The whole experience left me disappointed, and thinking that I may always
have to drive at least an hour and a half to be where I wanna be. Oh, well,
it'll just feel like a Moontribe excursion!

-Hoping to make it to that full moon/beach thing!-
xhughx

Rudi Rughoonundon wrote:
>
>How about SF-Raves starts to rate the raves ?
>
Unfortunately, so many parties that seem good by what is shown on the 
flyer don't hold up to expectations.  Conversely, there are parties that 
look like they would be *ah'iyt* but actually end up *blowin' up*.  So 
what do we have to go off of to decide what parties are going to be good?

First and foremost should be MUSIC.  What DJ's are playing, what live 
acts?  Remember that an out-of-town DJ does not necessarily mean a good 
DJ.  Although usually, an out of town DJ is good, there are several times 
I have been disappointed.  Also, hearing different DJ's has always been 
exciting to me. Some are good, some I didn't care for.  Some DJ's change 
their styles and abilities over time.  I do get tired of hearing certain 
DJ's too often in a time period.  So, maybe we can't always tell how the 
music is going to be.

Next, take a look at who is throwing the party.  If the last time you 
went to one of their parties, it was *BOOTY!*, there's chance it may be 
like that again.  But, there are some promoters that almost consistently 
throw great parties, but have an occasional bomb.

Now, Moonbounces, Velcro Walls, 80 Zillion watts of toe-tapping bass and 
carnival rides does not a good party make.  No, that would be a good 
carnival, not a good rave.  So, short of calling LaToya Jackson or Jean 
Dixon there is no exact science to knowing how a party will be beforehand 
(Hmmm, have you ever seen those two in the same room together?  *twilight 
zone theme-doo dee doo doo*).  As for rating parties before they happen, 
I don't believe that that could be done in a fair way.

Locations for most of my favorite parties have been undisclosed until 
tickets went on sale.  So, raves cannot be graded on that.  So, that 
pretty much leaves the line up and promoter track record.  But, even 
those are left up to someone's opinion.  Seeing how each person's 
experience at a party is unique, it would be difficult to put a number 
down that represented how the party will be.

Solutions?  I have no freakin' clue!  I still end up at lame parties 
occasionally despite my efforts not to.  A promoter will always pump up 
their own party, so they tend to be a bit biased.  Some DJ's are like 
that to.  The best bet is to ask your friends who have similar tastes to 
you, and trust your instinct.  Usually it is correct, but it can at times 
fail you.  

Vaguely Yours
Dre

P.S.  If you come up with some sort of rave chosing algorythm, please 
send it my way.3

Date: Tue, 24 Sep 96 18:37:42 pst
From: "Andy Wyszkowski" <awyszkow@smtplink.acer.com>
Message-Id: <9608248436.AA843615989@smtplink.acer.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Circle Dancing and It's Victims on the Next Geraldo...
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     
     At least circle jerking promotes involvement.
     
     Circle dancing seems pretty passive (20 people doing nothing, one 
     person jammin their ass off).  I was at a party where only like three 
     people danced in a 12 foot circle all night, and the rest of the place 
     was crowded as fuck.  All that room for what?  Gimme a break.
     
     Go to a party where everybody is dancing their asses off for the love 
     of music ... nobody is showing off, just loving the music enough to 
     commit their bodies to it.  That's fun.  I don't want somebody to stop 
     me and show me how much badder they are.  I'm really not interested.  
     I bet your car is nicer too... maybe your girlfriend has more 
     fashionable features this month than whoever I'm dating or with ... 
     maybe you can even kick my ass or beat me at chess .... I don't think 
     it's about that (well I'm hoping at least).
     
     Raving is about the collective group's search for individual happiness 
     and I don't think frontin and the often competitive nature of dance 
     circles add to my personal experience.  I've seen vibey circles at big 
     raves off to the side somewhere and that's totally cool.  There is a 
     beauty to doing anything that makes you happy, I've lived vicariously 
     through so many of you and shared your joy.  I don't understand the 
     circles, or what makes them fun for people (well when some of those 
     guys do the ol school head spin stuff it is pretty clean), but I could 
     say that at small parties they fuck it up for me a little because they 
     limit the places I can go, and sometimes keep a real protective vibe 
     (you can't come in here..).
     
     My 2 zloty
     AndyW

At 07:37 AM 9/24/96 -0700, you wrote:
knucklehead@club.net (Knucklehead)
>First off let me tell you it has been the best 1 1/2 years here in the SF
>rave scene and I'm sad to say I have to return home. I'm not from this time
>period. That's right you heard me correct. I'm from the year 2095, 100
>years from now.
>
>I was sent back in time to hopefully make a change in the rave scene. You
>see, in the year 2090 all rave music was band. Any type that you would hear
>at a rave or similar party was band for reason unknown, or at least it is
>keeped secret. If you are caught with and type of that music, you were sent
>to a holding cell for 5 years and a 10,000 credit fine, Oh, credits there
>are like dollars here,  If you were caught with any type of flyer the was 3
>years and 7,500 credit fine. We threw underground parties once a month or
>every other month and when I say underground, it was just that. Some of us
>dug underground tunnels about 100 feet below the surface and used cement
>and made little homes there and places to have parties. However it was
>getting so bad that we had to do something. With technology so advance from
>my time period, we have determined the time period the rave scene was
>influenced and when it started to effect my time period in a negative way.
>
>I was sent here to bring a positive vibe to this scene and to hopefully
>influence some people about how great this scene is.  I had to reach 6
>individuals that in some way effected our scene in 2095. Touch them in
>anyway I could that was positive. My supervisor would contact me when there
>was progress. Well that time has come.Two weeks ago I was told that our
>monthly party ended up getting busted, but no one was fined or sent to the
>holding cell. This has never happened since 2089. Usually the promoters was
>sent to the holding cell for life, equipment taken and smashed into nothing
>and records melted. Whoever they caught was sent to the holding cell for
>the normal 5 years and 10,000 credit fine. Anyway, no one was busted. So
>something was changed in 1996 that effected that. My supervisor didn't want
>to take a chance and told me to stay until the end of the month. The
>security droids that busted the party might have been tampered with or it
>is a plan to draw us out more so they can bust more people.
>
>Last night I was contacted again and was told they had 3 other parties 1
>underground and 2 in the deserted area in Old San Francisco's warehouse
>sector. This was the first ground level parties since 2089. The security
>droids came, looked around and said have a good time and keep it under
>control. My supervisor has told me my mission was succesful and to come
>home, they have looked over all the data from the computers and the time
>line has been changed.
>
>So, with everything going good there I must return. To all the people I've
>met, I wish you the best. It has been alot of fun. I can't wait to go back
>home to tell some of your grandchildren that there grandparent were some of
>the greatest people I've known and show them pictures that I've collected.
>In 2095, I party with alot of your grandchildren and you will love what
>they have done for our scene in 2095, you'd be proud. Maybe I'll get lucky
>and visit again in 15 years. That's when I'll be able to time warp again.
>
>Until then, keep the scene alive
>
>Tim (knucklehead)
>
>
>
>

Hi all!

 A reminder that Greg's B-Day party is this Saturday. It will also be 
another benefit for Omar and his Mom. As such I'm donating my time and 
equipment for both these causes. I encourage everyone to bring Greg a 
little something to make him smile!! I'll be the solo performer in the 
ambient room (YES!!) and I promise to be in a better mood and to fully GO 
OFF!!!

 I have transportation lined up but again could use some help. I need 
manuel labor (before AND after the party), some dayglo banners, and my 
sound system could use some assitance; mainly some subs [I have a Crown 
Macro 1200 to power the subs and a x-over] and a pair of medium size 
2-ways [12 inch woofer and horn] to help with surrond sounds would be cool.
If you are driving from far away we can pay your gas but otherwise this 
IS a benefit and we are trying to keep costs down. Guests are 
proportional to work and/or equipment donated. Prior DDreams crew members 
get first crack at this.

THANKS!!!!!!     =)

From: crunch@well.com (John Draper)
Subject: Just returned from 5 day yoga retreat totally energized
Cc: sd-raves@party.net, socal-raves@UCSD.EDU
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hi,

  I just got back from a 5 day intensive Yoga Retreat,  up at Liberty Retreat,
formed by "The Circle of Friends",  a really great group of people,  who
run this book store in North County (North of San Diego).

  I was in the company of beautiful women,  had great time healing others,
and getting healed...   3 intensive yoga sessions per day,   intensive
meditation,  Tai Chi,  and Tao Yoga sessions.    The Retreat is located
just 2 miles north of the Mexico Border,  about 65 miles East of San Diego,
out in the rugged high desert.  No phone, Email,  or modern conveniences,
but nice bathing deck,  clothing optional,  and a farm like atmosphere.

Wake up at 5 am...
Meditate at 6 am
Meditation walk at 6:30 am
Warm ups and stretching 7 am
Chores at 8 am  (Mine was feeding the farm animals)
Breakfast 8:30 am
Tao Yoga 10:30 am
Lunch 1:00 pm   2 hour break ( hot tub and bathing)
Meditation and breathing  3 pm
Kundalini Yoga,  Tai Chi,  or Feldenkreis 4 pm
   (different each day)
1 hour break 6 pm
Dinner 7 pm
Dance and social activities 8 pm
Discussion group, I ching, tarot readings 9 pm
Healing, Massage, and Raiki 11 pm
Sleep at Midnight

  There were about 20 other people in the group.   More women then men,
excellent relationships developed.  Met some wonderful new friends.
Very structured routines.

  I was gone for 5 days,   and just now getting back to answer my Email
and get in tune with the real world again.  Gathered more than 1000 mail
messages.... so it will be quite sometime before I read all of the rave
related mail.

  I have excellent pictures,  if anyone wants them,  please ask me.
Oh!   Tommorrow and the next day,  I get the DAT recorder,  and exclusive
use of the DJ setup so I'll be re-mixing my tape...   Soon,  I'll have
the money for duping them....  Best price I can offer is $13 per tape.
I want at least $5 per tape in profit.    Hope thats OK with those that
wanted them.

  I rode home with Branden (Narnia promoter),  and he heard the whole mix,
but I discovered that the right turn table had a channel missing,  so this is
why I had to do the re-mix... Branden commented...   "What name will you
want to use,   so I'll know what to put on the flyer?".  He was constantly
re-winding the tape to try and find the point where I mixed it!    :-)

  I've already spun at several parties down here....   :-)    But I would
rather be out on the dance floor....    :-)    :-)

Crunchman

MTV's electronic music show entitled AMP has already run twice and has
aired video's from Autechre , Afex Twin , FSOL , Chemical Bros. and others.
The producers of the show are thinking of making this a regular weekly
thing  from 2-3 am on Saturdays. I have obtained the shows producers e-mail
address and would like to encourage everyone who whould like to see this
show continue to e-mail the producer at pimentoed@aol.com and encourage
them to keep AMP on the air.

Date: Wed, 25 Sep 1996 00:47:48 -0700
Message-Id: <1.5.4.16.19960924004143.38773db8@popd.ix.netcom.com>
X-Sender: shawna-@popd.ix.netcom.com
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Light Version 1.5.4 (16)
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: frisco freaks <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
From: The Laffin Happy Trip Farmer <shawna-@ix.netcom.com>
Subject: belated Auto review
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Went to Auto on Saturday, saw Troy & Nicole (hi troy & nicole! :), went
there with our own SFRaves Ecto! :):)  The location was kinda dank & sweaty
and small, and it was pretty early on into the evening when the sweat &
humidity congealed enough to start dripping on people from the ceilings.  It
was a two level location, the main room was in the basement, felt very much
like a large shoebox, white & rectangular, with speakers & dj at the front.
Upstairs was a music-less chill area to rest in, with a few chairs and lotsa
free water & candy (good call on the free water guys! :)  

The vibe of this party felt very east-coasty, from what I've experienced and
what I've heard others describe.  It was very much like the vibe of that
party I wrote to you guys about in Montreal that I went to with Brad when I
was up visiting him in April.  This was a colder harder vibe, very intense,
that results from an entire room of people *really* getting into the music
and dance nothing else.  No fluffy sparkly chill-room people giving
massages, no beautiful day-glow banners, no black-lights or lasers, none of
the stuff I usually see at parties.  In the chill room, people did just
exactly that and no more.  This room seemed to be used expressly for the
purpose of giving your body a break from the frenzied dancing downstairs &
to cool off because it was so hot & sweaty downstairs.  Looking around, it
really looked like there wasn't anybody who appeared to have partaken of
disco biscuits, people just stood talking with drinks of water in their
hands.  The main room was totally devoid of decoration, blank white walls,
and in fact for lighting the room enough to see, they simply used blank
computer screens that had been turned on, & nothing more.  And it was all
good!  I, as I have mentioned before, totally love the soft & fluffy raver
atmosphere you find at so many vibey underground SF parties, but I still
have a particular love for that one kind of east-coast vibe you find at some
parties, that collective energy from every single person in the room totally
getting off on *really* killer music.  And I *loved* the music!  Good
detroit techno, I don't really hear that too often at the parties I go to
with the exception of the Esteemed Mr. Rice (who I dont see that often
anyway).  Yeah, I don't want that hardcore intense vibe at every party I go
to, but it really is unique and I love to experience it every now and then.
And as usual, really like Jon Santos's set.

And that's about all!

Love,
Shawna

            
          Do not go gentle into that good night!
         Rave! Rave into the dawning of the light!

Yo ravers, got a chance to hear some new mixtapes that I'm adding to the
catalof that you might like to know about...  if ya don't like BSP then
delete us now, I jus thought y'all might like to know about some new D -
O - P - E shit.

My new fave is from DJ Nomad (seattle) "From Within".  I didn't think I
was gonna like this one, but Dr Freecloud's reccomended it to me.  This
is some hypnotic subliminal acid trance shit.  Almost progressive
trance, but mroe "out there".  Kind of along the lines of DRC's "In
Between Worlds" which IMO is a damn excellent tape.

Also I'm listening a lot to Ellis Dee's "Hypnotica", which is deeeeeep
Goa trance, especially the A-side.  Lots of great tight bass there.  I
love a lot of bass in Goa trance.

Got a new one from Tim Lawson (uk) called "Evolution".  Some smooth-ass
progressive trance on that.

Tomorrow I will have the new one from Tony Gamboa which is a most
excellent and underbooked DJ in Los Angeles.  "Chemical Warfare" is the
name of that one, and its rumored to be some sick-ass hard fucking acid
trance.  His older tapes still blow me away, so I can't wait for this
one.

Anyway,
da kooky magic wacky Pure Acid Mixtapes booth will be set up at Magic
Wednesdays,
POSSIBLY the Meat Beat Manifesto show at the American Legion friday, (if
not, I'll be there anyway hanging out)
and Where the Wild Things Are on Saturday.

Seeyakids... may mixtapes be plentiful...
--ken (pure acid mixtapes)
310-793-1021

From: cubensis@well.com (John Bagby)
Subject: NRR: some perspective
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


If we could shrink the Earth's population to a village of precisely 100
people.......with all existing human ratios remaining the same, it
would look like this:

There would be 57 Asians, 21 Europeans, 14 from the Western Hemisphere
(North and South) and 8 Africans.
51 would be female; 49 would be male
70 would be nonwhite; 30 white.
70 would be non-Christian; 30 Christian.
50% of the entire world's wealth would be in the hands of only 6
people and all 6 would be citizens of the United States.
80 would live in substandard housing.
70 would be unable to read.
50 would suffer from malnutrition.
1 would be near death , 1 would be near birth
Only 1 would have a college education.
No one would own a computer

When one considers our world from such an incredibly compressed
perspective, the need for both tolerance and understanding becomes
glaringly apparent........

This was forwarded to me by a friend. If it makes sense to you,
forward it to a friend.

	I don't want this to get into any rants on merits of various
	economic systems -   ;-)    - but I recently found out some
	info that was pretty eye-opening about the tax system in
	our country....

	If the total tax paying population of the US were shrunk to 100
	people (note that I'm saying tax PAYERS, ie those who filed
	income tax returns) then you would find that:

	-  one person is paying 29% of all the taxes (federal income taxes)
	- the top 7 taxpayers are paying HALF of all the taxes
	- the top 25 taxpayers are paying 80% of all the taxes
	- the bottom 50 taxpayers are paying are paying under 5% of all taxes


	If you find this hard to believe, go to the library and look in the
	"Statistical Abstract of the United States", go to the chart on
	taxes paid per income group and work out the percentages
	yourself!

	Arguments over the pros and cons of the "fairness" of this will
	be routed to the bit bucket....


	jim thompson - CUBE ROOT FACT AXON INFO GRID DATA FATE

	id MAA10159; Wed, 25 Sep 1996 12:02:00 -0700
Message-Id: <199609251902.MAA10159@netcom15.netcom.com>
To: Tony Rotundo <tony@xinet.com>
Cc: "San FranDisco Ravers List" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: <NRR> CD player into mixer question? 
In-reply-to: Your message of "Wed, 25 Sep 96 11:44:40 -0800."
             <v03007804ae6f3b952838@DialupEudora> 
Date: Wed, 25 Sep 96 12:01:59 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>Let's say I have a mixer with two phono inputs.  Let's say I want to run a
>CD player into the mixer.  Is is legal to run a CD player into a phono
>input?  Will anything explode or sound really fucked up?

it won't explode, it'll just sound like shit. you could potentially
burn out the phono inputs, but that's very unlikely (unless it's a
gemini :-))

here's da problemz: for one, a phono input has RIAA equalization; for
two, phono levels are in the millivolts or microvolts, CD outs are in
volts (2Volts peak-to-peak maximum typically). even if you attenuate
the output of your CD player into 1/1000 to 1/100 the current output,
you will still have a really fucked up sound with boosted lows and
muted trebles (RIAA equalization -- lowers the level of high-frequency
clicks and pops that invariably occur due to needle tracking over dust
and scratches, and reduces groove width due to reduced bass content...
when a LP is recorded, reverse RIAA equalization is applied which, in
theory, is supposed to cancel out w/ the RIAA equalization in a phono
preamp while reducing the added click/pop noise from playback). Similar
principle is how dolby lowers noise on a tape, except without the bass
boost...

so unless you are desprerate, or unless your mixer has a "line in"
channel, you're SOL with your current mixer. there are mixers with line
and phono inputs out there. for example my pioneer M500 has 4 inputs, 2
switchable between line/phono, 1 switchable between line/cd, 1
switchable between phono/mic.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

At 11:36 AM -0700 9/25/96, J. Cohen wrote:
>i was wondering if anyone had thoughts on the MBM show at the fillmore w/
>dj spooky. im fresh to the area and basically know squat.  is the fillmore

>you attitude cause they are so used to the moshing types and not happy beat
>loving dancing folks?

>years ago with 808 state( whatever happened to those guys).  after seeing
>the ad in the paper for this show i went rumbling through my old industrial

Hello!

Well, let's look at the lineup from last week's calendar:

   Saturday, September 28th - Fantasy Island
   Metro (live), Barbara Tucker (live), Michelle Weeks (live),
   J.Sinister, Scott Richmond, Jeno, Garth, Spun, Tracy, Preston, That
   Kid Chris, Juan Kato, Davidson Ospina, Dreamer, Carlos, Eric
   Davenport, Hipp-E, Ghost, Frank Nitty, Jon Bishop, Pat Allen, Pete
   Avila, Neon Leon, Soulstice, Sounds from the Ground.
   Visuals by Lumatech Intelligent Lighting, Multi-Media Meltdown, Liquid
   Sircus Delights.
   415.437.6905 510.674.8663 916.491.6851 408.793.0287

First thing: Bagkok Tribe is putting on this party. Based on every other
party that they have put on that either I or someone that I trust has
attended, it sucked.

DJ's and live performances aside (there are quite a few in the lineup that
are really good!), and soley basing a recommendation using the "flyer size
is inversely proportional or party's quality" rule, Fantasy Island looks
like it's gonna suck. The DJ's will be great but I suspect that the
attendees will be "not of the most positive possible element."

Your best value (if nothing else is going on) is to stay home invite some
friends over and and listen to your mixtapes -- at least you won't be put
off by the by Adiddas sports-wearing, bad e pimping, circle dancing, 15
year old surburban gangsta-ravers which are sure to find a place like
"Fantasy Island" their home.

And remember, I'm not jaded, I am experienced. :-) -- I have been to *lots*
of parties big and small, and the big ones just don't give me the "rave
vibe" that I think most of us are out there looking for... (i.e. other
Bagkok Tribe parties, Cool World's, etc.)

Then again, if you are a circle dancer from Concord, I bet you'll have a
blast at this one! :-)

"Thompson. Jim" <jthompson@arkons.lmsc.lockheed.com> writes:
> 	If the total tax paying population of the US were shrunk to 100
> 	people (note that I'm saying tax PAYERS, ie those who filed
> 	income tax returns) then you would find that:
> 
> 	-  one person is paying 29% of all the taxes (federal income taxes)
> 	- the top 7 taxpayers are paying HALF of all the taxes
> 	- the top 25 taxpayers are paying 80% of all the taxes
> 	- the bottom 50 taxpayers are paying are paying under 5% of all taxes

The way Jim says it, it may seem that the current system is grossly
unfair, but when you take into account the fact that the top taxpayers
are also the top income-earners, the picture begins to even out.  I
looked in the same source as Jim (Statistical Abstract of the United
States), and I found that:

the top...
   0.7% is making 11.6% of the income, and paying 22.3% of the taxes.
   3.0% is making 21.4% of the income, and paying 36.3% of the taxes.
   6.1% is making 30.2% of the income, and paying 46.8% of the taxes.
  23.7% is making 61.3% of the income, and paying 76.0% of the taxes.

the bottom...
  48.4% is making 12.6% of the income, and paying 4.8% of the taxes.

I mean.. egad! 24% of the population is making 61% of the money, and
paying 76% of the tax! Is anyone surprised by this?

-Sho

Caveats: The above information was calculated using adjusted gross
income (AGI) instead of gross income, since it was the only data
available to me, and it's arguably a better number to be using anyway,
since it's the measurement used to calculate tax burden in the first
place.

References: <http://www.medaccess.com/census/94s0522.htm>

>        I don't want this to get into any rants on merits of various
>        economic systems -   ;-)    - but I recently found out some
>        info that was pretty eye-opening about the tax system in
>        our country....
>
>        If the total tax paying population of the US were shrunk to 100
>        people (note that I'm saying tax PAYERS, ie those who filed
>        income tax returns) then you would find that:
>
>        -  one person is paying 29% of all the taxes (federal income taxes)
>        - the top 7 taxpayers are paying HALF of all the taxes
>        - the top 25 taxpayers are paying 80% of all the taxes
>        - the bottom 50 taxpayers are paying are paying under 5% of all taxes
>
>
>        If you find this hard to believe, go to the library and look in the
>        "Statistical Abstract of the United States", go to the chart on
>        taxes paid per income group and work out the percentages
>        yourself!
>
>        Arguments over the pros and cons of the "fairness" of this will
>        be routed to the bit bucket....
>
>
>        jim thompson - CUBE ROOT FACT AXON INFO GRID DATA FATE


w/o posting how much each of these groups earns on a yearly basis -- info
that is also probably in the statistical abstract -- your statistics only
show that the rich have far more money with which to pay taxes than the
poor.  Income distribution is extremely unequal in the U.S., so of course
the rich pay so much of a proportion of taxes -- they have so much more to
begin with.  Also, taxes are on income, not wealth, which is even more
unequally distributed. We need to know how much money the top 1% makes as a
percentage of total income to assess whether it's fair that they pay 29% of
the taxes.

I can understand if you don't want this to become a big topic, but you make
an observation that cries out for more information.

DJ's jobs are not to be some sort of idol dictating good and bad parties
where they spin.  The DJ's job is getting a large number of people moving.
Although I am not a dj, I can imagine that the larger number of people
you can get moving, the more fun it is to DJ.

I mean, it is not like these promoters are out to do bad things... they
do parties.  If you don't like their idea of how to throw parties, then
you should not go.  Even though BT had some difficulties at their last party,
it DID go off, as I recal.

Sorry, but I think this comment is silly.  A DJs job is to MOVE people,
not to give/deny credibility to promoters.  Sometimes I think people
take partying and party politics way to seriously.  They are just parties, 
after all.

-troy

  OFFICE MEMO         RE> NRR -  That Tax thang             Date:  9/25/96

>        If the total tax paying population of the US were shrunk to 100
>        people (note that I'm saying tax PAYERS, ie those who filed
>        income tax returns) then you would find that:
>
>        -  one person is paying 29% of all the taxes (federal income taxes)
>        - the top 7 taxpayers are paying HALF of all the taxes
>        - the top 25 taxpayers are paying 80% of all the taxes
>        - the bottom 50 taxpayers are paying are paying under 5% of all taxes
>
>
>        If you find this hard to believe, go to the library and look in the
>        "Statistical Abstract of the United States", go to the chart on
>        taxes paid per income group and work out the percentages
>        yourself!
>
>        Arguments over the pros and cons of the "fairness" of this will
>        be routed to the bit bucket....
>
>
>        jim thompson - CUBE ROOT FACT AXON INFO GRID DATA FATE


>w/o posting how much each of these groups earns on a yearly basis -- info
>that is also probably in the statistical abstract -- your statistics only
>show that the rich have far more money with which to pay taxes than the
>poor.  Income distribution is extremely unequal in the U.S., so of course
>the rich pay so much of a proportion of taxes -- they have so much more to
>begin with.  Also, taxes are on income, not wealth, which is even more
>unequally distributed. We need to know how much money the top 1% makes as a
>percentage of total income to assess whether it's fair that they pay 29% of
>the taxes.

>I can understand if you don't want this to become a big topic, but you make
>an observation that cries out for more information.


     It sounds like in the above statement that Income is being distributed unequaly.  I didn't know it was being distributed at all.  Where can I get some?

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Mon, 23 Sep 1996 15:55:08 -0700 (PDT)
From: Chris Parry <laotzu@fsc.fujitsu.com>
To: ctomberg@oracle.com
Subject: Unix For the Masses (fwd)

>>>>> Forwarded message from Chris Parry <laotzu@fsc.fujitsu.com>

Unix For the Masses
 
 From: John Robinson <jr@ksr.com>
 Date: Thu, 12 Aug 93 11:50:06 EDT
 Subject: The beast himself
 
 ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 
 Linda Branagan is an expert on daemons. She has a T-shirt that sports
 the daemon in tennis shoes that appears on the cover of the 4.3BSD
 manuals and The Design and Implementation of the 4.3BSD UNIX Operating
 System by S. Leffler, M. McKusick, M. Karels, J. Quarterman,
 Addison-Wesley Publishing Company, Reading, MA 1989.
 
 She tells the following story about wearing the 4.3BSD daemon T-shirt:
 
 Last week I walked into a local ``home style cookin'
 restaurant/watering hole'' in Texas to pick up a take-out order. I
 spoke briefly to the waitress behind the counter, who told me my order
 would be done in a few minutes.
 
 So, while I was busy gazing at the farm implements hanging on the
 walls, I was approached by two ``natives.'' These guys might just be
 the original Texas rednecks.
 
      ``Pardon us, ma'am. Mind if we ask you a question?''
      Well, people keep telling me that Texans are real friendly,
      so I nodded.
      ``Are you a Satanist?''
      Well, at least they didn't ask me if I liked to party.
      ``Uh, no, I can't say that I am.''
      ``Gee, ma'am. Are you sure about that?'' they asked.
 
 I put on my biggest, brightest Dallas Cowboys cheerleader smile and
 said, ``No, I'm positive. The closest I've ever come to Satanism is
 watching Geraldo.''
 
      ``Hmmm. Interesting. See, we was just wondering why it is
      you have the lord of darkness on your chest there.''
 
 I was this close to slapping one of them and causing a scene--then I
 stopped and noticed the shirt I happened to be wearing that day. Sure
 enough, it had a picture of a small, devilish-looking creature that
 has for some time now been associated with a certain operating system.
 In this particular representation, the creature was wearing sneakers.
 
      They continued: ``See, ma'am, we don't exactly appreciate it
      when people show off pictures of the devil. Especially when
      he's lookin' so friendly.''
 
 These idiots sounded terrifyingly serious.
 
      Me: ``Oh, well, see, this isn't really the devil, it's just,
      well, it's sort of a mascot.''
      Native: ``And what kind of football team has the devil as a
      mascot?''
      Me: ``Oh, it's not a team. It's an operating--uh, a kind of
      computer.''
 
 I figured that an ATM machine was about as much technology as these
 guys could handle, and I knew that if I so much as uttered the word
 ``UNIX'' I would only make things worse.
 
      Native: ``Where does this satanical computer come from?''
      Me: ``California. And there's nothing satanical about it
      really.''
 
 Somewhere along the line here, the waitress noticed my
 predicament--but these guys probably outweighed her by 600 pounds, so
 all she did was look at me sympathetically and run off into the
 kitchen.
 
      Native: ``Ma'am, I think you're lying. And we'd appreciate
      it if you'd leave the premises now.''
 
 Fortunately, the waitress returned that very instant with my order,
 and they agreed that it would be okay for me to actually pay for my
 food before I left. While I was at the cash register, they amused
 themselves by talking to each other.
 
      Native #1: ``Do you think the police know about these devil
      computers?''
      Native #2: ``If they come from California, then the FBI
      oughta know about 'em.''
 
 They escorted me to the door. I tried one last time:
 
      ``You're really blowing this all out of proportion. A lot of
      people use this `kind of computers.' Universities,
      researchers, businesses. They're actually very useful.''
 
 Big, big, big mistake. I should have guessed at what came next.
 
      Native: ``Does the government use these devil computers?''
      Me: ``Yes.''
 
 Another big boo-boo.
 
      Native: ``And does the government pay for 'em? With our tax
      dollars?''
 
 I decided that it was time to jump ship.
 
      Me: ``No. Nope. Not at all. Your tax dollars never entered
      the picture at all. I promise. No sir, not a penny. Our good
      Christian congressmen would never let something like that
      happen. Nope. Never. Bye.''
 
 ----------------------------------------------------------------------
 Edited and converted to HTML by Dan Bornstein, danfuzz@milk.com.


<<<<< End forwarded message

> 
> Did you catch the remix of "The Way It Is"
> by Bruce Hornsby & the Range that night?  Beautiful song.  I'd love to know
> where to get that record.
> 
> There were actually a lot of talented DJs there that night (Marshall, are
> you reading this?  Bwassup?), most of none of whom I'd ever heard of
> before.
> 

I missed "The Way It Is", I think. That night was sort of a blur.

One thing I will say about Lucky Charms that night is that the DJ's
were really good. I don't think I've heard scratching (non hip-hop
scratching, that is) that good since then.

> I must say I was a bit sketched by the kid at the door who was grabbing
> people's money and shoving it hurriedly into his backpack.
> 

I was more sketched by the port-a-john (yuk!)

> Hmmm...
> 
> peas,
> 
> b))merang
> 

I was admitted free (because of a friend of friend), so it was worth
the money, despite the scary gangsta climate.

Hence my take on Bagkok parties: cool DJ's, sketchy people, too many
area codes. 'nuff said.

Steve

>
> Ravers can perfectly understand and have amazing conversations with anyone
> under the age of ten.
>
> Ravers know where all the best toy stores are.
>
> Ravers get the most mileage out of their shoes.  The toes and heels always
> curl because they are so worn down.
>
> Ravers always wish the dj would spin that bus track that they keep jearing
> on the bus ride homw.
>
> Ravers are the only ppl who dont have their age calculated in months, yet,
> still wear and use pacifiers.
>
> Ravers always consider every new place they go to as a possible location
> for a party.
>
> Ravers hugg everyone.
>
> Ravers can be found dancing everywhere, except the main dance room.
>
> Ravers understand the art of the bathroom conversation.
>
> Ravers choose their cloth by texture, colour and size.
>
> Ravers constantly point out the trippy visuals in everyday life.
>
> Ravers helped Adidas through the "lean" years.
>
> Ravers never know the name of their favorite tracks.
>
> Ravers know how to smile.
>
> Ravers always choose "e" on multiple choice annswers.
>
> Ravers are good at playing "guess what he's on".
>
> Ravers know what to do with a dead glowsticks.
>
> Ravers always have candy on hand.
>
> **coming soon: 101 things to do with a dead glowstick**

Like any of you care. Here are a few new ones from the old house 'o wayne:

Wayne's to do list:
	1. Stop eating meat		(done!)
	2. Switch to Windows95		(coming soon!)
	3. Vote for Bill Clinton	(just a couple more months to go!)

Why this is significant:
	1. I have eaten meat all my life. My diet mainly consisted of
burgers and pork.
	2. I worked on the Macintosh OS at Apple for 5 years, I angrily
defended Macintosh
		to the death. Well, Apple no longer deserves my evangelical
efforts.
	3. I grew up a hard-core right wing gun toting Republican in
Irvine, California
		mocking liberals and anyone not a strong member of the
Republican party.

Why I am happy about all this:
	1. I feel better not eating any meat/pork/chicken
	2. Apple's supremely tubing it these days and Windows
		actually looks like it doesn't suck anymore.
	3. Bob Dole is a bitter old codger who, it seems, would like to lock up
		everybody in AmeriKKKa (thanks Neils!) that isn't an anti-drug,
		anti-minority, right-wing Rush Limbaugh listening, mindless
		KKKristian bible toter. So fuck 'em. It's time to switch to the
		*thinking* side of "mainstream politics"
		(I voted for Reagan in 84, Bush in 88, Perot in 92... now
		I get to *happily* vote Democrat!)

flame on, tiny warriors!

OK. Here's another one. My company (http://www.e-benefits.com) is
looking to hire a Web Developer who can answer the following riddle:

You're on the Price is Right and Bob Barker picks you! He asks you which
door has the new car behind it and you say door #3. Now, as he always
does, he shows you the rotten prize behind door #1 and asks you if you
want to change your mind... What do you do?


When you figure it out, here's the job opportnity:

E-Benefits is looking for a Web Developer to design, develop and maintain
our web site. (http://www.e-benefits.com) Full time or part time, you will
take on a broad range of development projects. 

E-Benefits is a young, aggressive startup selling health benefits
(health insurance, dental, life, etc...) via the internet. Since we are
a fast-growing entrepreneurial company, this position is an opportunity
to demonstrate unlimited resourcefulness and creatvity.

-----------------------------------

Responsibility Overview:
-Work with E-Benefits Developer consultants.
-Maintain server, web content, discussion groups, etc...
-Design and develop web pages. Set development agenda and course.

Qualifications:
-Willingness to participate in a startup team environment.
-HTML, Windows, and other basic computer experience. Willing to learn
about Windows NT, Databases, and many other advanced topics.

Position:
Full or Part time, Flexible hours. (2 a.m. is OK)
Starting date ASAP.
Salary: Depends on Experience.
E-Benefits is an Equal Opportunity Employer.

Contact:
Andy Kurtzig
andy@e-benefits.com
Fax resume to: (415) 495-7685
Address: 330 Townsend Street, Suite 234, San Francisco, CA 94107

     Ummm... question.
     
     I assume you're a DJ and I said I had a gig lined up for you in 
     Belgium, 2 in England, and then four stops on the East Coast, would 
     you know intimately what would go off and what wouldn't (did I mention 
     that you're late on rent and I have a pen and some blood and a 
     contract?)?  Is there any way of knowing that you'd be playing solid 
     parties everytime?  Is there a chance a 'good' promoter or co-op could 
     go shitty or vice versa?  I mean, you get to spin your musics for 
     people, that's what you wanted right?
     
     Could it just be a matter of taste (don't get me wrong, I still fleed 
     in panic when I saw the crowd outside five... One question: I wonder 
     if they got to vote for the prom queen or if it was rigged).
     
     Sometimes great DJs play shit parties... no sense in passing judgement 
     on them.  I've heard some cool shit at bad parties, and just waited 
     until they played a good party later.  Or I kick myself for not going 
     to a party I KNEW was shit... but Carl Cox played and it would have 
     been free...
     
     Good thing you don't get judgemental BA...  ;)
     AndyW
     
     This Week in Raving...

     Tuesday    :@ 
     
     Wednesday  :(   <---I'm here... elf needs food badly

     ______________________________________________________________________
     
     Disclaimer... the author of the above post is speculating.  He tried 
     spinning once and after a short stint looking for an audience that 
     would be interested in a 100% mighty funky techno trainwrecks mixtape 
     (called 'Sniffin Your Caboose' or 'Exotic Polyrythyms Unleashed'), 
     gave up and ran out of money at the same time.

On Wed, 25 Sep 1996, Andy Wyszkowski wrote:

>      
>      Ummm... question.
>      
>      I assume you're a DJ and I said I had a gig lined up for you in 
>      Belgium, 2 in England, and then four stops on the East Coast, would 
>      you know intimately what would go off and what wouldn't (did I mention 
>      that you're late on rent and I have a pen and some blood and a 
>      contract?)?  Is there any way of knowing that you'd be playing solid 
>      parties everytime?  Is there a chance a 'good' promoter or co-op could 
>      go shitty or vice versa?  I mean, you get to spin your musics for 
>      people, that's what you wanted right?

Since we are "assuming" things, let's "assume" that the DJ is local and
knows what's up locally. What then?


>      Sometimes great DJs play shit parties... no sense in passing judgement 
>      on them.  I've heard some cool shit at bad parties, and just waited 
>      until they played a good party later.  Or I kick myself for not going 
>      to a party I KNEW was shit... but Carl Cox played and it would have 
>      been free...
>      
>      Good thing you don't get judgemental BA...  ;)

I am posing questions. Don't mistake questions for passing judgement. 

I have seen people *BLAST*(I have done so too) promoters and parties in
the past. Yet DJ's seem to be above questioning, as if they have
absolutely nothing to do with a party or its promoters(which
may be the case.) I am just asking why people think that is. 

Oh god, how dare I question yet another sacred cow?

I'm listening to some cool ambient on KPFA right now (Weds. 10 pm).
Lately, I have heard some really good dance-techno music on radio stations
lately.  My favorite (when I can get it) is KFJC 89.7 in Los Altos Hills.
They seem to play the most dance music of any other station.
When I went down to Harmony we listened to some good music the whole way
down to the South Bay that Saturday afternoon on that station.  In any
given week I have been able to find house\techno at least 4-5 times a week 
especially in the evenings.  On a Tuesday night I heard some good stuff on
KUSF and on Thursdays KALX has some good stuff.  Anyway, this causes me
endless amounts of joy because I can only listen to my mix tapes so many
times and the refreshing array of music is marvelous.  Plus, you get the
added bonus of an occasional dj telling you what tracks were played which
makes it so much easier to figure out what you'd like to buy.

Anyway, I was just wondering if anyone knew of schedules for certain
programs so I can look out for them.  I know the calendar has listings,
but many seem to be out of date.  

I'm so happy, can't you tell?!! :P

Thanks,
KaySEE

>>Cosmic Mass, Sunday, Sept. 29, 1996 @ We The People Auditorium, 200 Harrison
>>St., Oakland (entrance is on 2nd Ave, across from Amtrack Station and Jack
>>London Square).
>> Ritual is at 8 and will last about 1.5 hrs.  More music/dance after that. No
>>drugs or alcohol.  Everyone is welcomed.  It's free but we will gratefully
>>accept donations.
>>
>>The Mass's theme is celebration of the Angels. It coincides with the new
>>release of Matthew Fox and Rupert Sheldrake (well-known progressive scientist
>>from England) new book "The Physics of Angels".  In the book they compare the
>>sacred description/activity of angels to the activity of photons and
>>morphogenic fields.  Building a bridge between science and spirituality. The
>>purpose of the book and the Cosmic Mass celebration is to reclaim the Angels
>>from the overly sentamentalized/commercialized experience in our western
>>culture of these powerful beings/energies.
>>
>>The mass is a blending of western judeo-christrian worship with ecstatic
>>music and dance,  chant,  multimedia imagery, urban shamanism, eastern and
>>indigenous spiritual practices.  Matt Fox, Rupert Sheldrake and others will
>>lead the celebration.   There will be live music (Indian ragas by Russill
>>Paul) as well as DJ's Ammon & Ronan.

Before I depart on Sunday for my own time period let me give my 2 cents on
the DJ thing for this time period and then my own time period.

I've seen many DJ's in many different types of parties and IMO You will see
a good DJ play at a known to be bad or questionable parties because of a
few reasons.

1. Like someone said before, rent is due and bills are climbing. Some DJ's,
that's all they do for a job is spin at parties. For the ones that make
$500 for 1 1/2 - 2 hour set, which are alot of them if they charge the
promoter, they usually have at least 2 parties a weekend. What an awesome
$1000 a week job.

2. The love for the music. If there a decent DJ, and most of the crowd
already likes the DJ, the party may suck but people are enjoying the music
even if it's a bad vibe party.
   A. More then 90% of the post about shitty vibe parties the first thing I
remember being said is that the music was Great, but the vibe sucked.

3. Possible bookings by promoters attending the shitty party. Want to be
and already promoters come to parties to hand out flyers and maybe checkout
the DJ's. They know that party sucks, all they want to do is listen to the
DJ. The DJ might know this and try and give a great set regardless of the
party vibe and crowd.

4. If it's and out of town party, most DJ's ( I know 6 of them) get's paid
$1000, plane ticket and hotel for usually a 2 hour set. Hot damn the also
have a $500 dollar party the next night back home.

5. Money is money and who cares were it came from as long as they don't get
busted.


That's my take on the subject. Granted some DJ's spin for free also. Alot
of them either spin because they like it and/or just want to be heard and
be known for a ripping set.



Now in my time 2095, all the rotten and shitty promoters are all in the
holding cell because they just wanted to make a buck and was careless and
got busted. (if you remember in the years 2095 raves and rave music was
banned, right now it looks like I've done my job and there are parties not
being busted and are left alone. So I'll see what's up when I return) The
DJ's don't care who throws the party, it's a chance to spin and play some
killer music money or no money and because the love it.

So all we have are good vibe parties and promoters who care what happens at
a party because there are only once a month maybe 2 if we are lucky. If a
bad promoter cames about they quickly get caught or can't get a DJ and
therefore doesn't throw one.



So the point of the matter is, who care were a DJ spins. They have there
reason and it none of our damn buisness why. The more they spin, the better
they get (hopefully). Hell a bad party would be a killer place to try knew
things. Then they can bring it to the good ones knowing people would love
it and not try the things they know people won't like.


Tim (knucklehead)

does anyone out there have:

a Macintosh with
a _fast_ (ISDN, T1... the faster the better) internet connection
and an external HD of 100MB or more?

here's the story: i'm trying to learn unix/perl, and my remote host is
painfully slow (like typing delays of 5-10 seconds at times)...

i was browsing the web last night and came across info of a version of
LINUX for power macs... "great!" i thought, "i can set up a unix system an
my own computer and it will be much easier!"... ha ha. if only it were that
easy.

the file is almost 80 MB and for some reason isn't split up into easily
downloadable chunks. at the speed of my internet connection (14.4 and not
_even_ that fast in practice) that's a 16 hour download. not gonna happen.

i was wondering if someone with a fast connection could be persuaded to DL
the file for me and get it to me somehow (like an external HD).

i would be much indebted. i will try to compensate you in some way although
cash is probably not it right now since i'm kinda broke.

if any of you have used MkLinux, let me know-- if it's a piece of shit,
i'll save myself (and a friendly favor-doer) the trouble.

many thanks in advance.

love,

Bill Clinton is willing to change his mind on any subject to further
his career.

He has NO principles whatsoever.

" All Bill Clinton consists of is a huge appetite. " - Jesse Jackson
(Democrat)

He cares for nothing other than Bill Clinton.

There was a great Bill Moyers documentary a couple of years ago about
how Bill Clinton is the biggest friend of "corporate Amerikkka".
He'll help anyone who helps him.

He is a great used car salesman, maybe the best ever !

I have a 2-page newspaper article consisting of quotes from
environmentalists that are pissed off at him, because he never did
anything that he said he would do.

I'm sure anyone can find pages of angry tirades by gay activists who
are pissed off at him for the same reason.

How about the recent "attack" on Iraq, which made him look good in the
press, but which all the experts have concluded has only made Saddam
Hussain stronger.

How about misusing the FBI to frame various long-term employees of the
White House travel agency, in order to replace them with friends from
Arkansas.

How about illegally obtaining hundreds of FBI files in order to gain
information about his enemies, the scope of which is much greater than
anything that caused Nixon to resign.   (A Nixon staffer went to jail
for obtaining ONE FBI file.)

I could go on at length, including various vile things which his
administration has done which are never reported in the press, but
which have a lot more evidence than there was against OJ.  

All of this stuff scares me far more than anything Bob Dole might do.

"Any government big enough to give you everything you want, is also

Wow!
You could be surprised at how good some LARGE parties are.  Funky Tekno 
Tribe last Halloween in Sac. was a really good party.  Especially for 
it's location and size.  All the people who accompanied me also had a 
great time.

Granted, most huge flyer, multi-number, megaparties are mega-booty.  But, 
there are some that remind me why I became the person I am today.  When 
you have a few thousand kids freakin' out to a gajillion watt sound 
system with an awesome lightshow, it can be utter lunacy.  When matched 
with your personal favorite chemical (im)balance.  It can become a space 
you may never want to leave.

I have found that when I get outside of California, bigger parties tend 
to get a little better.  A lot of it, I feel is due to the notable 
absence of punk-ass gangsta ravers.  It's sad to think that the only 
place they can go on weekends is a place where they can piss on 
everyone's parade.  It's too bad malls don't stay open all night.

It's too bad we haven't found a solution to this problem.  Could you 
imagine if all the raves were on a good vibe?  That would be soooo dope...

...then I woke up...

-Dre

experienced them all prolly without much of a pattern.  But when the vibe 
does suck,  and I want to focus all my attention away from that fact, I 
greatly appreciate a dj that doesnt....

suck party" being linked to the fact that its in "Central Ohio".  Pgh's 
location allowed me to experience the pb-cle rave scene aka "Central Ohio" 
 as well as hopping down to the baltimore-dc and ny parties.  I'd have to 
say my best experiences were shared amongst all the scenes.  So I 
wouldn't generalize on what is gonna be the shit based on its location.

to leave.

faster....
Sleeping 2 hours and going to the boat party....

One of the best party weekends.

Bear(hug) with me hear...
Heard this 2 months ago and thought it was soooo killer, I have to find it....
Okay, now everyone prepare themselves to try and figure out what song this
is by my feeble attempt at phonetically describing a phunky beat....I heard
this for the first time at the reggae fest when the Wicked crew was
spinning...It's not a fast beat but kinda slow like a build up...like to say
"okay, get ready because here comes Garth" type beat...and after humming it
3 times (you gotta hum it 'case it's a vibrating fuzzy sound), change the
pitch, make it a little higher the next time And, it sounded *VERY* warm and
fuzzy..... I'm not expecting anyone to figure out what it is but
nevertheless, it'll make you all stop and hum it...smile...and that's a
distraction that we all need.   ;)


Boooom Booooom.....boo ba boo ba boo ba.........Booooom Booooom  <repeat>
or
Humm this:

Mmmmmm Mmmmmm....oooh aaaah ooooh aaaah ooooh ahhhh......Mmmmmmm Mmmmmm <repeat>


On this day, desperately yearning to be blown away by the power of the human
mind,

Steve

Nexus is known for doing cool things like free  massages, herbal
therapy, butterflies (OPEN!)  They are very cool.

One comment I wanted to make about that whole "DJ X playing at Y party"
thing: One thing that is a trend at many big headline parties is that
these "brand name", well known DJ's get paid sometimes 15 min after they
do their set so they can double book. This really annoys me bacause it
seems to put these DJ's on a higher plateu. I've heard people get all
giddy because they just got DJ X's autograph. Say what?! I'm sorry but I
just hate the idea of certain DJ's being "celebrities". 
EXAMPLE: One reason why I love F-8 parties so much is that when Mars and
Myster-E aren't spinning during the evning, they are out dancing with
the rest of us, or just chilling talking with some people. They really
mingle with the group. You can walk up to them and say "Hey man you were
awsome tonight!" And they are senciere when they accept your grattitue
and they let you know they appreciate you being here.  It's a much
better vibe and feeling of PLUR than: "Okay Casper the 'friendly' DJ,
here's your money. *Whoosh* he's gone!"
>>> Ariel Stallings <ASTALLINGS@gcwf.com> 09/25/96 01:24pm >>>

To that party's credit:  Nexus IS doing the chill room, so it can't be
ALL bad...right?  I've heard great things about Nexus...

Ariel

You know, I remember the good ol' days, when sfraves was more focused on
the rave scene.  Now we have a high volume of NRR posts, which continues
despite the pleas of several of the good folk around here.  Should we
make an effort to discipline ourselves, and make more use of private
exchange, or should those who don't like it GO TAKE A FLYING LEAP?
OK, seriously now: We're getting better in our use of this list, IMHO. 
Some of us are even so considerate as to include NRR in our subject
lines.  Still, there are disgruntled members on the list.  My advice to
those who don't like the way this list is being used is: a) unsub; b)
create your own list, with whatever restrictions you want; or c) grin
and bear it, 'cause it looks like things will remain the same around
here for the forseeable future.

Quit yer belly-achin' and start your booty-shakin'!  - E

     I wouldn't skip the Fantasy Island party just because all these people 
     dissed on it. From what I've read over the past months it seems that 
     most of the people on the list are not in to the larger parties. It 
     seems that most people on the list are in to going to smaller parties 
     where they know everyone and half the people at the party are 
     subscribed to this list. Personally I can have a good time at most any 
     party. Depends on what I'm in the mood for. You have to ask yourself 
     what is it that your looking for in a party? Maybe after you determine 
     that, the list can direct you to a party that might fit those needs. 
     If not Fantasy Island I would try at least one of the massives in SF. 
     The Funky Techno Tribe Holloween massive is coming up and I think the 
     Gathering is in December. There are a handful of smaller more intimate 
     parties on almost any given weekend so you'll have plenty of 
     opportunities to check out that scene. 
     
     "The world don't move to the beat of just one drum, what might be 
     right for you may not be right for some!"

your aural pleasure from the scenes I am more familiar with. Please eme....
     
On the topic of large parties, djs, and shady promoters.....I've 
experienced them all prolly without much of a pattern.  But when the vibe 
does suck,  and I want to focus all my attention away from that fact, I 
greatly appreciate a dj that doesnt....

> >hours, and while they are there, they are busy playing records anyway. And

After spending 4 years in pittsburgh, I'd have to disagree with "likely to 
suck party" being linked to the fact that its in "Central Ohio".  Pgh's 
location allowed me to experience the pb-cle rave scene aka "Central Ohio" 
 as well as hopping down to the baltimore-dc and ny parties.  I'd have to 
say my best experiences were shared amongst all the scenes.  So I 
wouldn't generalize on what is gonna be the shit based on its location.

        Yeah. . . Why do all of whoever hate circle dancers? Damn, am I a
bad person cuz sometimes I'll be dancing and a circle forms by me? I just
like to hang out where most of them dance, and there's nothing wrong with a
little playful competition. People who love to dance around, and who've
worked to get good at it, like a little appreciation on their dancing
capabilities. There are tons of people with glow sticks nowadays, and
they're actually worse then circle dancers cuz they have these bright lights
to draw attention. But no one complains about them? 
        I like circle dancing, it's fun to be watched, and I like to learn
from other people. A lot of times, I'll meet someone new because we were
dancing together (sorta) and we liked each others styles.
        I wasn't sure what you guys meant by circle dancing till just a few
weeks ago. Now I'm like, why??? What is acceptable to you? Does everyone
have to dance far away from anyone else in the corners of the room away from
the music? About the only thing I don't like about the dancing there is that
soooo many people think that you have to go to the dance floor to dance, and
thats wrong. I just like to dance near the speakers so I can lose myself in
the music.
        If no one danced to show off what they have, everyone would be
tapping there feet and jumping up and down.

pretty cool huh?

At 07:59 PM 9/23/96 -0700, you wrote:
>On Mon, 23 Sep 1996, Matt WietzkeDJ Xpress wrote:
>
>> I know this has probably come up mucho times, but why do most people dislike
>> circle dancing?
>
>A few reasons:
>
>1. It can totally disrupt the dance floor. They(circle dancers) tend to
>   take up a lot of space, and if a crowd gathers, there is that much less
>   space for those that want to shake their groove thing to do so.
But the person dancing would most likely have to take up a lot of space to
dance to their fullest anyway. And if there isn't enough room, you can
always go somewhere else. If there was a lot of room everywhere, everyone
would be dancing their heart out, but it ends up with people dancing so
close feet get stepped on constantly so you don't even really use your legs
and you can't use your arms cuz you'll hit someone. My chain that I wear
usually keeps people back about 3 or 4 feet.
>
>2. It becomes a spectator sport rather than having everyone involved in 
>   what is going on, and as an intangible really seems to have a
>   deleterious effect on the energy of the crowd.
Some people just go to watch and listen to the music. I'm sure there are
people there who just want to watch how others dance and maybe learn from
them before they try to build up enough courage to dance themselves (not in
a circle). A lot of people are afraid because they don't think they look
cool, but I don't think that many people actually know what they're doing,
but they all look cool when they try.
>
>3. It fosters a competitve attitude. Personally, I don't want to compete
>   with anyone when I am out making my attempt at what I call dancing....
>   ;-)
Is competetive bad? I'm sure most of us race to the party to get in before
everyone else, or to actually get in. Dancing isn't a sport, but it is kind
of competetive. It's more of a "WOW, that's cool, I wunnadooothat" kinda
thing, than a "WOW, that guys good, I haftashowhimup" type of attitude.
>
>				The third most voluminous poster here,
>
                                        				
>                                        	Black Adder
>                                    
>
>
>

Aryck

At 11:54 AM 9/24/96 -0700, you wrote:
>Hey,
>
>I occasionally appreciate circle dancing, especially among a group of
>dancers that have been dancing next to each other all night.  I like the
>mutual encouragement that happens between the circle and the person in
>the middle.  When I dance sober I draw a lot of energy and inspiration
>from the dancers around me.  (I don't feel really confident about my
>dancing. I don't have any 'moves'.  If you ever see me on the floor, you
>know I am there because my urge to move is greater than my shyness.)  I
>am mostly trying to find a way for my body to express what I am feeling
>about the music.  While I am out there I notice others going through
>similar forms of thought, and it is really great when a fellow dancer
>starts really "figurin' it out" on the floor.  (You know, the point that
>your body and mind are working together in a way that makes you
>personally pleased with yourself.)  Dancing makes you feel good about
>yourself, might as well show it.  I never read anything negative into
>the cocky arrogance displayed by the person in the middle.   The
>competitiveness that I have seen always seems to be in the spirit of
>fun.  Circle dancing is pretty neat-o by me.
>
>Dance on,
>D.
>
>
Yeah, who's got the right Idea???


Aryck
