Received: from cc:Mail by ccmail.rsco.com
	id AA843765731; Thu, 26 Sep 96 12:18:47 PST
Date: Thu, 26 Sep 96 12:18:47 PST
Message-Id: <9608268437.AA843765731@ccmail.rsco.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Shaminism -LONG
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     I really enjoyed this - I think it's relevant to our community. See 
     attached.
     
     ----->Liz.


"Who interprets the divinity inherent in nature for us today?Who are our shamans?  Who interprets unseen things for us?"

	Finds of ancient art nearly always are attributed by archeologists to a religious or cult function.  This is so, not just for major centers like Egypt and the Indus Valley, but for areas that vastly pre-date them.  Intriguing artifacts 10,000 to 40,000 years old are becoming more common.  How and why did man (and woman) become an artist?
	All of the arts owe their origins to the spiritual craft of shamanism.  <I>Shamanism</I> is the ancient universal tradition whereby personal and tribal healing and empowerment is nurtured, supervised and accomplished through the special skills and services of a charismatic individual.  This shaman may be male or female.  He or she may be called medicine wo/man, witch doctor, sorcerer/ess, magician, witch, psychic, yogi, yogini, kahuna, medium, seer and various other names around the globe.  
	The shaman can transcend normal human consciousness and travel among different cosmological planes.  As an intermediary between the visible & invisible worlds, this powerful <I>wise one</I> is guardian of the tribe's psychic and ecological health and welfare.  All over the world, shamans encountered in the last 200 years have functioned in the same basic manner using similar techniques. 
	In shamanic cultures many strong individuals also might fulfill at least some spiritual and healing needs for themselves and other members of their family.  There is a general shared awareness of the unseen world.  And certainly the community's professional shaman would take care of his family first, as they probably supported him/her economically. 
	<I>Shaman</I> has entered our vocabulary from the study of the Tungus people of Siberia, where a living tribal healing process was thoroughly observed and documented in the 19th Century.  The process itself is apparently a very ancient technology, the practice of which predates writing and all "civilization" as we know it.  Some variation or form of it is indigenous to all parts of the globe.  
	"Even in the historical literature from the Classical Mediterranean, or from medieval and Renaissance western Europe, one finds evidence that the same basic shamanic knowledge once existed there until it was largely eradicated by the Inquisition."<B>1</B>  
	The primary purposes of shamanic tradition are (a) to promote and increase order, health, wealth and happiness of the individuals and the whole tribe, (b) to instill a common vision with individual motivation, (c) to appease the ancestors and protect against evil influences (demons of illness & bad luck), and (d) to divine hidden truths and/or the future.  The shaman presides at the soul-rituals of birth, marriage and death, and conducts the annual tribal ceremonies and community sacrifices.  These seasonal festivals promote harmony and balance within the tribe, between men and women, and with the natural elements, the plants and the animals.  
	Shamanism functions in a fertile, supportive, positive social context.  Within the tribe it is revered as a reliable source of essential wholeness, energy and power.  It is the source of mental knowledge available to cope with the serious challenges to health and survival.  "In order to effect a cure of the patient, belief in what is happening must be held, reinforced, and intensified, not only in the patient, but in the audience as well, for their experience contributes directly to the effect." 
	The shaman is disciplined, courageous, tenacious---a mind/body specialist, master of kundalini, communer with spirits, supernatural healer, magical athlete, masker, artist & craftsman, herbalist, ecstatic traveler between the worlds, spiritual power-broker, cosmic metaphysician, tapper of infinite universal energy, creative illusionist, skilled performing-artist.  
	"...Medicine-men...are of immense social significance, the psychological health of the group largely depending on faith in their powers..." The shaman's personal power is amplified by a visionary guardian spirit: the tutelary, <I>nagual</I>, familiar, companion, assistant totem, power animal (etc.); and he/she may have a number of additional spiritual helpers as well.
	A shaman derives his/her unlimited power to serve the community directly from divine source, while the priest/priestess derives limited power from service to a cult or church.  Organized religions, sponsored by warrior class power, have historically co-opted the tribal spiritual base.  They have taken over the  magical crafts and arts developed by shamans, to serve their own economic and military ambitions.  
	By dividing and undermining group faith and support, by discrediting the shamans' divine credentials, and by offering a glamourous (militarily imposed) alternative to an economically powerful elite, missionaries have succeeded in devastating many shamanic tribal cultures world-wide.  They still do this!
	There is clearly a supportive, practical and interactive connection of the arts to spirituality and religion.  The arts have a capacity to create illusion and/or to manifest the impossible, the invisible, and the unknown.  They can visualize and then make the fantastic real.  This is miraculous magical power, and all spiritual traditions have employed the magic of the arts in one way or another.  
	Various art forms were developed by shamans to create a receptive atmosphere, a supranormal context for spiritual healing rituals.  They are also used as sensory triggering mechanisms to expand consciousness and/or induce shamanic trance states (both personally and for the group). 	
	It was discovered that recreatable multi-artistic experiences can be keys to access the inspiration of the higher self, and to reprogram the powerful instincts of the lower self.  Tattooing, piercing or scarification are used as the permanent reminder of a particularly important life lesson, healing or initiation.  
	Shamanic ritual is high theater!  "Professional cure by a shaman who is the central actor usually involves careful preparations, full publicity, and an eager audience; impressive setting and lighting, costume and makeup, theatrical properties and sound effects.  Actual performance includes dramatic invocation of evil or benevolent spirits, or both, for diagnosis and advice as to treatment; possession of or battle with the shaman by the spirits through ecstasy or frenzy which may be considered a supreme example of dramatic impersonation, often with elaborate use of voice, dialogue, and body pantomime; concretizing the disease demons, and driving them away, often with sucking out, sleight of hand, and display of disease objects; and luring home of the sick person's soul.  The performance may require the help of stage assistants, and active participation by the patient and the audience..."
	While many different forms of music are used in ritual around the world, drumming is particularly effective.  Rhythm and percussion typically are used to trigger trance states in the Barong dances of Indonesia and possession dances of Africa and African diaspora traditions in America such as Macumba, Santeria and Voudon.    
	Everywhere shamans make masks.  The mask embodies the spirit, and donning it the shaman accepts the presence of the spirit into him/herself.  The Tlingit and Tibetan shamans alike "utter the words of the spirit" when wearing the mask.  Elaborate masked pantomime dances punctuate the sacred calendar in South India with <I>Kathakali</I>,  in Japan it's <I>Bogaku</I>,  in Tibet <I>Cham</I>,  in Pueblo land the <I>Kachina</I>  dances.  Such masked dances are also witnessed in Africa, the Pacific Islands, North & South America as well as ancient civilizations like the Egyptian, Mayan, Inca, etc.	Architecture was originated by shamanic cultures.  So called "primitive" tribal peoples all over the world have built sophisticated giant structures and statuary to serve the community.  Natural cultivation of mental faculties enhanced through their shamanic traditions, enabled them to cut, shape and move heavy stone with simple tools.  Their impressive creative abilities can be attributed to a greater group consciousness, sense of cooperation, adaptability, intuition and psychic awareness.      
	The cycles of nature were keenly observed and respected by early man because they had such an impact on people's ability to survive and thrive.  Stonehenge and other earth and stone circles & alignments measured, symbolized and celebrated the ritual Wheel of the Solar Year---the medicine wheel, the 8-spoked Wheel of Dharma---with its solstices, equinoxes and cross-quarter days.
	In Europe megalithic monuments thousands of years old (shamanic cultural architecture with practical and spiritual purposes) were defaced, dismantled or built directly upon by the Christian church.  The knowledge of their function and use was systematically banned, scrambled and eradicated as the shamans, Druids, and "witches," were brutally exterminated.  Their followers "voluntarily" converted, if they wanted to survive.  Shamanic magic was dismantled and the spoils were divided between the forces of religions and the minions of science---both getting shortchanged in the bargain.  To this day neither religion or science can muster the pure positive communal transformative energy exhibited by the ancient shamanic high cultures.
	Curiously, circus arts also began as ritual effects.  In Japan the <I>Saragaku</I> tradition wove together the presentation of acrobatics, magic, divination, fire-eating and other circuslike acts.  The two-man dancing lion figure, now seen at <I>kung-fu</I> demonstrations and Chinese New Year parades, was commonly used in exorcism ceremonies throughout Asia.  In Tibet it was the protective snow lion, in China the temple-guardian Fu dog.  The dancing dragon, commonly seen in Chinese New Year parades, was often its companion.  
	The expulsion of the bad luck demons of the old year was accomplished annually in Tibet at <I>Losar</I> (New Year), a grand and national exorcism celebration.  "Amongst the festivities at Lhasa is the spectacle of 'Flying Spirits,' by performers who glide down a rope stretched from the summit of the Potala palace to its base."<B>5</B>  This feat was also performed in medieval Europe, with rope-dancers stretching incline ropes from the steeples of cathedrals.  It could only be described as an awesome sight.  
	At one time the European Christians enlisted actors & entertainers to present passion plays and morality pageants.  Later jugglers, magicians, dancers, mimers and all performers were persecuted by the Church.  They were all considered to be in league with the devil because of their special "powers" to exhibit fantasy, illusion and impossible feats.  Any power not administered by the Church was labeled as evil.  Theatrical performances were banned for hundreds of years, along with herbalism, midwifery and all kinds field & forest rituals. 
	In 16th century Mexico the Spanish found the Aztecs exhibiting a high-flying stunt.  Four men descended upside-down on ropes from a wheel rotating on top of a 50 foot high post (a trimmed straight live tree).  This spiritual spectacle is still done today.  The flyers play music as they swing down in a slow spiral.  This uniquely combines the prime shamanic symbols of the tree, the pillar or axis, the spiral and the wheel.
	The Aztecs displayed the upside-down art of foot-juggling.  This was also mastered by the ancient Chinese, along with object-balancing, acrobatics and animal training.  The horse was domesticated in the shamanic hotbed of Central Asia.
	The Tibetan state oracle would often bend a hard iron sword in half with his bare hands while in trance.  Fire-walking and fire-eating have been recorded in shamanic contexts all over the planet for thousands of years.  The Native Americans practiced it, as well as poisonous snake-handling, arrow-swallowing, puppetry, ventriloquism, the "shaking tipi" ceremony and numerous other impressive shamanic feats and vision-inducing ordeals.  
	Dolls or puppets were animated and used in divination by Eskimo and the Javanese.  Statues embodying the spirit which possessed the shaman/medium have been revered in China, Tibet, Africa and ancient Egypt.
	"Among the most important objects used by the [Tibetan-Mongol] shamans are the so-called <I>lekan</I>, simple effigies representing spirits...and made of wood, pieces of cloth, and furs.  These effigies are regarded as the receptacle or prison of an <I>ongon</I> [spirit], and in case the latter causes some harm, his representation will be beaten or even destroyed."
	Beautiful intricate sand painting mandalas are used by the Tibetans, the Nagas, and the Hopis for healing and empowerment rituals.  They are destroyed during or after use.  Thread-crosses used by Tibetan and Nepali nagpa lamas for weather-making and demon control are nearly identical to the traditional yarn <I>god's eyes</I> made by the Huichol people of Mexico. 
	The arts originated by the world's shamans include: drumming, music, dance, acrobatics, costuming (& clothes), masks, theater, architecture, models (dolls & mineatures) sculpture & carving, painting, sand-painting, body-painting, tattooing, mudra, sign, seal, & talisman, writing & literature, plant cultivation, astronomy, metallurgy and sea crafts.  Additionally there are the "circus arts": juggling, sleight of hand, illusionism, puppetry, ventriloquism, clowning, rope-walking, fire-eating, sword-swallowing and, of course, animal training.  (Modern shamans can also use photography, audio recording, film, video, computers, holography & CD-ROMs)

> >A few reasons:
> >
> >1. It can totally disrupt the dance floor. They(circle dancers) tend to
> >   take up a lot of space, and if a crowd gathers, there is that much less
> >   space for those that want to shake their groove thing to do so.
> But the person dancing would most likely have to take up a lot of space to
> dance to their fullest anyway. And if there isn't enough room, you can
> always go somewhere else. If there was a lot of room everywhere, everyone

Gee, thanks for your consideration of other peoples space. 

> would be dancing their heart out, but it ends up with people dancing so
> close feet get stepped on constantly so you don't even really use your legs
> and you can't use your arms cuz you'll hit someone. My chain that I wear
> usually keeps people back about 3 or 4 feet.

And this is exactly the point. So you have created a 4 foot arc free of
pesky people. And then you have whatever people that might normally be off
the floor crowded around you, taking up more space. This is not an issue
at some parties, granted, but at others it can be very annoying.


> >2. It becomes a spectator sport rather than having everyone involved in 
> >   what is going on, and as an intangible really seems to have a
> >   deleterious effect on the energy of the crowd.
> Some people just go to watch and listen to the music. I'm sure there are
> people there who just want to watch how others dance and maybe learn from
> them before they try to build up enough courage to dance themselves (not in
> a circle). 

That's totally cool. However why is it called a "dance floor?"  

> >3. It fosters a competitve attitude. Personally, I don't want to compete
> >   with anyone when I am out making my attempt at what I call dancing....
> >   ;-)
> Is competetive bad? I'm sure most of us race to the party to get in before
> everyone else, or to actually get in. Dancing isn't a sport, but it is kind
> of competetive. It's more of a "WOW, that's cool, I wunnadooothat" kinda
> thing, than a "WOW, that guys good, I haftashowhimup" type of attitude.

Maybe for you it is not. I go to parties to relax, not compete. Your
mileage may vary of course.

                                          Black Adder

Aryck wrote:

> Is competetive bad? I'm sure most of us race to the party to get in before
> everyone else, or to actually get in. Dancing isn't a sport, but it is kind
> of competetive. It's more of a "WOW, that's cool, I wunnadooothat" kinda
> thing, than a "WOW, that guys good, I haftashowhimup" type of attitude.
> >

Competetive isn't bad, but it can take away from a spiritual vibe imo.
Many ravers enjoy the community vibe that transcends toward a state of unity
consciousness where the feeling is that we are all on the same team rather
than competing with one another.
I'd rather do my competing on a sports field, and when I go to rave I like
to try and open up the the oneness of all the energy.  When I'm able to do that
I feel like I tap into an energy source that we all share.
Of course this includes the energy of the circle dancers.  I usually find it
a little more difficult to connect to the community vibe if I feel alot of 
competition going on.

:)
peter

> 
> You know, I remember the good ol' days, when sfraves was more focused on
> the rave scene.  Now we have a high volume of NRR posts, which continues
> despite the pleas of several of the good folk around here.  Should we
> make an effort to discipline ourselves, and make more use of private
> exchange, or should those who don't like it GO TAKE A FLYING LEAP?
> OK, seriously now: We're getting better in our use of this list, IMHO. 
> Some of us are even so considerate as to include NRR in our subject
> lines.  Still, there are disgruntled members on the list.  My advice to
> those who don't like the way this list is being used is: a) unsub; b)
> create your own list, with whatever restrictions you want; or c) grin
> and bear it, 'cause it looks like things will remain the same around
> here for the forseeable future.
> 
> Quit yer belly-achin' and start your booty-shakin'!  - E

I sense a lack of respect.  

I sense a lack of respect for people who are subscribed to many, many
mailing lists.  If all 10 or so of the mailing lists I was subscribed
to had the same amount of off-topic posts that SFR has, none of them
would be useful.  I would be forced to unsubscribe to them all.

Do you know how many times I have talked to people who would very much
like to be on sfr but can't simply becuase of the volume?  I don't think
you are respecting these people.  Nicole is one of these people.  I think 
all the off-topic posts are keeping more people from joining this wonderful 
community.

The only reason "things will remain the same" is because people have choosen
to keep them the same.  I would quit my belly achin' if the volume on
SFRaves was not denying people access to it.  But that is not the case.
Feel free to post as much NRR stuff as you like, I guess it does not matter
to you if you are keeping people off of sfraves... as long as YOU are having
your fun.  Oh well, its an anarchy so do as you will... nobodys going to stop 
you.

-troy

> From: TGARCI01@ccsmtp.farinon.harris.com
> Date: Thu, 26 Sep 1996 14:08:28 -0700
>      
>      actually this could be nrr's cousin...
>      
>      what if we had 2 sfraves mailing lists?  one for the strictly rave 
>      related stuff and one that was, shall we say, a little more "loose".  
> 

*gulp*

I think we confronted this issue recently. I've said before, and I'll
say it again:

It's a bad idea. Having two lists means everyone will post everything
to both lists (to reach the widest audience), then everyone follows up
by complaining that this message was off-topic for the this list, and
should only be posted to that list, etc. More fighting, more problems,
AND more traffic. In the end, everyone loses.

Examples? The domain policy/DNS admin list on the InterNIC. I received
400+ messages a day once it split into three lists (no kidding!).

Just be respectful of your net.neighbors. Remember that abUSENET
has over 10,000 newsgroups, including places to sound off about
politics, drugs, and "I love you" messages (check out alt.cuddle
sometime, if it still exists).

Steve

> what if we had 2 sfraves mailing lists?  one for the strictly rave 
> related stuff and one that was, shall we say, a little more "loose".  

This only exacerbates the problem.  Instead of one list with lots of
irrelevant stuff flying around, you have two -- people crosspost 
because they are not sure to which list a particular message belongs,
and pretty soon the signal/noise ratio plummets to zero on both groups.

However, it is somewhat amusing to contemplate a discussion group
whose focus is "irrelevant topics".  No one would be able to follow
up on any other post lest they be accused of forming a thread and
thus, being "on topic".

:)

	Sami

On Thu, 26 Sep 1996, Troy Sheets wrote:

> I sense a lack of respect.  
> 
> I sense a lack of respect for people who are subscribed to many, many
> mailing lists.  If all 10 or so of the mailing lists I was subscribed
> to had the same amount of off-topic posts that SFR has, none of them
> would be useful.  I would be forced to unsubscribe to them all.

well, I don't think sfraves traffic is any more NRR than any of the other
regional "rave" mailing lists, at least not compared to socal-raves (which
gets *much* more traffic).

> Do you know how many times I have talked to people who would very much
> like to be on sfr but can't simply becuase of the volume?  I don't think
> you are respecting these people.  Nicole is one of these people.  I think 
> all the off-topic posts are keeping more people from joining this wonderful 
> community.

procmail. :) 

:
* ^Sender:.*sfraves
* ^Subject:.*NRR
/dev/null

> The only reason "things will remain the same" is because people have choosen
> to keep them the same.  I would quit my belly achin' if the volume on
> SFRaves was not denying people access to it.  But that is not the case.
> Feel free to post as much NRR stuff as you like, I guess it does not matter
> to you if you are keeping people off of sfraves... as long as YOU are having
> your fun.  Oh well, its an anarchy so do as you will... nobodys going to stop 
> you.

I think the problem is that not everyone agrees on what sfraves should be. 
some people wanna read party reviews. others are just concerned with the
music.  others want to discuss "rave culture".  some people just want the
attention and to see their name on the screen. there are many peripheral
topics that come up, and it's tough to come up with any kind of consenus
on what belongs on sfraves.  the "topic" hasn't been clearly defined. 

fyi, here's the "official" word from sfraves.info: 

" Appropriate topics include: announcements of upcoming events;  reviews
of previous shows/DJ's/new records, etc; discussion about SF-related and
rave- culture-related topics, like smart drinks; discussion about
rave-related stories on TV/in the newspaper, etc. Ideally we should try
and stay away from, "Hey, did you catch that Orbital song on "Beverly
Hills 90210" last week?"  stuff, or from over-generalizing ourselves: "Can
Depeche Mode be considered "techno"?  ", etc. But, other than that, I want
it to be pretty free form. The list should _not_ be about rave scenes in
other parts of the world; an occasional post about a huge megaevent in LA
or a monthly report on the scene in other cities might be okay, but
remember there was a reason this is called SFRaves; if you want to start a
mailing list for your area, ask your sysadmin, as that was all I had to
do. If that fails, there's alt.raves, the USENET newsgroup, where you can
post just about anything you want. " 

I agree there is a problem, and I think everyone should re-read the
sfraves statistics that were generated recently and think about what they
can do (or not do) to improve the s/n ratio on sfraves (send me mail if
you would like me to forward them to you)... maybe if the numbers were
generated and posted monthly it would help keep people in check...


andy

On Thu, 26 Sep 1996, Andre Lucero wrote:

> there are some that remind me why I became the person I am today.  When 
> you have a few thousand kids freakin' out to a gajillion watt sound 
> system with an awesome lightshow, it can be utter lunacy.  When matched 
> with your personal favorite chemical (im)balance.  It can become a space 
> you may never want to leave.
> 
When I went to Spundae on Labor Day weekend, the main room was hopping.  I
knew what kind of vibe to expect so I put on my biggest smile, my silver
sneakers, and prepared to dance my heart out.  I ignored the women putting
on make-up in the bathroom, the ones adjusting their skin tight clothing,
the men without shirts wearing baseball hats, and dodged a few
ass-grabbers.  After that the I danced myself to sheer exhaustion driven
by Laurent Garnier.  I was pleasantly surprised at the crowd actually
because besides the air filled with ego-boosting and sexual tension,
everyone was there to have a really great time.  

What most impressed me was the dance floor.  I'm not good at estimating
numbers, but maybe there was over 500 people on the dance floor (whatever
it was it was a huge amount).  Although the vibe was somewhat misdirected
at times, the amount of people generating it was intense.  I would love to
experience that amount of people with a more directed vibe.  Imagine tons
of sweaty bodies totally going off and having an amazing time, totally
happy with the space they are in and happy every other person is sharing
it with them.  Experiencing this has made me want to check out a massive
to see if I can find even a glimpse of that kind of vibe.  The thought of
dancing in unison with thousands of other people seems like such the
full-on erotic, go all out, terrific kind of dream.  I'm waiting for my
next Gathering or other similar party to experience this!!  

-KaySEE

On Thu, 26 Sep 1996, Steve Simitzis wrote:
> 
> > From: TGARCI01@ccsmtp.farinon.harris.com
> > Date: Thu, 26 Sep 1996 14:08:28 -0700
> >      what if we had 2 sfraves mailing lists?  one for the strictly rave 
> >      related stuff and one that was, shall we say, a little more "loose".  
> 
> It's a bad idea. Having two lists means everyone will post everything
> to both lists (to reach the widest audience), then everyone follows up
> by complaining that this message was off-topic for the this list, and
> should only be posted to that list, etc. More fighting, more problems,
> AND more traffic. In the end, everyone loses.

I disagree, we started this off-topic list in NYC, and traffic dropped by
*75%* on NYC-raves.  NYC raves is now about: party announcements, reviews
of parties, and discussions about DJs/producers/music.  All of the
"friendly" msgs are on off-topic (i.e. political debates, what we do at
work, funny things we see in NYC).  It's a mailing list for a group of
friends in the NYC area and we'll even post our plans for the night, or
whatever.

I think that someone just has to take the initiative to *start* an
off-topic list.  The rest just follows... ;)

peace,
Marshal "Mars" Villarosa

Hey y'all.  I want to pass this along, because I think it's important to
all of us.  We all love and need water, in various degrees.
Love, your aquarian friend,
shamini

*************************************************************************
 About two weeks ago, a horrible bill (SB 649) SPONSORED BY THE OIL
 INDUSTRY passed both houses of the California legislature which removes
 many of the penalties and liabilities assessed corporations and firms that
 pollute California's water resources due to oil spills and similar mishaps
 in California.  This bill is opposed by the California Dept of Fish and
 Game, the District Attorney's Association of California, the Sierra Club,
 the Leaque of Women Voters, Common Cause, and many papers have written
 editorials urging Wilson to veto it.  
 
 IT IS NOW SITTING ON GOV. PETE WILSON'S DESK. HE HAS MONDAY TO EITHER VETO
 IT OR SIGN IT.  His press spokesperson has said Wilson hasn't decided yet
 to veto it or sign it so it's extremely important for all those living in
 California (and those who want to help California keep their water
 unpolluted) to contact the Governor's office AS SOON AS POSSIBLE for the
 decision could be made anytime.
 
 THE PHONE NUMBER TO GOV. WILSON'S OFFICE IS: (916) 658 2793
 
 THE BILL IS:	SB 649  (ASK HIM TO VETO IT)
 
 YOU CAN CALL ANYTIME (DAY OR NIGHT, WEEKDAY OR WEEKENDS) and leave a
 message (his office reviews all calls during the day so don't worry your
 message will be heard by his office).  Don't say anything bad about the
 governor or any decisions he's made that you disagree with or else this
 may just cause him to sign this horrible bill.  YOUR CALL JUST MIGHT MAKE
 THE DIFFERENCE BETWEEN HIM SIGNING IT AND HIM VETOING IT SO DON'T DELAY
 AND PLEEEESE CALL RIGHT THIS MINUTE!!! 
 
 The Sacramento Bee wrote a nice editorial urging Wilson to veto it.  I
 don't have the editorial but I have an article on it from the Sacramento
 Bee that i will now print.  Here it is: 
 

> > 
> > source: Sacramento Bee, September 13, 1996, pg. A4 by Brad Hayward
> > 
> > --------
> > 
> > Title: OIL-SPILL BILL TAINTED BY DONATIONS, FOES CHARGE
> > 
> >    Environmental and public-interest groups, suggesting that California
> > lawmakers have been bought by the oil industry, on Thursday urged Gov. 
> > Pete Wilson to veto SB 649, legislation that would make it tougher for
> > prosecutors to win some criminal cases against water polluters. 
> >    The groups released a study of campaign finances showing that since
> > 1990, oil companies have contributed $4 million to California legislators,
> > nearly $400,000 of it in the first six months of this year.
> >    Those contributions, coupled with the industry's expenditures on
> > lobbying, "laid the foundation" for passage of SB 649, said Ruth Holton of
> > California Common Cause, who was joined at the Capitol news conference by
> > representatives of the Sierra Club, Consumers Union and the Leaque of
> > Women Voters.
> >    "Money appears to be dominating lawmaking more blatantly than ever,"
> > Holton said.
> >    Under the bill, firms spilling a harmful material - such as oil or
> > poisonous chemicals - could escape criminal prosecution if they promptly
> > reported the spill.  
> >    Wilson spokesman Sean Walsh said the governor has not yet taken a
> > position on the bill.
> >    Opponents to SB 649, including the California Department of Fish and
> > Game, say it would gut key protections for the state's water and wildlife.
> >    "This is a question of whether people have clean water to drink in
> > California," said Harry Snyder of Consumers Union.  "Without inappropriate
> > money contributions from the oil industry, this bill would never have been
> > passed." 
> > 
> > ----------------
> > 
> > Thanks everybody.  Now go and call Wilson's office right now at (916) 658
> > 2793 and tell him to veto SB 649.

And, if that number doesn't work, you can try 916-322-2318!

Hi!

 Well as Greg is not supposed to work and the rest of the crew hasn't 
posted yet I've taken it upon myself to inform the list of waz happin'.

 On Saturday the 28th, Harmony and Hundred Acre Woods present a special 
B-Day party. It is dedicated to Greg Sandler, one of the founders of 
Harmony 3 years ago. He is the hardest workin', most humble DJ that I 
know and has so influenced and supported a segment of the underground 
that most of us love. HE IS NOT TO WORK ON THIS PARTY!!! IF YOU SEE HIM 
WORKING ON THIS ONE STOP HIM!!

 Party is in SF and will go from 9pm to 6am. DJs are;

Trent
Dano
Cloud
Minor Minor 
Ethan

With a special [short] set from Greg

Ambient room will be taken cared of by Dionysus Dreams and friends.

Map point is mandantory; call the info lines for more details:


[408]486.9591     [408]450.3044    [415]263.4885


 Again this is a benefit for Omar and his family. As Omar is in a coma, 
he can't be transfered to another hospital. His Mom flies out to see him 
twice a week and this creates a severe drain on the families finances.

 I personally would like to thank everyone out there who has helped Greg 
and the Crew and especially those of you who have helped make Dionysus 
Dreams a reality. Without the hard workers and the appreciative ravers we 
never would have been able to do any of this.  Thank you all.


Hugz,


Ran @ Dionysus Dreams

My aologies for being so tardy. I haven't had the time to do this for the 
last three days. Charity on Sunday at San Jose was great. Excellent time, 
excellent music. The experience was very interactive because we helped 
set up and pack up and stuff. Got to meet David, Libby, Adam, Robert, 
Jay, Heidi, Philip, Lucas etc. Lucas, Philip, and Adam were kind enough 
to have us over to their house and to feed us, and play an ambient set
in their living room with the cool black lighting and other eye candy 
around. I wanted to thank everybody involved with that for the wonderful 
time.

Hi all!

 I'm having some minor difficulty getting to our site for the party on 
Friday. I want to go up Friday and set up some stuff early so that the 
show will still be awesome yet I can rest on Saturday and play a 
mind-blowing set Saturday night.

 The deal is this; we only have from 4 to 6 pm on Friday to work. I would 
like to leave Santa Cruz at 1 pm, stop in Saratoga for supplies, then 
head to the City for set up. Then head back to SC for some rest. The ride 
should be in SC no later than 12:00 so I can grab my gear. If you pay 
your own gas then you get in to the party for free. If you help set up 
and tear down on Sat./Sun. then we will give you gas money.

 This a great chance for you newbies who want to get involved to do so. 
We like to work with the same people so if you work out for this show we 
will definately call you for future events {cause we ain't stoppin' now!}.

 I can be reached here or at work between 8 and noon on Friday. 
work; [408].459.4421


Cheers!


Ran @ Dionysus Dreams

YES!

1.      everybody please put NRR in your subject headings when dealing with
NRR material.

2.      anyone out there who doesn't know what filtering is, or your mail
reader doesn't seem to support it, please email me (or a number of other
people on this list) and ASK! i'll point you in the right direction.

love,

brian

Thanks for everyone who's been helping with info.  I haven't had much
time to pick up stuff myself recently, so this calendar is the product
of all of your help.  Please keep sending updates, and any new stuff
you come across.  

This weekend, I'm missing stuff for Friday, but I'm intrigued by 
SuperSensonic on Saturday.  Fantasy Island has a huge lineup but
with an equally huge flyer...  Stop by the Hemp Festival if you
aren't already hip to the medicinal marijuana proposition.


                                THE SFR CALENDAR
                                       
    http://www.hyperreal.com/raves/sf/calendar/gencal.cgi

     _________________________________________________________________
   
Upcoming Parties in the San Francisco Bay Area

   Thursday, September 26th - _Techno/Trance benefit for Food Not Bombs
   and the Prisoner Literature Project_
   DRC, Mars, Mystr-E, Tomcat.
   $3-$5 sliding scale
   no one turned away for lack of funds
   free vegi food
   9pm-2am, 21+, $5. El Rio, 3158 Mission @ Cesar Chavez, SF.
   
   Saturday, September 28th - _SuperSensonic_
   Dan Curtin (Cleveland), Ono Sendai Sound Technician (The Delta
   Quadrant), Zerox (Swell Records), Jon Santos (Mad SF), Bradley (yo
   mama).
   415.303.2312
   
   Saturday, September 28th - Fantasy Island
   Metro (live), Barbara Tucker (live), Michelle Weeks (live),
   J.Sinister, Scott Richmond, Jeno, Garth, Spun, Tracy, Preston, That
   Kid Chris, Juan Kato, Davidson Ospina, Dreamer, Carlos, Eric
   Davenport, Hipp-E, Ghost, Frank Nitty, Jon Bishop, Pat Allen, Pete
   Avila, Neon Leon, Soulstice, Sounds from the Ground.
   Visuals by Lumatech Intelligent Lighting, Multi-Media Meltdown, Liquid
   Sircus Delights.
   415.437.6905 510.674.8663 916.491.6851 408.793.0287
   
   Saturday, September 28th - _house!_
   adonis, uneke, kelvin.
   9pm-2am, 21+, Free. the top, 424 Haight St, SF.
   
   Sunday, September 29th - _Medical Marijuana Show and Hemp Festival_
   rave part presented by xlr8r & the Gathering
   3pm-6pm, $8. Hall of Flowers, 9th & Lincoln, Golden Gate Park, SF.
   510.533.0605
   
   Friday, October 4th - _The X Files_
   Jeno, Ghost, Frank Nitty, Donald Glaude, Essence, Kwashi.
   415.560.5314 415.509.5736 408.235.9344
   
   Friday, October 4th - Sunset & Electric Co. presents _Pacific_

Radio/TV Shows

     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Monday afternoon 12:30-3:00 pm - DJ Jerecho presents the best of
       the urban polyrhythmic experience jungle, acid jazz, techno,
       electro, breakbeat KDVS, 90.3 FM (Davis)
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - nocturnal transmissions - featuring house DJs from
       SF and around the world. mid-2am, 107.7 FM (SF)
     * Friday night - Your Mama's House w/Pete Avila - 3am-5am, 106.1
       KMEL.
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - the Uncle Noah TV Show - the best
       in Techno and House music. 3-5am, KDVS 90.3fm (Davis)
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday, 4pm-6pm - "Aural Fixation" w/Ted Vadakan. experimental
       ambient, trip hop, jungle musicality. KZSC 88.1 fm (Santa Cruz)
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * Saturday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. and
       Monkeywrench KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)

Administrative Notes

   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.com with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.com with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.com

Hello everyone!!!

        I am so fucking happy right now!!! I finally got my computer back!!!
(Mucho thanks to Brendan!!! Thanks Brendan!!!) 

        Anyways, I thought the first thing to do would be to post about this
Saturday's party!!! So here it is...

        Harmony and 100 Acre Woods present...

                                       "Stinky's Big Birthday Bash Bonanza"

        Dj's:           Cloud - Trent - Ethan - Minor Minor - Dano - Greg =)

        Ambient Room:     Dionysus Dreams


        This party is a hard core fundraiser for Omar! We have donated a lot
of money to Omar's mother, but she still could use a lot more. So we are
giving a $5 (maybe more) donation for every person that comes through the
door!!! That means you!!! So you should come and support our brother Omar!!!
The admission cost for the party has not been decided, (or at least shared
with me yet). But it is not up to me on this one. I have been told that I am
not to work, think, or do any strenuous activities at this party. So I
really don't know many of the details for this one. (Which is kinda cool!) 

        In any case, this party is gonna be really cool!! This will be the
first Harmony that I have ever not worked and been able to just sit and
chill at!!! I am stoked!!! (Fuck yeah!!!) There wil be a mandatory map point
close by the location. So call the info lines to get the directions and
stuff!!! There is a maximum capacity for the location, but honestly I don't
think you'll have a problem getting in as long as you get to the map point
early. I believe the map point opens up at 8:30- 9pm and will close when
enough tix have been sold. The party will start @ 9pm. (no, really) Just get
there early to avoid disappointment!!! I would love to see all of you there,
and for those of you whom I never have a minute to talk to, sit my ass down
a have a chat!!! I can't wait!!!

                        (408)486-9591   -    (408)450-3044    -    (415)263-4885
                             Harmony                       BP
Hunny

Peace, love and positivity,

Greg =)
-brendan-

>How about misusing the FBI to frame various long-term employees of the
>White House travel agency, in order to replace them with friends from
>Arkansas.

I really could care less about what happens at the white house travel
office. This is just a bunch of republican muckraking. As far as I'm
concerned, they should clean-sweep the place every 4-8 years anyways,
just to prevent any kind of entrenched bribery/extortion/backscratching
from taking root. "Friends from <wherever the incumbant is from>" is
the way washington runs, so nothing out of the ordinary here. I'm sure
similar stuff could be found w/r/t Reagan and Bush. Hell, much worse
stuff really, e.g. the CIA's Role (while Bush was the head of the CIA,
and later VP) in importing cocaine into the US to support the contras
and other "anti communist" covert wars throughout the world.  The
CIA/Cocaine/Contra connection is only hitting the mainstream press
right now, but it's been a well known subject that was snuffed out of
the press while Bush was anywhere near Washington. The CIA is
all-powerful -- and "mysterious death" has accompanied many reporters
who have linked and shown evidence for the CIA/drug connection (e.g.
Mabe Russel in the 1980's).  Anybody thinking we're living in a
democracy has been watching too much TV.

>How about illegally obtaining hundreds of FBI files in order to gain
>information about his enemies, the scope of which is much greater than
>anything that caused Nixon to resign.   (A Nixon staffer went to jail
>for obtaining ONE FBI file.)

This is typical Washington SNAFU (situation normal all fucked up) and
has been going on for years -- for almost the full 50 year reign of J
Edgar Hoover as the Republican shadow-president while he was the head
of the FBI. Hoover's FBI "investigated" plenty of republican policial
opponents, especially civil rights leaders and anti-vietnam protesters
during The Johnson and Nixon administrations. The FBI had secret dirt
on both Kennedy brothers, McGovern, Martin Luther King, Malcolm X, and
they used this information to play dirty politics for the Republicans.
Nixon and Ford were more than happy to have the FBI doing their dirty
work outside the beltway while they had their own hit squads doing
their dirty work inside (Watergate). Lets not ever forget the legacy of
deceit that the Republicans have fostered.

--------------------

I personally think Clinton is just a republican in democrat's clothing
and I will not vote for him either (even though I naively voted for him
the first time around). He is a traitor to the progressives that helped
put him in power, and I'm tired of him pandering to the right-wingers
and fascist-christians in this country that are peddling deceit, hate,
and  capital accumulation under the guise of morality and
right-thinking. Even though it's a wasted vote, I'm voting for Ralph
Nader and the Green Party. Representative democracy was never meant to
be a choice between two "lesser of two evils" putz-candidates. I
suggest you and your friends all vote for whichever candidate best
represents your views, unless you've found something particularly
endearing about Dole or Clinton. 

PS: if Dole wins because you do this -- personally, I don't think
anybody will notice the difference, except that it might be easier to
buy/sell cigarettes and alchohol, the price of cocaine will drop, and
heroin will become even more available as the republican US-oil buddies
will be able to get a stronger foothold in Myanmar (Burma) by helping
the fascist dictatorship capitalize on their cash crops -- Oil and
Heroin. Of course, in the US, they'll build more jails as it's hard to
make drug-sales profitable and politically actionable unless you can
keep prices high, supplies inexhaustible, and pay lots of police and
prison guards to jail those unfortunate enough to be caught in the
middle of this...  And you have a ready-made "problem" that heroic
republican politicians can "solve" -- a conventient snow-job to cover
up the fact that we don't need politicians in the first place. Your tax
dollars at work.

Aside from the deleterious effects of alchohol/tobacco/cocaine/heroin
and other drugs, this is the ultimate reason why you should "just say
no" -- because you're helping put money into the hands of murderers and
politicians. Don't be a dupe -- thinking is the best drug, and it's not 
illegal yet!

On Thu, 26 Sep 1996, Renzo Saunders wrote:

>      I wouldn't skip the Fantasy Island party just because all these people 
>      dissed on it. From what I've read over the past months it seems that 
>      most of the people on the list are not in to the larger parties. It 
>      seems that most people on the list are in to going to smaller parties 
>      where they know everyone and half the people at the party are 
>      subscribed to this list.

I'm not so sure about that anymore.  
First there was much bellyaching about raves which cost over $15.
Now some of the best raves (Harmony & Chrysalis for example) always 
charge $15 or more and no one bats an eye.  

When the Gathering happens, people on this list bitch to the ends of the 
earth because of the cost. ($20-$25).  They want to see the books 
opened.  But not one person questions the costs of other raves which have 
the same price tag.  Some are very obvious of what the costs are for (ie: 
a benefit for someone who has been injured).  I believe the Gathering has 
put on benefit parties for Malachy, yet people still gripe about Martin's 
events.  I'm just wondering about you folks.  Why bitch about one party 
and not another?  Is is purely the people who go?  I avoid parties such 
as Fantasy Island and Juggernot, and I have my specific reasons:  I 
prefer the folks who attend the not-as-advertised raves such as Friends & 
Family, etc. because most of my friends & sfravers (same thing!) attend 
these raves.  

And then we come to the sheer numbers of people who attend.  When we say 
a "small underground rave"  what exactly does that mean?  I heard that 
the last Harmony party had either 1,000 or damn near close.  No, it isn't 
2,500, but that doesn't sound small and underground anymore. 

I am not criticizing ANY promoters in this post: you all do a wonderful job!
I am just confused at the focus of the bitching and griping that goes on 
and what exactly constitutes "small underground party" vs. a "massive"
You all seem so quick to condemn.....

love,
Amy

Hello,

If "NRR:" is used in the Subject line, then there is no problem with
non-rave-related posts making the volume so high that it is impossible
for people to read and follow sfraves.

The only difference between using "NRR:" and having two physically
separate lists is that people who don't want both types of posts end
up receiving twice as much volume in their mailbox.

I know that 5 years ago, that would have been a problem, many people
were paying per kb of mail or for time - which worked out to being the
same thing in the end.

SO, are the NRR posts a problem because they make the other posts
harder to find ( which is solved by using "NRR:" in the Subject line )


OR

is the sheer kilobyte volume of sfraves messages a problem for people
( ie not is it a minor nuisance, but is it a problem ) ?


Cheers,

Ken                         <*>
kstuart@mail.telis.org

Precedence: bulk

KaySEE <scarab@value.net> wrote:
>I'm listening to some cool ambient on KPFA right now (Weds. 10 pm).

There's an excellent ambient-type show called Neptune Currents on KKUP
(91.5, located S Bay but with a pretty good range) Sunday mornings 8-11.
It's a bunch of different beatless stuff, with a lot of acoustic, or at
least non-synthetic, ambient done with guitars, digderidoo, flute,
whatever.  Mysterious early synth music too, lots of seventies stuff.
Great listening for when you get home.

KKUP has another ambient show Sundays at midnight that's a little more
electronic and beaty, sometimes drifting all the way to a trip-hop feel.

anarch@scruznet.com

Subject: NRR: today's happy word origin
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Hey, ever been curious where some of our goofy slang comes from? I
came across this one at:
http://www.sci.kun.nl/thalia/rapdict/

phat 

1) (adj) Great, addictive.

2) (adj) If a girl was phat, she had Plenty o' Hips And Thighs, in
other words PHysically ATtractive; old slang. Think 60's or early 70's
here. A bit more modern: Pussy, Hips And Tits.

Interesting how things mutate.

Steve

Beatles for the Computer Age!

Eleanor Rigby

Eleanor Rigby
Sits at the keyboard -
And waits for a line on the screen
Lives in a dream

Waits for a signal
Finding some code
That will make the machine do some more.
What is it for?

All the lonely users, where do they all come from?
All the lonely users, why does it take so long?

Guru MacKenzie
Typing the lines of a program that no one will run;
Isn't it fun?

Look at her working,
Munching some chips as she waits for the code to compile;
Where is the style?

All the lonely users, where do they all come from?
All the lonely users, why does it take so long?

Eleanor Rigby
Crashes the system and loses 6 hours of work;
What is it worth?

Guru MacKenzie
Wiping the blood off her hands as she walks from the grave;
Nothing was saved.

All the lonely users, where do they all come from?
All the lonely users, why does it take so long?

--

Unix Man...

He's a real UNIX man
Sitting in his UNIX LAN
Making all his UNIX .plans
For nobody

He's as wise as he can be
Programs in lex, yacc and C
UNIX Man, can you help me
At all?

UNIX Man, please listen,
my printout is missin'
UNIX Man,
The wo-o-o-orld is your 'at' command

--

Write in C

When I find my code in tons of trouble,
Freinds and  colleagues come to me,
Speaking words of wisdom:
'Write in C.'

As the deadline fast approaches,
And bugs are all that I can see,
Somewhere, someone whispers:
'Write in C.'

Write in C, Write in C,=20
Write in C, oh, Write in C.
LOGO's dead an buried,
Write in C.

I used to write a lot of FORTRAN,
for Science it worked flawlessly,
Try using it for graphics,
Write in C.

If you've just spent nearly 30 hours
Debugging some assem-bl-y,
Soon you will be glad to
Write in C.

Write in C, Write in C,
Write in C, oh, Write in C.
Only wimps use BASIC.
Write in C.

Write in C, Write in C,
Write in C, oh, Write in C.
Pascal won=92t quite cut it.
Write in C.

Write in C, Write in C,
Write in C, oh, Write in C.
Don't even mention COBOL
Write in C.

--

Date: Fri, 27 Sep 1996 14:17:22 -0700
X-Sender: sddpw@pop.sirius.com
Message-Id: <v01520d01ae71913078fb@[205.134.228.30]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: sddpw@sirius.com (Shimako-Dominguez Department of Public Works)
Subject: DJs wanted
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Hey all.

Well, I tried to quit sfraves.  Unsubscribed for almost six weeks!  But I
just needed that little fix of 100 e-mails a day, so I am back.

And things have been good while I was gone.  I know you're wondering, "How
could life be good when he was unsubscribed all those cold and lonely
nights", but it is true.  Things are rolling along, and I already need the
community's system.  I have the opportunity to put on a party, but I need
DJs.  Looking for downtempo stuff only.  Trip-hop, stoner beats type stuff,
maybe some acid jazz, but it should have a danceable feel.

So send me your demo tapes!!  Or call me at 415.864.8234 if you need more
info.  The first party is Oct 8 (a Tuesday) and could be a regular thing if
all goes well.

Of course, if you are not a DJ but have suggestions of your favorite
mixologist, send them to me ASAP.  This opportunity came up on me all of
sudden, and I don't have much time to throw it together, obviously.

By the way, I realize some people might object to this, in that I have been
of a long time, and my first post is kinda of BSP.  But i didn't want to go
into other stuff until I get a feel for what people are taling about at the
moment.  Yet, the need for DJs was immediate and I know many people on the
list are always looking for opportunities, so I thought it would be o.k.  I
will take any flack I deserve, but I wanted y'all to know it was not posted
in complete clueless ness.

THANKS.  Lookign forward to hearing from eveyone.

peace & misses......Arkay

X-Sender: knucklehead@host.domain.net

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: knucklehead@club.net (Knucklehead)
Subject: READ ME
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Why don't you people grow up! Who gives a rat's ass about NRR post. We are
a community. And whatever is talked about on sfraves is always related
because a raver either likes what was said or is some how involved. If you
don't like it, delete it. This moaning and complaining about NRR post is
stupid as shit.

You don't go up to someone at a rave and say " Your not talking about rave
stuff, I don't want to hear it and you shouldn't be talking about it at a
rave. Most of the people that complain about it just want to be heard and
get email.

If it's important enough to someone on this list to share with others, then
it is Rave related because a ravers is thinking about it.

I think you should stop complaining and get on with your life. I've seen
people on here chew the hell out of someone for some stupid ass post and
then see that same person at a party and expect them to be all lovey dovey
to them.

If you don't want to read something just delete the damn thing. I sometime
don't even read half of the mail on here because the subject just doesn't
move me. Why can't you do the same.

Go ahead and flame me for this post, I really don't give a shit. I love
email. This is part of the reason why in my time period raving was dying.
We all need to get along and stick together and quite complaining about
post that has nothing to do with a party. Don't any of you have a life
other then parties. Since I've been in the 1996 time period, I can't see
how raving latest up to 2095. WE NEED TO GET ALONG AND STOP MOANING.

You all probally think I'm fun of crap about me being from another time
period. Well after Sunday you will never see me again. Except for 3 of you,
you will have been accidently zapped into the year 2094 from what is know
here as 2010. Sorry I'm not telling who, I can't, but you never go back.
The 3 of you CARE to much about the scene to leave it the why it is in
2094.

Tim (knucklehead)

Message-Id: <199609272319.QAA25446@aoaioxxysz.organic.com>
To: San Francisco Raves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: *sigh* One last attempt...
Date: Fri, 27 Sep 1996 16:19:11 -0700
From: ozymandias G desiderata <ogd@organic.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I've been watching this most recent incarnation of the endless argument
over what exactly sfraves is trying to be with some interest. The
argument has gotten intense, many good points have been raised, but it's
my depressing conclusion that nobody's really paying any attention to
what the other people are saying. In particular, those of you who feel
that you have an innate right to post whatever inane crap pops into your
heads have been particularly irritating me.

Look, there are very obviously two groups of us here: those of us who
think of sfraves as a community forum, and those of us who think of
sfraves as a place to discuss raves in the San Francisco area. The two
different groups have very different aims and needs, and it's getting to
the point where it seems like the second group is not only getting
ignored by the first, but straight-out insulted. Tim's and Eric's recent
messages are particularly egregious examples of this.

I'm a reasonably social person, and raving, DJing, and promoting are very
important parts of my life. I have a lot of good friends in the San
Francisco rave scene, and I'd be lying if I said that the internet and
sfraves had had nothing to do with that. However, I'm also busy, and I
receive a _lot_ of email. I've gotten ~300 messages so far today, and I'm
sure that I'll have received somewhere in the neighborhood of 1000 by the
end of today. The frightening thing is how much of it is ABSOLUTELY
USELESS banter from sfraves.

Yes, I have an email filtering system (mailagent, for those of you who
are curious -- it's a huge perl / C hybrid, but it does lots of stuff in
a reasonably intuitive and extraordinarily powerful way), and I'm
automatically chopping huge swathes through my incoming sfraves mail. But
that makes me uncomfortable, because I know that hyperreal is going to
the trouble of sending me these messages, and consuming network bandwidth
to do it that could have been better used for something else.

I like a lot of you a lot, but the internet is _not_ somebody's comfy
living room. Resources are finite and the fact that we _all_ get to hear
_everybody's_ earth-shattering pronouncements, never mind how insipid or
banal they may be really bugs me. The simple fact is that I don't think
that it's unreasonable for me to not want to have to deal with all of
this junk email, and I do NOT feel like I'm being a whiner for pointing
this out. I feel like I've been patient with sfraves and the people on it
beyond any reasonable expectation.

So, besides merely venting, I'd like to point this out: if you still feel
like you want to talk about anything and everything, PLEASE be assiduous
in your use of the NRR header, and remember that someday Hyperreal may
have to be moved or shut down because of the intense amounts of bandwidth
that it consumes (Organic only bestows network largesse upon Hyperreal
because Organic doesn't currently need it). I've started automatically
deleting anything from sfraves with NRR in the heading, and it's doing
wonders for my sfraves reading experience. You can all talk about
whatever the hell you want. I'm going to read about raves.

cranky old
ozymandias

       . . . the self-reflecting image of a narcotized mind . . .
ozymandias G desiderata      ogd@organic.com                 Think "bus"
(415)278-5674     http://www.organic.com/Staff/ogd/       ::AOAIOXXYSZ::

Message-Id: <199609272325.QAA17912@netcom17.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: NRR: a compromise
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


How about this:

1) people who want to post NRR stuff please *always* use NRR to satisfy
those with filters
2) people who don't want to read NRR stuff please get some filters 
running
3) everyone else: stop bitching

I'm sick of reading this stupid debate. It wastes more of my time
and more of hyperreal's system load/network utilization than any
other thread on this list. (and I apologize for contributing to
the discussion)

There's no solution. There are definitely two camps to this, so can
we please compromise?

I'm sooooo sick of reading people argue about what's appropriate, not
appropriate on X mailing list or on Y newsfroup. 

arrgggghhhhh!!!!
#%$^)*(^
I feel better now :)

enough ranting, back to raving...

Steve

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Fri Sep 27 16:37:11 1996

From: Troy Sheets <tsheets@xanadu.cyborganic.net>
Message-Id: <199609272337.QAA07345@xanadu.cyborganic.net>
Subject: food not bombs was the bomb.
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Fri, 27 Sep 1996 16:37:05 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL25]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Well, okay, maybe not the absolute bomb, but it was such a clever play on
words. ;)

When you first enter the El Rio it looks like a somewhat seedy Mission
bar... but once you make your way past the pool tables in the back, you
find a very nice outdoor patio.  There they had some good Food Not Bombs
info, and a whole lot of good veggie food.  I suspect this is the same
food they give out free, every day, 7 days a week... many more times a day
on some days.  This included veggie burgers, chips and salsa, brownies,
Odwalla, black beans and a bunch of other goodies.

>From the patio you could check out the dance area, where the F-8 boys
were spinning.  They were spinning their typical trance set that had
everybody moving, despite a sound system that was kinda thin on the low
end.  By 11 there was a good, friendly vibe going, both on the dance
floor and on the patio.  It was a pretty nice evening to be outside.

The food not bombs people seem pretty cool.  Saw a lot of Harvard shirts...
its good to see that school produces people who have other goals besides
bribing the government to make laws that allows their totalitarian 
corperations make more money with no regard to how they are actually
affecting the human species as a whole.

Food, trance, a good cause... fun night.

For me, a small underground party has lees than 300 people and costs less 
than $10.  A "regular" party (if there is such a thing) is from 300 - 500 
people and costs between $15 - $20.  Anything larger / more expensive is 
a massive, although most massives here automatically become over 1000 
people without even trying :)

Mind you i have been to some massives that were less than $15 and some 
"small underground parties" that were $20 (okay, ONE, and i knew the 
promoters were money-grubbing twerps but i went anyways) ....

You may think that you are being humourous, but I really doubt that the 
people who volunteer hours upon hours month after month, working to bring 
the techno/electronic music/rave community a wealth of *free* 
information, would appreciate that kind of sarcasm.  I for one don't.  I 
maintain several links pages on hyperreal, and I put a lot of time into 
them (i get 5-10 emails a day and check each one individually) I'd rather 
not see hyperreal have to retire because all of poor use of resources.

> >  Resources are finite 
> yeah...let me know if someone shuts off the power, what are you worried
> about? bandwidth? hard disk space?

I imagine if hyperreal had to pay for its own bandwidth it would cost 
well over a $1000/month.  That's a nice donation from the company that is 
hosting it, we should all respect that *privilege* to have the kind of 
bandwidth available that we do.

you think it would be.  Do you know of many spare T1's preinstalled that 
would be able to handle the load hyperreal creates?  I'm not flaming you, 
I just don't think you understand how much bandwidth and care hyperreal 
needs.

I want to thank all of you who came to El Rio last night.  The party was a
big success by Food Not Bombs standards.  We raised aproximately $400 after
expenses.  That is a lot of rice and beans (a pity we have other expenses,
too).  The DJ's were great, agreeing to play for close to nothing, and
spinning great sets.  Special thanks to Tomc@t for taking the first slot,
and having to contend with a nearly empty floor.

A lot of people put in a lot of hard work, and it paid off.  We hope to put
on more such parties in the future.

My biggest regret was failing to meet anybody from the list.  Thought my
bright yellow shirt was a giveaway.  Course, its mainly my own fault for
enjoying the music so much, that I was unable to stop dancing long enough to
socialize.  There is a small chance I will make it to FM tonight.  If so,
I'll make a bigger effort to find y'all.

Peace and love,
Kerry

PS re: Troy-

there are no Harvard grads in FNB, although not because we wouldn't accept
any!  The majority of the group is working class (mainly service industry),
under employed, unemployed, on General Assistance, and, of course students.
But the group is pretty diverse, and there are people from all walks of life
to be found in the FNB family (from the homeless to those who work in high
tech--some even own computers :>) ).

Thanks for coming, Troy.  Hope to figure out who you are sometime.

One last thought about this NRR as well as other crap. Putting NRR in the
Subject is great. That's what should happen. I also think that the use of
the good old CC:  (for those with no clue that Carbon Copy)

I think people should lay off CC: sfraves when posting. Some of it's ok.
But almost every post, come on. I love getting email, but hal the post are
usually someone yelling at someone else which causes someone else to get
involved.

Final note on this matter is put NRR on subject line and quite complaining
about NRR post. And quite using the CC: to sfraves so much and just reply
to the originator. That would cut half the "crap" mail people are
complaining about. I think that most of the bandwidth that's being used is
because of the CC: to sfraves and everyone leaving the entire email message
there replying to in the text.  If there wasn't any NRR post this list
would be almost like the Calendar and alot of people probally wouldn't be
on here. I've met alot of great people when I replied to an NRR post. So
the NRR post are a big part of this "Community". Just stop using the Carbon
Copy: sfraves so much.

Enough of this.

Tim (knucklehead)

I suggest getting the MkLinux version 2 CD-Rom from Prime Time Freeware
(http://www.ptf.com/) -- specifically http://www.ptf.com/ptf/products/MKLP/.  
It is generally very helpful to be able to free up your hard-disk for your
own files/system files, and be able to load up Linux sources, as well as
other app sources or even app binaries "as needed" from the CD-ROM, rather
than having to fetch them over a slow internet connection.

I haven't tried MkLinux because I don't have any macintosh harware, but I
can tell you that when all those cheap 2-processor 250Mhz PowerPC clones
start coming out, MkLinux on those boxes is going to kick the shit out of
SGI, Sun and Microsoft/Intel offerings, esp. for web servers. I hope Linux
smacks the living hell out of those greedy & arrogant wankers. I've even
heard rumors that Apple will be putting out their macintosh desktop with
MkLinux as the underlying OS. (Anybody wanna confrirm that??).

FYI -- Prime Time Freeware seems like a pretty reputable company and
they're decent-seeming folks and charge very fair prices for their goods. I
know this because they included some of my software on their Prime Time
Freeware for Unix distribution and they contacted me to ensure that it was
ok to do so, and even gave me two distributions of their disks for free.
I've also heard good things about them through people they haven't
"comp'd".

PS: I personaly run Linux on a Pentium laptop and it rocks. 

PPS: Rave-related: Mr Goodwrench ofn KFJC (89.7) is playing (Fri 10PM-2AM)
an interesting techno show comparing Detroit Techno (transmat, derrick may,
etc) with English techno (Kurt DeGeorgio, ART Records). very educational
lesson on the roots o' techno and Detroit/UK cross-pollination. It's the
bee's knees!

--------------------
                 
      MkLinux: Microkernel Linux for the Power Macintosh
    
                                    MKLINUX
                                       
         Apple Computer is funding the development of MkLinux,       a
   Mach-based version of the Linux operating system.       MkLinux currently
   runs       on the 6100 / 7100 / 8100 (NuBus, PowerPC 601) series       of
   Power Macintosh computers,       as well as most recent Intel-based PCs.
     Apple intends to continue development,       adding support for at least
   the PCI-based Power Macintosh       and PowerPC Platform (formerly CHRP).
   
   
         Mach has been ported to a number of single and multiprocessor
   platforms.       Ports of MkLinux to these platforms could thus emerge
   fairly rapidly.       Meanwhile, the PowerMac version of MkLinux gives
   interested parties       the ability to work with the system.
   
       Please Note:            Neither Apple nor PTF is offering any kind of
   direct support       for any of the MkLinux releases.       Do not call,
   write, or email either firm asking for help!
   
         Apple has set up http://www.mklinux.apple.com[1]       as the focal
   point for MkLinux information.       See this site for late-breaking news,
   documentation,       mailing list information, updates, patches, etc.
   By obtaining the current distribution and tracking the Web site,
   interested parties should be able to keep up with (and assist!)       the
   development of this new operating system.
   
Developer Release 2

         More than 4000 copies of MkLinux DR1 have been distributed,
   establishing an active community       of experimentally-minded users and
   developers.       Many of these people are already wearing our
   T-shirts and sweatshirts[2],       featuring the cute MkPenguin mascot.
   
           With DR2, Apple is making MkLinux accessible       to a wider
   community of users.       As a "Beta quality" release, DR2 provides:
   

      * greatly increased performance       * improved reliability

      * new and improved drivers            * more Mach features

      * a larger command set                * and many bug fixes


           In short, if you've been waiting for a good time to try out MkLinux,
         this is it!       (If you're one of our stalwart crew of early
   adopters,       using a hacked and patched copy of DR1,       this is a
   great time to upgrade!)
   
           DR2 is a snap to install.       It contains pre-installed versions
   of the usual Linux commands,       including X11R6.1 and a full GNU
   development suite.       A large collection of RPM archives is also
   included,       in both source and binary format.             Note:       At
   present, MkLinux only runs on the 6100 / 7100 / 8100       (NuBus, PowerPC
   601) series of Power Macintosh systems,       including some 61XX Apple
   Performa models.       PCI / 604 support is expected in late Fall.
   
   
   
Some Bad News, Some (Very) Good News...

         DR1 was produced by Apple and distributed by PTF.       DR2, in
   contrast, is a joint effort.       This means that we must charge more:
   $20/disc       ($14 each in quantity 10+).       Fortunately, we have also
   instituted a number of discount offers.       It is almost certain that one
   of these will meet your needs.       For detailed information, see our
   Ordering[3] page.
   
Consumer Alert!

           A disc entitled "MkLinux Fall 1996" is being sold in CD-ROM stores.
        It appears to be a "drag-copy" of the DR1 disc,       plus the July 8
   FTP update (not applied).       In any event, it is not the same (DR2) disc
   PTF is selling.       Commercial bias aside, we recommend that you avoid
   this product.       It does not contain the new "baseline"  version of
   MkLinux,       has no added value to speak of, and will not be supported by
   Apple.
   
The MkLinux reference release is coming soon!

         Prime Time Freeware has been selected       to publish Apple's
   reference release of MkLinux.       "MkLinux: Microkernel Linux for the
   Power Macintosh",       being edited with the assistance and support of
   Apple,       will contain a variety of reference material       about Linux,
   Mach, MkLinux, and the Power Macintosh.
   
         This product is scheduled for release in December 1996.       For
   detailed information, see our       Ordering[4] page.       To receive an
   emailed publication announcement,       contact info@ptf.com[5].
   
--------------------

X-Mailer: Forte Agent .99f/32.299
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii

Hello,

On Fri, 27 Sep 1996 16:19:11 -0700, ozymandias G desiderata
<ogd@organic.com> wrote:

>Yes, I have an email filtering system (mailagent, for those of you who
>are curious -- it's a huge perl / C hybrid, but it does lots of stuff in
>a reasonably intuitive and extraordinarily powerful way), and I'm
>automatically chopping huge swathes through my incoming sfraves mail. But
>that makes me uncomfortable, because I know that hyperreal is going to
>the trouble of sending me these messages, and consuming network bandwidth
>to do it that could have been better used for something else.

This may have been true 5 or 6 years ago, but it is far from true
nowadays.

This "conserve bandwidth" thing was only meaningful back when modems
were 2400 baud and hard drives had 20MB.

Nowadays, the network bandwidth that e-mail mailing lists use, is a
small percent of what is used for all the other more important uses
that dominate the Internet:

- Downloading the latest browser version 
- Downloading erotic images
- Making a long distance telephone call over the Internet using
Internet Phone software
- Listening to a radio station over the Internet using Real Audio
- Watching an inline MPEG video on a web page
- Playing Nintendo-style games live over the Internet
- IRC chat that uses more bandwidth to discuss the same NRR stuff


Cheers,

Ken                         <*>
kstuart@mail.telis.org

Larry, Melissa, and I were planning to go to the party at Mt. Tam, but as
that ceased to be an option, we decided to give The Om Lounge a try.
Before I say anything else I gotta say I enjoyed the live music.  That was
good.  But The Om Lounge had about as much vibe as my 17th Century Lyric
class.  Everyone stood around looking as cool as icebergs, cocktails in
hand, vogueing without even moving a muscle.  I stood there thinking to
myself, 
 
"OOOOOOOOMMMMMM."
 
"OOOOOOOMMMMMMM my god this is so pretentious."
 
"I want to go HOOOOOOMMMMMMMM."
 
So we left in search of the ever-elusive party.  We did a few drive by
hearings, The Bahia, The Top, and decided to just go to the beach and
watch the waves, listen to the original ambient music.  That was nice.  It
was actually a fun night.   :)
Krishna.

>I'm not so sure about that anymore.  
>First there was much bellyaching about raves which cost over $15.
>Now some of the best raves (Harmony & Chrysalis for example) always 
>charge $15 or more and no one bats an eye.  
>
>When the Gathering happens, people on this list bitch to the ends of the 
>earth because of the cost. ($20-$25).  They want to see the books 
>opened.  But not one person questions the costs of other raves which have 
>the same price tag.  Some are very obvious of what the costs are for (ie: 
>a benefit for someone who has been injured).  I believe the Gathering has 
>put on benefit parties for Malachy, yet people still gripe about Martin's 
>events.  I'm just wondering about you folks.  Why bitch about one party 
>and not another?  Is is purely the people who go?  I avoid parties such 
>as Fantasy Island and Juggernot, and I have my specific reasons:  I 
>prefer the folks who attend the not-as-advertised raves such as Friends & 
>Family, etc. because most of my friends & sfravers (same thing!) attend 
>these raves.  
>
>And then we come to the sheer numbers of people who attend.  When we say 
>a "small underground rave"  what exactly does that mean?  I heard that 
>the last Harmony party had either 1,000 or damn near close.  No, it isn't 
>2,500, but that doesn't sound small and underground anymore. 
>
>I am not criticizing ANY promoters in this post: you all do a wonderful job!
>I am just confused at the focus of the bitching and griping that goes on 
>and what exactly constitutes "small underground party" vs. a "massive"
>You all seem so quick to condemn.....
>
>love,
>Amy
>
The difference between some $20 parties and others is the promoter's
decision. Some promoters will donate all of the proceeds to a "Charity."
Others will buy equiptment so that they can provide a better party next time
(like Gateway) (which is great). Some will spend every last dollar of their
budget on the party, and take a huge chance of losing $. (like Harmony)  And
some will make sure their party makes them a few $. Truth is, I don't know
very many promters that are "getting rich quick", but there are a few.

Now the Harmony 3 year had about 1100 people, and no that is not a small
underground party, but we refrained from making it comercial. We had the
opportunity to involve many record labels and magazines in the promotion of
the party, but fuck that!!! If we can't promote our own party good enough,
than we just suck!!! I would consider the 3 year "underground", just not
"small." Honestly, their is no line between "underground and not," look at
FnF. This party gets sometimes 800+. What's the difference? It is how it is
promoted...

Peace,

Greg =)   
-brendan-

Kent Stuart said:

> This may have been true 5 or 6 years ago, but it is far from true
> nowadays.
> 
> This "conserve bandwidth" thing was only meaningful back when modems
> were 2400 baud and hard drives had 20MB.

What are you basing this on?  The T1 which Hyperreal consumes is more
mail-related than anything else -- web traffic included.  This is a
fact.

> Nowadays, the network bandwidth that e-mail mailing lists use, is a
> small percent of what is used for all the other more important uses
> that dominate the Internet:
> 
> [...etc...]

For the internet as a whole, I can't agree or refute this.  Care to back
it up?  In Hyperreal's case, on the other hand, e-mailing lists are most
definitely the largest consumer of bandwidth.

However, the main point of this discussion isn't "shut up with your NRR
stuff".

The point is this: when making a post to sfraves, consider that it will
be sent to (at present) 439 other people.  Do all 439 people need to read
what you have to say?  Is it relevant to the sfraves charter you get when
subscribing?

This is about showing some respect for your neighbors.  I am not big on
"PLUR", but I am big on respect.  If you continually shove irrelevant
junk mail into my mailbox via sfraves, then you are showing a distinct
lack of respect for those who joined this list expecting what is described
in the list charter and for those things which make Hyperreal possible in
the first place.

	Sami

btw- I do not buy the argument, "Well, your post is only contributing to
the problem you are complaining about!"  Wrong.  A solution to what I
perceive as a problem will only come about through discussion, not through
pacifism.
