With the recent discussions of what should be posted, what is rave-related,
and what is not,
it makes me wonder how many people on this list percieve raving.
Does one consider themselves to be a raver because they go to a rave?
like to dance?
post on sfraves?
Wear "rave clothes"?
Does raving need to have some spiritual significance?

Whether you do or don't consider yourself a "raver", 
what does raving mean to you?

I know this may be very difficult to put into words, 
but I still would appreciate any effort to do so.
After all isn't that some of what this list is for?


:)
peter

Hello,

On Sat, 28 Sep 1996 12:36:18 -0700, PETER FOGEL <peterbf@pacbell.net>
wrote:

>With the recent discussions of what should be posted, what is rave-related,
>and what is not,
>it makes me wonder how many people on this list percieve raving.
>Does one consider themselves to be a raver because they go to a rave?

This isn't an answer to your question, but it did remind me of
something I saw a couple of days ago that is indirectly related.

A 1965 British movie called "Having a wild weekend" (featuring the
British pop group the "Dave Clark 5") was on TV.  The plot is that two
tv commercial actors run away from the set for the weekend.  They
steal a car and somehow end up at this house in the country where some
long-haired beats/hippies are hanging out.

When the two are asked where they are from, they reply "London".

One of the hippies responds "Oh, you must be London ravers".

Another comments "No, they're weekend ravers" (meaning, of course,
that during the rest of the week they return to normal societal values
and conformity.)

And that was written and filmed well over 31 years ago...


Cheers,

Ken                         <*>
kstuart@mail.telis.org

Received: from emout16.mail.aol.com (emout16.mx.aol.com [198.81.11.42]) by lazlo.steam.com (8.7.3/8.6.12) with SMTP id RAA04755 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Sat, 28 Sep 1996 17:06:34 -0700 (PDT)
Received: by emout16.mail.aol.com (8.6.12/8.6.12) id UAA17084 for sfraves@hyperreal.com; Sat, 28 Sep 1996 20:04:28 -0400
Date: Sat, 28 Sep 1996 20:04:28 -0400
Message-ID: <960928200428_319708684@emout16.mail.aol.com>
To: sfraves@HYPERREAL.COM
Subject: What I Ended Up Doing Saturday NIght:(
Sender: owner-sfraves@HYPERREAL.COM
Precedence: bulk

Well, some friends and I kept the faith even though we couldn't get through
to the Harvest Moon number. Wanting to do something killer for our nieghbor's
B-day, we piled into the car here in Monterey. We ambitiously did the drive
over the bridge, calling on a cellular the whole way up, encouraged by a post
that said -just keep trying. Just as we passed over, we finally got through
to hear about the bust.

I felt so bad for all of the promoters. You all seemed so amped about this
one! Also, I was thinking that this would finally be my chance to meet
another lister face to face. 

I must say, my roommate, Kelly, and I are really worried that we'll end up
either being normal people again soon, or that we'll start listening to house
exclusively, since that seems to be that predominant dance music around this
area.
We haven't given up yet, though. I guess it would be easier if we lived
closer to the bay.

Anyway, we went to Haight St. to se if we could scratch up a plan B.
Unfortunately, none of us were familiar with the area, and had no clue. I
have never craved to hold a rave flyer in my hand like the moments we stood,
peering into the windows of the closed shops, seeing piles of them only
inches away. Too bad we couldn't just read the phone #'s and call around for
the info. (Now, I call that DESPERATE for a good time!)

We all ended up driving back home and having pancakes.

I guess I've learned something out of all this, I just don't care to examine
it yet. But, I know that, someday, I'll know my way around and I'll get to
have fun ANY TIME I WANT!

-hugh

Hello everyone,

Just wanted to announce that Franklin MinorMinor, Darin Marshall, and Seth
Sutekh (myself) will be hosting a RECORD SWAP on Saturday, October 5
from 1-9pm at our beautiful Oakland warehouse.  

We're hoping to give dj's one day to buy, sell, and trade records directly
with other dj's, rather than selling them to a record store for next to
nothing.  You'll also be able to look through other djs' crates and laugh
at all the lame records they bought for full price :)

We will provide pricing supplies, 4 turntables for listening, live
deejaying, snacks, and free guided tours through the Belief Systems
recording studio!

Bringing records to sell/trade is optional, though encouraged. 

If you're interested, send me email and I'll give you directions.  Hope
you can make it!

-Seth

On Sat, 28 Sep 1996, Ken Stuart wrote:

> On Fri, 27 Sep 1996 16:19:11 -0700, ozymandias G desiderata
> <ogd@organic.com> wrote:
> 
> >Yes, I have an email filtering system (mailagent, for those of you who
> >are curious -- it's a huge perl / C hybrid, but it does lots of stuff in
> >a reasonably intuitive and extraordinarily powerful way), and I'm
> >automatically chopping huge swathes through my incoming sfraves mail. But
> >that makes me uncomfortable, because I know that hyperreal is going to
> >the trouble of sending me these messages, and consuming network bandwidth
> >to do it that could have been better used for something else.
> 
> This may have been true 5 or 6 years ago, but it is far from true
> nowadays.
> 
> This "conserve bandwidth" thing was only meaningful back when modems
> were 2400 baud and hard drives had 20MB.

Really? What makes you think that? Do you know the state of the current
Internet? The fact that the big players are scrambling to get OC-3's up
and running, as the DS-3's that much of the Internet is running on simply
cannot handle the load? Load is in fact increasing exponentially, as
people are starting to use telephony and video apps across the wires. 

> Nowadays, the network bandwidth that e-mail mailing lists use, is a
> small percent of what is used for all the other more important uses
> that dominate the Internet:

*SNIP* 

You are making assumptions. While as a general statement what you say is
true as it applies to the Internet at large, it does not follow that this
also applies to the bandwidth that hyperreal.com uses. In order to make
that determination it would require you know how much of the bandwidth
that hyperreal.com uses to distribute the various mailing lists it handles
vs. the rest of the traffic(web, ftp, etc.) 

                                             Black Adder

Hello,

On Sat, 28 Sep 1996 19:13:47 -0700 (PDT), blkadder@value.net wrote:

>On Sat, 28 Sep 1996, Ken Stuart wrote:
>
>> On Fri, 27 Sep 1996 16:19:11 -0700, ozymandias G desiderata
>> <ogd@organic.com> wrote:
>> 
>> >Yes, I have an email filtering system (mailagent, for those of you who
>> >are curious -- it's a huge perl / C hybrid, but it does lots of stuff in
>> >a reasonably intuitive and extraordinarily powerful way), and I'm
>> >automatically chopping huge swathes through my incoming sfraves mail. But
>> >that makes me uncomfortable, because I know that hyperreal is going to
>> >the trouble of sending me these messages, and consuming network bandwidth
>> >to do it that could have been better used for something else.
>> 
>> This may have been true 5 or 6 years ago, but it is far from true
>> nowadays.
>> 
>> This "conserve bandwidth" thing was only meaningful back when modems
>> were 2400 baud and hard drives had 20MB.

> [SNIP]

>> Nowadays, the network bandwidth that e-mail mailing lists use, is a
>> small percent of what is used for all the other more important uses
>> that dominate the Internet:
>
>*SNIP* 
>
>You are making assumptions. While as a general statement what you say is
>true as it applies to the Internet at large, it does not follow that this
>also applies to the bandwidth that hyperreal.com uses. In order to make
>that determination it would require you know how much of the bandwidth
>that hyperreal.com uses to distribute the various mailing lists it handles
>vs. the rest of the traffic(web, ftp, etc.) 

But the original message said:

"because I know that hyperreal is going to the trouble of sending me
these messages, and consuming network bandwidth to do it that could
have been better used for something else."

Maybe he meant "server bandwidth" but he said "network bandwidth".

IF the server used by hyperreal is in danger of being overloaded, the
sfraves list owner should post a message in sfraves saying so, and
then I'm sure, like the community we are, we would adjust our posting
habits accordingly.

However that has not happened yet.   And, unlike any other resource
such as water or energy, bandwidth can't be "saved" and used another
day.   So, it is either available or it isn't.  ( Which, for example,
is why my ISP charges nothing for usage between 1 am and 5 am, because
they have loads of extra bandwidth at that time of day that is just
wasted. )

To summarize my original point, e-mail takes up much less bandwidth
than any of the real-time Internet uses.   I download the whole day's
worth of sfraves in a few minutes, if that.   Probably a small group
of fantatical Internet real-time game players use more Internet
bandwidth than all of sfraves combined.


Cheers,

Ken                         <*>
kstuart@mail.telis.org

> > >to do it that could have been better used for something else.

> > 
> > This "conserve bandwidth" thing was only meaningful back when modems
> > were 2400 baud and hard drives had 20MB.
> 
> Really? What makes you think that? Do you know the state of the current
> Internet? The fact that the big players are scrambling to get OC-3's up
> and running, as the DS-3's that much of the Internet is running on simply
> cannot handle the load? Load is in fact increasing exponentially, as
> people are starting to use telephony and video apps across the wires.

not increasing exponentially at hyperreal's host site, organic online,
which was ogd's original point.

> 
> You are making assumptions. While as a general statement what you say is
> true as it applies to the Internet at large, it does not follow that this
> also applies to the bandwidth that hyperreal.com uses. In order to make
> that determination it would require you know how much of the bandwidth
> that hyperreal.com uses to distribute the various mailing lists it handles
> vs. the rest of the traffic(web, ftp, etc.) 
> 
again, speaking from real knowledge on the subject, as ogd was, a huge
percentage of the bandwidth used by hyperreal goes to mailing lists.

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sat Sep 28 20:35:11 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id UAA08974; Sat, 28 Sep 1996 20:35:11 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from localhost by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with SMTP id UAA08964; Sat, 28 Sep 1996 20:35:08 -0700 (PDT)
Date: Sat, 28 Sep 1996 20:35:07 -0700 (PDT)
From: Brian Behlendorf <brian@hyperreal.com>
To: Knucklehead <knucklehead@club.net>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: READ ME
In-Reply-To: <v02130500ae719204e906@[205.231.222.75]>
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.95.960928200946.6331C-100000@taz.hyperreal.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

On Fri, 27 Sep 1996, Knucklehead wrote:
> If you don't want to read something just delete the damn thing. I sometime
> don't even read half of the mail on here because the subject just doesn't
> move me. Why can't you do the same.

I used to tow this line, but there are limits to the amout of
interest-filtering that one human can do.  The basic problem I have the
idea of "you can look at the subject line, and delete the message if you
don't like it".  Very rarely does the subject line actually relate or
accurately capture what's in the message, *especially* as the topic goes
on for a number of posts or days.  Worst of all, it encourages an attitude
of "oh, I've already been through all that, I can't waste my time
repeating myself".  If you're wondering why some of us who have been
around for a long time don't post very much, that's probably a good place
to start looking - that kind of attitude means that those who have already
talked through a subject (such as, "is the E in SF cut with heroin?") will
ignore new posts on that topic, even if those new posters have something
interesting to say.  And that's unfortunate, because it essentially
*forces* a turnover on the list; people last 6 months, maybe a year, see
all the different common subjects, and then don't post anymore because
they feel it's all been said already and they're too busy deleting the
posts they think talk about stuff they've already been through to actually
have the energy to contribute to anything.

I think the fact that you, Tim, don't read 1/2 the mail on this list, the
fact that I don't read the list except once every couple of weeks and even
then only cursorily, the fact that many people out there take a very
blase' attitude towards the signal/noise ration, is a *problem*.  I'm not
harshing on you or anyone in particular, because this is a group behavoir
issue.  Like I said, I used to say exactly the same thing, "you can just
delete it", but after experiencing first-hand the act of deleting 975
messages out of the 1000 in the queue, I suddenly realize how unfortunate
this situation is.

I have always wanted SFRaves to be a chatty place; I think the list would
get *extremely* boring if it were just party reviews and music
discussions.  This topic is about a very diverse culture, one which its
participants take to heart very deeply, so I absolutely appreciate the
desire to talk about one's personal life.   

So, what's the answer?  There's no magic bullet here, folks.  It's your
list, ultimately.  There's not a big topic I felt shouldn't have been
discussed, or any group of individuals I feel is abusing this
intentionally or grossly.  Maybe there are some things that can help - an
well-maintained SFRaves FAQ so at least people can be "caught up" on
certain issues like, is E cut with heroin or not.  And maybe this "moving
on" phenomenon is just a necessary outcome of the way mailing lists and
internet discussion groups work.  I don't know.  I just hope people think
about this issue, particularly the "you can just delete it" phenomenon,
and maybe make a change.  *shrug*.  

	Brian

for $15, but people from this list get it for $10. Email

On Sun, 29 Sep 1996, Ken Stuart wrote:

> >> This "conserve bandwidth" thing was only meaningful back when modems
> >> were 2400 baud and hard drives had 20MB.
> 
> > [SNIP]
> 
> >> Nowadays, the network bandwidth that e-mail mailing lists use, is a
> >> small percent of what is used for all the other more important uses
> >> that dominate the Internet:
> >
> >*SNIP* 
> >
> >You are making assumptions. While as a general statement what you say is
> >true as it applies to the Internet at large, it does not follow that this
> >also applies to the bandwidth that hyperreal.com uses. In order to make
> >that determination it would require you know how much of the bandwidth
> >that hyperreal.com uses to distribute the various mailing lists it handles
> >vs. the rest of the traffic(web, ftp, etc.) 
> 
> But the original message said:
> 
> "because I know that hyperreal is going to the trouble of sending me
> these messages, and consuming network bandwidth to do it that could
> have been better used for something else."
> 
> Maybe he meant "server bandwidth" but he said "network bandwidth".
> 
> IF the server used by hyperreal is in danger of being overloaded, the
> sfraves list owner should post a message in sfraves saying so, and
> then I'm sure, like the community we are, we would adjust our posting
> habits accordingly.
> 
> However that has not happened yet.   And, unlike any other resource
> such as water or energy, bandwidth can't be "saved" and used another
> day.   So, it is either available or it isn't.  ( Which, for example,
> is why my ISP charges nothing for usage between 1 am and 5 am, because
> they have loads of extra bandwidth at that time of day that is just
> wasted. )

Like telephone companies, people using or providing bandwidth have to 
plan for peak loads. Bandwidth cannot simply be available or not be
available. Bandwidth *must* at all times be available if you are
attempting to maintain a network that can send and receive data 24 hours a
day, 7 days a week.  Network managers/engineers must plan for these peak
loads, rather than simply saying "Oh well, guess we're out of bandwidth,
too bad."

> To summarize my original point, e-mail takes up much less bandwidth
> than any of the real-time Internet uses.   I download the whole day's
> worth of sfraves in a few minutes, if that.   Probably a small group
> of fantatical Internet real-time game players use more Internet
> bandwidth than all of sfraves combined.

Your statement is not applicable to a mailing list. It takes *you* a few
minutes to download all the mail for sfraves for a day. Now, multiply that
by what, 439(I believe this was given as the number of subscribers.) This
is what hyperreal is pushing out.  

                                       Black Adder

>Like telephone companies, people using or providing bandwidth have to

Yes, but what I was saying is that we have received no evidence that
the bandwidth used by Hyperreal is anywhere near the peak capacity.

If it is, then there undoubtedly would have been an official
announcement.

If it is not, then we gain nothing by using less bandwidth, because as
I said before, bandwidth cannot be saved for another day.

>

>> than any of the real-time Internet uses.   I download the whole day's

>> of fantatical Internet real-time game players use more Internet

sfraves e-mail at 28.8kb --- but Hyperreal is pushing out the e-mail
to 439 people over a T1.....  it's still not much bandwidth compared
to a dozen game players who are on the Internet for the whole
afternoon.

You know I just could'nt resist putting in my 02c worth.......... 
 
who cares !!!! it's menial bullshit....... yak yak yak, with nothing to
say....... It makes me wonder what the average age of the SFRaver
is.......... sadly, I'd say about 16 1/2 years old. Usually, I ignore all
the bantering back & forth, but sometimes (like now) I just explode with
disgust........at the pissy & useless subjects that I see people posture
over. 
 
I find SFR a great place to find info on parties, to contact friends, and
to give info out about selling my rave related items (records, tapes,
equipment etc...). as well as a place to air my views. (rave related of
course) 
 
I find asking for hugs over a broken relationship, is completely too
personal a subject to share with 450 people......... kind of selfish and
self serving if you ask me (not that anybody did).  
 
I feel that NRR items have their place, if it's intelligent conversation,
not just opinions that blast other peoples opinions for the sake of being
heard. 
 
Even as I write this e-mail, I wonder if I am not myself a hypocrit, being
that this post relates to other peoples posts, and it's an opinion
etc.........I suppose I should begin with myself........... point well
taken. 
 
As I will be gone in another 4-5 weeks, you will have one less opinion to
put up with, So I'm not even sure why I bother to publicly denounce all the
nit picky stuff, I guess I would just like to see the SFRaves used in a
much more positive way.......sorry    moonpup 
 

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Sep 29 12:16:45 1996

Received: from mh1.well.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with ESMTP id MAA01418; Sun, 29 Sep 1996 12:16:41 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from [199.106.63.240] (mac950.zone.org [199.106.63.240]) by mh1.well.com (8.7.6/8.7.5) with SMTP id MAA28665; Sun, 29 Sep 1996 12:16:37 -0700 (PDT)
Message-Id: <199609291916.MAA28665@mh1.well.com>
X-Sender: crunch@mail.well.com
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Sun, 29 Sep 1996 12:26:42 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: crunch@well.com (John Draper)
Subject: Where the Wild things are!  - A review
Cc: sd-raves@party.net, socal-raves@UCSD.EDU
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

A review of "Where the wild things are!"
An Inland Empire rave experience.

I learned just in time that the ODP was busted,  and moved.   Wasn't really
sure I
wanted to make the trek to San Bernardino for "Where the Wild things are"
until a
few people from the Loft wanted a ride and was willing to pitch in for gas.

Using the trusted MapBlaster,   I gathered the approach vectors to the location
according to the info line and soon headed out...

After about 1 1/2 hours of driving,  we finally arrive.  Lots and lots of
cars,
indicated this one was going to be BIG.    I was right.   We arrive at the
venue,  a
large Mexican restaurant,  pay our admittance and was greeted by a nice
security
person saying "Enjoy yourself" and waved us though.   We arrive in this
spacious
outdoor patio with lots and lots of people hanging out,  and I walked by
the main
dance area,  and immediately knew that this one was going to be very good.

On the way in,  I was greeted by a stranger who said "You're an interesting
dude!  I
can tell"  We exchanged greetings,  and Almost immediately I was recognized
by a
few people from San Francisco who were very surprised to see me this far from
the Bay Area.    I told him I had moved a month ago,   and almost
immediately,  was
approached my a host of SoCal ravers and I instantly know the PLUR factor was
going to very high for his party.

It didn't take me long to start groovin to the music,  and in just a few
minutes was
totally in trance state,   helped along by my 5 days of intensive Tao Yoga.

I had thought about dropping,  but totally spaced it out,   I was just lost
in the
energy and totally tracing out with no electrical stimulants this time.  I
didn't
have to....   the 5 days of Tao has had the effect of about 6 months worth
of high
dosages if every imaginable drug,   but without having to ingest anything.

I don't know how long I was out there dancing,  I was so engrossed in the
music,
sometimes being taken out of my trance by a tap pn my shoulder from someone
wanting to say hi,  hug me,  or whatever.    Complete strangers came up to
me and
said "I like your energy... what's your name?"...  I was overwhelmed by the
amazingly high PLUR factor that was of the likes of Friends and Family in SF.

I estimated that over 80 people would say 'There's Jerry Garcia!"
referring to my
big bushy beard.   It was rather comical,  but everyone had big smiles and
happy
vibes all around.

The music was amazing,  not that trancy,  not that hard,  just about right.
Some
tracks were a little low in energy,   but then again,  some were unusually
high.  The
music,  although not a consistent Thump Thump,  was extremely varied,  and
the Dj
Switchovers were a real giveaway....   Sometimes the the turn tables would just
power down,  to be replaced with new songs,  totally different.   There was
also
narration or MC'ing to some extent over some of the tracks,  I thought were
somewhat amusing,  but kind of fresh and new.

By this time,  people were tuning into my energy,  dancing around me,  each
person
trying to grab my attention on the dance floor.    I remember one dude with
a hand
puppet waving it's arms in front of me,  as I waved around and danced in synch
with him.    Many girls came up to me,  wanting to know who I was,  some
asking of
I was the Cap'n.

I don't know when I managed to find my way to the chill area,   but somehow
found
$5 for a killer massage,  as there were 2 tables set up out in the patio,
giving
massages.   I was finished just in time for the hard trance to come on,  so
with
renewed energy and all my blockages removed,  I made beeline to the dance
area to
get down to the business of groovin again.

The main dance area was really spacious,  despite the fact it was a Mexican
restaurant,   and the green lasers were really good eye candy.   Speaking
of Eye
candy,  one dude was wearing this amazing pyramid had that had an amazing
rainbow iridescent reflections from the strobes and lasers.    The strobes
were a
bit too much and disorienting at times,  evident when I was often
unintentionally
bumping into other dancers.   But I was focused on that dudes amazing hat,
totally
tracing out on some amazing eye candy...

All too soon,  the music stopped,  rather abruptly,  and I snapped out of
my trancy
state just in time to have my eyes assaulted by the bright lights.   Don't know
when that was,  but it was just about sunrise.   Then rather rudely,  the
security
said "everyone out!,  come on,  lets keep moving out the door"    I
eventually hooked
up with Mike and the other person and we left.   At the exit,  I was
helping Mike
hand out flyers to his upcoming party...   We eventually went to our cars
and headed
south to San Diego.

Crunchman

unnnnnhhhh

i've been up 32 hours......................................................

I'm sure glad!!!!    +)



 The BDay party was da phattest dope around! Gateway has just been getting 
better and better and the Dance Floor was _incredible_. Visually sublime 
and breathtaking, with high powered articulate audio reinforcemant. I was 
in awe.


 I was pleased with the ambient room, although I wish I had about another 5 
hours and more food this time around. It seemed folks really enjoyed the 
idea of interactive kiosiks that controlled audio and lighting in the 
room. I definately intend to persue these areas of exploration in the 
ambience.

 I did take home some items left behind; a packpack and a set of keys. A 
good description will allow you to claim them. Please email me privately 
and I'll respond promptly.


 I really need to say that what I accomplished in this ambient room (and 
H3 for that matter), could not have been done without the love and 
community that many give freely to our scene, that allows folks to create 
our own little special space. Thank you and may the blessings of the 
Sacred Trinity enrichen all your lives.


Ran @ Dionysus Dreams

On Sat, 28 Sep 1996, PETER FOGEL wrote:

> Does one consider themselves to be a raver because they go to a rave?
> like to dance?
> post on sfraves?
> Wear "rave clothes"?
> Does raving need to have some spiritual significance?
> 
> Whether you do or don't consider yourself a "raver", 
> what does raving mean to you?
> 

Where do I go to learn....

...to set my prejudices aside?
...to be tolerant of others?
...to experience diversity?
...to participate in self expression?
...to give of myself?
...to understand what it means to be human?
...how to relate to others?
...to explore my deepest feelings?
...to feel the sheer joy of movement? 
...to have fun decorating myself?
...that I can trust myself?
...to see people for what they are: people?
...how music flows through my body?
...the sincerity of a hug?
...that someone can express love without asking for anything in return?
...to express my creativity?

I go to a "rave."

And that's just a "few" reasons!!!

That's what raving means to me.

-KaySEE

I'm 25, and like sfraves to find other musicians to talk about gear and
making house music and stuff. I've posted a message here and there about
certain types of gear for the sake of information and possibly finding
other people out there that I have never met who have the same interests.
I have gotten messages from a person or 2 that talking about gear is "not
rave related" -- Funny, I thought creating the music was the very essence
of a rave.
Sometimes I wonder if this mailing list is strictly for 16 1/2 year olds
who like blow-pops and like to sneak out of their house to drop E just for
the sake of  the fact that they are getting away with it.  I could and very
well be completely wrong, but, I have to agree with moonpup- and it's the
impression I get many times.  Yes, i may be being a hypocrit too, as I am
bitching and moaning right now, and I have posted more than my share of
stupid messages, but I had to get in my $.02 in too. And when I was 16 1/2
years old, I snuck out many times. Maybe more than I should have. E wasn't
popular at the time though, I just drank. :) - anyway, I'm willing to get
more serious about my posts.
I don't think that any kind of threshold can be set as to what is "rave
related" and what isn't - but common sense can tell you what to post - I
don't think that rave related topics are limited to the dancefloor or the
turntables or the music or anything else, house music has expanded my mind
into realms so vast that anything can be tied to it.
But I do have to say, I know there are a lot of people who are on this list
who subscribe just to listen and not to speak - and I wish they would
speak. Many musicians, DJ's, promoters, business owners, I think it would
be very valuable to everyone on this list.
        So, If anyone wants to flame me, please feel free. I'm willing to
take it.


Courtney Nielsen

Electronic Artists Collective
408 275 9972
cnielsen@earthlink.net

Greetings and PLUR from San Jose

Every harmony party that I got to keeps getting better. I keep reaching a 
new level of happiness and community each time. 
Great music... especially whoever played the sunrise set. that Dj was the 
captain of my ship, if you know what I mean.
Great ambient room set up. hats off to Dionysius Dreams. Especially the 
Harmony tree  with the furry neon leaves. 
Beautiful People.... truly. 
It seems like all the people that I saw at Beautiful People, met at 
Harmony ... I finally got to hang out and talk and interact with. 
Hugs and love to everybody who was at the party. These are all the names 
I remember.....
David, Wes, MAtt(Tie), Rob, Greg, Brendan, Eric Peterson, Jule, Julian ( 
who was slated to fly back to England today.) Ashley, Alison, Rick, Adam, 
Jayne (Ben's neighbor) and of course Libby. That's about all the names I 
could conjure up from my scrambled memory. The faces are all familiar but 
it's the names.... 
Hope to see all of you at Charity next week. 

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Sun Sep 29 20:01:22 1996

From: simitzis@netcom.com (Steve Simitzis)
Message-Id: <199609300301.UAA11763@netcom17.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Stinky's BDay parteee
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

Good morning everyone! (okay, it's 7:30pm, but it somehow feels like morning)

Despite terrible back problems, lack of sleep (I think I was in that
studio for over 24 hours straight), and forgetting to pack food, I
managed to survive and have a great time. Surprisingly, I spent very
little time dancing (very unlike me).

Randy, thanks for putting together the best ambient room yet! Those
crazy swirly lights lurking behind the sheet on the ceiling did wacky
things to me. The whole room was simply beautiful, and it was sooo
much fun to jam out with you and the rest of the toyz. And thanks
everyone for helping me break in my new JX-8P!!! It's now filled with
good vibes and ready to crank out some killer tunes.

I spent so much time in the chill room that I missed most of the main
dance music. Minor, as usual, spun a killer set! That guy has the
grooooviest record collection, in addition to being a cool guy. Missed
most of everyone's sets, unfortunately, boo hiss :)

The last half hour or so of the night, however, totally kicked my ass!
The music was so fast, hard, and fucking phat that I had no control of
body (and proceded to dance my ass off, of course). And hey, David!
Thanks for being up there with me in the end! It's so cool to know
that someone else can still be out of control at 6:30 in the morning
:) My plan was to dance until I had to pealed off of the dance floor,
but the music stopped before I could reach my goal of self-destruction.

Despite my intense back pain, no back-rubs were made available to me
[*sniffle* *sniffle*, no it's okay... really... ;)] But after cleaning up
and taking a brief nap, my back mysteriously healed to the point where
I could walk without looking goofy! So maybe dancing around like a
maniac has some sort of healing properties that I'm not aware of...
Use only as directed.

Anyway, a big thanks and big-ass phat hug to everyone who came,
everyone I met, everyone who I met but forgot their names...again, and
all of the wonderful people that I always look forward to seeing at
every Harmony party :)

What a crazy weekend. I'm almost looking forward to the serenity of my
little office and the Evil Sparc 20.

Don't forget about the pre-Mad dinner tommorrow. Tommorrow will be
special treat for Indian lovers (yummy yummy). More info is coming :)

Steve

Subject: rave-related posting?
Author:  PETER FOGEL <peterbf@pacbell.net> at ccsmtp
Date:    9/28/96 12:36 PM


With the recent discussions of what should be posted, what is rave-related, 
and what is not,
it makes me wonder how many people on this list percieve raving.
Does one consider themselves to be a raver because they go to a rave? 
like to dance?
post on sfraves?
Wear "rave clothes"?
Does raving need to have some spiritual significance?
     
Whether you do or don't consider yourself a "raver", 
what does raving mean to you?
     
I know this may be very difficult to put into words, 
but I still would appreciate any effort to do so. 
After all isn't that some of what this list is for?
     
     
:)
peter

From sfraves-owner@hyperreal.com  Mon Sep 30 09:05:29 1996
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) id JAA26822; Mon, 30 Sep 1996 09:05:29 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from gcwf.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.7.5/V2.0) with SMTP id JAA26804; Mon, 30 Sep 1996 09:05:24 -0700 (PDT)
Received: from SOCAL-Message_Server by gcwf.com
	with Novell_GroupWise; Mon, 30 Sep 1996 09:06:29 -0700
Message-Id: <s24f8d95.085@gcwf.com>
X-Mailer: Novell GroupWise 4.1
Date: Mon, 30 Sep 1996 09:06:06 -0700
From: Ariel Stallings <ASTALLINGS@gcwf.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject:  GREG'S BIRTHDAY PARTY
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I wish it had been >MY< Birthday party because it really WENT OFF! 
What an abolutely WONDERFUL space to be in!  It seemed to give what I
love to do so much more respect...dancing in a space >>designed<< for
dancing!  With that wonderful hardwood floor, full mirrors, bathrooms
that were actually sanitary and pleasent, a payphone upstairs, couches,
and it was all so CLEAN!  None of those morning-after black boogers that
one usually ends up with after partying in some dirty warehouse. 
(ahem, I KNOW you all know what I'm talking about.)  I feel kind of spoiled
now...don't ravers deserve better spaces ALL the time?  (then again, as
one of the above said ravers, could I afford to pay higher ticket prices to
have those better spaces?  Probably not...)

The space was great (although I think I'm going to bring my own fan next
time) but the people were even better!  I got the joy of meeting the
Birthday Boy himself and ran into so many of my favorite people from
Harmony...some I knew, some I know now!  And the music?  Lordy! 
Although I am a not-so closeted funky breaks fan, I was really enjoying
the music!  Cloud spun an especially great set...was it him who played
that song from the Trainspotting soundtrack?  Whoever it was made
extra points in my book...

The chill room was wonderful...when I managed to stop dancing I would
go join my friends on some big round pink flat thing in the back of the
room, which was nice.  Music? Good!  Visuals!  mm, tasty!  Gropage
Factor?  Very high.  I'm all for a little E-tardation at times, but there were
some folks GOIN' OFF!  (or was that GETTIN' off?)  Ah well!  Too much
love never hurt anyone (although those friction burns...TEE HEE!  JUST
KIDDING!)

Um, anyway.  In sum, yet another amazing harmony experience.  And
afterwards?  The most wonderful chill-out session with a dozen or so of
my friends in the jacuzzi in Hayward.  AHHHHHHhhhhhhh!

Still a'glowin!
Ariel

fun, joyous, intense, hot, full of love, and an experience that was
worth ten times the amount of work we put into it :)  It was also a
learning experience for me in the planning and pre-preparation aspects,
which will help me to be of more value as a crew member in the future
:)  My precious Valerie was there, but didn't make an appearance.  I
think she soaked up enough of that unbelievable vibe to help me deliver
an outstanding performance next time :D
I thoroughly enjoyed meeting new friends, seeing newer and older
friends, giving and receiving love, and especially hearing some sweet
Led Zeppelin vocals mixed with beats (Baby, I'm gonna Leave You - who
was the dj, anyone?)!  Ethan's set was one of the highlights of my
experience (you DID spin, didn't ya?  ;)).
Love to all, and hope to see ya out there again soon.
THANKS!!!
Eric

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Mon, 30 Sep 1996 11:10:08 -0500
From: David Garrard <david@sloangroup.com>
To: nyc-raves@hyperreal.com, ne-raves@world.std.com
Subject: (nyc) Has the scene come to this?????

Sorry for the long post, but I feel very strongly that this needs to be
said.  This past Friday, I decided to check out Unity at Vinyl here in NYC.
The place was crowded and poorly ventilated.  So after a bit of dancing
(which by the way most people were NOT doing), I decided that I needed air
and the chance to cool off.  I got some water and headed over to the side
exit to chill when a security neanderthal decided that people shouldn't be
hanging out in that area.  I stood up, but decided to hang around.  Then, a
group of security guards pulled this kid out of the room that was across
from the steps.  The kid was completely wasted.  He couldn't stand up and
he apparently didn't know where he was.  Security felt that the best way to
deal with this situation was to toss the kid out the door and on the
sidewalk.  They were about to toss him out the door when they decided to
prop him up on the wall beside the doors.  At this time, the girl that he
was with wandered out of that same room, fucked out of her mind.  She
didn't know where she was or even who she was.  She teetered over to the
top of the steps and sat down, staring aimlessly.  Then, the same security
guard that hearded people away from that area walked up the steps to the
girl, straddled her, began fondling her body and kissing her, totally
taking advantage of the situation.  She was so fucked up that she didn't
even know what was going on.  I couldn't believe what I was witnessing.
Here is one of the people that supposedly is supposed hired to "protect" us
is abusing his authority.  WHAT A FUCKING PIG!!!  I was so disgusted by
this that I gathered my friends and left, and I will NEVER set foot in that
place again as long as it remains open (I don't care if God himself is
spinning).

I've been going to so called "raves" for the past eight years and I've seen
a lot of fucked up shit, but this was the absolute worst site I've ever
witnessed.  It seems to me that over the past year, the focus at a party
has shifted from dancing and socalizing to "let's see how fucked up we can
get".  YO, PEOPLE!  WAKE THE FUCK UP!!!!!  Don't EVER let yourself get so
far gone that you have to put your trust (unwillingly) in a total
stranger!!  In case you haven't noticed, the world in which we live isn't
all that safe.  And, if you choose to indulge and let yourself go over the
edge, then that's poor judgement on your part.  Know your limits and for
god's sake, get the scene back on track.  I'm tired of having to wade past
the cracked out little kiddies dribbling on their Tommy Hilfiger trainers
to get to the dance floor.  That's not amusing to me, and neither is rape.

Date: Mon, 30 Sep 96 03:16:42 pst
From: "Andy Wyszkowski" <awyszkow@smtplink.acer.com>
Message-Id: <9608308441.AA844104410@smtplink.acer.com>

Subject: The Other Side of Miracles... Harvest Moon
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

     Argh!
     
     I decided I would keep my self to one rave a weekend for a while...
     
     So I tell my drummer and beloved friend that I will finally take him 
     to a rave.  He flakes, and leaves me with this other guy I used to 
     work with (who is a self centered jerk) with me.  I figure I have to 
     mellow him out > READ COMATOSE (this alone probably required clear 
     cutting of half of Humboldt county's finest).  After adequate sedative 
     therapy (you all really would have liked him) we go to Harvest Moon.  
     After following the directions, I freaked... this is where EVERY 
     mountian bike ticket I've ever recieved was... and nobody as there at 
     1:00am (hello!).  I found the parking lot right away, but knew that 
     couldn't be it (no cars you see).  So we drove around the Marin 
     headlands for a while, even going so far as to wander into the 
     military base.
     
     The military base was uneventful, thankfully (nightmares of latex 
     gloves and bizarre searches and questioning).  The area was beautiful, 
     and I would like to thank those that tried to throw this party for 
     trying, and not to freak and use Acme or the Jerrold deli for their 
     next attempt.  I was awestruck by the beauty of the area at night, and 
     I'd love to just rave/dance/freak there someday.  High risk raves... 
     those are the ones that go *legendary*.
     
     IT WOULD HAVE BEEN SOOOOOOOO!!!!!
     
     Viva beautiful outdoor parties... I'm hearing about another Moontribe 
     party down south coming up... anybody want to commute?
     
     Love,
     AndyW
     
     P.S.       And after a while, I started second guessing everything, 
     and the quote "It's a REAL underground" or something like from the 
     voice mail that kept ringing in my head as I passed the 'authorized 
     vehicles only' sign.
     
     Final Note:        After meeting some people at the bottom of the 
     hill, it turned out some high ranking officer of the Coast Guard was 
     getting married that very night, and security had been ramped up for 
     the event (it was at that illuminated pier on the water just east of 
     that big rusty colored thingy).  Maybe that didn't help.  Bummer...

> Subject: (nyc) Has the scene come to this?????
> 
> from the steps.  The kid was completely wasted.  He couldn't stand up and
> he apparently didn't know where he was.  Security felt that the best way to
> deal with this situation was to toss the kid out the door and on the
> sidewalk.  They were about to toss him out the door when they decided to
> prop him up on the wall beside the doors.  At this time, the girl that he
> was with wandered out of that same room, fucked out of her mind.  She
> didn't know where she was or even who she was.  She teetered over to the
> top of the steps and sat down, staring aimlessly.  Then, the same security
> guard that hearded people away from that area walked up the steps to the
> girl, straddled her, began fondling her body and kissing her, totally
> taking advantage of the situation.  She was so fucked up that she didn't
> even know what was going on.  I couldn't believe what I was witnessing.
> Here is one of the people that supposedly is supposed hired to "protect" us
> is abusing his authority.  WHAT A FUCKING PIG!!!  I was so disgusted by
> this that I gathered my friends and left, and I will NEVER set foot in that
> place again as long as it remains open (I don't care if God himself is
> spinning).


Do you know why the guy who wrote this didn't do anything?  Instead of
leaving, it might have been better to get the guard OFF of the girl.  This
is typical of what happens in rape cases.  Women being raped are told to
yell "Fire" instead of rape because people won't help them if they think
they are being raped.  I'm not passing judgment here, I don't know the
particulars, but maybe gathering his friends and helping the girl would
have been more productive than leaving.  Not that the author is
saying this, but frequently women get "blamed" for being raped because
they were too fucked up to know any better.  I fully support being
responsible for your own actions, and I would never allow myself to get so
incoherent that I didn't know what was going on, but even so no one
deserves to be raped if they make mistakes.
I do hope that something was done about the man raping this woman.  He is
the one that holds the responsibility here because he was the one who was
in control at the moment things happened.  

I really don't want this to turn into some big flame-war.  I am concerned
that this happened, and want to know if you know any more of the details.
Obviously, the author is rightfully concerned, and I thank you for
bringing this to our attention.  No one deserves to have this happen to
them.  Unfortunately, there are many people who think that this is okay
behavior. 

Thanks, 
KaySEE

> 
> I've been going to so called "raves" for the past eight years and I've seen
> a lot of fucked up shit, but this was the absolute worst site I've ever
> witnessed.  It seems to me that over the past year, the focus at a party
> has shifted from dancing and socalizing to "let's see how fucked up we can
> get".  YO, PEOPLE!  WAKE THE FUCK UP!!!!!  Don't EVER let yourself get so
> far gone that you have to put your trust (unwillingly) in a total
> stranger!!  In case you haven't noticed, the world in which we live isn't
> all that safe.  And, if you choose to indulge and let yourself go over the
> edge, then that's poor judgement on your part.  Know your limits and for
> god's sake, get the scene back on track.  I'm tired of having to wade past
> the cracked out little kiddies dribbling on their Tommy Hilfiger trainers
> to get to the dance floor.  That's not amusing to me, and neither is rape.
>

Well I hate to say it but....

Apparently some channels showed the Leeza show this morning (9-10am on 
the Santa Cruz/Monterey station). My wife (a non-raver) saw it and
it sounds like the fears of many were justified (sorry to say this
Leslie!). Yes, Leslie came over very well but it sounded like they
didn't give her much time to speak, and instead focussed on the
teenage runaways and the drug-dealer in the audience, and made
raves sound like total drug-fests. Apparently there were a bunch
of "ravers" in the audience - spiked-hair, leather-clad transvestite-
types - I mean, hardly representative! Anyone sitting on the fence about
raves would have been given completely the wrong impression about
raves - at least the kind WE know and love! From the sound of it
(I haven't seen the show myself - this is from my wife's description)
any parent watching the show would feel VERY worried about their
kids wanting to go to a rave and would probably forbid it or at
least discourage it. 

I've only ever known the SF rave scene, so maybe it's totally different
in other places (sounds like it is in nyc!). It sounds to me like we
have something very special here and we have to work to protect it
and keep it the positive scene that it is. We should remember that
in our hearts and treasure it for the beauty that it is. *We* know
how incredible this thing is - maybe that's going to have to be enough.

- martin

Thanks everyone who helped put this together. It's amazing what to see 
the work that goes into these parties- large or small! It's even more 
amazing what it takes out of the people after it's all over. Hi-fives 
all around to the walking dead were scraping up gum and stuff after the 
music stopped. 

Thanks to all the happy faces, the crazy fools that were dancing at 6:30 
in the morning, the DJ's, the folks who own the space (which is really 
nice!), Ran & Steve for the ambiance, Greg for having a birthday and 
Ethan for not killing me when I nudged the decks (boo alex!).

-peace-
alex

Enough Already!!!!  Jesus H Fucking Christ!  Who gives a flying rats ass 
whats Rave and whats Not Rave.  Does it Really Matter??  We're all 
friends here right?  Right???  I'd be pretty damn bored with my friends 
if all we talked about was Raves and $2 Water Bottles and E and Music and 
Dancing.  It makes for some pretty boring conversation if talked about 
24/7.

Lighten up.  A *communitee* is built on *communication*.  If you dont 
like what you're reading, use the delete key.  Everyone seems to have the 
BSP and NRR headers down.  Look for those, if you dont want to read it, 
delete it.  its easy.

I've said it before, and I'll say it again, I LOVE SFR just like it is.  
Makes my days at work a little more intertaining.   And Hey, Just think, 
you might actually learn something from some of those NRR posts.

plur

  A friend once said to me (back in the early 70s), "We've danced to the
Dead in Golden Gate Park, and we've seen God in a flower. NOW what do we
do?"
  Even now: the DJ stops and packs up the turntables, and we return to
"the common light of day." The only answer I've found so far to this
radical rupture in our lives is this Zen koan:

 CHOPPING WOOD BEFORE ENLIGHTENMENT.... CHOPPING WOOD AFTER ENLIGHTENMENT

Hi folks-

 I was able to see the first half hour of the Leeza show, and to sum it up is 
easy.  They (producers, writers, etc, etc) probably had a preconcieved idea of 
what they wanted to show.  Leslie represented herself well, but from what I saw 
the show wasn't giving her any opportunity to explain her viewpoint.
 Watching the show in the workout room with my fellow employees taught me 
several things:  1) I work with people who are very influenced by TV, 2) these 
people think all raves are like what was described on the show, and 3) my 
collegues couldn't believe that someone like myself was involved with raves.  
Anyway, I felt that I needed to vent my two cents to others who can understand.

-Thanks, Todd

Hi people-

 Trying to find this record may be difficult.  It was originally put out on 
Cheeky records last year about this time.  Trying to find a copy state-side may 
be difficult, but here are some recommendations to places that might be able to 
help you.

Resonance Records-www.netcreatioins.com/resonance/
Secret Tunes Club-193.123.77.10:80/NWAIAG/stc/
Tag Records-www.tagrecords.co.uk/


 Resonance is located in Florida, and they are good about getting imports.  STC 
and Tag are both located in the UK, and they have a better selection of top 
choons from Europe if that's what you're looking for.  If I can be of any more 
help, let me know.

-Todd

Date: Mon, 30 Sep 96 14:03:07 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I'm taping and watching....

(1) Drugs, drugs, drugs, drugs, drugs, and how raves help introduce
    innocent little 13 year olds to drugs. Shots of audience members "eyes
    rolling" when people say "it's not about the drugs, it's about music."

(2) It's "cult like". Secretive locations keeps parents from finding out
    what their kids are doing. Most of the rhetoric aimed at "what your
    teenager is doing behind your back"...

(3) Leslie Ayres came off very well, however, she is the only one that
    really cast any positive light on this at all -- by being one of the few
    people that spent any time defusing the drug/cult/danger-to-youth message
    of this show. Kudos to Leslie for not landing on the cutting-room
    floor. They didn't give her much time on the air, but she did get
    in some good counter-punches, e.g. 13-16 year olds don't have any
    business doing drugs, and that parenting isn't about "controlling your
    kids". But they never let her get past sound bytes, and it was basically 
    ten against one, with leslie being the only believable defender.

(4) Lots of "club kids" looking like freaks. I'm all for freaks, but it's very
    rare to see tons of people looking like that at raves, even in NYC. I'm
    sure the guys fellating the lollipops will play well with the hayseeds
    in the midwest....

(5) This show concentrated entirely on the under-21 set. Most of the
    ravers I've seen/known are over 21, and most of the raves I go to seem to
    average at about 25 years old. This show made it seem like raves are
    just for kids who want to sneak out of their houses against their parents
    consent and do drugs.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=
==      Niels Mayer -- http://www.eit.com/~mayer -- mayer@netcom.com       ==
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=

-----BEGIN PGP SIGNED MESSAGE-----

Hey!  I'm sure you're all really shocked to see another glowing review of
a Harmony rave by me!  ;)

That's right, Harmony once again succeeded in totally blowing our
collective minds on Saturday!  It was, of course, sheer insanity.  I had
gone for a long, long walk with my friend on Saturday afternoon/evening
(from my place on Haight, up Buena Vista park, across the ridge into UCSF,
all the day down Judah to the ocean, up the beach to Geary, then along
Geary to home.)  So of course I was a total basket case before I even got
there.  In fact, my intention was to leave early - yeah right!

The voicemail was giving the wrong address at first - 3779 16th - but I
guessed (correctly) that they meant Komotion.  I was flakey and tired
enough that I forgot to write down the actual *address* I was going to,
instead merely figuring that knowing it was 24th & Mission would be
enough.  Duh!  So I spent some time wandering around Mission, looking for
co-conspirators.  In the end, I followed some glowing sticker-covered
people who looked like they knew where they were going :)

I was early, I guess - the music hadn't yet started, so I got to hang out
with the wonderful people, try to lend a hand where it was needed, gawk at
the pretty colors - you know.  I was totally brain-dead with fatigue, but
of course that's never stopped me before, and it didn't again!  Yay!  The
music was hopping, of course.  Early on I got recruited by Matt to help
out selling water.  FUN!  I never imagined how much fun it could be, and
the buildup of energy in me was great fun (I could hear the music, I
wanted to move, but I was trapped... so the energy accumulated...)
Whoever was spinning at that point was spinning HARD stuff!  Whoa.

Steve eventually relieved me, which allowed me to release that explosive
pent up energy (and to learn why everyone was so sweaty!  It was *hot* in
there!)  Wooooo!  I could only go for a few minutes at a time, though.  I
have no self-control.  When I dance, it's all out or nothing!  But when
it's hot like that, I stop being able to breate after a few short minutes
of dancing :S

I was "tricked" into working the water bar again through most of Minor
Minor's set.  I got a kick out of it, though - the Harvest Moon people
(whose party had been busted the night before) brought all the food they
had, for us to give away.  Very sweet of them, and made for a lot of
smiling faces!  (mmm.... blueberry muffins....)

At some point we sold out of water, so I got to boogie the rest of the
night.  Yaaaay!  Whoever that last DJ was kicked all our asses... incl.
Steve "I'm too broken to dance at all tonight" Simitzis.  Kept us moving
to the bitter end.  Steve - you have no idea how close I came to falling 
over, carrying you off the dance floor :P.  Boy was I tired!!!  But
happy!  So much for leaving early!  

Lovely to see all your smiling faces again.  I met a *lot* of wonderful
people!  Got my weekend's dosage of hugs & love.  Of course, I haven't
really slept yet, as I spent yesterday helping our old friend Robert Brown
move.  Ugh!  Tired.

Mege-mega-mega hugs to Greg -- Happy Birthday!  Let's have another one
next weekend!  Whooooo!  Charity!!  I'll see you all there!

: : J. David Lowe :: dlowe@best.com :: http://www.best.com/~dlowe/ : :
:  "I will not play at tug o' war. / I'd rather play at hug o' war.  :
:   Where everyone hugs / Instead of tugs. / Where everyone giggles  :
:           And rolls on the rug, / Where everyone kisses,           :
:  And everyone grins, / And everyone cuddles, / And everyone wins." :
:                                -Shel Silverstein, "Hug 'O War"     :
 :: fingerprint: 1F E7 D3 24 04 18 72 67   CC E6 66 1B 79 79 CB 3A ::

i was too!

>    in some good counter-punches, e.g. 13-16 year olds don't have any
>    business doing drugs, and that parenting isn't about "controlling your

>    ten against one, with leslie being the only believable defender.

i do not know leslie, but i think she did a great job of showing herself as
an intelligent human being who enjoys having a great time with her friends. 

i think the reason why there was so little air time on leslie is because she
did not come across as someone whose life has been ruined by going to raves.
i mean, for rating purposes, why give time to someone who is responsible,
happy with her life and making sense.  if they gave her more time she may
have said something that the youth of america could relate to, which would
defeat the purpose of the show and make people want to check out our
wonderful rave community!  they could not let that happen!

great job leslie!!

"Let me have silence always in the centre of the shouting, that is
essential. Let me have silence so that no pin may drop and not be
heard, and not a whisper. Escape is for all our spouting, nor the
needle scratching upon this gramophone of the circular cosmic spot.
Hear me, mark me, learn me, throw the mind's ear open. Shut up the
mind's eye, all will be music. What sculpture of sound cannot, what
cannot as a fluid token words, that nothing else cannot." 

						-Wyndham Lewis

> "Let me have silence always in the centre of the shouting, that is
> essential. Let me have silence so that no pin may drop and not be
> heard, and not a whisper. Escape is for all our spouting, nor the
> needle scratching upon this gramophone of the circular cosmic spot.
> Hear me, mark me, learn me, throw the mind's ear open. Shut up the
> mind's eye, all will be music. What sculpture of sound cannot, what
> cannot as a fluid token words, that nothing else cannot." 
> 
> 						-Wyndham Lewis
> 
> 

	

	**************************************************************	
	Go to the mountains and the oceans and the forest, go naked in 
	the summertime that you may regain the old joy and love gladly 
	and freely under the stars.

						-John Whiteside Parson
	**************************************************************

socal-raves@ucsd.edu.Looks.like.the.powers.that.be.at.T.I.M.E.and.us.over.here.a

Status: U

Research are about *that* much closer to confirming such an event for
Friday, Nov. 8th.  I'm not sure how many of you on the list were there
at "Plantasia" (New Years Eve '95) to see his first show out here.  If
you did, then you know what to expect. If not, then be prepared for
about an hour of TECHNOlogy and funk intertwined like you've never
heard by Carl Craig (aka Paperclip People and 69).  This will be a
"live" show, unlike some that claim to be live but twiddle knobs to a
DAT recording (Moby and Dee-Lite to name a couple).

    It would be nice if you guys could come out and support this event,
since that would make it easier for the promotors at T.I.M.E. to stick
to their commitment of showcasing more Detroit talent in the future.
It's not about happy hardcore or funky breaks over acid lines, it's
just pure techno.  A better definition can be found in the 50th edition
of URB magazine who did (IMO) an excellent job in its presentation of
where and how the American techno scene was born.

    Carl will be planning to stay out here for about a week, so if
anyone else would like to have him perform at his/her event, please
contact me at Plug Research.  Thank you and goodnight!

Joe Babylon
Plug Research
phone/fax (818) 999-2230

Just one comment in reply to Neils, the SF scene is very atypical and most
of the "underground" parties elsewhere, certainly in the Northwest, have
a very young average age -- 18 or less, and it's been falling for a couple
of years.  The lack of diversity is one of the reasons I'm not going out
hardly at all any more.

At 07:09 PM 9/29/96 -0700, Steve wrote:
>
>Hello; just wanted to let you know that I went on Thursday, and I had
>a great time :) Any chance that the next venue can be a little less
>restrictive on age? I wanted to bring some other friends, but have not
>entered 21 land yet ;)
>
>The food kicked ass! It was the best I've eaten in sooo long.
>

Glad you had a good time, Steve.  Yeah, the 21 and up restriction was a
pain.  We will be looking for a less restrictive venue for the next event,
but this is not easy.  Food Not Bombs has very little money for an initial
investment.  The arrangement with El Rio allowed us to keep the door
proceeds, while El Rio kept the bar tab.  It was a pretty good arrangement
for us both, plus the owner is really into FNB.  However, their license does
not allow them to do something like giving stamps or bracelets to those over
21 in order to allow those younger to get in.

If anyone knows of any venues that are either cheap (or willing to donate
their space) or willing to make some kind of arrangement like El Rio, yet is
willing to let in a younger crowd, PLEASE email me.

Thanks and take care.

Kerry

Tony Rotundo <tony@xinet.COM> wrote:
>You know it was a good night when in what seems about an hour the party is
>over and you're pulling Harmony flowers off the wall until 9am.

Did anyone else get this?  I know time passed remarkably quickly for me,
and a couple of people I talked to mentioned the same effect.  When someone
said the final DJ was on, I could hardly believe it until I checked the
time and found it really was already after 5:30.  I figure it's good...when
you can't keep track of the time, something cool must be absorbing your
attention.

sho@goonsquad.spies.com (Sho Kuwamoto) wrote
>I just wanted to point out that the rave scene in the bay
>area has the oldest crowd that I've seen. In many cities,
>people over the age of 21 are the minority.

Which shows, one might suggest (OK, emphasis on the "might"), the
superiority of the Bay area rave scene's appeal to genuine maturity and
understanding, a result equally of its participants and its producers.  I
hope, anyway, that the Bay area can sustain a rave scene whose appeal does
not depend on adolescent rebellion but on a real commitment to joy for all.
